"
Death:          You're speaking of a true or actual world.
                Imagine, if you can, a world so blurred
                that its inhabitants are one another
                --an idiotic monster of negation:
                so timid, it would rather starve itself
                eternally than run the risk of choking;
                so greedy, nothing satisfies its hunger
                but always huger quantities of nothing--
                a world so lazy that it cannot dream;
                so blind, it worships its own ugliness:
                a world so false, so trivial, so unso,
                phantoms are solid by comparison.
                But no--you can't imagine such a world.

Santa Claus:    Any more than such a world could imagine me.

Death:          Very good. Now as to this ungivable something
                you're trying to give, this gift which nobody can take
                --what, just exactly, is it?

Santa Claus:    I don't know.

Death:          I do.

Santa Claus:    Do you?

Death:          Yes. It is understanding.

Santa Claus:    Understanding?

Death:          Yes.

Santa Claus:    Tell me, how do you know?

Death:          You told me, when you answered "I don't know."
                And when you said you had something to give, you told me;
                for isn't understanding the only gift?
                Well there's precisely your predicament.
                We are not living in an age of gifts:
                this is an age of salesmanship, my friends;
                and you are heavy with the only thing
                which simply can't be sold.

"


from _Santa Claus_, a morality by e.e. cummings (1946)

[i recommend it. some of it is rave related. -brian]

We were talking -- about the space between us all
And the people -- who hide themselves behind a wall of illusion
Never glimpse the truth -- then it's far too late --
when they pass away.

We were talking -- about the love we all could
share -- when we find it

Try to realise it's all within yourself no-one else
can make you change
And to see you're really only very small,

may find, peace of mind, is waiting there--

we're all one, and life flows on within you and
without you.

I find it fasinating that there seems to be more of a sense of kaos on 
this list lately. 
I haven't been reading all the posts as I've found many to be 
redundant, but there is something appealing to this sense of kaos.  
There have been some very REAL feelings bubbling on the list lately. 

I wonder if many of us have been dancing enough?
Parties have been getting busted a little more lately.  Its seems that 
there has been more verbal dancing lately here, though it seems like it 
has been more of the slam dancing as of late.

The thing that keeps me going to these parties is the love of the music 
and the love of dancing.
One of the reasons I read this list is to feel connected with others 
who love techno and dance.
Seeing whats been going on here lately, makes me think even more so how 
wonderful this scene can be.  Here we have people arguing, insulting, 
misinterpreting....but we all, (I'd like to think) or most of us share 
that bond that can come from some music playing through the speakers.  
When that happens, its so cool how all these people with their 
differences can come so much closer to one another on the dance floor.

Even as we have our differences here which is definitely cool, the beat 
of the music is alive in us all.  It is so wonderful that we share, and 
it is ours to enjoy.

peace and whatever else you may be feeling,
:)
peter

Still reading? Did I make it past the kill-filter? Wow.

An observation:

Many of you seem rather upset about all the negativity you perceive on
this list, and are making a big show of leaving or threatening to leave.
To those people I would ask this: What positive contributions to the list
have *you* made recently?(I am not bitching, so don't try to throw this
back in my face.) 

You don't like the discussions going on; they are bitchy, crappy,
disrespectful, or whatever, fine, by all means *START YOUR OWN* Inject
something positive into the list if that is what you are looking for, if
that is what you need to see. Put a little effort into putting forth the
kinds of posts that you want to see on this list, without expecting
everyone else to do so, and then being pissed off and upset when you do
not see those types of posts you want to see here. 

Myself, I am a pretty serious, and vocal person most of the time, and most
of my posts are not shiny and happy. I do not apologize for this, that is
my nature. 

But dammit, you all have the power to post whatever you want. CT has taken
to re-posting old "positve" posts from the archives. Is that what we are
left with? Does no one have anything original to say? 

The next time you start to complain about the negativity on the list ask
yourself what you have done to change the tone of the list recently, what
you have contributed. It's not a spectator sport folks.

                                          Black Adder

Received: from well.com (phred@well.com [206.15.64.10]) by mh1.well.com (8.7.6/8.7.5) with ESMTP id CAA08252 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Fri, 6 Dec 1996 02:49:19 -0800 (PST)
Received: (from phred@localhost) by well.com (8.8.3/8.8.2) id CAA15414 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Fri, 6 Dec 1996 02:49:17 -0800 (PST)
Date: Fri, 6 Dec 1996 02:49:17 -0800 (PST)
From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.com>
Message-Id: <199612061049.CAA15414@well.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: A Modest Proposal
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

sfraves has gone through shitstorms before, and will survive this
too, but the volume and extent of the last week convinces me that
all this has escalated to a new and dangerous level.  

A modest proposal: we are as a group being very hard on ourselves here.
Everyone here has a valid point of view, but that is starting to be
lost in the effort to "win" on every nuance. 

Facts are facts.  Observations and opinions are important, but are
no more than what they are.  Respect only survives when it goes both
ways.  

I'm not going to preach and lay down "rules of good online behavior."
Y'all already know 'em anyway.  

A lot of us rely on this list to keep up on the electronic dance music
scene, to stay in touch with our friends, to laugh a bit and learn
something.  I don't mind disorder and disagreement.  I don't mind
people testing the envelope of what is 'appropriate' for the list.
I do mind it a lot when this important resource in my life starts
taking on the flamewar symptoms that burden many other online areas.

Whether you've been on this list five days or five years, it is
your responsibility, it is all of our responsibility, to circulate
facts, opinions and respect for positive purposes.

peace out
phred

"It's time to move.  It's time to get down with it!"

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Thu, 5 Dec 1996 12:15:00 -0800 (PST)
From: Speak Out Speakers and Artists Agency <speakout@igc.apc.org>
To: affirmativeaction@uclink2.Berkeley.EDU,
    aa-coalition@uclink4.berkeley.edu,
    ethnicstudiesgrads@uclink2.Berkeley.EDU,
    ihouse-comm@uclink2.Berkeley.EDU, lavendergrads@uclink.Berkeley.EDU,
    qgradsofcolor@uclink.Berkeley.EDU, puertorriquenos@uclink2.Berkeley.EDU,
    csa@therock.CS.Berkeley.EDU, students4hiphop@uclink2.Berkeley.EDU,
    raza_at_cal@uclink.Berkeley.EDU, blackmail@uclink4.berkeley.edu,
    csa@therock.C.S.Berkely.edu, pilipinos@uclink.Berkeley.EDU,
    students4hiphop@uclink2.Berkeley.EDU
Subject: FYI

The following is a message we think you should be aware of.....
Sorry if you've already recieved this...


>
>Please forward, especially to those in other schools.
>
>The following message regarding pending legislation that
>would restrict student aid to anyone who is not 'born' in the US, regardless
>of their resident status (even naturalized US citizens).  The implications
>of this legislation are far reaching, not just for the quality of our
>student pool, but more so as a reflection of a growing xenophobia in this
>country.  Please consider these another implications of this legislation and
>contact your representatives in the Senator and House.
>
>RE:     No Financial Aid for Non-US born Citizens/Residents
>
>  Whether or not you were born in the US, the following is some information
>  which important to us all.  Spread the word.
>
>  I thought the following issue would interest you.  It hasn't received
>  much attention yet, because it's still a bill going through Congress.
>  What it all boils down to is this:  If HR-4 passes, students who are
>  permanent residents, even NATURALIZED U.S. citizens, will no longer be
>  eligible for financial aid -- Stafford loans, Perkins loans, Pell
>  grants, etc., even though these citizens and LEGAL immigrants have been
>  paying taxes all along.  The qualifying factor for student financial
>  aid, according to 4HR-4, is having been BORN in the United States.
>  NOTE:  This is no longer an attack on illegal "aliens", but on people
>  who have entered the country LEGITIMATELY and who are trying to
>  continue their contribution to this society through attainment of
>  higher education.
>
>  PLEASE help increase awareness of this issue by letting as many people as
>  you can know about what Congress is attempting, and contact/write to the
>  senators and representatives of your district to express your position
>  on the matter.  We need to kill the bill at its early stages.
>
>  WARNING: THE US GOVERNMENT WANTS TO TAKE FINANCIAL AID FROM STUDENTS
>
>  In addition to a bill recently passed in the Senate to cut Federal loans
>  programs by $10 billion, the Senate and the House have both passed bills
>  that will effectively curtail student aid benefits to LEGAL immigrants,
>  including Pell grants, subsidized Stafford loans, and other federal
>  financial aid programs.
>
>  These proposed cuts, hidden deep within a welfare reform bill (HR 4),
>  are to be achieved through a process known as "Alien Sponsor Deeming", in
>  which the income and assets of an immigrant's sponsor are added to the
>  immigrant's own resources in determining eligibility for government
>  financial aid programs.  Since most immigrants must have a sponsor in
>  order to immigrate here legally, deeming would disqualify many legal
>  immigrants from receiving aid by falsely inflating their income and
>  wealth.
>
>  WHO WILL BE AFFECTED?
>
> *A new draft report issued this month by the General Accounting Office
>  in Washington, D.C. states that 390,000 legal immigrants received Pell
>  grants nationwide in 1992-93.  The Pell grant program is designed to
>  help the neediest students and has a maximum award of $2,340 per year.
>
>  *In California, legal immigrants make up 32.6% of Pell grant recipients.
>  An analysis performed by the UC president's office found that more than
>  25% of UC students who receive need-based aid are legal immigrants.
>
>  *In New York, legal immigrants make up 26.5% of Pell grant recipients.
>  In Florida, the total is nearly 16%.
>
>  *The Senate version of this bill (S. 269) would also restrict aid for
>  naturalized citizens.
>
>  *The bills now under consideration would essentially affect anyone who
>  was not born in the United States.
>
>  *A total of $21 million in Pell grants and $31 million in subsidized
>  loans could be lost among the nine UC campuses alone.  These
>  restrictions will affect private colleges as well.
>
>  *As Permanent Residents of the United States, legal immigrants have been
>  eligible for federal financial aid for many years.
>
>  *Permanent Residents pay federal income taxes and are subject to the
>  draft.
>
>  *The bills now being considered by a Joint Committee of the House and
>  Senate would restrict benefits to many legal immigrants by changing
>  eligibility requirements.
>
>  *Two classes of citizens would be created, and legal immigrants would
>  effectively be denied opportunities for higher education.
>
>  WHAT CAN YOU DO?
>
>  A list of those members of Congress who are on the Joint Committee
>  considering these bills will soon be made available. We will try to
>  organize letter-writing, faxing, calling, and emailing campaigns. We
>  will also try to get in touch with local and national news media. Ethnic
>  newspapers definitely need to be targeted.
>
>  More specific information on what you can do will be coming in the next
>  few days.  If you are interested in working on this issue or getting
>  more information, contact the ASUC Executive Vice President's Office at:
>
>        Phone: (510) 643-9830
>        Fax:   (510) 643-6396
>        Email: urd@uclink2.berkeley.edu
>               asucexec@ocf.berkeley.edu
>
>  Thanks for your attention and support!!!

<><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><>
Speak Out Speakers and Artists Agency
P.O. Box 99096
Emeryville, CA  94662
Phone:  (510) 601-0182

Speak Out is the country's only national not-for-profit speakers and
artists agency, representing over 200 men and women who are shaping
movements for social change and defining contemporary issues.  For a full
listing, email your name, (snail) mailing address, and telephone number.

Subject: In response to PLUR, Cool World, and the issues of gangsters at parties

In response to what has been written about Cool World and PLUR:  Which can
also be applied to the gangster issue as well.

(by the way Paul, I think I am qualified to respond, although I can't check
my tag because I really dislike underwear...its too restricting!)

PAUL WHOA!  Slow down and think about how you are responding here.  I agree
with you I believe that we come together at raves to experience and
celebrate peace, love, unity, and respect for all.  But in living and
holding this light you must view the world compassionately instead of
agressively or negatively.  To love means to love all and to love all you
must understand another persons logic.  Although you don't have to imbibe
their logic into your reality.  If change in others is what you seek then
you must project love to them and understand the motive that drives the
others logic and visualize and manifest the change through your thoughts
and love.

Through thoughts and fears the hegemonous race ties us to this action of
continually attacking back.

But with our beliefs it is waste of time and energy to be angry about
another persons actions.  If they affect your life as in a stolen article
you have to look at it as being only their response and their response does
not have to trigger a release of emotions of hatred or anger on your part.
It is uncomfortable to have a pocession or loved one removed from your life
or to experience pain but if your happiness lies in what you own or having
your loved ones near or alive or in having all your limbs then what happens
if you lose these things.  Will you no longer generate happiness and love?
Will you carry a grudge of hate with you for whomever brought upon this
horrible experience?  How will that assist in healing the planet or
mankind?

Focus your thoughts to visualize powerful change instead of wasting them on
attacking or complaining about another.  When you attack or complain, by
actions or thoughts, you only feed into this continous struggle that
charecterizes our human existence.  A person will be as you see him as.
The student whose teacher believed in him succeeds while the students who
were put in lower level classes with teachers that saw them as slower than
others continued to fail in life.  The world is a mirror of your beliefs.
You draw into your life exactly what you fear and believe.

If you truly wish to integrate Peace, Love, Unity, and Respect into the
world than consider the idea of unconditional love.  Where love is not an
emotion it is a state of being.  Love has no object.  Unconditional love is
the experience of BEING; there is no I or no "other" and anyone or anything
it touches is experienced in love.  You can only BE unconditional love.  It
is a sense of oneness with all that is.  This experience arises when we
surrender our seperateness into the UNIVERSAL.  It is a feeling of unity.
You don't love another, you are another.  There is no fear because there is
no separation.

As humans we learn by right association.  What works for another is
observed and integrated into our own lives.  Concentrate on the holding the
light of the ideas of PLUR.  The hegemonous culture will self destruct.  We
are destined for so much more.

Jocelyn

Hello,

I'd just like to take the time to send a group fare-thee-well to
everyone else who's leaving on this list.  Me, I'm stayin' ... There
will always be newbe's arriving, and there will always be olde-timers
leaving...  It has happened and never ends.  It's the cycle. And it's a
good one. 
I view SFRaves as a marriage of sorts, there are High times (E-times)and
Low times(Spun-times).  The communities mentality in general is
reflective to society in the fact that, "if I don't like it, then I'll
leave."
That's why divorce is so popular nowadays, & , it seems a lot of
sfravers want a divorce from sfraves.
But it's all good, I've gone thru this stage two years ago (willfully)
and last year as well(against my own will)...  Unlike a divorce SFRaves
will take you back...

Even if your on or off the list you are my dear friends (and you know
who you are...)  I tend to keep friends close to me unless you royally
screw me (and I haven't been screwed for quite some time... =])...

Take care friends and lovers,

---Adam

"Stay Connected..."

Good morning!

The list isn't really that bad all the time.  I've been on this list for
over 4 years, and I have seen so much drama tear thru the list it has made
me sick.  But it's all done at certain times of the year.  We get this huge
flux of crap about two to three times a year.  It's like the list gets
constipated and then everyone starts spewing out there opinions like a
heavy dose of laxatives!

I personally just leave it all alone and sit back and watch as people come
and go.  I've learned that the list isn't going to change and that leaving
the list isn't the right answer let alone fueling the fire.

So everyone relax cause this will all be better soon enough and we'll all
be back to our normal selves soon.  I'll give everyone the benefit of the
doubt and blame it on the holidays and finals!

I hope everyone is having a wonderful Friday.  What is everyone doing this
weekend.  Maybe a few of us can get together and do something!

Take care,

Noah Ruiz =)

Hey All,
I wanted to take a second to thank everyone who went out of their way to
send me a quote on why they rave for my paper on Ecstasy and the Rave
culture. It is by no means a "difinitive" work, but simply a few pages
of my take of Raving and E.  Its done! I think it came out really well,
I only wish I wasn't being held to 10 pages. (Its 15 anyway!) I will
gladly forward it to anyone who would like to read it. If you sent me a
quote and asked for a copy, I'll do my best to get those out asap. Could
take a while. I'm out in Boulder, CO and Lust 5 is going off in Denver
on Sat. nite....should be fantastic! I'm so psyched! Any of you MTN
people going?? Have a groovy weekend....lots of love....
Ari

On Fri, 6 Dec 1996, Brian Denny wrote:

> >Sorry but i have seen many people TRY aand do this only to be filtered out on
> >accident or ignored with the rest?? But to say that people aren't
> >participating positivley is an incorrect statement. Jonathan
> 
> ok, some people are participating positively... but not enough. and it's
> also important not to contribute to the negativity. (which you, jonathan,
> haven't particularly, i'm not directing this at you...) as i said before,
> when you see a post you don't like, responding critically only fans the
> flames. best just to ignore it and start a discussion about something you
> want to discuss.

Sometimes some of us want to discuss these issues that are hot topics and 
may seem negative to some.  What everyone here I think needs to realize n 
some sense is that just because this is a rave related list doesn't mean 
the content is going to be all pretty/happy/candy/lovey and such.  There 
are negative threads on this list yeah.  There are happy threads yeah.  
There's lot's of complaining lately.  I've been on the list for over two 
years now, folks sometimes life's hard, but you still make it through the 
tough parts.  When my life is difficult I don't just say, I'm 
unsubscribing from my life to get away from it all!  I think everyone 
should just calm down and relax. 

love drenalin

Subject: SFRAVES
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Fri, 6 Dec 1996 10:57:57 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL25]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I joined SFRaves in June of this year and it is thanks to it that I met many
of the people I now consider my friends.  I think one of the most important
functions of this list is to help those new to the SF area or to the rave 
scene to find people they have things in common with and to find parties
where they can meet these people.  I no longer need the list to know what 
parties are happening.  I know enough people to find that out myself.  My main
reason now for being on the list is to help out those that have come after
me.  

I think a lot of the recent posts have not only caused a lot of longtime
SFRavers to unsubscribe but scared away pontential new ones as well.  We are
not only hurting ourselves but also the scene.  

I will be go back to school on the east coast in January and will be unsubbing
from the list on my last day of work December 20th.  Until then I encourage any
of you new people out there that may be looking for a ride to a party or just
someone to go with or meet up with to contact me.  I'll be going to Freaky
People on the 13th, The Gathering on the 21st, and some New Year's party.

I really hope this list can continue to be a gateway to the rave scene for many
people and that when I come back in the summer I find it prospering.

love to all,
j

P.S.  For those wishing to stay in contact with me when I go back to school
email me.

jwiley@cisco.com

Thank you SO MUCH, Terry, for posting this!!

I wrote this post in the first blush of love last spring... and promptly 
lost it.  After eight months, me and the "boy" in question have scaled the 
heights of happiness, experienced the lows of a romance gone sour, and 
finally settled on a good friendship.  But in all that time, I never got to share this first post I 
wrote of us when I very first fell for him... and now, thanks to you, 
I belatedly get to share it with him.

:)
Thank you!

love,
N

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Nancy)
Subject: Ravers In Love
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Here is a tale of ravers in love...of a boy and girl going to a rave
together with a mutual friend...and the boy warming the girl's heart with
his floppy hat and big happy smile, and how he ran all around the party in
glee and bounced up and down on the dance floor...and the two then going to
Sunset, and Mad, and Chrysalis...of sitting in a car the morning after for
four hours, still soaked in sweat and covered in sparkles, discovering that
the love they shared for raving was based on their deepest personal beliefs
and experiences, and the bond that created between them...of touching each
other for the first time with Orbital playing softly in the background...of
knowing that they found each other because of the openness of their hearts
and the willingness to give love a chance...

Subject: another positive something-or-other
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Seeing wayne, brendan, leslie, sherry, jonathan and tim tell us they're
unsubbing in the course of a day is the saddest thing I've ever seen on
this list, and I'm  wondering why???

People, please, stop JUMPING on each other!

I'm serious. Every one of you is thinking "damn, I wish all these SFR
assholes would stop arguing" but many of you still do it! every little
negative post contributes toward a bigger group of negative posts that just
snowballs into the kind of shitfest we're seeing here right now. with that
in mind I have two things to say:

1) before you post, THINK. think about who will gain from it, who will be
interested, and what your motives are for sending an e-mail to 400 people.
if it's for selfish reasons or you think people might not be interested or
you just feel like being a jerk, DON'T POST IT PLEASE. I get enough e-mail
as is without a bazillion "you're a jerk and I'm right" posts every day.

2) there are certain people on this list (I'm so CLOSE to naming names it's
not even funny) who I have NEVER, in my year and some-odd months on SFR,
seen a positive post from. These people (i think you know who you are;
you've all been posting alot lately) seem to think that their vitriolic
commentary, "back in the day" bitching (it's not back in the day... it's
TODAY so make it a good one!) and endless "FUCK YOU's" somehow benefit the
community. Well, they don't. I'm not being a PLUR cop, but I do think this
list could stand to live without alot of assholes who seem to think they've
subscribed to SFSoapBox. This list is a local mailing list, and when you
get 400 people together, most of whom hang out together on weekends, you're
going to get a lot of NRR fluff, which is just something you'd have to deal
with. think of it as a virtual rave... when I go to a party, I LIKE making
NRR conversation. Same goes for SFR: I see it as a way to bring parties
into our everyday lives, rather than keeping them restricted to weekends.

        And who the hell wants to go to a rave to hang out with some
asshole who
        probably had a "fuck you" key installed in his keyboard to cut his
        typing speed in half???

I'm unsubbing in a few weeks too, because I'm spending my xmas break in
Poland. I'll see my mom and my little bro for the first time in many moons,
and I'll be over there hanging out with the fam and thinking of the
gathering and fnf and harmony and all the beautiful people and beautiful
parties I'm missing, and although seeing my family i something I've been
looking forward to for awhile,  ---->I'll be glad to come home.<-----

I just hope SFR is still around when I get back.

concerned,
-m.

I feel like I had some way of starting all this blasting on the list. I
made the comment about the Phish concert, and if anyone had seen them.
Suddenly, everyone starting coming out and arguing over something that
is so meaningless in the whole spectrum of what is really important;
which is: we are all different, we all have different tastes, yet we can
come together and bounce ideas off eachother.
I'm very new to town, three months actually. I joined the list a month
ago, and the Phish comment was the first thing I posted. Now I'm not too
sure I want to post anything else. Call me ignorant, but I had no idea I
was supposed to put "NRR" in front of things that weren't rave related.
I'm sorry, I didn't mean to cause a stir. I personally think Phish is a
rave within itself. Just my opinion. Please don't blast me for that. I
hope this note doesn't sound negative, that wasn't my intention. 
I hope everyone has a wonderful weekend, full of fun and energy.
Thanks for spending a few of your minutes reading this.
Claudia

particular style, I think...I'm sure one or the other could put together
some jungle.

>

   Jocelyn wrote (past comment):
>>
>> And if they are here and if they have been here for some time, they are not
>> really aliens or extra-terrestrials are they?

Alchemist wrote (in response to above):
>
>but they are not physical beings... consult your dimethyltriptamine...


MY new response:

I am very familiar with the dmt experience and actually don't even need to
partake anymore to experience an encounter with entitys living in other
dimensions. Alien means not of this world and extra-terrestrial means not
of this planet earth, So I guess if you consider anything that does not
exist in our 3-dimensional space of which all humans can view by
3-dimensional perception it does not exist in this world or on earth.  But
if you consider the other dimensions to be existing on this earth and if
other entitys are viewable to those who selective people who use dmt or
those who have their third eye open then they must exist here.  I am under
the understanding that they affect our lives on earth as a whole through
the collective consiousness and our individual unconcious reality.  So in
my mind they are a part of this world and really are delineated in an
unapproprate manner with names like alien as I responded earlier.

It our fears of of what we don't understand that seperates us.


Jocelyn wrote (past comment):
>
> The word alien is almost
>> another discriminating word that we humans have created to seperate us from
>> everything else.  If the goal is to come together back into some sense of
>> unity and oneness with everthing than we have to include the cosmos and
>> everything in it or else we will always be seperate from something.
>>
>Alchemist (responded with):
>what's to say we aren't pawns in some nanotech conspiracy?  they've
>already developed this technology on this plane to create single cell
>organisms out of nothing... pretty soon they'll be able to make chicken
>dinners, like on Star Trek... could it be that we we're developed from a
>nanotech virus sent years ago, to progress humanity into a technology
>creating force to build things such as the internet?  of course we all
>have our egos now that we are beginning to stumble upon the kitchens of
>the gods... but when they return to see how the seed was spread.....
>
>read "Childhood's End" by Arthur C. Clark


MY RESPONSE NOW:
I try not to subscribe to the conspiracy theory.  Don't get me wrong I
belive all that exists, the illuminati and the regressive aliens paths to
the control the world.  But personally I believe that my reality is a
product of my thoughts, and the world is a product of the collective
thoughts of all humans.  So really I think that they can be what ever you
request them to be.  And if you find ones that seem to be on a more
regressive, dominating, or hegemenous than I think you will find that they
even know that we are more capable and powerful than them by being
spiritually aware through love.  And at this moment in time there are more
progressive positive entitys surrounding us, assisting in raising our
conciousness (hence raves).

Jocelyn

> >Hmm, pure oxygen...  Isn't that, like, flammable or something?
> >I think the flammability factor would go down when dispersed, but a
> >concentrated amount coming out of a fogger???
> >just pondering...

I'm not sure who originally wrote this, but as far as I know Oxygen itself
is not flammable.  It is necessary for the combustion of other materials:
the more that is present, the faster the reaction.

I've heard of some science geeks who use liquid oxygen to prepare a
barbecue pit.  The fill it with charcoal and light it on fire.  Then they
use a LONG board with a 1 gallon bucket of oxygen on the end of it to pour
in the oxygen from a safe distance.  In 1 hot second, the charcoal is
reduced to coals, perfect for cooking. 

Just my $.02...
.:blossom

Claudia wrote:
>I feel like I had some way of starting all this blasting on the list.

Don't blame yourself. I signed off over the extended thanksgiving weekend,
so I'm not to sure exactly all that happened. Most likely it was a
cumulation of several posts which set people off.

Jim Wrote:
>Don't feel too bad!  I'm sure I've done my bit to ramp things up a bit!
>I've been trying to inject some (what I thought was) intellectually
>stimulating discourse onto the list[...]

True, this is a rave list, but I enjoy some of the other periferal topics
that come up. The volume can be upsettingly high on some days, but then I
always just scan the subjects and elminate the ones I don't think I'll be
interested in.

Claudia wrote:
>I'm very new to town, three months actually.

I'm fairly new also. I've lived here for a year, and I've been on the list
for  just over a month. I haven't met any of you, though I've enjoyed the
feeling of community I've found here. I do want to go to more parties and
meet some of you, but logistics have always seemed to get in the way. I
think there is a good thing here and it would be a pity to write it off.

Terrence.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Dec  6 17:00:27 1996

From: JNRF62B@prodigy.com (MR MICHAEL E ROBINSON)
Date: Fri,  6 Dec 1996 19:17:38, -0500
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: NRR: Once upon a time...
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

A young man thought the world was a pretty shitty place.  He wore a 
lot of black and generally avoided people he didn't already know.  
Then one evening he and a friend decided to go to a rave.  whoo hoo 
he
thought, a bunch of mindless happy people, targets for his caustic 
wit.  So off they went, and to their amazement, people weren't afraid 
of them, or ignoring them, them were just happy to meet them.  This 
was 
not normal.  And after a little while, he began to smile back at 
people.  And for a little while, left his self-
conciousness on the wall and danced.  
He smiled all the next week.  Said hello to people he'd never seen 
before.  And wore something that wasn't black.  The very next weekend,
 he was off to another rave.  He danced a bit more, gave and recieved 
hugs (perhaps from some of you, we don't know), and kept smiling.  
Pretty soon weeks went by and he didn't stop smiling, and he started 
to think maybe the world isn't a big 
heap of trash.  He had new friends, and old friends, and a much 
better attitude towards his life.
Someone told him one night about a mailing list, and he thought, oh 
I'm on the net, let's see who else is
out there.  He posted a few short notes, mostly read and watched, and 
said hi when he saw people he'd 
read.  
Well, now I'm here, and I'm posting something a little longer, just 
to say hello.  Thanks for being
wonderful people, and for every smile I see at every rave I go to.  
  Happies to all of you.  

               Mike.
Only 5 short months and you too can be a much more well adjusted 
person.  
See you all sooner or later!

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Dec  6 17:02:12 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id RAA27808; Fri, 6 Dec 1996 17:02:12 -0800 (PST)
Received: from emout16.mail.aol.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with SMTP id RAA27768; Fri, 6 Dec 1996 17:02:01 -0800 (PST)
From: TeKnODiVa@aol.com
Received: by emout16.mail.aol.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id UAA12990 for SFRaves@hyperreal.com; Fri, 6 Dec 1996 20:01:25 -0500
Date: Fri, 6 Dec 1996 20:01:25 -0500
Message-ID: <961206200123_1186570390@emout16.mail.aol.com>
To: SFRaves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: The future of SFRaves! (very long!)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

   I have kept quiet for a few weeks now and listened to all sides of the
story (stories, arguments, whatever).  After all that listening I have come
to a conclusion and have decided to break my silence.  I am the youngest
member of SFRaves and that's a lot younger than most of you would think.
 Here's my story in an abreviated sort of way...

          I was bored over summer and looking for interesting URL sites
having to do with the love of my music life-- techno.  As luck would have
it... I came across a site called #evarneet (an internet chat for teen
ravers).  The site has since been shut down... but I followed the links to
the Hyperreal site.  Much to my surprise there was a mailing list for Bay
Area ravers to talk about their passions.  My excitement rose as I hastily
subscribed.  I didn't know what I was getting into, but the whole idea
sounded wonderful.  
           The list was great.  You could sit for days and listen to peoples
stories.  It was like a soap opera-- you can come in at any point in the
story line and easily become a part of the characters' lives.  Only on
SFRaves the people were real.  The posts were about music, raves, friendship,
politics, jokes, troubles, or whatever was on the writer's mind.  They could
write anything and get support for it, whether it was RR or not.

        ....That story wasn't too short, but it will do.  Since that day when
I signed on, members have left and new members have signed on.  The feelings
have become more hostile because people no longer want to hear anything other
than RR topics.  The point is, that I love SFRaves for it's community and
posts.  If I'm having a bad day, I want to be able to write in and get a lot
of smiley huggy PLUR messages in return.  I want to hear what people do
outside of the raves, and how it contributes to their raving life-style.
 Maybe some of you older people take it for granted.  You have jobs, and you
just want mail about the music and parties.  Raving is a privilege.  I can't
go to many raves because of my age, but I stay on this list to learn from
people.  The NRR posts are just as enjoyable as as the RR ones.  No one
should be Flamed or shunned for wanting to address an issue outside of
parties.  
            Now I've rambled so much longer than I usually do that I've lost
my point.  I'm just so sad that something that was created to bring people
together in a common interest is turning into one big argument.  If you don't
want to read NRR posts then don't.  And don't yell at a person for writing
them.  It has been pointed out numerous times that there are other mailing
lists available.  Some of them may be more rave related or friendly than
ours.  However, I wouldn't switch over.  I've grown to love the posts on this
list and the people who write them.  You're all sort of my role models.
 Someday I'll get to meet you all and talk with you in an enviroment that is
less hostile.  So no matter what anyone puts on this list, it should be
regarded with the PLUR motto.  So that's my pent-up opinion that I've been
saving forever.  WE ARE THE FUTURE OF SFRAVES.

            hugs,
              'trice                              <<<<RAVEON>>>>

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Dec  6 17:13:19 1996

Date: Fri, 6 Dec 1996 17:13:10 -0800 (PST)
From: KaySEE <scarab@value.net>
Reply-To: KaySEE <scarab@value.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: A moment to reflect...
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.95.961206161821.25492B-100000@value.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

...on what I've gained from raving.  I remember times in my life where I
wished I had more friends, good friends.  I remember feeling lonely and
insecure, something we all go through from time to time.  Finding people,
thinking they were friends, then sadly realizing they were not.
Graduating from college, unsure what the hell to do with life.  Not
surrounded by people anymore.  Worried I'd never find friends.  Suffering
some difficult realizations about my life.  Going to raves.  Overcoming my
fear of dancing.  Discovering how amazing it feels.  Wow!  Having special
connections with people.  Seeing those people turn into friends.
Overcoming the fear of "not being enough".  Learning to love myself so
others would too.  Learning that to not judge others is the best way to
not be judged.  Learning that I am the sole root of my own fun.  Finally
going out by myself to create the time I wanted ALL BY MYSELF.

On May 3rd, 1996 I attended Beautiful People with a dear friend with whom
I "discovered" what raving means to me.  That night, if I had to pick, was
probably my favorite party.  I met about 6-8 sfravers, saw a ton of really
happy, sharing people, was blown away by the vibe that was so thick you 
could cut it like a knife, and danced for hours upon end. I watched the
sun come up while dancing like my life depended on it (maybe it did), and
was flabbergasted that I had the capacity to experience
such joy.  If you remember the story I wrote (Children of the Night), a
lot of the "feeling" came from that night.  I no longer try and explain to
people what that feeling is because, if they don't know, they just won't
get it.  

So, tonight I am having a party, partly in celebration of my birthday,
partly to, as my roomate put it, to get loaded with your friends.  And,
THERE is the key word, FRIENDS.  I can't believe that what I always
dreamed about came true.  I don't know how because I thought I was doomed
to a life of solitude.  Something in me changed.  I became less judgmental
of myself, and somehow I have quite a few friends.  And, I am happy to say
that some, if not most, of this came from realizations I had while raving,
simple self-discovery.  Some of these people I developed
friendships with as a direct result of the shared interest of raving and
the music.  

If you had told me three years ago that I was going to have a party
tonight, and that so many people will be there we have to worry about the
cops, I would have said "Bullshit."  Only other people had parties like
that.  Not me.  So, now I have begun to create the life I want to live
rather than let someone else do it.  And, if it weren't for raving, who
knows when, or if, this would have happened.  

In short, I grew up.

I'll be unsubbing for a week because I'll be gone, but I wanted to write
this before then.  How do I say this without being totally corny?  I guess
I don't, but believe me, it ain't all fluff.  There are aspects of raving
that are more than just a party, and raving touches people's lives.  I
just hope that that continues, and doesn't get swallowed up by the desire
to be cool and get fucked up.


Chau, nos vemos pronto...

cheers,

KaySEE

Having not danced for awhile, I am defintely feeling the anxiety of not
having done it.  I plan on going to Freaky People, and I hope to meet some
people, and re-live the little things that are important to me.

This isn't a reply to austin's post, it's just a general reply on the topic.

        I just can't possibly have fun at a party where: 

                There's no room to dance
                It's sweaty, humid, and slick
                The people are just all f*****
                There's too many people
                You can't breathe
                You can't get away from all the commotion 
                You can't even sit down, either from the floor being all
disgusting and greasy, or there's just no damn place to sit!


        Even if the music's bad-ass, Even if there are just some PISSED OFF
visuals,
        Even if the fairy rave mother sprinkled her magic dust upon my
noggen, THE 
        PARTY WOULD STILL SUCK (to me), unless of course. . . I was all
under the         influence of some little pill or whatever.

ALSO: Cool World just pisses me off!!! (But that's somethin else)


Aryck

X-Received: from gryphon.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with ESMTP id KAA25241; Thu, 5 Dec 1996 10:42:25 -0800 (PST)
X-Received: (from vision@localhost) by gryphon.com (8.7.1/8.7.1) id LAA29464; Thu, 5 Dec 1996 11:02:05 -0800 (PST)

From: Max Vision <vision@gryphon.com>

Most of the talent lined up is really good, and despite the cost, I 
believe there will be enough to experience and enjoy to make it worth 
it.  I enjoy and sometimes dearly miss underground raves, but for New 
Year's Eve, perhaps a "party" would be good.  I (as do most of us) rave 
every weekend/(day:).  But I don't "party" very often.  I am still 
considering the Cloud Factory event, but only because my friends are 
going to it.  (I don't recognize any of the dj's; if someone does maybe 
say what you think of them?)  To hear some incredibly phat beats 
including drum and bass/jungle, I pretty much have to go to Cool World.
About people who say the party will suck, I would wonder if they would 
say that out loud in room with JasonMouse, Flux, Jeno, Tony, Graeme, 
Carlos, JonWilliams, FreakyChakra, Darkhorse, Thomas, CrystalMethod, and 
the other DJ's...  Is their music going to "suck"?  Ahem.  I wouldn't 
care if they were playing in a cave!!  (Thomas is billed to play in NYC 
the same night so unless he's going to fly in a concord someone is going 
to be dissapointed)
I understand the resentment I've been reading about.  I understand the 
*huge* difference between a beautiful rave versus a massive party.  I 
just think all things considered, CW will be a fun place to be.  After 
all, everyone seems to agree it's the people who make the party.  Well 
whereever we go, there we are - each of us will make our own good time of 
what we have around us.

Why am I posting about this thread?  Who knows.  Human nature urges us to 
speak out and contribute our views.  Perhaps my meaning is "have fun 
wherever you may go!"

love,
Max

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Thu, 5 Dec 1996 17:38:39 +0000
From: Jocelyn <nephesch@autobahn.org>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: RE:  RACE, GANGSTAS, COOL WORLD, ALIENS, SEPERATENESS AND UNCONDITIONAL LOVE 


       "Race is a part of American society, face it, or not, you're living
in it,"   written by deeje.

There is no such thing as race.  Race is a myth that we svbscribe to the
color of our skin.  But can we really define color? There are so many
shades that it all becomes a blur.  We are all one human race.  And because
we allow ourselves to channel or be a receptacle of fear we use words to
create differences where there really are none.  We attempt to dominate
what we don't understand.

I think that we can better term the differences as differences in cultures
(the imprints that we have been given and raised in since our birth) and
instead of attacking others for what they are doing wrong in our own eyes
we should try to understand why they are feeling a certain feeling and why
they need to react in the way that they are reacting.  Only by
understanding another person's logic can you really love them.  And only
through love can you visualize that person actually changing. If it is
change you really seek.

It is my understanding the reason we rave is to bring people together to
create a sense of unity and love for one another.  So if this the goal for
coming together than by being together in all of our cultural differences
we must experience unconditional love.

Unconditional love does not set one apart from anyone else it is a state of
being.  Unconditional love has no object.  You  cannot have unconditional
love for another because it is an experience of being.  There is no "I" or
no "other" and anyone or anything it touches is experienced in love.  You
can only be unconditional love.  It is a sense of oneness with all that is,
This experience arises when we surrender our separateness into the
universal.  It is a feeling of unity.  You don't love another, you are
another.  There is no fear because there is no separation.

If indeed another life force from the cosmos is about to make public
contact with earth in the near future.  How will we be receptive to it if
we are still in fear of each other?

Jocelyn

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Thu, 5 Dec 1996 19:45:35 -0800
From: Brian Denny <bri@value.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: How to handle negativity on sfraves in a positive way

Friends,

it saddens and disturbs me to see people unsvbscribing from this list due
to recent negativity.

i have two observations:

1.      when positive, loving people unsvbscribe from the list, the list
loses that person's warmth, becoming more negative.

2.      the best way to influence the direction of the list is by posting
the kind of material that you want to read. that is to say: if you don't
like NRR posts, you will be much more effective by bringing up a
rave-related discussion topic rather than criticizing the NRR material.
even more relevant right now: if you don't like
negative/critical/"unplurry" posts, the best thing to do is to ignore them
and post something positive/fun/loving.

negativity, hate, violence, etc. feed off of themselves. this can be
observed all over the real world as well as right here on this list.

the best way to stop violence is to be peaceful.
the best way to stop hate is to be loving.
the best way to stop negativity is to be positive.

plr (unity can wait),

brian

> Friday December 6 3:57 PM EST
> 
> Supreme Court to Decide Internet Indecency Law
> 
> WASHINGTON (Reuter) - The Supreme Court agreed Friday to decide a
> landmark case on free-speech rights in cyberspace arising from a
> federal law that effectively bans indecent material on the Internet
> global computer network.
> 
> The U.S. high court said it would hear a Justice Department appeal
> seeking to reinstate the law's prohibition on the dissemination of
> sexually explicit material to those under 18 years old.
> 
> Backed by President Clinton, the Justice Department asked the Supreme
> Court to overturn a precedent-setting ruling in June by three federal
> judges in Philadelphia declaring unconstitutional key parts of the
> Communications Decency Act.
> 
> The nine high court members will hear oral arguments in the case early
> next year, with a decision due by July.
> 
> The law, signed by Clinton in February as part of a telecommunications
> overhaul, bars the distribution to minors of indecent or "patently
> offensive" materials on the Internet, which is used by an estimated 40
> million people.
> 
> The law defined indecent as anything that "depicts or describes in
> terms patently offensive, as measured by contemporary community
> standards, sexual or excretory activities or organs." The law does not
> target obscenity or child pornography, which already are illegal.
> 
> Violators face criminal punishment of as much as two years in prison
> and a $250,000 fine. The ruling barred the Justice Department from
> enforcing the law.
> 
> The law had been challenged on free-speech grounds by the American
> Civil Liberties Union and groups representing libraries, publishers
> and the computer on-line industry.
> 
> They charged the law essentially bans indecent material, limiting the
> adult on-line population to "only what is fit for children" and
> transforming the Internet into the most heavily censored form of
> communication.
> 
> Acting Solicitor General Walter Dellinger of the Justice Department
> warned in the appeal that the ruling by the three judges would have
> far-reaching consequences.
> 
> "The decision ... imperils the government's ability to protect
> children from exposure to sexually explicit material that is now
> widely disseminated on the Internet," he said.
> 
> "Equally significant, the decision leaves many parents who do not want
> to expose their children to sexually explicit material with little
> choice but to severely limit or altogether deny their children's
> access to the Internet," Dellinger said.
> 
> He defended the restrictions as necessary. "Patently offensive
> material is widely disseminated on the Internet, and computer-literate
> children -- of whom there are many -- can easily find and retrieve
> it."
> 
> If the high court upholds the law, rapid technological changes may
> result in new ways to restrict access to children of sexually explicit
> material, Dellinger said.
> 
> Many commercial sites on the World Wide Web that display sexually
> explicit content already use credit cards and other adult verification
> devices to screen for age. Chat-room users can set up rules limiting
> participation to adults, he said.
> 
> American Civil Liberties Union attorney Christopher Hansen urged the
> justices to affirm the June decision.
> 
> He said the judges correctly found it economically and technologically
> infeasible to comply with the law. The restrictions infringe on
> constitutionally protected speech on topics such as safe sex and gay
> rights, he added.
> 
> Lawyer Bruce Ennis, representing the other parties who challenged the
> law, agreed the lower-court ruling was correct.
> 
> But he did not oppose the government's request for Supreme Court
> review because the case involved the first application of
> constitutional free-speech principles to an important new
> communication medium.
>

--------------370A58EF665D

<strong>
<!-- Yahoo TimeStamp: 849905820 -->
Friday December  6  3:57 PM EST
</strong>
<h2>Supreme Court to Decide Internet Indecency Law</h2>
<!-- TextStart -->
<p>
	    WASHINGTON (Reuter) - The Supreme Court agreed Friday to
decide a landmark case on free-speech rights in cyberspace
arising from a federal law that effectively bans indecent
material on the Internet global computer network.
<p>
	    The U.S. high court said it would hear a Justice Department
appeal seeking to reinstate the law's prohibition on the
dissemination of sexually explicit material to those under 18
years old.
<p>
	    Backed by President Clinton, the Justice Department asked
the Supreme Court to overturn a precedent-setting ruling in June
by three federal judges in Philadelphia declaring
unconstitutional key parts of the Communications Decency Act.
<p>
	    The nine high court members will hear oral arguments in the
case early next year, with a decision due by July.
<p>
	    The law, signed by Clinton in February as part of a
telecommunications overhaul, bars the distribution to minors of
indecent or &quot;patently offensive&quot; materials on the Internet,
which is used by an estimated 40 million people.
<p>
	    The law defined indecent as anything that &quot;depicts or
describes in terms patently offensive, as measured by
contemporary community standards, sexual or excretory activities
or organs.&quot; The law does not target obscenity or child
pornography, which already are illegal.
<p>
	    Violators face criminal punishment of as much as two years
in prison and a $250,000 fine. The ruling barred the Justice
Department from enforcing the law.
<p>
	    The law had been challenged on free-speech grounds by the
American Civil Liberties Union and groups representing
libraries, publishers and the computer on-line industry.
<p>
	    They charged the law essentially bans indecent material,
limiting the adult on-line population to &quot;only what is fit for
children&quot; and transforming the Internet into the most heavily
censored form of communication.
<p>
	    Acting Solicitor General Walter Dellinger of the Justice
Department warned in the appeal that the ruling by the three
judges would have far-reaching consequences.
<p>
	    &quot;The decision ... imperils the government's ability to
protect children from exposure to sexually explicit material
that is now widely disseminated on the Internet,&quot; he said.
<p>
	    &quot;Equally significant, the decision leaves many parents who
do not want to expose their children to sexually explicit
material with little choice but to severely limit or altogether
deny their children's access to the Internet,&quot; Dellinger said.
<p>
	    He defended the restrictions as necessary. &quot;Patently
offensive material is widely disseminated on the Internet, and
computer-literate children -- of whom there are many -- can
easily find and retrieve it.&quot;
<p>
	    If the high court upholds the law, rapid technological
changes may result in new ways to restrict access to children of
sexually explicit material, Dellinger said.
<p>
	    Many commercial sites on the World Wide Web that display
sexually explicit content already use credit cards and other
adult verification devices to screen for age. Chat-room users
can set up rules limiting participation to adults, he said.
<p>
	    American Civil Liberties Union attorney Christopher Hansen
urged the justices to affirm the June decision.
<p>
	    He said the judges correctly found it economically and
technologically infeasible to comply with the law. The
restrictions infringe on constitutionally protected speech on
topics such as safe sex and gay rights, he added.
<p>
	    Lawyer Bruce Ennis, representing the other parties who
challenged the law, agreed the lower-court ruling was correct.
<p>
	    But he did not oppose the government's request for Supreme
Court review because the case involved the first application of
constitutional free-speech principles to an important new
communication medium.
<!-- TextEnd -->

At 2:46 AM -0000 12/7/96, Austin Woffington wrote:
>Hey Ethan,

>What's up with FnF lately.  Any plans for a NYE party  Begin again
>perhaps?  Just wanna go again.  Thanks.


FnF, like a lot of groups, is looking diligently for the right space to
throw a quality party.  There is no immediate plan for an FnF, but we are
working hard at it.

Tony

knucklehead wrote:
> What the fuck!!!! fucking...fucking...fucking...fucking...shit...fuck 
> FUCK...fucking...Pissed off.

So how come is it that we get more angry at the person who calls out
injustice than the person who committed it?

I sense a dangerous trend here.

Also, can we please not use the word 'fuck' as a pejorative?  What's
_bad_ about fucking?  Thank you.

*** begin skippable digression about Disney ***

And for those who don't believe Disney isn't all harmless fun, check out
the messages that their films send.  I take the Lion King as an example
because it's the only recent one I've seen:

1) Leadership has nothing to do with talent and everything to do with
heredity (divine right of kings).
2) Females are helpless without the male around to lead them.  (Unlike
real prides, where the lionesses do most of the hunting.)
3) You can tell what others are like by what race and color they are. 
Jackals, for instance, are bad (note that they're black, unlike real
jackals), and Scar is dark-skinned too.  (Also note that in reality
lions frequently steal kills from jackals, being bigger.)
4) We are all helpless without the proper leader.  Once we restore him,
even his prey will rejoice.

Insidious, ain't it?  I don't claim that there has to be any conspiracy
involved, just a pandering to existing prejudice.

// grigsbeast

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Dec  6 20:38:07 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id UAA12574; Fri, 6 Dec 1996 20:38:07 -0800 (PST)
Received: from scruz.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with ESMTP id UAA12560; Fri, 6 Dec 1996 20:38:00 -0800 (PST)

Date: Fri, 6 Dec 1996 20:40:59 -0800

From: anarch@scruznet.com (Anarch)
Subject: Re: Good things about Cool World NYE
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Max Vision <vision@gryphon.com> wrote:
>Most of the talent lined up is really good, and despite the cost, I
>believe there will be enough to experience and enjoy to make it worth
>it.
 [...]
>I understand the resentment I've been reading about.  I understand the
>*huge* difference between a beautiful rave versus a massive party.  I
>just think all things considered, CW will be a fun place to be.

I have just one comment on this whole thing, and I've been trying not to
get sucked into giving it, but this finally tipped the scale (cause I feel
the same).  I don't think anyone really cares exactly what's going on at
this CW deal--I'm sure there are dozens, if not hundreds, of other New
Year's affairs far more non-ravey, non-PLUR, non-techno, whatever bugs
you--but the *claim*, by the CW producers, to represent the underground
dance culture (implicit, but definite) pisses people off.  The people that,
rightly or wrongly, feel themselves true members of the culture they see
misrepresented.  I think CW probably will be a fun party, though I wouldn't
pay to go myself, and I have nothing against people who will enjoy it, but
it does bother me that those people may go to CW and think that they have a
good understanding of rave culture and, by extension, me.  It's a natural
phenomenon, unfortunately, just part of the process that is moving rave,
house, techno, whatever, towards the mainstream.  What to do about it?
Beats me.  Just get up and do your part to distinguish whatever *you* love
from everything else.

anarch@scruznet.com

At 02:02 PM 12/6/96 PST, Ivan Vasquez scribbled something like:

>Does anyone know of any raves going on in Las Vegas this weekend? Is there
>an emailing list for vegas raves?

Hello Ivan,

        Being a former Sin-city resident, I can tell you that the rave scene
there is pretty much dead.  Last time I was there (8/96), I tried my
damndest to find a rave (I was just in one of those moods, you know?).  I
came up empty handed, so took some Vitamin X and grooved with some friends
at their house.  I think the scene there is really unorganized right now,
but it looks somewhat promising.  I gathered from some talk that the local
DJs seem to like mostly West Coast progressive trance.  But whatever you do,
_stay_away_ from the weekly called Utopia, I made that mistake, it's held a
club that I can't remember the name of right now (Gee, what happened to my
memory?) somewhere on the Strip.  Basically, it's a bar with a pretty cool
dance floor.  I, personally, don't beleive that alcohol and raves mix.  The
night ended up really bad, basically a bunch of drunk UNLV frat boys making
asses of themselves and the second DJ I saw couldn't spin worth a damn (I
think Hellen Keller could have done a better mixing job, maybe he was
trashed too? :-) )  Ok well that was my $.02

If you want more info, I hunted down a web page while I was there,
http://www.unlv.edu/~bright/LVraves , not too sure if its still there or if
I remembered that correctly but it's worth a try, eh?

Happy Groovin',

Jayson
[way_too_long_sig]
check out my waste of bandwith at http://weber.u.washington.edu/~donk

Dear SFRavefriends,
	
	I don't think Jim meant to say that raves are only about PLUR, or
that PLUR is the be-all end-all of raving.  What I understood him to be
saying is that raves are about more than music and dancing, and I consider
that to be something worth saying.  PLUR is a simple saying, it need not
be taken as the sum total of everything we want to express, only a hint of
it.
	While the acronym PLUR may not have emerged until a couple years
ago, the scene's positivity that inspired it has been around much longer,
and I think was strong in many ravers in 1991-92 as it is strong in
many now.
	It's true that MTV could start throwing PLUR up on the screen, and
"exploiting" the term, or ravers could be ridiculed for it, as indeed we
already are being ridiculed for it even on this list.
	Personally though, if we as a movement/scene are going to be
pigeonholed, I think being labeled as people into peace, love, unity, and
respect would not be such a bad thing.  
	Should we take raves seriously, or just have fun?  Who says we
can't do both?  

PLURally yours,
				<<< Starchild >>>

My computer tells me that on Thu, 5 Dec 1996, Sami Khoury shared:

> On Thu, 5 Dec 1996, Thompson. Jim wrote:
> 
> > 	Raving is supposed to about MORE than just dancing and
> > 	having a party.  Otherwise, why is Raving any different or any
> > 	better than ballroom dancing to Lawrence Welk?
> 
> Supposed to?  According to whom?  And why is it an issue that raving is
> better than something?  Did you have fun at the last rave you went to?  If
> so, what more justification do you need for going than that?
> 
> I've been going to parties since 1991 -- I attended the first rave ever
> thrown in Houston, TX, and have not looked back since.  PLUR was nowhere
> in sight then -- I anxiously awaited the weekend parties to *dance*, to
> stomp my feet to fat beats, to have a good time, basically.
> 
> This notion of PLUR has emerged I'd say within the last two years.
> 
> Ultimately, I think "plur" is bad for raving.  Why?  Because it's a
> pigeon-hole.  Because once you've categorized yourself like that, you're
> doomed to be exploited until the thing you love is dead.  Why does the
> underground continue to survive?  Because it has no face -- it has
> no quick, one-line summary.
> 
> Now, raving is far from underground, but when we start seeing PLUR-like
> video montages on MTV and this list erupts with complaints that "they're
> ruining our scene", I'm going to say, what did you expect?  Professing
> that raves are all about *this* (gesturing to PLUR) is essentially handing
> yourself over to be exploited.
> 
> As far as Neils' post goes, perhaps he was a bit rough.  But he's got an
> excellent point: replace "plur" with "jesus" in your standard-fare sfraves
> post and you've got yourself a religious zealot.
> 
> 	Sami
> 
> 
>

Subject: Re: Name the tune 
In-reply-to: Your message of "Fri, 06 Dec 96 21:24:01 PST."
             <9611068499.AA849937312@CCMAIL.AIRTOUCH.COM> 
Date: Sat, 07 Dec 96 09:14:52 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


>     All I know is it has James Brown "all aboard..the nighttrain" in the 
>     tune. Who is it by ?

This may not be the song you're thinking of, but I do know that the UK
group "Dub Syndicate" had a song called "night train" that repeated
this sample that said "all aboard the night train". Whether that was
James Brown or not, I couldn't tell you; I always thought that it was
Bim Sherman (occasional vocalist for dub syndicate back then, now solo)
who was just singing that sample.

It's not techno, it's a unique blend of high-tech dub/mixing by Adrian
Sherwood played by both Englishmen and Jamaicans-living-in-the-UK which
thrived from about 82-90 in the UK and is clearly a forebearer of some
of the dubby sounds you hear in modern rave music (IMHO).

You can get the track on On-U Sound's "Dub Syndicate Classic Selection
vol 1" 1989. The single was previously only available on an import 12"
from Contempo Records (Italy).

PS: one of the best live shows I've EVER seen was a Bim Sherman show in
London ca 1988 with Adrian Sherwood on the decks and many members of
the Dub Syndicate "band" playing their instrumens (guitars, drums,
congas, keyboards, bass, etc). Yeah, the Spectrum and Shoom and the
Ibiza scene were fun too.

> asses of themselves and the second DJ I saw couldn't spin worth a damn (I
> think Hellen Keller could have done a better mixing job, maybe he was
> trashed too? :-) )  Ok well that was my $.02

FYI, the reason why all those Helen Keller jokes existed is that the
press and politicians and people in power at the time couldn't actually
argue with her political activism (voting rights for women, labor rights,
socialist-tending ideology that made the captains of industry afraid of the
potential power of the people). So instead, they trashed her for her
disabilities, plastered the newspapers with cartoons and jokes about
her, and thereby conveniently got people to focus on her as a joke
so that nobody would take her message seriously. 

Nowadays, it's much easier -- one would just say, "oh she's just a
negative person who doesn't understand PLUR" and you'd effectively tar
and feather the message and the messenger that the establishment
doesn't want you to hear -- after all, this is the best of all possible
worlds and we should just accept our fates as being part of the natural
order. Let's all just be peaceful and fluffy while the man has his way
with us. SO drop another hit of X and bleat on little sheep, bleat on!

Subject: y'all are makin me feel like a punk rocker at a hippiefest!
Date: Sat, 07 Dec 96 09:39:54 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>

Precedence: bulk


now that we have 20 minute extended ambient/techno noodlings that
starts from nowhere and ends up nowhere. now that we have a cult of
musician idol worship... it's becoming just like the mid-70's prog-rock
scene again -- boring! I think it's high time for a punk rock attitude
to reenergize the somnolescence of the rave scene... or maybe the next
clintonesque mothership needs to land and show us all how to groove
with the funk, pop us out of this suburban white rocker attitude. the
rave scene has grown long-in-the-tooth and boring what with much
talking about PLUR and not enough dancing and grooves and real honest
emotion (you know the kind that would make you bust out in tears of joy
right in the middle of the dance floor). I guess that isn't allowed
anymore, we just need to glue that sparkly plastic smile on our faces,
cast a veneer of sameness over vast underlying differences -- when you
pass people on the streets you say "have a nice day" like an automoton
but nobody really means it. I don't think that's what the "house
nation" was supposed to  be about.

(wake up ya bloody PLUR wankers!)

Discuss.

party.  Amazing!!!  Just really really really amazing!!!  Happy vibes all

friends.  We had the best connection after the rave that is just sooo
unexplainable, you would have to expirence.  Everything today is absoulty
beautiful and wonderful it's just sooo rad.  Everyone there was way way way
cool, and I don't know what say it was soo amazing.  Anyway I think you
recived my point here.  That was the best, THE BEST, party ever!!!!!!  Love
you all,
Peace, Love, Unity, and Respect,
Eric Vandenbroek

Yes!

Chai can be enjoyed at home...

Dice up fresh ginger and cinnamon and cloves and cardamom and licorice 
and any other spices that meet your fancy and simmer them to create a 
tea.  Strain the tea, add lots of yummy natural organic sweetener and 
your milk choice.. enjoy to warm the body and soul!

There are many pre-mixed herbs available as Chai in natural food 
markets... I recommend, of course, Organic Santa cruz NUB Chai because 
it has been carefully blended from only the finest certified organic 
ingredients (no easy task).  

Organic Santa cruz NUB Chai will begin to show up in Bay Area stores in 
the next few weeks (even sooner if you request it of your local market!) 
but you can order it from us by calling 408-458-2071 or sending email.  
Also, for more information on Chai than is available anywhere else, 
point your web browser to the NUB in cyberspace at 

http://members.cruzio.com/~nubchai 

Happy brewings-

Nate
NUB Circus

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Dec  7 13:21:45 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id NAA06468; Sat, 7 Dec 1996 13:21:45 -0800 (PST)
Received: from proxy2.ba.best.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with ESMTP id NAA06463; Sat, 7 Dec 1996 13:21:40 -0800 (PST)
Received: from 206.86.220.227 (bwret.vip.best.com [206.86.220.227]) by proxy2.ba.best.com (8.8.4/8.8.3) with SMTP id NAA04830; Sat, 7 Dec 1996 13:18:03 -0800 (PST)
Message-ID: <32A9D188.7051@best.com>
Date: Sat, 07 Dec 1996 13:20:24 -0700
From: Alex <bwret@best.com>
X-Mailer: Mozilla 2.02 (Macintosh; I; 68K)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
CC: radon@kzsu.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Record Bag 12/7/96
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Short Reviews this month. Hope it's useful!
-alex

-------------------------------------------------------------->
Dispatches- Hidden Agenda- Metalheadz

Incredible considering the jazzy style they've been hanging with for the 
past year. Sharp, crisp beats as always, but they're charting darker 
territories these days. "Intelligent" doesn't even come close.
-----------

Split Personality- Total Science- Timeless

Also known as Q-Project and Funky Technicians, this 12" has one dark 
amen stomper and a more jazzy steppers track on the flip. Useful and 
quality.
------------

Da Flow- Tobestar- Glow

German Jungle which sounds a year behind the times. Nevertheless, top 
notch arrangement on all 3 tracks. Melodic, dark, uplifting...it's all 
combined to gether onthis great 12". Too bad the pressing's wack...
------------

Hardstep- DJ Rap- Proper Talent

Infectious hard jump-up number. One cheesy sample can be forgiven. 
Proper indeed.
-------------

1,2,3- Keen (ss rmx)- Formation

Another quality jump-up track from the formation camp. SS takes this 
song and delivers the craziest bassline I have yet to hear. Warp 10.
--------------

The 3rd Sequence- Photek- Astralwerks

Get this now. Master Rupert Parks has so much material recorded that 
even songs for video-games turn out like butter. From the Wipeout XL 
video gamesoundtrack, only 1,000 of these were pressed. domestic, too. 
Everything you'd expect it to be.
----------------

Hold it Now- Majistrate- Splash

Solid roller from one of the reigning kings. Deep and energetic. 
-----------------

The Wind Changes- Mission Control- Genetic Stress

Label that juno reactor releases jungle on. Cool mellow electronic 
piece. Will go over well with the intelligent crowd. Very pretty:)
-----------------

Bladerunner- Forensic- Flavour Vinyl

Amazing track is the Flavour label's 4th release. Almost like a Goa 
jungle song, but with incredible drums and bass-line.
------------------ 

Out There- Higher Sense- Moving Shadow

What is up with this label lately? Recent releases have been much harder 
and aggressive as of late. Really moving away from the wimpy edge of 
intelligent which they'd cornered. 2 solid hard but melidic pieces here. 
Out There starts off jazzy, but don't be fooled. Everything, the flip, 
is a sinister stepper.
---------------------

Beings- Tecnical Itch- Moving Shadow

Wimpy A-side by funky technicians. The flip side by tech itch, Beings, 
is a brilliant stormer with extra-terrestrial themes. Metallic and dark.
----------------------

Reprazent- Roni Size- Mo'Wax

Really good 2x12" from Bristols favorite jungle producer. Along with 
Tricky, Massive Attack and Portishead, Roni Size becomes the next star 
to come out of this unassuming town. 4 solid crisp numbers definately 
more on the jazzier tip than usual. Still dubby and sparse. For those 
who like reading between the lines.
------------------------------------

Well, I'm too tired to do more. Check out my top 10 on the sfjungle 
homepage. www.sfjungle.com/charts

Subject: quotation, not so much discussion... but relevant none-the-less
References: <199612071739.JAA22777@netcom6.netcom.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

the following is taken from the Praxis label newsletter in England 
(issue#10)

More and more signs appear that the age of techno is fading, that rave 
culture is finished, or become part of an industrand therefore stripped 
of the elements that made it interesting for us.  Of course that is a 
question of definition - and we should remember that the tyranny of the 
4/4 beat was pointed out years ago by some people (e.g. Force Inc. in '92 
when they embraced the more subversive potential of breakbeat), certainly 
with the domination of trance the 4/4 beat became a tool of power and 
control which eliminated the associate concepts of liberation.  From 
being futuristic and experimental per se Techno became a style and 
largely conservative.  Hardcore tried to escape this development by 
becoming even harder, faster and more extreme; but it is only a minority 
scene that is too busy with little feuds and sectarianism - attacking 
each other rather than the real enemy (like the entertainment industry 
for example, and its role as a ministry of propoganda for the current 
political and social system).  I am not proposing a hypocritical concept 
of unity here, the diversity is a strength, what i am suggesting is that 
changes are about to happen and a new scenery will establish itself in 
which neither those plagued with petty bitter jealousies nor those 
preoccupied with niche marketing will play a role.
     I shall quote from the book "The Sekhmet Hypothesis" by Iain Spence 
(1) where in one chapter he elaborates a thesis about the coming 
youth culture he calls "Storm" which comes after the Hippie / Punk / Rave 
trilogy and completes the "cosmic mandela", an ultra-aggressive and dark 
movement that is more militant and politically sussed than Rave, more 
organised than Punk and totally hostile to bourgeois society in general. 
 It will also be misunderstood and misrepresented as 
'fascist','totalitarian' and 'apocalyptic' by the media, but with its 
brutal force it will ravage old age values over the next few years...

naturally the politically situation is different with the ultra right 
wing criminal justice bill slingin rascal mystery schools (hell, even in 
ontario, canada we have governments with police welfare state agendas)... 
we need to move forward, not go back into punk... this cycle is 
complete... we have to evade "the game" once more... chaos lingers in the 
subgene xenophrenic... because we choose to know the score...
please. discuss.
the alchemist

Hi there friends, bruddahs, sistahs!

What's going on tonight? I NEED TO DANCE!!! Damn, I've got so much pent-up 
energy, I'm bouncing off the f@*%$ng walls!!!  I've got not sexual frustration, 
but something even worse- RAVE FRUSTRATION!!

What made it even worse, is that after listening to a jungle CD all day (which 
gets me wired!) I convinced one of my roomies to go out last night. The deal 
was, I would go with her to some Irish bar, if she would go with me to X-files 
or King street garage. Well, we went to the bar, then around 1:00 went to King 
st. garage, but through several complications which I won't go into here, did 
not go in. She wouldn't go to X-files, so we went home. How was King Street? 
Did anyone go? But more importantly...

WHERE THE HELL IS EVERYONE GOING TONIGHT???   Karma? or, the place on Broadway? 
How are the dj's scheduled for Karma- opinions, please. Or is there anything 
else going on that's not on the calendar?  


Vielen Dank fuer deine hilfe!!

Nathan

 "Beyond Rage"
 They're a band.
 Who are they (really)?
 Where are they (playing)?
 Why are they (making it so hard for people who like their
   music to find them)?
 How are they (alive)?

  they do live tekno-ish stuff.


I think their name is actually "Beyond Race", but I could be wrong. I saw them 
at Burning Man, and they blew my mind ('course I was pretty far gone to begin 
with!)  They had a drum machine, a "techno-machine" (don't know what it's 
called, but I see them all the time at raves), a live drummer, a bongo player, 
maybe a keyboardist, and a distortion-guitarist. Just an incredible sound- very 
raw, powerful.  I posted back then to the Burning man list about how to find 
them.  Someone else posted back a message with a phone number. Called it, left 
a message, never heard from them.  Possibly have an album, that may be sold at 
Amoeba in Berekeley?   If you DO find out where to buy  some of their music, 
would you please email me?  Thanks!!

-Nathan

From: "Ciaran OHara" <ciaran.ohara@CCMAIL.AirTouch.COM>
