To: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: y'all are makin me feel like a punk rocker at a hippiefe
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     
     I have to agree that punk rock and techno/rave/whatever it's called 
     this week have many similarities. Punk rock was/is Do It Yourself 
     music. It was no longer necessaary to have the right suits, haircuts, 
     equuipment, accents to form a band. Guitar, bass, drums and  an 
     attitude were all that was needed. 
     From the raw energy of Iggy Pop wearing stockings and disfiguring          
     himself with beer bottles to the nihilism of the Sex Pistol's "anarchy     
     in the uk" punk spoke for a generation that felt alienated by              
     commercialism, corporate cock-sucking and the bloated, self-indulgent rock 
       dinosaurs of the seventies.
        Similarly, dance music grew out of a reaction to the stale musical 
environment of the 1980's. When I look back on that decade I see much pomp and 
preening but little real social commentry coming from the manufactured pop 
groups of the period. Spandau Ballet, Kajagoogoo, Duran Duran, The Human league,
ABC, Alphaville, and countless other lipstick and tea-towel wearing good looking
boys from middle England may have looked good on Top of the Pops but said 
nothing much to their audience about life in the real world. 
        In my opinion, the only real group of substance to emerge from the 80's 
were Manchester's The Smiths. This was in fact a group with real punk 
sensibilities, albeit playing in a more pop idiom. I think Morrisey summed up 
the whole 80's music scene succinctly in the song "Panic" : " Hang the DJ, Hang 
the DJ, Hang the DJ, because the music that he constantly plays says nothing to 
me about my life, hang the blessed the DJ".
        Anyway, back to the techno/punk comparisons. As sure as punk meant 
everyone could form a band with "three chords and the truth", techno meant that 
anyone that saved up enough to buy some basic equipment could put together a 
dance track in their own bedroom . No need to play the shmoozing game, 
developing an image, concentrating on market segments, having a musical vision 
watered down or altered by a producer who couldn't care less. Many a classic 
dance tune has been made inexpensively not in a 32 track recording studio but in
the home of someone with imagination, time and creativity.
        Many of the people working in techno today cut their musical/creataive 
teeth in the punk scene of the seventies. It is the whole DIY spirit that is the
most important comparison between the two scenes in my opinion. As punk reacted 
to the right-wing Tory  governemt, un-employment, stale rock acts with big stage
shows (Spinal Tap/Kiss anyone ?) and bigger hair, similarly the dance movement 
can be seen to setting itself up against the right wing. The government in 
Britain recently passed the Criminal Justice act. An act of Parliment which 
forbids the playing of electronically generated music in public places. Talk 
about targetting minorities. In retaliation, a group going under the banner of 
"reclaim the streets" has recently taken to turning up in public places in 
groups of up to 10,000 and basically setting up sound systems and partying for 
hours on end. 
        I've always felt that good music should have the power to move you in 
many ways. To make you feel happy, sad, angry, elated, ecstatic, relaxed, horny,
hopeful, etc.,. In the heat and confusion of a rave or party it may not be the 
time or place for political discussion but by virtue of thr fact that most 
people on the scene with a political/world view would tend toward Leftism then 
perhaps we have the means to force social/political change in ther same way punk
tried to....


Just my two pennies worth,


COH.





______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: y'all are makin me feel like a punk rocker at a hippiefest!
Author:  "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com> at atlas
Date:    12/7/96 9:39 AM


     
now that we have 20 minute extended ambient/techno noodlings that 
starts from nowhere and ends up nowhere. now that we have a cult of 
musician idol worship... it's becoming just like the mid-70's prog-rock 
scene again -- boring! I think it's high time for a punk rock attitude 
to reenergize the somnolescence of the rave scene... or maybe the next 
clintonesque mothership needs to land and show us all how to groove 
with the funk, pop us out of this suburban white rocker attitude. the 
rave scene has grown long-in-the-tooth and boring what with much 
talking about PLUR and not enough dancing and grooves and real honest 
emotion (you know the kind that would make you bust out in tears of joy 
right in the middle of the dance floor). I guess that isn't allowed 
anymore, we just need to glue that sparkly plastic smile on our faces, 
cast a veneer of sameness over vast underlying differences -- when you 
pass people on the streets you say "have a nice day" like an automoton 
but nobody really means it. I don't think that's what the "house 
nation" was supposed to  be about.
     
(wake up ya bloody PLUR wankers!)
     
Discuss.

==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       == 
== When yer swimming in a creek and an eel bites yer cheek, that's a moray!==

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Dec  7 15:53:22 1996

	id AA850003055; Sat, 07 Dec 96 15:40:40 PST
Date: Sat, 07 Dec 96 15:40:40 PST
From: "Ciaran OHara" <ciaran.ohara@CCMAIL.AirTouch.COM>
Message-Id: <9611078500.AA850003055@CCMAIL.AIRTOUCH.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: PuNk and TeChNo
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     
     
     Hello all, I decided to put this letter into an  e-mail of it's own 
     with a new subject line. Also ran spell check to catch all those 
     mistakes. Maybe we can start a thread or something......
     
     
     I have to agree that punk rock and techno/rave/whatever it's called 
     this week have many similarities. Punk rock was/is Do It Yourself 
     music. It was no longer necessaary to have the right suits, haircuts, 
     equipment, accents to form a band. Guitar, bass, drums and  an 
     attitude were all that was needed. 
     From the raw energy of Iggy Pop wearing stockings and disfiguring      
     himself with beer bottles to the nihilism of the Sex Pistol's "anarchy 
     in the uk" punk spoke for a generation that felt alienated by          
     commercialism, corporate dick-sucking and the bloated, self-indulgent 
     rock dinosaurs of the seventies.
     
     Similarly, dance music grew out of a reaction to the stale musical 
     environment of the 1980's. When I look back on that decade I see much 
     pomp and preening but little real social commentary coming from the 
     manufactured pop groups of the period. Spandau Ballet, Kajagoogoo, 
     Duran Duran, The Human league, ABC, Alphaville, and countless other 
     lipstick and tea-towel wearing good looking boys from middle England 
     may have looked good on Top of the Pops but said nothing much to their 
     audience about life in the real world. 
     
     In my opinion, the only real group of substance to emerge from the 
     80's were Manchester's The Smiths. This was in fact a group with real 
     punk sensibilities, albeit playing in a more pop idiom. I think 
     Morrisey summed up the whole 80's music scene succinctly in the song 
     "Panic" : " Hang the DJ, Hang the DJ, Hang the DJ, because the music 
     that he constantly plays says nothing to me about my life, hang the 
     blessed the DJ".
     
     Anyway, back to the techno/punk comparisons. As sure as punk meant 
     everyone could form a band with "three chords and the truth", techno 
     meant that anyone that saved up enough to buy some basic equipment 
     could put together a dance track in their own bedroom . No need to 
     play the shmoozing game, developing an image, concentrating on market 
     segments, having a musical vision watered down or altered by a 
     producer who couldn't care less. Many a classic dance tune has been 
     made inexpensively not in a 32 track recording studio but in the home 
     of someone with imagination, time and creativity.
     
     Many of the people working in techno today cut their musical/creative 
     teeth in the punk scene of the seventies. It is the whole DIY spirit 
     that is the most important comparison between the two scenes in my 
     opinion. As punk reacted to the right-wing Tory  government, 
     unemployment, stale rock acts with big stage shows (Spinal Tap/Kiss 
     anyone ?) and bigger hair, similarly the dance movement can be seen to 
     setting itself up against the right wing. The government in Britain 
     recently passed the Criminal Justice act. An act of Parliament which 
     forbids the playing of electronically generated music in public 
     places. Talk about targeting minorities. In retaliation, a group going 
     under the banner of "reclaim the streets" has recently taken to 
     turning up in public places in groups of up to 10,000 and basically 
     setting up sound systems and partying for hours on end. 
     
     I've always felt that good music should have the power to move you in 
     many ways. To make you feel happy, sad, angry, elated, ecstatic, 
     relaxed, horny, hopeful, etc...,. In the heat and confusion of a rave 
     or party it may not be the time or place for political discussion but 
     by virtue of the fact that most people on the scene with a 
     political/world view would tend toward Leftism then perhaps we have 
     the means to force social/political change in the same way punk tried 
     to....
     
     
     Just my two pennies worth,
     
     
     COH.

      It seems that the horrific torrent of mean and NRR stuff that belongs
on private channels has finally slowed down.  I checked my mail several
minutes ago and found everything that belongs there:  party reviews, music
reviews, music-related discussion.  Maybe the weekend brought about some
good vibes. I dunno.  The purpose of this is simply to thank everyone on
this list for (seemingly) calming down. This is a valuable community and it
hurts to see so many members unsub -- on less than voluntary terms.  We've
weathered the storm and now it's time to rebuild.  Thanx for listening =)

     What is the differece between a clubber and a raver ? 
     
     As far as i can make out a rave seems to entail having my eardrums 
     battered into submission by Goa trance for 10 hours and if this is the 
     case I don't want it. I'm sure there are renegades going on that cater 
     for more than the one type of music, but where ?
     
     And while I'm at it. I Don't mean to dis Goa which I was into a lot 
     more a couple of years back, especially as the people that go to these 
     parties are the coolest/most beautiful etc.,etc., but if you are 
     throwing a Goa party PLEASE PLEASE have an ambient room. People need a 
     place to chill/retreat. 
     
     The open policy ambient room at Karma tonight sounds cool.

Sami wrote:

>> As far as Neils' post goes, perhaps he was a bit rough.  But he's got an
>> excellent point: replace "plur" with "jesus" in your standard-fare sfraves
>> post and you've got yourself a religious zealot.
>>

>>Response:

If the ideals of peace, love, unity, and respect are ones in which we as
ravers or humans wish to incorporate into our life rather than the ideals
that are opposite or move in the direction towards the opposite than by
living this we must become these ideals and others who see ideals working
for another will change for that reason.

If the world is eventually to see world peace then words like peace, love,
unity, and respect have to be so imbedded into our collective conciousness
and must be understood for what they have to offer us rather than the only
looking at them as ideas or slogans.  And yes MTV and Coca cola will have
to assist in spreading this message.  Why would anyone want to keep the
ideas of peace, love, unity, and respect underground.

Why fear what others will think of you if truly believe and practice your ethos?

Peace, Love, Unity, Respect, Understanding, Compassion, Unconditional love
... I am not ashamed to be labeled any of these ideas and hope, pray and
visualize the mainstream effects of these ideals in place upon the world.

Only by integrating these into society and raising spiritual awareness can
world peace come about and dissolve the dominator paradigm that we have
been living under for so long.  All these ideals have made attempts into
the world through religions or other groups such as the 60's but hegemoney
took over suppresed them through division, rules, policys or what ever to
see that true ideals were not upheld.  With raves this is happening through
cliques and egos.  Personally I have always seen the parties as a stage
that brings us together to celebrate to the music the ideals of peace,
love, unity, and respect.  I don't see these ideals as being a part of some
cult practice.  Loving and respecting another means loving, respecting and
understanding anothers logic and differences but no longer keeps them in
division against each other.

An example that the "Church", that preaches love, has brought in that has
been used to control people is the institution of monogamy that we uphold
in this culture.  The institution of monogamy breeds fear.  If we truly
lived in an unconditional love society there would no rules because there
would be no fears we would not harm each other because we would have no
fear driving us to harm, regulate or control others.  We wouldn't choose
one over another we would love all.   Homosexuality and even incest
wouldn't be thought of as taboo.  Sounds crazy huh?   We would be like
children promiscuously playing in the Garden of Eden.


Zealot for PLUR

[the following text written by my roomate Susan. -brian]

"Vibe So Thick You Could Eat It With A Spoon"

        The space was excellent, the decorations were glorious, the music
was sublime, and the vibe was maple syrupy, sweet and thick. Tyler
particularly enjoyed giving anteater kisses to all the shiny happy people.
Here are a few highlights:

        --Dave's proposal to Tuvee!!! the music kept building and swelling,
so i knew something was up, then a glowing "Marry Me Tuvee" banner was
hoisted aloft. a huge circle of cheering ravers formed around the couple,
for amazingly intense energy.

        --the kiddy pool filled with big 3D foam snowflakes. I met Bridget
&    Mick lounging in the pool-- we instantly became "foam friends" and
they spent the morning recovering at my house

        --dj tom's set in the morning! for the first time i was able to let
go and dance myself into an ecstatic state. i have never been so
un-selfconscious; the music left me no choice but to jump, shake, scream,
and grin.

        --meeting:
                -Aphrodite (Heather) who _radiates_ beautiful energy
                -Eric, who came with 250, yes 250, Blow-Pops (tm) to give away
                -Jamie, who was at his first party, on his first E, who
                 completely understands - he's part of the family
                -kelly, who is tuvee's dad. {a raving dad- it just doesn't get
                 and cooler than that}

        Lowlight: grafitti in the guy's bathroom. the dance studio is a
wonderful space and i'd hate to see us lose it...

        This party was 100% happy. I'm prone to really worrying about
trivial little things at parties- last night I didn't think at all, I just
felt. Many hugs to the stupendous Lepidoptera crew; they are now on my list
of "can't miss" parties.

Love and oozing golden vibes to all,
Susan & Tyler-the-Raving-Anteater



---------------------------------------------------------------------------

And in the end,
The Love you take
Is equal to the Love you make.

--The Beatles

ok, I'm not new to the scene.  I've been partying in LA for a few years
now.  In LA, there was no concept of "Goa Trance"...  not at the paties
I was going to, (FAMILY, fresh produce, insomniac, Insight, Equal) ...

Is "goa trance" the music that has no beat at all, just weird things
bleeping in and out... just pretty much random noises?  Or is it the 4/4
acid trance.. kinda hard, maybe 140 bpm.. heavy analog use..?
or something else altogether?

disclaimer:  I'm not trying to start a lengthy flame war that devides us
down the middle over what we consider to be "Goa Trance"..  please. :) 
*email* me what YOU think "goa Trance" is..  posting it to the list may
not be the best thing to do.  I've seen the Socal-raves list get crazy
over a topic like this.. :)
-- 
Steve Cooley

          First off I'd like to say I just moved to the Bay a few weeks ago
and I wuz wondering if anyone could hook me up with the 411 on the dopest
raves.  It wuz easier in LA, even the 7-11's had lists.  Now that I got that
out of the way I'd like to say although I see the similarities with raves and
punk what about the funk era?  I see more similarities with the funk of the
60's and 70's then punk.  Dance to music with a dope beat, have sex, and if
there's time left over trip out on ecstacy too.  A lot of the stuff worn to
raves comes from the funk era , glow in the dark paint and the whole
whatever.  That's all I'm trying to say, and I have an open mind so you can
try to change it if u want.

relentless beat.  The only reason i know this is goa is cos it says so 
right on the tape.  otherwise, i would have assumed it was just plain ole

On Sat, 7 Dec 1996 nephesch@autobahn.org wrote:

> If the ideals of peace, love, unity, and respect are ones in which we as
> ravers or humans wish to incorporate into our life rather than the ideals
> that are opposite or move in the direction towards the opposite than by
> living this we must become these ideals and others who see ideals working
> for another will change for that reason.

What does this sentence mean?

> If the world is eventually to see world peace then words like peace, love,
> unity, and respect have to be so imbedded into our collective conciousness
> and must be understood for what they have to offer us rather than the only
> looking at them as ideas or slogans.

The early settlers of North America set up missions to school the Native
Americans in the ways of religion -- to embed the idea of salvation into
their collective consciousness.  The settlers' intentions were good, they
really believed that their way was *the* way to a better life.  What wound
up happening, though, was a near total destruction of the Native
American's culture.

So... in what way does your goal of ingraining PLUR into the collective
consciousness differ from that of the early settlers?

> Only by integrating these into society and raising spiritual awareness can
> world peace come about and dissolve the dominator paradigm that we have
> been living under for so long.

And this will be accomplished by attending raves?

Now there are PLUR-like things I do appreciate: when I step on someone's
foot accidentally while moving through a crowded rave, I apologize and I
get a smile and a pat on the back in response.  Or when a total stranger
offers me water while dancing.  Or when there's a goddamn *rainbow* in the
sky at F&F when the sun rises, the warehouse door rolls up, and people
tumble out dancing to house.

I think the danger lies in formalizing experiences like these into an
ideology.  My knee jerk response to "peace, love, unity, respect" is
"just do it". 

	Sami


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Dec  7 21:49:18 1996

Heelo SFR,

You know, I really never thought I would write this at this time.  I am
pretty much a stalwart, and am not likely to retreat, but after some
reflection, I have decied to leave SFR permanently.

The reasons are varied, but to say the least, I find the actions of many on
the list to be arrogant, and short sighted.  I have found a rave "religion"
to enter the list, and it is really not to my taste.  I have seen long time
contributors to the list heckeld for not upholding some dynamic the more
vocal ones adhere to.  I have found many new people on the list to be open,
but some others to be a closed-minded as the people they despise.

My most recent interaction with one of the more "elder" members of the
list, to be less than tasteful, very judgemental, very predjudical, and
generally  very shrill.  I have found the attitude of SFraves , over the
years to be very open, and generally open-minded.  I have found, in the
past, the people on the list open to new ideas.  I have had the great
fortune of inciting enough discussion so that memebrs of the list would do
thier own thing.  F&F is part of the result.  It was because of OPEN
discussion that it ever came to pass.  This and a host of other SFR-type
events are due to open and free dicussion.  Often times of things that are
not RAVE RELATED.  It has also been my fortune to make friends with the
people I have had the most lively discussions with.  Neils P. Mayer being
one of them.  Phred, Larry, Sun...Jeno, Markie, Martin, Preston, Jack D.,
Ethan, Bryce, Brenda B., Moni & Tom, Roxy, Amy S., Cassandra, and all you
other lovely sisters and brothers who escape me at the moment. and the
trest of you old-skool motherfuckers!  Love you guys, seriously!

But as I was told, things change, get with it.  It seems to me the
open-mindedness is gone.  Replaced by the drone and happy go lucky PLUR.
Something touted but often not practiced on this list, nor in life.  To
some people SFR is a major part of thier life, it is no longer just a
party, but a church.  And I don't want to be known as the artist who did
"Piss Christ" in this church.

I have plenty of things going on in my life, rave and parties are
definitely a back seat item.  But I look at SFR than so much more than
parties.  It thought it was a good thing; the dicssuion of 209, race,
colloquialisms, etc.  I think all these are about rave, because these are
all about the experiences we have at parties.

+++ more +++ (my mailer is broke) see part #2.



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Dec  7 21:49:33 1996

Subject: it's time to go part #2 (part 2 of 3)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

One of the things I had to think about is "What value do I provide to the
list?"  I have my criticisms of others, but in the end I have to look at
myself.  I can say this, I hardly go out anymore, primarily because I have
been there and done it all.  Before most of you, and will continue long
after most of you are as experienced, or jaded as I. Getting back to the
point, I hate long protracted battles.  I love argument, but hate to fight.
If I have to fight I want it to be very physical, so that I can feel each
blow, and deliver them accordingly.  Virtua Fighter I am not.  It just
don't translate well to this medium.  Debate?  Not on the list anymore,
things degrade to fighting and nothing is accomplshed except alot of bytes
being sent to plenty of people.  There is little argument, just preching,
and fighting.  Hta is CERTAINLY what SFR is NOT!  I often define things as
to what they are not that way what they are becomes much clearer.

One of the reasons I haven't gone to any SFR events can be seen through the
eyes of Jack Diamond, who has gone to far more events than I.  I have
always found SFR to be very cliquish.  But that has not stopped me from
making friends from SFR away from the SFR sponsored events.  To me this is
golden.  I am sorry that I have not had the good fortune to meet many of
you, but you will know wherre to find me, at Wicked or Stompy, period.
Nope I am not open to new shit. Why?  Becuase I know what I like ,simply
said.  I go to some smaller events, by the Good Times Kids, and of course
D7 parties when they happen.  UG's will always be  a part of my life, but I
cannot share them here or else hear the cry;s of "Why didn't you tell us?"
to which I reply "why didn't you know?".  UG should be that, publishing a
UG to the list is not UG to me, but maybe that may be one of my arcane
rules. UG's are word of mouth, not word of computer, IMO.

Some beefs:
I would like the lot of you to look up the word racist, not the redfeined
for your digestion by the more "vocal-that-be" on the list, but the
perscribed definition.  And please check yourselves.  I checked myself to
day and found some bigotry, but racist, no.

People, you can redfine what words you want.  Do not be suprised if someone
in the real world bucks up against your SFR definition.  We exist, here on
this list, as a subculture.  Just as hip-hop does to the larger culture.
In the end, bad is BAD, dope is DOPE, and a racist is a RACIST.
Colloquialisms or not, there is a defninition, and unless it is accepted by
the bulk of humanity, you are left in subculutre status.  Is it any wonder
people within the same super-culture and same country cannot understand
each other?  It is becasue of the flexibility of language.  Unfortunately
for language reality crosses.  I cannot walk into Apple and start throwing
around my redefinitons (colloquialisms) of things.  I have to be
understood.  The same with you.  So please next time you want to call me a
racist, be sure we agree to the definition.  And no , it is not ok to label
me unless we agree. It's the human thing to do.

Just because I say that Larry is Asian, I am African-American, and Jack D.
is white, does not make me a racist.  Look up the word.  It may make me a
categorizer, it may make me annoying, it may make me plenty of things, but
a racist?  Get real folx, get real.  Unless you have felt the sting of it,
please do me and every other person who is reminded of it in the
super-culture, shut up, you really don't know what you're talking about.  I
truly think that if this list were comprised of mostly my Jewish bretheren
(Iam I racist for citing Jewish?), we would probably not be having the
discussion of what is a racist, since both sides have felt the stings, in
history and recently.

The only thing I have asked from you intelligent beings is the capailtytondrsandothersoutid ou ralm.Unfoutely al Ihv
enountered is intoleranc  Someoft surelfrme,butfor he ostpar,ver thpas2 yars, hav sd litt, ver litle, a reslt of
meunsbbinlast time, andbeing mr oleat. St the categorzatio
an t rbbihan e onwih hedace.  Afte al,hat is whyou'r
hre sn' i?

++moe +++

I have got alot of things going on, asi I have said before, I really don;t
have time for what I see to be the rampant religion and intolerance on the
list.

I found parties  much more fun when I didn't know as much as I did.  The
same can be said of SFRaves, I was alot happier when I didn't even know
about it.  No, I have no regrets.  One of my good plas , my best friend, I
met over argument on this list.  His name is Geoff White, and he will
always be my homie, in the true black, African-American, Raza, Son Of
Abraham, sense of the word.  I have learned much from him and will continue
to learn.  I leave he and other warrirors to the fight that looms ahead.
For I think there will be much more nonsense, more religion, and more
predjudice than even he can shake a stick at.

As for the ladies; Sisters, I am really sorry if I sadi anything to offend
you.  My Bra & Booty Betty's was an attempt at humor, and it did not take
into account your feelings.  I meant it in fun, but am sorry I ever used
it.  I am sorry.  I have great respect for the ladies.  I never hit on any
ladies while at parties, and have enjoyed thier company for the most part.
So, for you my sisters, keep up the fight, the boys are in the house, and I
do mean boys.

AS for the rest of you, my white borthers, my brown brothers, my yellow
brothers, and sisters in kind, much, much love.  I do hope you all get
along.

Sheeit, I've had a great time here, and hope that new people who come to
the list have as good of a time as I have had.

To all you newbie screwheadz, yo, it's all about having a good time.  It's
all about dancing, it's all about the music, and it's all about the people.
There are LOTS of good parties going on.  Do 'em all.  You ain't no damn
raver unless:
- You spend $35 to get into the party of the century
- You are excited about going to a party
- You dance your ass off and can hardly walk the next day
- (optional) You take soooo many drugs that your eyes are like slot
machines in vegas
- You catch the blue buddah, or at least see it.
- You make tons of friends, some for years on end
- You get to know who does what party
- You get to know the DJ's
- You get on the guest list (at least once) <- this is highly optional, but
you gotta at least try.
- You become an experienced raver who despises the term because you are now
a partygoer. ;)

Yep, that's it.

Yo baby, pump up the volume...Ima go and spin some records.  And that's
where I'm at today.

Much love, Much peace, I'm Audi 5000,
John

*SUPER DUPERS TO B. Behlendorf, YOU'RE THE MACK!*
*SHOUTS TO ALL OLD SKOOL SFR: KEEP IT REAL !!!  *

P.S.  There was a time, oh my little droogies, that we didn't need no
fucked up enumeration of PLUR.  It was understood in the dance, and in the
music.  The second you try to define something so special, and reduce it to
4 componenets, it loses that which made it special in the first place.
Just a thought; there was a time you couldn't define rave...but there I go
again, looking to history to understand today.  Man am I dumb.  :)  Audi 5
g-money on the backside.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Dec  7 22:01:22 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id WAA06453; Sat, 7 Dec 1996 22:01:22 -0800 (PST)
Received: from scruz.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with ESMTP id WAA06449; Sat, 7 Dec 1996 22:01:18 -0800 (PST)
Received: from [165.227.109.23] by scruz.net (8.7.3/1.34)
	id WAA24498; Sat, 7 Dec 1996 22:01:14 -0800 (PST)
X-Sender: anarch@mail.scruznet.com
Message-Id: <v01530501aecff1fa6457@[165.227.109.23]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Sat, 7 Dec 1996 22:04:19 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: anarch@scruznet.com (Anarch)
Subject: Re: Beyond Rage
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Rob Rayle <robertr@autodesk.com> wrote:
>	"Beyond Rage"
>	They're a band.
>	Who are they (really)?
>	Where are they (playing)?
>	Why are they (making it so hard for people who like their
>			music to find them)?
>	How are they (alive)?
>	At least one inquiring mind (mine) wants to know.
>	Anybody on this list know anything about them?

Well, as we've heard, it's actually Beyond Race.  They're an SF band, been
around about two years.  I love em.  Trippy blends of fast noisy funk and
different Mideast/Indian/tribal sounds, with a dash of electronica.
Sometimes hard-edged, sometimes very spacey and atmospheric.  Some good
players...I think they've had a slightly different lineup every time I've
seen them, but the core is a drummer and a pair of guys trading off bass,
guitar, and keyboard, variously embellished with didgeridoo, tabla, violin,
other drums, more.  They were at Be Here Now last week as, I think, a
five-piece--drums, bass, and keys plus an additional guitarist, so there
wasn't any switching around, and some more drums.  Seemed to be having some
technical difficulties, unfortunately--sound was bad, and they didn't play
long.  Like Nathan mentioned, they were at this year's Burning Man--they
played on the central stage after the burning, with a really elaborate
coterie of dancers and freaks up on stage with them, fantastically
costumed, including a huge puppet alien menacing the crowd [Cap'n
Crunch!--I ran into you there].  They also played the earlier nights, much
more stripped down, just out in the camp.  They were at last year's, too,
the same way.  They have an album, Reptilian Confunktion, but I don't know
where you'd find it (I got mine from them direct).  For info, try
415-331-1500 x407.  I haven't called, but it's on the album liner--"ask for
Dan or Phaaron."  I've seen Dan and Phaaron (Aaron) at occasional raves,
and I've gotten flyers for their shows there, too.  Keep your eyes open!

anarch@scruznet.com

This list is going to be godawfully monochromatic, boring, uninspired
if you're not here to check 'em and lend us your experiences.  I
personally think you should stay and perhaps we can all come to an
understanding that this is SFRAVES not SFPLURBAPTIST-REVIVAL.. You let
them win by driving out diverse elements and voices that don't fall
into the uniform drone of boring unintrospective groupthink. And you
make it easier for them to believe PLUR has a meaning because it is oh
so easy to think that a group of uniform race, outlook, ethos and
economics can all share common language/referents and appear to be
unified simply because they've effectively exluded diverging opinions
from ruffling the group featherbed.

Instead, why don't all the PLUR heads unsubscribe and start your own
list where you can drone on and on about how fluffy your teddy bears
are, and how you got glitter in your eye one night and thought you were
a fly. And any time anything that interrupted the monotonous mantra of
PLUR-testimonials started happening, you could all just reply in unison
-- "oh you just need a hug" (vapid as that may be over e-mail versus a
real hug) -- then the conversations could go back to the usual drone 
"i truly had PLUR in my heart last night: i passed out 12.1lbs of candy
last night, and felt a frightful lack of PLUR from the diabetic that
refused me, as well as the overweight person who said he was on a diet
 ... i then affixed 131 stickers to 131 bodies, and told 13 people that
i didn't know that i loved them because they looked and dressed just
like me".... Groupthink posting that is tantamount to saying "look at
me, I'm so hip!"...

As far as I'm concerned, what's really going on in PLUR-land is you are
cheapening the meaning of the words Peace, Love, Unity and Respect.
Notice that PLUR doesn't include the word DIVERSITY. How convenient.
You can't have peace without war, you can't have love without hate,
etc. And I personally never thought the word Love should be diluted
into a marketing slogan.

At one point in time christian AGAPE had meaning, but how much LOVE is
present when that state of GRACE is reserved for the whitebread upper
middle class middle-amerikkkan nuclear family, not for single mothers,
single fathers, fatherless children, people of color, people of
different sexual persuasion, people of different politics, people of
different beliefs. When you can reduce a complicated concept to a
marketing slogan, you're just begging for trouble, as with AGAPE, as
with PLUR.

From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


>> now that we have 20 minute extended ambient/techno noodlings that
>> starts from nowhere and ends up nowhere. now that we have a cult of
>> musician idol worship...
>
>replace ambient/techno with jazz-funk, and it sure sounds like an early
>funkadelic album to me ...
>matt.

I think what happened was that Clinton et al wanted to do the crossover
thing given that extended psychedelic jams were the money-making thing
of the time. And black artists were still not getting paid. But it
wasn't long (like 1975-77) before they launched themselves into
mothership space with some tight funky numbers. Mothership Connection
AND Chocolate City albums were released in '75 and it was a  totally
new sound -- tight and emotional and booty shaking. I see the early
funkadelic era as chops-development for the group as musicians
exploring perfusing acid rock with a soul sound. The
parliament/disco/dance stuff of 75 was when the mothership really took
off. Their songs had a point, had a story (even if outrageous), and had
brevity, soul, and wit.  Real emotions were happening while Rick
Wakeman was pounding out has-been pretentious wanna-be classical music.
By the late 70's Parliament paid another visit back to earth finding
their black funk monolith misinterpreted into milquetoaste and treacle
by a bunch of white brits and australians and amerikkkan bandstand
sensibilities. SO they relanded to "rescue dance music from the blahs",
and hit us with their bop gun.

And it was an era of change, the MC-5, Iggy, Bowie were in the air,
punk's ugly (but truthful) head would be rearing by '77. The Meters had
just partially completed a tour with the rolling stones, introducing
funk to the white rocker audience....

Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Precedence: bulk

>     What is the differece between a clubber and a raver ? 

        CLUBBING: 
        You go out on weekends, pay $5-10bucks to get into a club
        at around 9 or 10pm (always the same location) sit around, 
        chat with some people, drink a little (or a lot), dance to 
        EuroDisco, House, and Pop music. The bar closes at 2am, most people
        leave and go home. If you are not 21+ then some of the above
        might not apply.

        Clubbers dress far too formal yet casual at the same time (I forgot the 
        word) in other words, Jeans, Nice Collared shirt, etc. (some of course
        might go to a club wearing a Tshirt, shorts and tennis shoes. The
        idea is (depending on the club) to pick up on someone else. (Cruising)

        RAVING:
        You go out on weekends, pay $5-15bucks and get to a rave at
        around 9 or 10pm (most of the time a different location). You
        can choose to sit around and chat with EVERYONE, Drinking (besides
        water is not usually found at raves) so people take things like
        E, Acid, Shrooms, etc etc. (drugs). Some people choose to dance
        for hours to loud repetitive techno, and some just decide to 
        relax and enjoy themselves and each other in the Ambient room.
        (depending on rave). Since there is no bar, the rave lasts 'till
        the sun comes up. Often till 7 or 8am. (unless the party gets 
        broken up by the police)
        
        Ravers dress according to their persona. The buy their clothes based
        on Color, Texture and Size and on who their character is. Some go
        to raves wearing fabulous fluoresent colored jackets and some
        baggy jeans, some go wearing just a tshirt and some will come in shorts 
        and some tennis shoes. The idea is to be yerself.


>     As far as i can make out a rave seems to entail having my eardrums 
>     battered into submission by Goa trance for 10 hours and if this is the 
>     case I don't want it. I'm sure there are renegades going on that cater 
>     for more than the one type of music, but where ?

        I loveeeeeeeeee GOA! who said it batters your eardrums? I haven't
        felt it yet ;)

>     And while I'm at it. I Don't mean to dis Goa which I was into a lot 
>     more a couple of years back, especially as the people that go to these 
>     parties are the coolest/most beautiful etc.,etc., but if you are 
>     throwing a Goa party PLEASE PLEASE have an ambient room. People need a 
>     place to chill/retreat. 

        Ok...I agree to this 100%. What if someone is 'Sober' at a party
        or are sick! and want to stay the whole night at the party but
        are a bit tired of dancing. Where would they go!?

>     The open policy ambient room at Karma tonight sounds cool.

        KARMA...(disappointed).. Where was the Ambient room anyway?

  My beef with you is that you've become so mind blowingly self-rightous
in your pronouncements about how EVERYONE besides you and John on the list
are. THAT IS PURE BULL SHIT.... Now if you want to make everyone aware of
how SOME people on the list are like that - I buy your words... BUT your
BLANKET WAY, WAY overgeneralized pronouncements are more bull than ANY of
these people have EVER spewed.... Plus, YOU are being overly cruel if
not to say unkind in your pronouncements. I've met John and the smiling
man which I met was one of deep thoughts, feelings and comittments... IF
that man really thinks about what ( and the way you made) your post said,
he'll realize in a heatbeat that what you said comes from the EXACT same
prejudicial space that other forms of bigotry, racism and hate arrise from.
 
  Since I'm one of the "elders" who lurks on the list - I like, John, have been
there, done that etc.. BOTH in the rave scene and more importantly life itself.
Many of the people you would accuse are young and by taking the strong mind
drugs are opening themselves for the first time to the "potentials" of the
human spirit.... They are like young eagles trying their wings and soaring
for the first time but as such many don't soar as fast or as high as the
elder more experienced birds - so what? At least they're out of the nest.
At least they're loving someone, even if as you would accuse it's a smaller
group of ravers... later it will be others. In my youth people like Tim Leary,
Ram Dass ( Dick Alpert ), John Lilly etc. were doing the very same explorations
with in many cases, the same limitations, as you would accuse people on this
list of having. But once you begin trying to reach out - especially when it
involves opening your mind to expanded potentials, things have a way of growing.
Of course, at first many are trapped by the phenomenon of the experience and
many become over enthusiastic in their descriptions of the "joy" of first
contact with a deeper self. As life goes on, many will trap themselves in the
current of life and fall into eddies of tritness and shallowness, but I am
convinced that many of the "next" generation of great thinkers will some day
arrise from the rave scene ( and other "scenes" of course ).... BUT at first
there will be what I call the  "OH WOW look at that shiney glitter phase"...
( As I say this I see many of the hippies and explorers of the 60's doing
the EXACT same thing...) 

  I've been quiet thoughout this "funny" discussion until I read your last
post. Then your bull shit and implications of how "advanced" you are just
got to me... especially after arguing with Leslie last night about how
raving and its simple minded PLUR is not going to change the world directly..
in the final analysis MOST of raving is about going to PARTIES. It's just
a party folks. BUT because of the use of drugs and the opening of community,
it's a party of a difference sort and it will be the seed of change in many
of its individual participants. They will move on to things that grow beyond
the party EXACTLY like some of the people from the 60's grew beyond the
boundaries of the bull shit "summer of love"... the hype then as now was 
often way beyond the reality where many people like Clinton didn't inhale -
hell I even tried acid but I didn't absorb was, of course, the "unasked"
question answer.  Many of the people from the 60's and summer of love hipe
got high, got fucked( many times) , avoided the war ( once was enough here )
and then proceeded to fold themselves back into the mass of racist, greedy,
dishonest consumers that we are surrounded with today but (and a VERY important
BUT ) not all did.... So it will be with the ravers. So it's always been
with any movement. SO what's new there? 

  It's your condescending tripe about YOU and JOHN being the saviors of the
world by being the only ones on the list who are not PLUR churchmembers etc.
(Not your EXACT words of course BUT those WERE your implications.) So please,
do me a favor and take your stupid, bull shit ass else where - you obviously
don't enjoy it where you've put it, you think WAY too highly of yourself 
and you're the worst example of a blind "archie bunker" dumb shit I've had
the opportunity to read on the NET.... previously, I read your posts with
humor and thought of you as thoughtful but now you come across  as one of
the most bigoted dumb fucks I ever been mistaken enough to read....
Damn people who make statements like you just made who come in any color
make me mad.... I'm pissed as hell that dumb fucks like you even exist much
less on "the list" and I don't even give a flying fuck about PLUR as
preached by ravers.... but I DO respond to calls for respect as preached by
the likes of Martin L. King, Ghandi, M. Theresa etc. AND what you just
said makes their work all the more important and your thoughts about your
supposed superiority all the more small and trite.....

        Hi Guys, I just thought I should review KARMA.
        
        Eric and I got the the mappoint at around 9pm soon after the line
started to build up
        (it almost seemed as if the party was on the street) Anyhow, payed
our 8bucks and headed
        on to 973 MINA ST. (between 10th and 11th). Got there at around 10pm
or so,got in. The 
        place wasn't all that IMHO. It seemed to be someone's house. (I
would love to have a house
        like that though). Anyhow, music was playing, people started dancing
and taking their drugs 
        (I had decided to be sober for the night... and forced Eric not to
take anything 'till midnight) ;) 

        Anyhow, at around 10:45 or so the music goes down low. People wonder
what's up. Some
        say the police are driving by or whatever... music comes back up.
5minutes later, the
        music stops. 10mins later it starts again... then it STOPS
completely and the DJ comes
        out and says the party has to end.

        So the police clear everyone out and the party is over at 11pm....

        SO, we headed down to the Friends&Family party just down the
street... (about 6blocks)
        Eric and I got in, the place seemed to have nice vibes, nice people
and nice music
         
        Anyhow, thats my feedback.
        love, harmony and art

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Dec  8 16:03:00 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id QAA07627; Sun, 8 Dec 1996 16:03:00 -0800 (PST)
Received: from cats.ucsc.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with SMTP id QAA07623; Sun, 8 Dec 1996 16:02:56 -0800 (PST)
Received: from si.UCSC.EDU by cats.ucsc.edu with SMTP
	id QAA22165; Sun, 8 Dec 1996 16:02:52 -0800
Received: by si.UCSC.EDU (8.6.13/4.7) id QAA07927; Sun, 8 Dec 1996 16:02:51 -0800
Date: Sun, 8 Dec 1996 16:02:51 -0800 (PST)
From: Randy C Cone <randream@cats.ucsc.edu>
Subject: Ascendance (review)
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9612081557.A6412-0100000@si.UCSC.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



Hi all!

 Well I heard Saturn might have something to do with all the (ahem) 
nastiness floating around the communication byways. Maybe it didn't hit me 
too hard as Saturn is my ruling planet. Of course I'm certain the 
holidaze stress factor had nothing to do with it.  ;)

 Ascendance was really fun! Pallokaville is a nice dancehall with wood 
floors. Sound seemed pretty good (for a shoebox ;). There is an 
alternative refreshment bar there (smothies and such) in addition to a 
regular bar. My fav part though was NO SMOKING!!!! I hate tobacco smoke 
and inhale way too much at raves in general (lousy ventilation in 
combination with the inconsideration most smokers show for non-smokers in 
combination with no in/out policys at most partys). This place has great 
ventilation and it never got too muggy.

 The music was really nice. Ther openers were the promoters (?) or maybe 
just one and a friend; Joe was playing some really nice trance (almost 
psi-trance) but the other person was playing something like a  
house/hip-hop/trip hop thang. Not so much to my tastes but okay if you 
like that stuff.

 Greg Sandler came on next and played his usual eclectic set; 
housey-trance, hard house and a tiny bit of acid and acid house. Very 
tasty and fun to dance to. Astral Matrix was at bat last and played some 
really good trance and psi-trance. My ride wanted to leave a litle early 
so I had to go. :( It was all good as I had to study.

 The decorations were simple yet very nice. The crowd was really friendly 
with a notable lack of hard looks from the usual hard look crowd.

 I'm looking foward to more Ascendance and recomend it highly to the 
Santa Cruz crowd!!

 It was nice to see some familiar faces there; Larry Ching, friends from 
SC and the extended Harmony family.

peas,



Ran D.Dreams

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Dec  8 16:08:28 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id QAA08042; Sun, 8 Dec 1996 16:08:28 -0800 (PST)
Received: from uclink4.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with ESMTP id QAA08037; Sun, 8 Dec 1996 16:08:23 -0800 (PST)
Received: from [128.32.160.49] (hmfmac11.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.160.49]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.7.6/8.6.12) with SMTP id QAA15031; Sun, 8 Dec 1996 16:08:19 -0800 (PST)
X-Sender: lachim@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Unverified)
Message-Id: <v02130512aed1070ae750@[128.32.160.49]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Sun, 8 Dec 1996 16:08:20 -0800
To: Steve Cooley <Stevec@pobox.com>
From: lachim@uclink4.berkeley.edu (michal migurski)
Subject: Re: "Goa trance"
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>Is "goa trance" the music that has no beat at all, just weird things
>bleeping in and out... just pretty much random noises?  Or is it the 4/4
>acid trance.. kinda hard, maybe 140 bpm.. heavy analog use..?
>or something else altogether?

goa trance has a really simple 4/4 beat (usually in the 140-160bpm range, I
think) that keeps you dancing, but sits still in the background while
complex washes of layered 303 tunes and other shit give it a rich
complexity unlike any other kind of techno. if you're from LA, I'm sure
you're familiar with Thee-O's style: he plays straight up dead-center goa
trance. Around here, dj's to watch for are Dutch, Tom, and anyone from
C.C.C.

it's an interesting form of music, because each song is so complicated and
textured that it doesn't really NEED to be mixed. for example, goa gil (the
most famous goa trance dj in the world) keeps all of his tracks on DAT and
uses a pair of DAT walkmans instead of 1200's. apparently, he considers it
a desecration of the music to mix it up, letting each track do its own
thing. the result is that you can hear pretty clearly where the mixes
occur, but it doesn't matter because his music (I do mean "his music:" much
of his arsenal was produced by him, and exists only in his little box of
tapes) is so powerful... plus the idea of a 10-hour set of driving pounding
superfast techno is an attraction in itself.

if anyone disagrees, let me know 'cuz I'm in no way an authority on this
subject.

-m.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Dec  8 16:32:58 1996

Date: Sun, 8 Dec 1996 16:32:34 -0800 (PST)
From: Randy C Cone <randream@cats.ucsc.edu>
Reply-To: Randy C Cone <randream@cats.ucsc.edu>
Subject: Mantra review (San Francisco)
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>, Is it Trance? <604@party.net>,
        Know 1 <knowoneness-l@teleport.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9612081653.A6412-0100000@si.UCSC.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



Hi all!  =)


 Mantra was really fun!! 

 We had an all nite location (YEA!). The basement was used for the main 
dance floor, with the upstairs used for the ambient room. The dance floor 
looked really wonderful (as usual) with all the fluro banners and Dave's 
black-lites. Ravens altar was an amazing space again and Brendan's smart 
bar was perfection (and a main social area!).

 The music was electrifying! (sp?) Dutch on first. He was mixing his 
usual acid-trance seemlessly. I just loved dancing to his set and 
listening hard to what he was doing.

 Anon was on next. I didn't hear much of her set due to my work upstairs  
=(  but what little I heard brought a smile to my face.

 Caban was then on. He has a full on GOA sound not dissimilar to what I 
heard from Goa Gil when he was in town a couple months back, except 
Caban's sounded just a bit harder and faster. It really moved my body in 
that uncontrolable yet synchronus way that I love; busting a move to a 
break I didn't know (consciously) was coming, etc. .

 The next person I checked out was Jeremy Starseed. I really like the 
changes and evolution he has taken with his music since the last few 
times I've heard him. Really good stuff!!!

 I had fun in the ambient room but was ultimately not really happy. The 
doors that were used for the entrance were supposed to not have been used 
and I based my design around that preconception. Oh well (shrug).

 I was really happy that we stopped letting people in when we did. Around 
3 am we had this huge influx of the under 18 crowd. The basement got 
really slippery and muggy but one person said they liked the dance floor 
slippery. It was kinda fun. It would have been nice to have better air 
flow though.

 HUGE thanks to the folks that helped me!! Dhiran and Ben just completly 
kicked booty and C-Jay was indespensible in the morning with his good 
humor and help.

 Special bonus prize!! I met Nichole from the knowoneness list. YEA!! She 
is the first person from the list that I have met since I signed on. It 
was wonderful talking to her. I really felt a tunnel of calmness open 
between us as we talked.

 Also very nice was the young lady I met very near the end of the party 
whose name was way too unfamiliar for me too remember. We had an amazing 
discussion about trance states and their percursors and such.

 Some of you may have read my last post and noticed that I said that 
the next Mantra would be on Jan. 3rd. We don't know for certain that it 
will be so please stay tuned.

hugz y'all,


Ran D.Dreams

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Dec  8 16:55:42 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id QAA11229; Sun, 8 Dec 1996 16:55:42 -0800 (PST)
Received: from dfw-ix4.ix.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with SMTP id QAA11212; Sun, 8 Dec 1996 16:55:32 -0800 (PST)
Received: from  (rayvonie@smx-ca9-43.ix.netcom.com [207.93.148.107]) by dfw-ix4.ix.netcom.com (8.6.13/8.6.12) with SMTP id QAA13754 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Sun, 8 Dec 1996 16:54:53 -0800
Date: Sun, 8 Dec 1996 16:54:53 -0800
Message-Id: <199612090054.QAA13754@dfw-ix4.ix.netcom.com>
From: rayvonie@ix.netcom.com (Ray Vonie)
Subject: Re: Media alert:  Burning Man on TV
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

David wrote: 
>
>On Monday, Strange Universe(ch 44, 10 p.m.) will feature a story on
>Burning Man.  It's usually a good show, they eschew the tabloid TV
>approach for a semi-serious look at paranormal topics such as the
>Unarians and Bigfoot.

I rally like the Strange Universe Show.  If I can watch it, i record it 
so that I do not maiss an episode.  It is like (fore those of you old 
enought to remember) a peranormal and acult version of Real People, or 
the Riplies Belive it or Not, or Thats' Incredible.

But I am not writing this to inform you of my tv viewing choices.  I 
have a serious question.  

    This is something to think about.  This show has aired some realy 
interesting stories, and has made public things that I never new 
existed.  Strange sightings, ufo abductions, and bigfoot, yah sure 
thats ok, wee all belive in ghosts and aliens, and telepathy.  but this 
show has bradcast stories of things even I never heard of and mabee 
never would have been exposed to if I had not seen the program,  
Therefore I feel like it is a good thing.  But what about the people 
that make it their careers to solve these misteries, and are the true 
core fersion of the topics of the stories covered by this show??  do 
you think that they are happy or even like this show "trivializing" 
their reaserch.  Or mabee taking stories, and experiences that are very 
personal to them, and airing it out to the world??  Do you think that 
those people feel like there is some substance lost, or taken away by 
the show as the information is passed on to the uninformed public, even 
though the information is important to be shared, and needs to be 
known???
    And what about the TV station, arn't they just in it for the 
rating, which translate to comercial sales and the botom line of 
money??  Do you think this ofends the people or the subjects which the 
stories are based.
    But if it were not for this show, how would sa many of us find out 
about such reclusive events that are not in the normal media, andwhat 
about the educational benefit that these shows provide by bringing this 
type of information to the public??  It certainly does a good job of 
exposing unaware people, if just slightly to interesting subjects, 
sparking intrest in those who might waht to persuit it to a deeper 
level,....Mabee....posibly some people, but definently not all.

    Does anybody see were I am going with this analogy, or am I just 
working on my typing skills???     

    Yes, there is a lot of corolation between this, and the issues that 
were debated about the Massive Parties (Cool World in perticular) and 
the undergrounds feelings about them. 

    In every form of entertainment the isues of tradeofs and values are 
going to be debated.  The comprimises of dilution of substance, as a 
tradeoff for mass exposure are in every form of entertainment ever 
imagined.  It is a natural conflict that is all too common in the 
industry. 
    Yes, thats right, I did just imply that raving is an entratinmnet 
industry, and it is seceptable to all the BS that entertainment comes 
with.  
    The nice thing about raving, vs. amany other forms of 
enetertainmnet, is that it has stayed undergroung long enought to 
develop a fery deep and powerfull meaning and message that comes with 
it.  This message, In the form of PLUR, is very substantial, as we all 
know.  This is why so many people get so hot and bothered by the 
direction that raving is going. 
    Yes, It is all going to be mainstreem eventualy, and the 
underground will gradualy decline with the expansion of the market, but 
it will still exist, and its message will still be present in the mass 
exposure of the mainstreem.  This is where the most positive evect of 
the rave sceen,...Mabee.... will be felt.  By its efect on the public.

    This is where things get Lost, as far as the concentraton of PLUR, 
and a lot of the substance and meessages in the music, but the tradeoff 
is the knowledge and exposure of the message to a large audiance.  
Those who take it to heart will persue it and become true suporters, 
and those who are just touched, In any way, are still benefited by the 
knowledge they experience by being exposed to the music, and message.

    Evolution in any form of entertainmnet takes usualy 2 directions, 
which are usualy inversly related.  When any sceen is mostly 
underground, there is still a small aspect of it that is mainstreem, 
that is where it gets its influence.  When a sceen gets blown up and 
goes mostly mainstreem, it still retains a samller, but very focused 
underground origin, which serves as the source of the mainstreem 
reflection that becomes the publics perception of the way it apears.
(that is a hard thought to grasp)  

    Anyways, this hapens, and the easeist thing for many of us to 
undrstand is that it is enevitable.  The rave sceen will eventualy go 
very mainstreem, Radio stations, MTV, the groups Images , Agents, Huge 
Festivals, and so on.  And with this, the underground will take a new 
influence from the mainstreem, merge it with the concentrated rave 
underground, and remaining core, and a new underground will be born.

    This has hapened to RAP, Hip Hop, Grunge, Ragea, and is now going 
to hapen to raving, and after that probably to Gothis, and Jungle, ad 
everything else.  
    Change is inevitable.  Fighting it gives us character, and 
divirsity, and makes us all human.

Please do not get me wrong.  I love the Rave sceen.  I have spent the 
last 7 years of my life in it.  I am in no way sying that we sould lay 
down and let huge record labels, and holywood, and MTV rol us over like 
bolwing pins.  But I am trying to explain to those that have bothered 
reading this far, that it is natural, and the best thing we can do is 
guide the expansion of the rave sceen into its mainstream directiuon 
with as much positive influence as posible.  Going out and being 
present at large festivals, masives, clubs, and other forms of 
entertainment that are picking up the sceen and educating people on the 
meaning of PLUR, and its importance to the origin of the culture.  

If we do not make our presence know, the mainstream will eventualy faze 
us out compleatly.  This way we can make a stronger influence and feel 
positive about our contribution towards something that meens so much to 
all of us.

I am not sure why I wrote all this, but I just wanted to represent my 
perspective on whats going on in our culture.  Those of you who belive 
that raving is some form of religion, or a way of life, or anything 
more than just entertainment will never agree with me.  And I certainly 
wouldn't expect you to.  You are going to be the people whose beliefs 
will influence the next underground.  Weather its Jungle, or Politiacal 
Music(which is going to be very cool when it comes out) or spken word 
or rave-gothic, or Undeground Ragee....The point is that no one should 
give up their individuality or desires because of the natural course of 
entertainmnet, or eventualy, all entertainmnet, Music, and Dancing will 
go stagnent, and dull, and mabee even die.

Believ in Yourself....You are the one that will make the difference.

PLUR.   Ray Vonie.
bad spelling is my trademark.

commonly known as butterflies!

hi all:

we're preparing to put our RealAudio 3.0 server into full operation, and i
wanted to hear your thoughts on a simple question:

for 28.8 bps encoding, we've got a few options, but they all boil down to
the following: would you rather have (a) a mono codec with 5.5 kHz frequency
range, or (b) a stereo codec with 4.0 kHz frequency range?



also, for those of you who haven't heard, i have two RA 3.0 files on the
test server for you to try:

if you've got dual-channel isdn, point your realaudio player at :

pnm://mouth1.x-radio.com/x-radio/music/EQ2006/6.ra

and if you've only got a 28.* line, try:

pnm://mouth1.x-radio.com/x-radio/music/EQ2006/8.ra

both the tracks are from an Eye-Q release graciously supplied by Rich Sihiling 
( mailto:rich@eye-q.com ), so thank him if you can!

let me know how it sounds, i'm dying to hear the DC-ISDN myself!

References: <199612071739.JAA22777@netcom6.netcom.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Niels P. Mayer wrote:

> it's becoming just like the mid-70's prog-rock
> scene again -- boring! I think it's high time for a punk rock attitude
> to reenergize the somnolescence of the rave scene...

Punk is even more moribund than rave right now, as a culture.  Doesn't
mean there aren't spots of genuine fun and coolness in both, just that
the "culture" has become codified, with lots of glossy magazines ready
to show you what a raver looks like if you're not sure, and about 10,000
derivative clone tracks for every genuinely innovative, booty-shakin',
foot-stompin', bouncing-off-the-walls track.

I see the problem as "Now that everyone has agreed to be nice to each
other, what's the next step?"  To me, this was the _big_ revelation of
the rave scene -- a bunch of total strangers being nice to each other
instead of projecting heavy 'tude.  And for the person who first
discovers it, it is a revelation indeed, and I don't want to trivialize
anyone's first encounters with it, or the fact that it is a wonderful
thing.

However!

All that this radical niceness does is _allow_ something to happen.  To
me, it almost feels like we're on this huge mothership, engines warm,
and it's still sitting on the ground because everyone's still so excited
about finding it, and after a while we start thinking that it's just a
big dance space.

This potential energy could go in any number of directions.  There's the
full-on Dionysian sex-mosh of Crash Worship (well, CW two years ago),
the extended-play art madness of Burning Man, the street
takeover-festivals of everything from Critical Mass rides to SRL shows
to Earth First! lockdowns -- add your own to the list, please.

Just some thoughts.

// grigsbeast

Message-Id: <v02130500aed146d72d2b@[207.33.94.74]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
X-mailer: Eudora Pro 2.1.3
Date: Sun, 8 Dec 1996 21:06:31 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: bri@value.net (Brian Denny)
Subject: i go to raves, dammit!
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

ok, folks. just had to jump in to this one.

i'm getting really pissed off at some of the "older" ravers who keep
bemoaning that there just aren't "raves" anymore, 'least not like there
used to be...

especially when these same ravers don't go out to parties anymore.

y'know what? when you leave a scene (or a mailing list) because that scene
just isn't good enough for you, you are (1) sure not helping the scene any,
and (2) being just a little bit holier-than-thou, don't you think?

i really honestly believe that it's backwards to say "i'm not going to this
party because it's just not up to my standards"  -- 'cuz you know what?

_your external reality is a mirror of your internal reality_.

in "raver lingo": Create Your Own Vibe.

what i'm trying to say here is this: if you believe and expect that a party
isn't going to do it for you, guess what? it's not. not only will you not
have a good time, but you'll bring others down, actually affecting the real
vibe of the party. on the other hand, if you go with a good attitude, you
will most likely have a good time-- and if enough good attitudes show up at
the party, the vibe _will_ be rich. i've seen it happen.

and for goodness sake, anyone who has posted negative material on sfraves
has no business complaining about the negativity on the list. your
negativity may be a mirror of the list's, but you'd better believe the
converse is true too.

so if you want to believe that raves don't exist anymore, go right ahead
and believe it. just don't show up at my party if you're not fully ready to
have a good time. and don't subject me to this belittling crap.

i've only been raving for 4 months, so what the hell do i know, right?

i know that i have seen people transformed by what we call raves. i have
seen my life totally turned around. i have seen one of my closest friends
change from one of the most negative, unpersonable people i'd ever met into
a positive, loving human being. i've seen raving provide a much needed
support group for many friends with difficult issues. i've seen people
learning to discard their inhibitions and DANCE for the first time in their
life.

i've seen a hell of a lot in four months-- more beauty and positivity than
i'd seen my whole life before that.

if you belittle that, then you're putting the nails in the coffin of
whatever's left of that precious rave scene whose supposed death you're
mourning.

love to all, and respect to those who haven't utterly pissed me off--

brian


---------------------------------------------------------------------------

And in the end,
The Love you take
Is equal to the Love you make.

--The Beatles



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Dec  8 21:49:48 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id VAA04424; Sun, 8 Dec 1996 21:49:48 -0800 (PST)
Received: from boris.ucdavis.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with ESMTP id VAA04417; Sun, 8 Dec 1996 21:49:41 -0800 (PST)
Received: from localhost by boris.ucdavis.edu (8.8.3/UCD3.7.3)

Date: Sun, 8 Dec 1996 21:49:38 -0800 (PST)
From: Uncle Noah <napodaca@ucdavis.edu>
X-Sender: ez031733@boris.ucdavis.edu
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: whadda weekend
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.3.95.961208213706.13030C-100000@boris.ucdavis.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Well, after venturing to the city for a job interview Thursday and making
it to Davis with the help of my friends, I found myself wanting a party.
My buddie Joe was itchin' to dance and so was I and seeing as I don't get
to spend enough time with all you happy people, I wanted a good old
fashioned SF rave, ya know what I mean?  Anyway, as Saturday evening drew
upon me, I found that I had no way of getting to the city as every raver
in Davis was going to a house party in town (with the Davis DJ posse:
Hannibal Selecta, Jeyson, Jericho, Brian, etc.).  My personal vibe got
thrashed as I realized that I had let down my friend who really wanted to
go have fun in the city.  

So I ventured across town to the house party.  I found the greatest vibe!
Now, I have to say, the Davis house parties that I describe aren't the
bumbin' bass, get a chic go get laid kinda house parties that you'd
normally expect in a college town.  These parties attract the ravers and
extend into the morning with solid breakbeats and skillful DJs and folks
who seem to really buy into the whole PLUR thing.  Anyway, the party
started with a little group that consisted of a drummer, a guy with a
keyboard and a rad sampler and a very talented singer.  It was kind of
Portishead-like and a great start to the vibe.  Then the decks came out
and the wax started spinnin.

Of course, I loved Jeyson's set, but the highlight of the evening was
Hannibal Selecta's old skool techno set.  With the old skool revival
ripping through SoCal, I felt right at home.  The DJ of the evening award
has to go to Jericho, however, as he kept the folks jumpin' until damn
near 2.30am.  This boy has some real talent and it's amazing how similar
his musical tastes are to mine.  He's a great guy.  :)  Check out his show
on KDVS sometime!

Anyway, I know that I let down my buddy and that makes me feel really low,
but I did get to hear some great tunes and show him that there is an
active scene right under his nose that doesn't require much more than some
shoes that are good for walkin' in.  :)  

So the trip north was good.  The interview went well, I danced and I got
home in one piece.  Can't ask for much more!

PLUR!!

ps:  I'm not leaving the list :) *HUGS TO EVERYONE*

     dBP dBP dBBBBb  dBBBP  dBP    dBBBP
                dBP

      "Uncle" Noah Apodaca - UCDavis Graduate, DJ, Electronic Musician

[ to sfraves list ]

Health Report:
 Starting Friday , I got progressively sicker at work, and finally left
30 minutes early due to a strange weakness. I've been sick with some
sort of intestinal thing from Friday evening until tonight , Sunday
evening. Slight nausea, fever, and an ache in my guts in the area 
between my ribcage and my navel after I ate anything. My wife Mary
took very good care of me, and I got a lot of sleep. Feel much better
now ( - actually, I knew I was going to be better tonight when I woke 
up at 5PM and thought it would be nice to have a medium-rare rib eye
steak, nice and warm from the grill, with me grinding into it bare-handed
like some velociraptor ...)

 Anyways, I haven't read my SFRaves email since Friday afternoon -
sheesh! Too much to reply to individually or in detail. Here's
some short takes -

RE: SFRaves Stuff Recently
 I said this to Randy when I saw him at ASCENDENCE - SFRaves can be like a
family reunion get-together. Two of the uncles start arguing about some
damn thing or another ("Clinton's nuthin' but a goddamed fornicator
draft dodger!""Well, your Perot's a nutcase with too much money who 
wants to be an American Hitler!") , and the rest of the family just 
moves off and has conversations of their own until the temperature of
the argumentation lowers.  

Punk Rock Comparision
 Something I remember from the early days - I think The Dammed and some
other punk band was touring in England with some other more established
( pre-punk ) bands , in the time period just after The Sex Pistols first
album had been released. One thing a remember from the article was how
much condesending attitude the punkers got from their "elder" tour mates.
Of course, the journalist who wrote the story was definitly on the side
of the punkers, so what the other side of the story was, who knows?

I'd like to say something about this subject, but I think it deserves
more work than I feel like putting into a post just now, before I go
to sleep:
 Advice/Condescension/Nostalgia - From Oldsters To Youngers

 Bye! 

 Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

[ to sfraves ]

 Since I'm not feeling too energetic, I'll just use Randy's reveiew of
ASCENDENCE instead of writing my own - 

>  Ascendance was really fun! Pallokaville is a nice dancehall with wood 
> floors. Sound seemed pretty good (for a shoebox ;). There is an 
> alternative refreshment bar there (smothies and such) in addition to a 
> regular bar. My fav part though was NO SMOKING!!!! I hate tobacco smoke 
> and inhale way too much at raves in general... This place has great 
> ventilation and it never got too muggy.

 This is a nice venue. And I was wondering what was missing from my
hair when I got home - the smell of tobacco smoke ( just fog machine
juice )

>  The music was really nice. Ther openers were the promoters (?) or maybe 
> just one and a friend; Joe was playing some really nice trance (almost 
> psi-trance) but the other person was playing something like a  
> house/hip-hop/trip hop thang. Not so much to my tastes but okay if you 
> like that stuff.

 I liked their set(s) a lot! I've been over-Goa'd lately, and something
more funky was certainly called for! 

 Just before Greg's set, the last tune they spun was that Los Kings Del 
Mambo's song ( which proper title I can't remember just now ) with the
"I'm so in lovelovelove with you girl" chorus. It was so good to here
this! A real nostalgic shot - this tune was popular when I first got into
raving back in 1992 , and always brings back memories of Bonny Doone
beach and the One Step Beyond club in San Jose.
 
>  Greg Sandler came on next and played his usual eclectic set; 
> housey-trance, hard house and a tiny bit of acid and acid house. Very 
> tasty and fun to dance to. 

ditto!

> Astral Matrix was at bat last and played some 
> really good trance and psi-trance. My ride wanted to leave a litle early 
> so I had to go. :( It was all good as I had to study.

 After the trance set he did some drum & bass! That was good to hear & dance
to . The closing music was good too -
 
>  The decorations were simple yet very nice. The crowd was really friendly 
> with a notable lack of hard looks from the usual hard look crowd.

 Seemed like the "Santa Cruz" type of crowd - mixed and friendly/tolerant.
 
>  I'm looking foward to more Ascendance and recomend it highly to the 
> Santa Cruz crowd!!
> 
 .. and folks like me from "the valley" as well , I hope!

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com
