> From: Brian Denny <bri@value.net>
> To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
> Subject: i go to raves, dammit!
> Date: Sunday, December 08, 1996 9:06 PM
> 
> ok, folks. just had to jump in to this one.
> 
> i'm getting really pissed off at some of the "older" ravers who keep
> bemoaning that there just aren't "raves" anymore, 'least not like there
> used to be...
> 

I'm sorry that your getting pissed off but in my opinion this is true, but this
is just my opinion.  Some people said this back in 92 (that there were no
longer any raves).  I know it may hurt but I will still stand by the statement,
you need more than just an illegal party in a wearhouse to call it a full on rave.
Occasionally a party comes up that fits the bill, some of Ethan's FnF parties definitely
do. But much of the action that happens right now falls far short.


> especially when these same ravers don't go out to parties anymore.
> 

Well I don't go out to parties 3 times a week like I used to (the vibe just isn't there)
But I still might go out more often then you :) Just because you don't see me at the
parties that you go to doesn't mean I don't go out. I prefer smaller undergrounds these days
most of which are not on this list.


> y'know what? when you leave a scene (or a mailing list) because that scene
> just isn't good enough for you, you are (1) sure not helping the scene any,
> and (2) being just a little bit holier-than-thou, don't you think?
> 
> i really honestly believe that it's backwards to say "i'm not going to this
> party because it's just not up to my standards"  -- 'cuz you know what?
> 
> _your external reality is a mirror of your internal reality_.
> 

Hmm I can't agree with this, people make choices of where they party, get educated,
buy their food, eat out all on standards.  Some people don't go out because the
parties and people that they used to meet were so amazing and the Scene now just doesn't have those
types of opertunities anymore (or at least not as consistantly)


> in "raver lingo": Create Your Own Vibe.
> 
Some folks are trying, they are throwing their own parties or becoming DJs.
When you learn to DJ it's great cuz you have the capability to ignite the vibe in foreign places.

I myself am looking forward to going to Brazil sometime next year, to help 
a brazilian brother who used to live here get things started, I think Brazilian culture with is
earthy sensuality and love of music and dance is prime to be the next spot for Rave culture to explode.


> what i'm trying to say here is this: if you believe and expect that a party
> isn't going to do it for you, guess what? it's not. not only will you not
> have a good time, but you'll bring others down, actually affecting the real
> vibe of the party. on the other hand, if you go with a good attitude, you
> will most likely have a good time-- and if enough good attitudes show up at
> the party, the vibe _will_ be rich. i've seen it happen.
> 

This is very true, but you do need a critical mass of people who can consistantly
generate the Vibe to realyy make this happen else the only thing that happens is the
Vibe Generators just get burned out.


> and for goodness sake, anyone who has posted negative material on sfraves
> has no business complaining about the negativity on the list. your
> negativity may be a mirror of the list's, but you'd better believe the
> converse is true too.
> 

Negativity comes in many forms on this lists not nust in "negative" posts.
Besides sometimes the self-righteousness gets so high that a few short fused
people feel that the list needs some shock treatments.


> so if you want to believe that raves don't exist anymore, go right ahead
> and believe it. just don't show up at my party if you're not fully ready to
> have a good time. and don't subject me to this belittling crap.
> 

I'm sorry you feel this way but I'm entitled to my opinion as well.
Therer aren't any be-ins or love-ins any more either.



> i've only been raving for 4 months, so what the hell do i know, right?
> 
> i know that i have seen people transformed by what we call raves. i have
> seen my life totally turned around. i have seen one of my closest friends
> change from one of the most negative, unpersonable people i'd ever met into
> a positive, loving human being. i've seen raving provide a much needed
> support group for many friends with difficult issues. i've seen people
> learning to discard their inhibitions and DANCE for the first time in their
> life.
> 
> i've seen a hell of a lot in four months-- more beauty and positivity than
> i'd seen my whole life before that.
> 

No one is belittling those experiences, and no one is saying that Transformation is no
longer available on the dance floor, I've been to massives and seen it with my own eyes as well.

But things are different, the Police are different, the party goes are different, they have moved from
co-conspiritors to spectators and consumers.  

> if you belittle that, then you're putting the nails in the coffin of
> whatever's left of that precious rave scene whose supposed death you're
> mourning.
> 

She changes everthing she touches,
Everything she touches changes


> love to all, and respect to those who haven't utterly pissed me off--
> 
> brian

Brian
the people who piss you off deerve your respect even more,
some times a little respect for your supossed ennemies goes a long way.

Eventhough I never liked and sometimes feared the cops, I gave them props
and proper respect and they very often would let our parties continue, Galen and
the Sun Set Crew are prime examples of what a little respect can do.

> Anyway, I know that I let down my buddy and that makes me feel really low,

anyways?  ;)  It started a little slow, but before I knew what hit me, I 
stepped back for a minute, and realized that the vibe in that place was so

even got to spin (albeit, for only a few tunes)!  (btw, nice choices!) So

from Dave Barry Calendar, 3/30/93

You know how, during the Preflight Safety Demonstration, flight
attendants
tell you that in the event of an emergency, oxygen masks will pop out of
the
ceiling?  My question is:  _Who_wants_oxygen_?  If I'm going to be in an
emergency seven miles up, I want _nitrous_oxide_, followed immediately
by
Emergency Intravenous Beverage Cart Service, so that I and my fellow
passengers can be as relaxed as possible.  ("Wow!  Those are some
beautiful
engine flames!")

On Sat, 7 Dec 1996, Ciaran OHara wrote:

>      
>      What is the differece between a clubber and a raver ? 
>      
>      As far as i can make out a rave seems to entail having my eardrums 
>      battered into submission by Goa trance for 10 hours and if this is the 
>      case I don't want it. I'm sure there are renegades going on that cater 
>      for more than the one type of music, but where ?

--	

...and digressing,

	This is just a thought, but have you thought about wearing ear plugs?
I always have two (one to use, and one to share :) ) clean sets in an empty 
film cannister in my rave-survival backpack (which elicits many stupid 
comments from bouncers, e.g. "Why do you go to raves/clubs to wear 
earplugs?", etc.).  This is not as lame as it sounds. The music volume 
at raves (especially by the speakers; my usual hangout) is literally deafening.
I am all for that 
sitting-with-your-back-against-the-sub-woofer-getting-your-world-rocked-by-the
-bass-while-dropping-a-pill experience, but there is such a thing as 
common sense. I have found that one (or dare to be safe and use both 
according to manufacturer's specs--I recommend the squishy yellow ones) plug 
half-in in one ear is enough to eliminate that shrill next-day-dog-whistle-
noise many of us have known. Besides, the music is loud enough that 
you _will_ hear/feel it through the plugs.  You can always take them out 
at any time (it helps to take them out during conversations--as well 
as your pacifier).

*Hugs*
MellowDrama


Post Scriptum:	I usually don't need my ear plugs when peaking, but have 
found them indispensable when raving sober.  Has anyone else noticed the 
difference concerning their ear sensitivity before and after a pill?

>      throwing a Goa party PLEASE PLEASE have an ambient room. People need a 
>      place to chill/retreat.

> Do 'em all.  You ain't no damn
>raver unless:
>- You spend $35 to get into the party of the century
>- You are excited about going to a party
>- You dance your ass off and can hardly walk the next day
>- (optional) You take soooo many drugs that your eyes are like slot
>machines in vegas
>- You catch the blue buddah, or at least see it.
>- You make tons of friends, some for years on end
>- You get to know who does what party
>- You get to know the DJ's
>- You get on the guest list (at least once) <- this is highly optional, but
>you gotta at least try.
>- You become an experienced raver who despises the term because you are now
>a partygoer. ;)  **I perfer the term scenester***

a party free that you don't even know who's throwing it...***

On Mon, 2 Dec 1996 Jondabomb@aol.com wrote:

> Ok, I figured I was going to the Capital of Rave city...(whatever that is) I
> thought i was going to check out some sick party in the Warehouse
> district(wherever that is), i thought this is going to be a trip of a
> lifetime!!!!=) I went completley clueless, i didn't know anything about
> anything, so I figured I would just figure shit out as I went along. 
> 
--	Bad idea.  For anyone going to London to party for the first 
time, I suggest buying a copy of the weekly Time-Out at the first newstand 
(in London) you see.  And for your second purchase, make it a pocket 
sized color A-Z street index, also at the same newstand ;) .  For some 
reason (I still haven't figured this one out yet) almost all happenings, 
wether club/rave/party, are listed in Time-Out.  I don't think raves are as
frowned upon by the local authorities there as at home.  Of course, 
depending on press time and other stuff, flyers in record stores never 
hurt.  


>        The second day i was there, I found a piece of paper that said
> Ministry of Sound...Bingo! Except the date was 9/12/96 a little to late....

--	Thank God you didn't end up there.  The Ministry is basically a 
Palladium (I assume all SF'ans have somehow ended up there once in their 
lives) for rich Chelsea teeny-boppers.  The first and last time I was 
there, feather boas/bare midrifs/and halter-tops seemed to be the rage 
(it was supposed to be a smashing party as well.  It was put on by Puschka, 
and had some wannabe drag queens--Okay, i'm a bit judgemental there, but 
San Francisco has elevated drag into an art form--so I figured I couldn't 
lose...wrong.  
^	From what I remember, The Fridge (Brixton tube) offers two 
rotating Goa nights.  One was called Return to Samsara and the other had 
some similar name.  I believe one was a monthly and the other was weekly 
(or I could be completely wrong and they rotate every two weeks).  I was 
at the gala RFSamsara and wasn't too impressed.  Be sure to 
check the listings, 'cause you might end up at hip-hop night in this venue.
A cool place is Plastic People right on Oxford street (Tottenham 
Court Road tube).  It is a really small intimate club with good music 
that is super cheap (about 3 quid I think).  I really liked the vibe at 
club DTPM on Sundays.  It is a predominantly gay club, but there are 
cool ravers there as well _and_ the DJ's can _spin_.  I haven't had a 
silly grin like that on my face for a long time.  Besides, you won't find 
anything that comparable on a Sunday; all the Night-owls converge there.  
On the way there or home, don't miss out on the bus shelter that pumps 
excellent-- get this--techno 24 hrs a day.  Another good intimate club is 
the Gardening Club @ covent Garden (next to the RockGarden restaurant).  
That's were I had my first intro. to London Garage (I still don't know 
what it is--house/jungle?) in a Catacomb-esque venue.  It's somewhat hit 
and miss though, due to its variety.  I still have to find that 
ever-famous rave-in-a-hanger-at-Heathrow-airport party that keeps being 
mentioned to me. This is all I could think of at the moment (and probably 
angering the purists of SFRaves, but if Jonathan had some information 
before he left....), I hope someone can get some use out of this bandwith.

released in the UK (like Suede or certain Moby releases), so if you get it 
there, it wuold save you money from dealing with import prices--if you can 
find a source for that specific CD in the states of course.

Goa trance is very similar to any other kind of rave dance music... 4/4,
a speedy beat, ect.

I think what makes a track "goa" is a particular texture of the synths
used, and how they are layered.  Goa trance usually has several layers
of synthesizer sounds, including a several high speed, high pitched 
bleeping patterns that have a tendency to resonate inside of your head
and may serve to induce a trance state faster.  These blippy patterns
often sounds like "pure energy" being pumped into my head from the speakers.

All music blurs in and out of different styles these days, so it is unlikey
you would hear traditional, pure goa trance at a party.  It will probably
be mixed in with techno and other types of traditional trance music.

Personally, I am desperately awaiting the Goa/Jungle fusion!

-troy

> I was going to, (FAMILY, fresh produce, insomniac, Insight, Equal) ...
> 
> Is "goa trance" the music that has no beat at all, just weird things
> bleeping in and out... just pretty much random noises?  Or is it the 4/4
> acid trance.. kinda hard, maybe 140 bpm.. heavy analog use..?
> or something else altogether?
> 
> disclaimer:  I'm not trying to start a lengthy flame war that devides us

Precedence: bulk

>  This is just a thought, but have you thought about wearing ear
>  plugs?

Earplugs are an outstanding idea. I am surprised more people don't 
use them. What will kill your hearing the fastest is the 
treble/higher pitched sounds. Big bass isn't that detrimental to 
hearing.

> I always have two (one to use, and one to share :) ) clean sets in
...
> a thing as common sense. I have found that one (or dare to be safe
> and use both according to manufacturer's specs--I recommend the
...
> through the plugs.  You can always take them out at any time (it
> helps to take them out during conversations--as well as your
> pacifier).

The squishy yellow earplugs are pretty good. They are sufficient for 
most parties/clubs I have been. It is better to get 
fitted ones that have multiple gaps in them - they fit better and 
they provide much better ear protection, but I haven't seen those 
readily available in the civilian world. Maybe from doctor ?
 
> Post Scriptum:	I usually don't need my ear plugs when peaking, but
> have found them indispensable when raving sober.  Has anyone else
> noticed the difference concerning their ear sensitivity before and
> after a pill? 

Can't say much on how you perceive sound on drugs, as I don't use them, but using any sort of drug 
won't reduce your ear's physical sensitivity to the sound waves blasting the ear drum. 

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Dec  9 11:22:45 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id LAA19664; Mon, 9 Dec 1996 11:22:45 -0800 (PST)
Received: from guilder.ucdavis.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with ESMTP id LAA19648; Mon, 9 Dec 1996 11:22:40 -0800 (PST)
Received: from smtp.ucdavis.edu by guilder.ucdavis.edu (8.8.3/UCD3.8.1)
	id LAA27593; Mon, 9 Dec 1996 11:22:51 -0800 (PST)
Date: Mon, 9 Dec 1996 11:22:51 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <199612091922.LAA27593@guilder.ucdavis.edu>
X-Sender: szriffle@peseta.ucdavis.edu
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Pro Version 2.1.2
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: kclark@apsylog.com
From: Rick Riffle <rdriffle@ucdavis.edu>
Subject: Ear Plugs
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

There should be a FAQ file in the archives about earplugs if there isn't
already.  This topic comes around about every 6 months.

I got mine from my docotor.  Just went in for a hearing test and told him I
was a dj/musician and wanted to check and protect my hearing.  We did a test
and found I had minimal damage but still within the normal hearing range.
They took molds of my ears and gave me custom plugs.  My insurance covered
all of it.  They work great, and I've even used them while dj'ing when the
monitors and headphones had to be screaming loud to drown out the sound from
the main room.  They cut out the harmful sounds while letting the rest
through.  I was told many big time muscians use this particular brand on
stage.  They are called "Rock Star Sound Suppressors."  :) Dig that name.
But hey, they work.  Being that this music and these parties we call Rave
are of primary importance in most of our lives, I think it's really
important for everyone to consider ear safety.  What would you do if you
lost your hearing?

Rick 

ps. They are also really good for campout parties where you can't really get
away from the music, just pop them in and go to sleep.  Used them at BM as
well.  



At 10:49 AM 12/9/96 -0800, you wrote:
>>  This is just a thought, but have you thought about wearing ear
>>  plugs?
>
>Earplugs are an outstanding idea. I am surprised more people don't 
>use them. What will kill your hearing the fastest is the 
>treble/higher pitched sounds. Big bass isn't that detrimental to 
>hearing.
>
>> I always have two (one to use, and one to share :) ) clean sets in
>...
>> a thing as common sense. I have found that one (or dare to be safe
>> and use both according to manufacturer's specs--I recommend the
>...
>> through the plugs.  You can always take them out at any time (it
>> helps to take them out during conversations--as well as your
>> pacifier).
>
>The squishy yellow earplugs are pretty good. They are sufficient for 
>most parties/clubs I have been. It is better to get 
>fitted ones that have multiple gaps in them - they fit better and 
>they provide much better ear protection, but I haven't seen those 
>readily available in the civilian world. Maybe from doctor ?
> 
>> Post Scriptum:	I usually don't need my ear plugs when peaking, but
>> have found them indispensable when raving sober.  Has anyone else
>> noticed the difference concerning their ear sensitivity before and
>> after a pill? 
>
>Can't say much on how you perceive sound on drugs, as I don't use them, but
using any sort of drug 
>won't reduce your ear's physical sensitivity to the sound waves blasting
the ear drum. 
>
>

On October 4th, Charity Productions first party (Charity =) )
was held, to raise money for the LACY (Legal Advocates for 
Children & Youth) program and the Omar fund.  

A check for $2059(!) was presented to LACY.  Charity Productions 
recently received a thank you letter from Rochelle McNamara, the 
Executive Director of the Santa Clara County Bar Association 
Law Foundation!    

This "thank you" really goes out to all you Ravers out there
who showed up and supported Charity!  I have reproduced the
letter below, give yourselves a hand, you deserve it!!  Special
thanks to everyone who donated equipment and time, otherwise
it could never have happened!

Thanks again for all your support, and I hope to see you all
at a future event!

Smiles,
     Chin

-------------------------------------------------------------

On behalf of the Board of Directors, my sincere
appreciation for the generous donation to our Legal
Advocates for Children & Youth (LACY) program.

We are very honored to be the first charity to benefit
from your Rave fundraiser and wish you the best of luck
on your future events.  It is heartwarming, indeed, to see
a group of young people interested in helping the needy
in our community.

Please know that the money generated by your hard
work will be used to help children to lead happier and
healthier lives.

Best regards,

     Rochelle McNamara

Hello survivors of the SFR Exdious....

Well, well, well, a fine weekend was had.  And I have the bruises to
prove it.

Friday-  House party in Mountclare.   Yours truly spun at this lil
event, along with German Progressive acid house DJ Sahid and the Hostess
of the party, (She doesn't have a DJ name so I'll call her Special
Guest).  The  party in itself was intimate with a younger crowd (17 -
21yrs) but with a message was conveyed ,throwing down a fine blend of
European acid and trance.  Things went strong till about 12:30 - 1 ish.
I helped break down/ clean up, chilled for a bit and  drove off to one
of my secret hilltops to watch the sunrise....

Saturday :  Karma  Dropped by F-8 to see an exasperated Mars running
around issuing tickets... 
The dilemma of space was very prevalent here... On one hand (talking to
Thomas Trouble)  the promoter didn't want to oversell the venue ( Thomas
called  2 or 3 times telling us "ok, stop selling at 275" ,  "Stop
selling at 300 it won't hold anymore"  
And on the other coin, partygoers coming from Napa, San Jose, Valejo
(even two from South Carolina) that would get really bummed if we turned
them away because of no space...
Helping Mars, the mappoint soul'd out @ 11...
The sight of some fine SFPD crusers greeted us (us being Mystr-E, Mars,
and a few friends ) @ the venue @ 11:30 .  Everyone was pretty much
mulling around giving info about the other parties going on  ( A friends
and family in the SOMA and another party going on in the mission @ the
dance studio).  Thomas was trying to get everyone to skate and come back
in an hr or two and restart the party, but the fire marshals had other
plans...

@ about 12:15 everyone pretty much went their separate ways, a few
people to whom I discussed with told me that FnF were letting people in,
"by invite only"... 
Which is cool, 
                     I guess.  
Although I do know of the FnF crew I wasn't invited , so off to the
Mission....

Arrived @ the dance studio @ about 12:30 and hit the dance floor. Housey
mostly but some trance, jungle, and breakbeat tossed in for good
measure.  Danced only for two hours, until I re-strained my leg...  So
now it's restive for Mr. Crazy Dancer  ( I NEED to be better by NYE).
Chilled for about 1 1/2 @ the venue until the police showed up @ 4AM to
shoo away all us happy scenesters...  
Two busts in a night, Guess the KARMA was on the Yang side Saturday...

Too bad no Sunday parties happen cos that would round of the weekend to
a T.  Maybe someone has a garage some of us happy scenesters  can spin
out at in the AM while listening to some cool tunes (I'll provide the
cool tunes...)...

With the current damage done to Mr. Leg.  the possibility of raving
might be on  hold for the next few weeks...

---Adam



"Stay Connected..."

Just a note here.  I can assure that the party that you are referring to 
was not an FnF.  There were several people helping who do normally help 
with FnF but the party was a small party mostly organized by our friends 
Greg'n'Cindy and Tony.  In their promotion of the party they specifically 
told anyone invited that it was an invite only party and that the doors 
would close at 1am.  Thing s were going fine until unfortunately someone 
at the busted Karma told many people that they could use their tickets to 
get into tony/greg/cindy's get together.  We ended up having to be very 
strict at the door because of the influx of people, even turning away 
people who had been invited at some points because of the size of the 
space.  I was at the door part of the time and my feelings go out to 
anyone who was hoping to party that night but couldn't find somewhere to go!

love drenalin

Precedence: bulk

> The squishy yellow earplugs are pretty good. ...

	Short of the incredibly excellent but expensive earplugs that
you can get from Kath Peck & the H.E.A.R. foundation in SF, my favorite
type of earplugs are the silicone things that are designed mostly for
swimmers to keep water out of their ears. They provide about a 25 dB cut,
but you can adjust this for more or less cut by thinning or thickening
the silicone. You can also use them to make the opening of your ear smaller,
rather than completely blocking it.

casually suggested during a visit to Dave Q's house. Dave!!!

school before he met Tuve and to see how much he's become because of 
that love awes me. I could not keep my mouth from hanging open when he 
had told us he was going to propose to Tuve and showed me the ring. So 
many people special to me worked on this party and it became such a huge 
success despite "setbacks."

since the location they were supposed to use was raided on Thanksgiving.

men had no penii and we were seriously convinced the women had no

Subject: The State of Raves
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1

Precedence: bulk

Time for my .02c for all u2c on the state of raves.  
You really should read this for the better of the future of raves as we
know it.

I was clubbing in Chicago when the whereHOUSE scene was born.  The
housescene started in response to clubs becoming too expensive with
covers and too crowded with the suburbanites - the worst of ignorant
rank amateurs.

The dance crowd, a truly open mix of strait, white, latino, black,
didnt have the cash for covers or the tolerance for rank amateurs
flooding the floor. So they started the house scene. Chicago had empty
wherehouses everywhere so finding a FREE spot usually was no problem.
These non-public House parties kept out the rank amateurs, gave us room
to move, and were usually FREE. The vibe was positive - no bashing, no
bangin, and no suburbanites. I was drawn into the House in 1987 by the
Berlin Crew :). 

OK.  So, why are we "old-timers" dissin' the current scene?  The only
real shit I've heard and agree with is about the corporate raves - back
to paying $35 to get in?!!! And fucking waiting in line with 3,000
people? With fuckin wank meathead security!  Of course it sucks. Were
faced with what we left in the first place!

But my attitude is it's ever evolving.  I totally dig on how raving
really flipped positively when it returned from England - E took over
the snow monkey cocaine - and that's exactly what was needed - a new
more positive love child hyper drug - which probably made the dress &
scene evolve to its current state.  

I love todays raves - the technology, the visuals, the people, the
mostly positive vibe..........
(HEY GANGSTAs - try walkin through the projects at midnight, bangin
aint no shit to be you stupid fucks - wait till your faced with a
wacked trigger itchy twelve yr old packin a Glock - your baggies gonna
be filled faster than you can scream PLUR - death is final - you dont
need an agro attitude to be noticed or get respect - let go, be you, be
happy and live).

If any "old-timers" don't like the newer rave scene, just wait till
1999. Guaranteed there will be a corporate sponsored "free rave",
policed by a serious hardcore gang. Some gangstas gonna blow away a
raver front and centa'.  Happened in 69 at Altamont during the Stones
show (after their well documented corporate sell-out) courtesy of the
Hells Angels, to sadly end the Hippie 60s era. The way things are
going, MslutTV will throw a free rave, the corporates thinking they are
all hip with the hardside will get the Crips doin security, and Bang -
there it goes. :(

THATS WHY CORPORATE RAVES SUCK. Corporates are the death of raves. 
They are back to what we escaped (hi cost and rank amateurs*) and the
its leading towards the end. And thats why old-timers who really know,
can be legitimately bummed on the current scene.

Love what you have, and lets try and change the future.  Instead of
death and the end in 99, I hope someone gives birth front and center to
a future raver. And I hope to be right there, trancing my little mind
away.

= ~ o ~
see the stone float

seestone

* Rank amateur is based on ignorance and stupidity - not on how long
your in the scene.  Someone that is just a complete intruding idiot. 
ie. He can't handle his alcohol / drugs = he's a rank amateur.

Monday Night Dinner, (always at 8:30 pm) a different cuisine and location
 each week, yet somehow they all taste the same.  
 
 Dependably-bland dinner companions, gathering awkwardly each week to
 silently chew their cut-rate dinners (while expertly avoiding direct
 eye-contact with the Newbie on the other side of the table).  Surly wait staff
 always manage to surprise us with a new insult, and once again you can bet
 that certain person is going to be three dollars short on their bill!
 
 Everyone who reads this is welcome to come (I guess).   Be there or be
 talked about!
 
 Join our happy group tonight at:
  		Caffe Freddy's Eatery in North Beach
 
 Italian cuisine at 901 Columbus Avenue (at Lombard), San Francisco
 Telephone:(415) 922-0151
 
 Prices:   Inexpensive, entrees between $5-$9.  They spoke excitedly about how
 their veggie dishes could become vegan dinners, so vegans are safe to attend!
 This colorful North Beach retreat attracts a younger crowd, and is known for
 it's fine pizzettas, delicious pastas, and abundant portions.  Can you
 believe that they are also known for their sketchy service!
 
 Afterwards; we go mad at MAD, <<Bahia Cabana - 1600 Market @ Franklin>>
 Prizes too.
 
 DJs tonight:
 Krista
 Sho
 Joe Rice
 
RSVP for a place at the table to inanna@slip.net

       An old woman came into her doctor's office and confessed to an   
     embarrassing problem. "I fart all the time, Doctor Johnson, but 
     they're soundless, and they have no odor. In fact, since I've been   
     here, I've farted no less than twenty times. What can I do?"
     
       "Here's a prescription, Mrs.Harris. Take these pills three times a 
     day for seven days and come back and see me in a week."
     
       Next week an upset Mrs. Harris marched into Dr.Johnson's office.   
     "Doctor, I don't know what was in those pills, but the problem is
      worse! I'm farting just as much, but now they smell terrible! What do 
     you have to say for yourself?"
     
       "Calm down, Mrs.Harris," said the doctor soothingly. "Now that we've 
       fixed your sinuses, we'll work on your hearing."
     
     * * *
     
     Just trying to stay in that scatological/gastrointestinal groove...
     
     Peace,
     AndyW

Adding to what Troy said:

> I think what makes a track "goa" is a particular texture of the synths
> used, and how they are layered.  Goa trance usually has several layers
> of synthesizer sounds, including a several high speed, high pitched 
> bleeping patterns that have a tendency to resonate inside of your head
> and may serve to induce a trance state faster.  These blippy patterns
> often sounds like "pure energy" being pumped into my head from the speakers.

It seems to me that most of the Goa that I have uses square wave LFOs
and MIDI clocked tapped delays alot (which I totally love!). That's
what gives it that strobbing, pulsating, 1/16 note hipnotic effect. I
love the "pure energy" it gives you, and this pulsating is a big part
of that energy. I workout to Goa every morning.

> Personally, I am desperately awaiting the Goa/Jungle fusion!

YEA! DO IT!


=Darrel
darrele@netcom.com

Yes, MTV is getting in on the act. Camel (RJ Reynolds Tobacco) already is.
The corporate rave is not new. The idea has been alive and well in Europe
for years now. Rave is BIG BUSINESS. As soon as money and fame enters the
equation you kiss goodbye to your principles, unless you are very careful.
(Witness the political bullshit that already exists between promoters and
DJs.)

PREDICTIONS FOR 1997

More vibeless, money oriented parties.
Promoters who resemble your bank manager and insurance salesmen.
DJs who resemble Bon Jovi  -the DJ as rockstar. Can't wait for the videos.
Bad drugs in the scene, in higher quantities (remember the end of "hippy"?)
More kids getting fucked up on bad drugs, and not knowing why.
Hoards of clueless "ravers" who go 'cos it's trendy.
Bad attitudes.
Billboards advertising "raves"
TV commercials (we already have radio ads.)
DJs will get booked because of their image rather than their abilities
(this already happens to some extent.)
The music will get REALLY commercial and shitty and generic (it's getting
there already.)

If this is raving, then I quit.

Time to take the underground back. You have to create it YOURSELF.

RAVE IS DEAD, LONG LIVE THE UNDERGROUND.

        *****************************************************
        WAXING LYRICAL 'BOUT 1971...THE HANGOVER OF THE '60s.
        *****************************************************

Date: Mon, 9 Dec 1996 18:12:42 -0800 (PST)
From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: DIY/Rave/Punk/Grunge
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
cc: scarab@value.net
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9612091728.A6350-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



I saw a fascinating documentary this weekend that really echoes this 
discussion about punk/rave underground sensibility and death by corporate 
takeover.  "HYPE!" chronicles the birth and rise of the "grunge" music 
movement in Seattle - a type of music I had previously held in some 
disdain because of its inseparability, in my mind, of the music with MTV 
and big record labels and packaged teen culture commodity.

But the documentary took me to the beginning, before the product of 
"grunge" had been retooled and packaged to be sold to me.  It explored 
the feeling of Seattle back in the 80's, all the tiny clubs where anyone 
could get up and play for their friends, how so many people came together 
and found a positive, creative outlet that drew more and more 
converts.  It was about audience participation and forming your own 
labels, making your own music.  It showed how punk directly gave rise to grunge and how the entire movement 
formed a collectivity intent on DIY, self-expression and group experience.

But then Nirvana's single hit and the corporate vultures descended on the 
scene - the place overrun with media, copycat bands proliferating, one 
sound being identified as "grunge", even "grunge" fashion layouts in 
Vogue.  Because of its marketability to "alienated youth," this concept 
of "grunge" was seized upon and sold, and its repackaged form was 
baffling to most people in the true scene, even people in the film like 
Eddie Vedder, who has of course become a multi-millionaire off of it.

The commodification of the concept, of course, effectively ended the grunge 
underground.  The movie was really a sobering experience - but also 
educational.  It really showed me the difference between the genesis of 
something, something real, and the form in which it is sold to mainstream 
America by corporate America.  We all know that corporate raving doesn't 
resemble what a lot of us think of as raving - in fact, I think it almost 
bastardizes the word until "rave" has lost its real meaning.  Rave as a 
concept, a product, is obviously being sold - just not on the scale as 
"grunge" because (record companies and MTV being economically short-sighted 
here) its potential marketability has not been realized.  I think MTV, 
etc. still think this is a passing fad (at least, I sure hope so!).

"HYPE!" also reinforced my feelings that commodification and the real 
experience are mutually exclusive.  To get real, you have to go back to 
the people, not to corporatism, which acts to homogenize everything in 
hopes of selling it to as many consumers as possible.  It's the 
difference between the crap that is mainstream radio and the incredible 
music we hear in the underground.  It's like the instant something is 
taken over and refashioned as a product, it is cannibalized by its own 
bizarre hybrid and is destroyed.

<sigh>
We need to keep the underground as strong as possible.  Let's not give 
into the cynicism of the "real world", abandoning SFR and treating each 
other with the coldness of capitalist culture - let's rededicate 
ourselves to creating the scene we want!  Because it really is up to us - DIY - it 
must come from the hearts of the people.  Who else will create it if we 
won't?

Much Love,
Nancy

> The music volume at raves ... <snip>
> eliminate that shrill next-day-dog-whistle-
> noise many of us have known. Besides, the music is loud enough that 
> you _will_ hear/feel it through the plugs.

Usually, I don't post a "me, too" message, but when it comes to this
issue, I feel I need to say that I agree with you!  I *do* enjoy being
washed over with sound, but I don't need to go deaf doing so.  I've been
using cotton/earplugs at raves for about 3 years now, and I'm glad to
say that I can't tell any difference in my hearing range. 

Please, people! use SOMEthing in your ears.  You're going to need your
hearing when you're older.  (I felt like a parent there.. whew.. weird)
..  but on the real, take care of your ears.. there's *no* difference in
sound, and in fact, you can hear a broader range of sound when you do
use some protection in your ears.

Oh yeah, and I don't wanna hear any of that 'Oh, it's already too late,
my ears are fucked up and why bother now?" ... 'cause that's bullshit! 
Cells *DO* regrow, and if you're not fuckin' em up every weekend by not
using at least a ball of cotton (last time I checked they're about $0.01
apiece) you'll be doing yourself a favor.. 

ok.. 'nuff said.  I just care, that's all.
-- 
Steve Cooley

The heathen have come unto thine inheritance, thy holy temple have they 
defiled.  They have laid Jerusalem on heaps.  Their blood as they shed 
like water round Jerusalem...like, like, they fuck and they piss, and 
they shit like the fucking scum that they are.  Forgive me lord, that was 
not me, no, it was the spirit of Lucifer, forgive me lord, forgive me.  
How long lord, shall they be angry forever,  shall they jealously burn 
like fire, shall they keep on fucking, pissing, and shitting in each 
others faces?  Forgive me lord, that, that was not me. <- The Reverend 
Peter Shane, Crimes Of Passion

You got any last words?, Yeah, I got some last words...FUCK ALL 
YALL, Switch! <- The Nigga You Love To Hate, Ice Cube, Amerikkkas 
Most Wanted

I heard my brothers and sisters voices calling me across the plain.  I 
heard their cries of woe as I left the fold.  I thought I could turn my 
back and start anew, but that was not to be so.  For I had left for them 
an empty space.  A space that would be filled with anger, intolerance, 
and most of all ignorance.  I knew then what work my brothers and sisters 
wanted completed.  I knew then my job was NOT done.

I AM BACK!

As the Great Minister Louis Farrakhan said To some I am a dream come 
true, to others I am a nightmare!.  Indeed.

After much thought and deep contemplation, I have decided that SFRaves, 
like the rest of San Francisco, is at a critical juncture.  Will SFraves 
become like the rest of San Francisco, washed out, lilly white, bland, 
like the Fillmore, like the Haight has become, like theyre trying to do 
to the Mission, or the other side of Potrero Hill (hows that for code 
words).  Or will it, like the Phoenix rise to the DIVERSITY it once had.  
I think my going was premature, this list needs some color, less it 
become as sorry, and as bland as its namesake San Francisco.  Nope, this 
list needs some color, and an enema.  It needs people who have been here 
for more than a tepid 3 years raving or listing.  It needs people who 
know the movers and shakers.  It needs people who still know what rave 
WAS (since there arent any any more), and what underground still is 
(since there it still exists in small WORD OF MOUTH pockets), it needs 
people who have seen the blue buddah, and have wiped tears off thier 
faces because the energy and the music reached deep spiritual wells.  
This list, like SF needs people with a sense of history, its , for lack 
of a better word, rave elders, who helped build this house we now all 
live in.  It needs people who can live in several worlds at once, 
understanding the delicate balanace between them.  It needs people who 
are raising children, one of the REAL and most SIGNIFICANT contributions 
one could make to a society.  It needs teachers who can show the new 
people what IT really was so that they may know what IT really is to 
them.  I may not be all these things, but I am certainly most of them, 
along with the others here on this list who have, paid thier dues, and 
done thier time.  As well as others who have learned through doing.  And 
those who just enrolled.

It takes more than a TV interview to raise conciousness, it takes real, 
and dedicated people who understand the value of what this is, and its 
place in the larger society.  For how would many of you know what a 
corporate rave was unless it was for the old-skool who knew what it was 
like to live in danger by throwing an underground.  Nope, I cannot leave, 
to many dummies and know-nots still out there.  Too many unititiated who 
think rave is some religion, complete with slogans, and methodology.  To 
many people not practicing what they preach.  Too many hypocrites and 
rules-makers who come from the ranks of the unitiated.  These people MUST 
be saved.  If nothing else, they must be taught.  I dunno if Im the 
teacher, or necessarily the ONE to do it.  But with my other brothers and 
sisters, whose voices mixed with mine make a beautiful chorus, we will 
strive to help the ignorant, or at least attempt to inform them of a 
different truth, a different reality.

Some have said I am spoiling it for the newbies.  No I am not, you are 
with your intolerance, and sloganeering.  Rave is about expereinces, not 
about an ethos.  Rave is about dance and music.  Bonus round for making 
some pals for the long term.  Double bonus if youre on a REAL guest 
list, that is in a list of people who you call friends.  The other kind 
of guest list is a bonus too ;), but that one pales in comparison to 
being with friends, listening to tunes.  Or buying records with friends, 
or going out with friends, or hanging out with friends.

As for the name calling categorizers who say what people belong and dont 
belong at raves, lemme help you out:  Fuck All Yall!  Everyone, I said 
EVERYONE belongs at parties.  As long as you are there, and cause nobody 
pain, you belong.  As long as you can be there in peace, you belong.  As 
long as you dont jump on turntables you belong.  If you want to cross 
your arms, and have a furrowed brow, you belong.  Rave is about dancing 
and music, rave is not about passing some silly-ass PLUR litmus test.  
Like I have said, the best parties were the ones w/o slogans.  The ones 
promising to blow your fucking mind with music.  Anything more is just 
hype, anything less aint nothin but a tea party.  Check you own damn 
selves.  So if you wanna wear some Adidas and call your homies from 
Potrero Hill, the Mission, Oaktown, or anywhere else, you are welcome as 
long as you come in peace.  And that is the ONLY pre-requisite to having 
fun.  I should know, I had all KINDS of hometowns in my parties, and 
never had any trouble.  Check that!

One more lesson for ya, and you know who you are: 209 is blocked!  NAH, 
NAH, NAH NAH, NAH! ;) No more rolling back the clock.  Thank g-d for 
liberal judges.  Thank g-d for some good BLACK African-American liberal 
ones to boot.

Black, White, Yellow, Brown, all points in-between.  African, Asian, 
Caucasian, all the same.  All artificail, I know, but all REAL here in 
the US of KKK.  Until such time passes, I beleive were all in the same 
family.  Making such categorizations makes one a categorizer, or a 
racialist.  Passing judgement, cuasing harm, supremacy becuase of it 
makes you a RACIST.  There are plenty of those everywhere.  Next time you 
buy some gas at Texaco, remember those jellybeans.  And I was NOT the one 
who coined the phrase, or I should say the people who did sure as fuck 
didnt look like me, nor act like me.  Get the point?  Didnt think so.  
Oh well, a lost cause anyway for the blind ones, for the ones who refuse 
to see a dual reality, since they never have to live in one.  Open your 
reality, and your mind, maybe your ass will folow and you will learn how 
to dance to the rhythm of life.

In your face, that is how I am sometimes.  Often times I will continue to 
be silent so you wont have to wipe me off ;).

I remain ever vigilant in the face of adversity, and lack of diversity.

To my brothers and sisters whose voices I heard, I love you.

I am here to stay.  YOU dont like me?  LEAVE! 

C-Ya,

DJ Chief Boot Knocka

But you may know me as John S. Lee

P.S.  I love you old-skool, and some of you new skool too!  Shall we dance?

P.S.S.  Less I be branded a hypocrite like some of you, here is a code 
word list and the real meanings behind the phrases:
-like theyre trying to do to the Mission, or the other side of Potrero 
Hill 

theyre refers to the power structure.  Who is primarily the wealthy 
white land barons who run this land-filled peninsula.  Theyre also 
refers to the political engine and its big headed leader one Willie 
Brown.  BTW, I like Willie, but I KNOW who he really represents other 
than himself.

other refers to the black side of Potrero Hill.  One side of that hill 
is pristine and one of the OLDEST neighborhoods in SF.  It is also one of 
the most desireable with GREAT views of the city.  It is like South 
Africa over there.  The whites live on one side and have walking patrols 
(I was there when they started that crap), the blacks live on the other 
side (BTW this is OJs old neighborhood, remember him?  hes The butcher 
with the sharpest knife has the warmest heart Simpson.) primarily in 
low income housing and projects.  But fear not, gentrification has 
already started, theyve moved plenty of the others to other places in 
the bay area, and are ready to make Potrero Hill one big milk factory, 
despite the impending defeat of 209.  yay..one great bland city filled 
with money grubbing yuppies.

Are there any other questions?  

My pleasure.

Bye now.


I must say, I had a good time with this message.  And yes, I am really 
glad to be back!

I often get quite depressed about commercialism, submission to
institution, sheepishness, etc. At those times I repeat one of my
favorite mantras:

THERE WILL ALWAYS BE AN UNDERGROUND! 
THERE WILL ALWAYS BE AN UNDERGROUND! 
THERE WILL ALWAYS BE AN UNDERGROUND! 

Then I remember that there are so many truely wonderful, original,
creative, glowing people who know how to have real fun without anger
or hate toward others. And as many as those are, there are always more
just looking for a way to become like them.

And of course "raving" won't be around forever, but the results of it
will, and the people will, and there might be something even better
the evolves from it! THERE WILL ALWAYS BE AN UNDERGROUND!

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Dec  9 20:38:34 1996

Received: from [206.86.235.114] (lesliea.vip.best.com [206.86.235.114]) by shellx.best.com (8.8.4/8.8.3) with SMTP id UAA22244 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Mon, 9 Dec 1996 20:28:32 -0800 (PST)
Date: Mon, 9 Dec 1996 20:28:32 -0800 (PST)
X-Sender: lesliea@best.com (Unverified)
Message-Id: <v01530508aed0df97bfea@[206.86.235.114]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: lesliea@best.com (Leslie Ayres)
Subject: Hello Everyone
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Yes, I'm still here, and at this point, I'm not going anywhere.  SFRaves is
important to me, and so many of you are part of my life.  We have much to
learn from each other.

Because I took a stance in the recent inferno, I wanted to say a couple of
things that I believe to be true.  These are some of my fundamental
personal beliefs. Take them as you will...

1 ---------------------

The only thing you should expect to have in common with anyone on this list
is a love of raving ... but they may see raving entirely different than you
do.

Some people have been raving for many years, some have only been to one or
two parties ever, in fact there are people on this list who for whatever
reason (age, location) haven't been to a real party yet at all.  It's fresh
and new and eye-opening to some, and it's tired and redundant and burnt out
to others.

Some of us think it's only about the music, that it's just a party, and
some of us find a deeper meaning in raving that affects us and changes us
forever. Some of us pretty much have our heads in the clouds, some are
wisely realistic through observation and/or experience, some of us are
incorrigible  cynics and pessimists to the core.

Is there one right way to be a raver?  Obviously not.

There are many paths for many people, and each one is doing what they need
to do. So remember when you post that you are talking to 450 different
people, and don't be surprised when you hear a point of view that's totally
opposite of yours ... you might learn from listening to those points of
view, so it's always at least worth listening with an open mind.

2 ---------------------

The person you appear to be on the internet is probably very different from
who you really are.  It is critical -- if you want people to understand
your point of view -- that you word your messages as carefully as possibe.

Especially when you're talking about subjects that may trigger emotional
reactions (you'll usually know what those subjects are but sometimes
someone will come out of the blue with a reaction when you least expect
it).

Write and rewrite, edit and soften, try to read the words through the eye
of the reader who cannot see your face, hear the tone of your voice.  Work
hard to say what you need to say in a way that will be understood by the
people who read it, because if what you say just pisses them off, they'll
never be able to get your point.

3 ---------------------

Each one of us can truly make the world a better place, every day.  Whether
its on the internet, at the grocery, in your workplace or classroom, or
walking down the street, be someone who leaves positive change behind them
as you pass.

I'm not talking about shallow 'have a nice day' lip service, I'm talking
about making a real difference, even if its small.  Smiling directly at and
complimenting someone on the street, being gracious to others while
driving, simple politeness and manners are a great start.  Taking time to
help someone who needs help, to share what you have with someone else, to
give your time and effort to change something that needs changing.

If you act with an open heart and an open mind as your starting point, and
you make all of your encounters sincere and personal, you will be someone
who lifts the spirits and the hearts of others around you, and your
influence in the world will be felt.

4 ---------------------

The internet is not real life.  Use it to gain information, use it to make
connections with new people, use it for entertainment.  But be aware of how
your online behavior might be different if you actually personally knew the
person you are talking to.  Would you scream at them? Would you use
profanity and a nasty tone?  Would you call them names?  And would you do
it in front of 450 people?  No? Then don't do it, hiding behind the
anonymity of your computer.

Your rules of behavior online should be the same as the rules in real life.
Be polite, listen to other points of view (how else will you learn
something new?), avoid rudeness, don't embarrass people in front of others,
and if you don't like someone, you don't have to talk to them, just like
real life.

Show respect and consideration ... and remember that you have a right to
expect it to be shown to you in return as well.  We do not have to quietly
accept rudeness and personal attacks, but neither do we have to retailiate.
We can simply refuse to participate in that low level of communication.
It's your choice.

These are not "raver" rules, this is not new-age-speak "PLUR" -- these are
some basic guidelines for civilized behavior.  Of course you can disagree
with people, but do it in a respectful manner, and you'll usually get the
same in return.

5 ---------------------

People change.  For those of you who just started raving, or just fell in
love, or just started anything, cherish that excited feeling, but don't
forget that you will evolve and change and your feelings will change.
Better or worse, they will change.

Nothing stays the same, and we wouldn't like it if it did.

One of the biggest lessons I've learned in life is that it's important to
see when you're "over" something, and do something about it.  Don't let
your unhappiness fester, because it just makes everyone miserable, and
you're wasting precious time in your life being unhappy.

Everything we do in our life is a process, it goes up and it goes down and
it changes. When we learn what we need to from something, or when our
interest wanes, that's the time to move on to find something else that
sparks your passion again.

Whether it's your romance, your job, or raving, when you need a break, take
a break. When it's not fun any more, then move on.   If you're not happy
any more, figure out what's wrong, and take responsibility for bringing
that excitement back into your life with something new.  Change can bring
wonderful new experiences into our lives, so embrace it.

6 ---------------------

Don't live in the past, don't wait for the future.  This is now, and it's
all we have.  Make today count, because no matter what you did yesterday,
no matter what you're hoping for in the future, this moment is all you can
count on.



I am looking forward to seeing this list regain its momentum as a forum for
some of the most interesting and interested people around to discuss their
likes, dislikes, ideas, concerns and experiences.

Some of you feel shy to post (no wonder, really!) and some of you are such
lurky lurkers you don't even want people to know who you are (ah yes, but I
do, V!) -- but each one of you has something meaningful to contribute.

Share your ideas and thoughts, and try to make them from the heart and with
some substance.

For those who may find this post "preachy" ... oh well, after all, I am the
Fairy RaveMother.  Sometimes.

Much love and support,

Leslie

The evolution of the 'rave' scene has got me thinking a lot lately.  At
one point a few months back, I was talking to a friend who is a professor
at a local University.  He said another prof's son was doing documentary
research on the punk scene, so as to create a record of what the scene
really was and to try to lend academic validity to the experience of it.
I started thinking, hey a cool Master's program would be : Counter Culture
in America:  'Genreation X' and the Rave Scene.  Is anyone out there
thinking of/working on this kind of thing?  With all the talk about how
much the scene has changed, I bet in a few conversations you could get
enough sociological data to create a real sincere and kick-ass thesis.  
Or should we let the scene become documented only by Hard Copy
'investigations' and faded memories of an Altimont-like event with a
day-glow MTV hanging in the background?  I am starting to give this some
serious thought as a project, so if anyone else thinks it might be
interesting, let me know, okay??
PLUR
KEEP RAVING!
:)

********napodaca@ucdavis.edu**************************************************
      "Uncle" Noah Apodaca - UCDavis Graduate, DJ, Electronic Musician

>"The heathen have come unto thine inheritance, thy holy temple have they
>
>I must say, I had a good time with this message.  And yes, I am really
>glad to be back!

I liked your message... well put. I have come very close to leaving sfraves
a couple of times, either I get fed up or feel like I've outgrown it. But
then I realize that you can't just ignore a part of something you love. You
can refine your relationship with it, minimize that part or purify it, but
you can't really turn your back on it. Otherwise it will just keep tapping
you from behind, and start itching at and annoying you. I'm sure that some
day, maybe even soon, I will unsubscribe... but it will be because my life
will be so rich with other things that I lack the energy to make my
relationship with it worthwhile, not because I think it has turned into a
negative thing. cause the only real negativity is in me, and if I see it as
negative, it's the perfect place for me to try and start spreading the
positive, and help myself grow into something more than I already am.

But more to the point, welcome back. I'm glad to see your kick ass spunk
shake this list and help it to shine.

-john.

i will be unsubscribing presently in order to concentrate on personal
issues for a while...

those of you who have read my posts know that i am not leaving because of
anything that's happened on this list. i really believe in sfraves as an
online community, and will remain here in spirit during my absence.

constantly, and always love hearing from fellow ravers.

i shall return.

From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>

Precedence: bulk


is mail filtering. I use MH's slocal(1) which lets me add entries
like this to my ~/.maildelivery file.

##
## Annoying people from SFRaves
##
>From lesliea@best.com destroy A -
>From mdpkl@best.com destroy A -
>From lachim@uclink4.berkeley.edu destroy A -
>From meclay@ix.netcom.com destroy A -

If you're in the above list, please don't bother sending me private mail as
I will never see it. Your public postings will not reach me as well -- it's
all good. Also, feel free to add my address to your mailfilters -- I will
be happy to register a resounding thud as my ASCII hits the bitbucket. This
way we can customize our world-view to correspond to our tastes or
distates. And keep it up the good work, as I intend to expand this list in
the coming months, in the hopes of reducing the callouses off my 'd'
finger.

Rave on!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==
== When yer swimming in a creek and an eel bites yer cheek, that's a moray!==

From: ejordan@csulb.edu (Eric Jordan)
Subject: In Love and Light
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>From my humble beginnings as a techno-enthusiast, I later came to know a
wonderous realm of beautiful people and beautiful music that came together
in a fusion of love and dance. The music and the people created a mystical
atmosphere and a generation of energetic individuals with love in their
hearts and rhythm in their souls. Everything that encompassed this realm
became less of an escape and more of a way of life. For the earlier part of
my life, I had been living in something of a temporal present that gradually
unfolded itself into a romantic lifestyle of futuristic subsistence. This is
where I stand now. When I drive down the long freeways toward Los Angeles,
the expanse of intense road lights become the hazy glow of some dense
metropolis in a fanciful japanimation flick. When I stand outside on the
steps of a cafe, I smoke a cigarrette with the style of a hard-edged
day-dreamer straight out of some future landscape not yet realized. Im sure
some of you may feel the same way. I could be wrong. I know some of you feel
different. That's simply because its true. We are different. We are the
future. It it us that make up the embodiment of a premature generation of
loving individuals, slowly but constantly creating a utopia of love and
light in which music of the future unites us in a dreamscape that will
eventually become a reality. It begins with a positive attitude, which I
know you all carry with you. Sure, we get upset at times and have a negative
outlook on a lot of things, but we are humans. It is the foundation of our
minds that count, the love that swims through our consciousness. We are the
balanced people that the earth has been waiting for to come along and take
society under our wing for the sole purpose of letting love loose into the
heart of mankind. We have danced with each other, shared the same smiles,
gazed upon the beautiful things in nature, and done it all on our own. We
are a team of spiritual soldiers and love is our weapon. We inject love into
everything we come across and that is our power. I am proud to be a part of
you all, and I hope you all realize how special you all are. Don't let hard
times get the best of you, share your love with others and they will do the
same to you. Be safe, and take care my beautiful friends.

Love,
Eric Jordan [Future-Kid]
ejordan@csulb.edu

> care it can get tarnished all to heck!
> 
> Some people never give their soul a second thought. They ride roughshod
> over it for years and years, never paying it any mind. All the while their
> soul is
> becoming weak and worn, ugly, useless...

From: anarch@scruznet.com (Anarch)
Subject: Re: "Goa trance"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Troy Sheets <tsheets@xanadu.cyborganic.com> wrote:
>Goa trance is very similar to any other kind of rave dance music... 4/4,
>a speedy beat, ect.

One comment here, nothing to do with tsheets particularly...there ought to
be an established term in rave culture for a rhythm based around a steady
bass drum (or synthesized drum sound, yes) at one kick per beat, and "4/4"
is not it.  "Four on the floor" is pretty good, and generally means what I
think a lot of people want to mean when they say 4/4.  4/4 means only that
there are four beats for each periodic section of the music, which goes for
almost every piece of contemporary dance music that I've ever heard.  The
most fucked-up funky jungle break you've ever heard probably still has a
four-part measure, even if it doesn't have exactly four even bass thumps.

>[...]
>Personally, I am desperately awaiting the Goa/Jungle fusion!

I think there is some music like this...not really goa-jungle, maybe, but
goa sound with more prominent, complex drum tracks, breakbeat style.  I've
never heard much of it, mostly just flashes in larger sets.  There was some
stuff like that, a bit slower than your average goa, sometimes an
almost...uh, illbient?, atmosphero-jungle? (whatever...I can't even pretend
to be familiar with all the nuances of genre labels in the synthetic music
realm--but that's good, you know, all the uncertainty and variety indicates
a flourishing synthetic scene; when there's a particular couple of labels
that each mean something everyone knows, that's a constricted musical
world) feel (wow, what a complicated sentence), going on downstairs at the
Goa Gil birthday affair in Berkeley...anyone know who was responsible for
that?  I'd love to hear more.  I love goa, but my favorite techno style has
always been hard breakbeat, which I don't hear nearly enough of these days
(around here...things may be better elsewhere).  A fusion would be
wonderful...

As long as we're on the topic of goa varieties, does anyone have any
suggestions for some seriously aggro goa?  Actually, I don't know quite
what to call the music I'm thinking of, but it's definitely a goa
sound...the best example I know of is whatever was played for CCC at
Burning Man (this year) just as the alien invader was being immolated.
Anyone know what that was?  Evil goa?  Acid-core?  Whatever it was, I
haven't been able to get much more...I have one tape (Thee-O) that was
described as "dark goa," but though I like it a lot, it's not quite what
I'm thinking of.  Theta Blip, Dutch also approach what I mean, but that's
not quite it.

Isn't there a Goa list?  I haven't looked, but anyone interested ought to
check Hyperreal (http://hyperreal.com).

anarch@scruznet.com



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Dec 10 01:52:59 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id BAA12032; Tue, 10 Dec 1996 01:52:59 -0800 (PST)
Received: from scruz.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with ESMTP id BAA12008; Tue, 10 Dec 1996 01:52:53 -0800 (PST)

Message-Id: <v01530501aed2d36d1ff7@[165.227.109.23]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Tue, 10 Dec 1996 01:56:11 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: anarch@scruznet.com (Anarch)
Subject: Earplugs (was "Re: Clubbers, Ravers, Rockers, Sinners")
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Rob Rayle <robertr@autodesk.com> wrote:
>	Short of the incredibly excellent but expensive earplugs that
>you can get from Kath Peck & the H.E.A.R. foundation in SF, my favorite
>type of earplugs are the silicone things that are designed mostly for
>swimmers to keep water out of their ears.

I don't know if the kind I use are for swimmers, but I like silicone
plugs--they seem to have a flatter attenuation than the foam kinds, and
they're also usually not as strong.  But...they have one big problem: when
things get hot and humid and sweaty they don't adhere to my ear canals as
well as the foam kind.  Fine if you're using your plugs to inspect an
industrial worksite or somesuch, as I'm sure they were designed to do, but
problematic in a rave environment.  I still use them, but I try to bring
along a foam pair in case my jumping around happens to dislodge one of
those sweat-slick blobs...I find that the foam "Noise Husher" variety,
available in most drugstores, are excellent, although they really kill the
treble and they can make casual conversations difficult.

I suppose I should admit that I often give in around 4 am or so and ditch
the plugs...good hearing is wonderful, of course, in the long term, but I
just can't deny the joy of pure volume, RIGHT NOW.

anarch@scruznet.com

> Date: Tue, 10 Dec 1996 01:56:07 -0800

> 
> I think there is some music like this...not really goa-jungle, maybe, but
> goa sound with more prominent, complex drum tracks, breakbeat style.  I've

I'd imagine that a goa/jungle fusion would be pure noise. Frenetic
breakbeat drums with complex layered synthesizers? It might be too
much...space and air are nice. The nice thing about goa is the simple
kick pattern that allows the music to breathe. Vice versa with jungle.

But(!) it might be neat to experiment with. Anyone out there in SFR-land
who's writing jungle? I'll make trance, you'll make jungle, together
we'll make noise.

Steve

Subject: In defense of pop music!
In-Reply-To: <9611078499.AA849998135@CCMAIL.AIRTOUCH.COM>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.3.95.961210012748.17127G-100000@pluto>

Dear SFRavefriends,

My computer tells me that on Sat, 7 Dec 1996, Ciaran OHara shared (in
part):

>         Similarly, dance music grew out of a reaction to the stale musical 
> environment of the 1980's. When I look back on that decade I see much pomp and 
> preening but little real social commentry coming from the manufactured pop 
> groups of the period. Spandau Ballet, Kajagoogoo, Duran Duran, The Human league,
> ABC, Alphaville, and countless other lipstick and tea-towel wearing good looking
> boys from middle England may have looked good on Top of the Pops but said 
> nothing much to their audience about life in the real world. 

	Now I have to take severe exception to all this.  I'm well used to
people dissing "Europop" (aka New Wave) groups like Duran Duran and the
Pet Shop Boys.  Putting down these type groups seems to be for the '90s
what "disco sucks" was for the '80s, which I heard constantly during
junior high school.
	However I think the criticism is misplaced.  If some of them wore
lipstick, is that a crime?  If I was of a John S. Lee mindset, I'd call
it homophobia. Is looking good (as opposed to making oneself ugly, which
punk made an art form of) something to criticize?  Isn't this the same as
all the dumb blonde jokes -- assume that if someone's a babe (guy or
girl), they must be an airhead?
	The same school of thought that says "real men/women like rock 'n
roll" by way of dissing pop, also generally puts modern techno and house
into the same category of lightweight music.  Just look through a rockers'
magazine like BAM and see how much credit they give to techno artists or
any form of dance music, from ambient to jungle.
	Before there was techno-house, there were groups like Tears For
Fears, Dead Of Alive, Cyndi Lauper, and all kinds of great artists that
everybody puts down because they sold a lot of records, were too
androgynous, had big hair, used other instruments besides the guitar, saw
the value of a catchy beat and hook in their songs, etc.  I'll bet many of
the people on this list enjoyed this music.  I still do, and I'm not
ashamed to say it.  New Order, Blondie, Style Council, General Public,
Alison Moyet, Depeche Mode, Howard Jones, they're all good.   
	But the best way to judge these pop artists is to let their lyrics
speak for themselves.  Tell me these words are shallow, tell me these
words are not poetry, or say nothing about life in the "real world":

"All day, hiding from the sun
 Waiting for the golden one
 Waiting for your fame
 After the parade had gone
 Outside was a happy place
 Every face had a smile like a golden face
 For a second
 Your look was white as your fingers curled
 The shot that was heard around the world, for a second
 It took seconds of your time to take his life
 It took seconds"
		-Human League, "Seconds" (a song about the killing of JFK)

"When your world is full of strange arrangements
 And gravity won't pull you through
 You know you're missing out on something
 Well that something depends on you
 All I'm saying, it takes a lot to love you
 All I'm doing, you know it's true
 All I mean now is one thing, this one thing
 That turns this gray sky to blue
 That's the look of love"
				-ABC, "The Look Of Love"	

"We're miles away from nowhere
 And the wind doesn't have a name
 So call it what you want to call it
 Still blows down the lane
 People tell me I haven't changed at all
 But I don't feel the same
 And I bet you've had that feeling too
 You just can't laugh all the time
 And if the fires burn out there's only fire to blame
 No time for worry cause we're on the roam again
 The clouds all scatter and we ride the outside lane
 Not on your own so help me please hold back the rain"
				-Duran Duran, "Hold Back The Rain"

>         In my opinion, the only real group of substance to emerge from the 80's 
> were Manchester's The Smiths. This was in fact a group with real punk 
> sensibilities, albeit playing in a more pop idiom. I think Morrisey summed up 
> the whole 80's music scene succinctly in the song "Panic" : " Hang the DJ, Hang 
> the DJ, Hang the DJ, because the music that he constantly plays says nothing to 
> me about my life, hang the blessed the DJ".

	Yeah, the Smiths were great!  But I don't only like them because
their music had a little harder edge to it generally than the other bands
mentioned above.  Morrissey is simply a great poet, imho, and his singing
with Johnny Marr's composing made a terrific contrast.
	If you like the sentiments Morrissey expresses in "Panic," there's
another great song along similar lines called "I'd Rather Jack" by the
Reynolds Girls, which is more purely pop, and again imho, a no-apologies
string-em-up defense of the music, not to mention a fine dance track.
	
"All we wanna do is have a good time
 Then they went and took our house away
 No one ever asked for our opinion
 No, no we don't get a say
 AM, FM, all that jazz
 We'd rather sing along with Yazz 
 What happened to the radio?
 They never play the songs we know!
 Golden oldies, Rolling Stones, we don't want 'em back
 I'd rather jack than Fleetwood Mac
 I'd rather jack!
 No heavy metal rock-and-roll music from the past
 I'd rather jack, than Fleetwood Mac
 I'd rather jack! 
 Can't they see that every generation
 Has music for its own identity?
 Why the DJ on the radio station is always more than twice the age of me?
 Who needs Pink Floyd, Dire Straits?
 That old music's out of date
 Demograpic stereo,
 They never play the songs we know..." (etc.)

	Now personally, I like Pink Floyd and Dire Straits too, so please
don't jump all over me about that!  I didn't write the lyrics, I just
thing they sound good.
	I just couldn't let somebody get away with saying '80s music is
shallow.  The '80s get dissed way too much as a decade already.  I'm not
buying into all that media crap about the "decade of greed."  That came
out of the frustration the left felt at having 12 years of Republican
Presidents Reagan and Bush, not out of any solid statistics about people
being greedier or anything.
	But I digress.  The point I basically wanted to make is not only
did the artists have style, but their music had substance as well.

Much love,
				<<< Starchild >>>

"All I wanna do, is make you listen from now on"  -Lightning Seeds   ;)

[ to sfraves ]
Recently, Neils Mayer gave his alternative to unsubscribing -
> is mail filtering. I use MH's slocal(1) which lets me add entries
> like this to my ~/.maildelivery file.
> 
> ##
> ## Annoying people from SFRaves
> ##
> >From *@*.com destroy A -
>.... 
> This way we can customize our world-view to correspond to our tastes or
> distates. And keep it up the good work, as I intend to expand this list in
> the coming months, in the hopes of reducing the callouses off my 'd'
> finger.

 I've never used a "kill" file or filtering yet, because I've yet to
find a person I've gotten email from via SFraves that consistently
pisses me off with every post. Even the worst ones < and my list of those
folks will remain private for now > post something cool every once and awhile.
And my 'd'elete finger isn't sore yet...( I am using it more , tho ).

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

PS - I wonder what would happen if you did use "*@*.com" in a mail filter?
 Probably end up with a lot of sophomoric stuff from *.edu sites... < duck! >

--- On Tue, 10 Dec 1996 01:56:11 -0800  Anarch <anarch@scruznet.com> wrote:
>Rob Rayle <robertr@autodesk.com> wrote:
>>	Short of the incredibly excellent but expensive earplugs that
>>you can get from Kath Peck & the H.E.A.R. foundation in SF, my favorite
>>type of earplugs are the silicone things that are designed mostly for
>>swimmers to keep water out of their ears.
>
>I don't know if the kind I use are for swimmers, but I like silicone
>plugs--they seem to have a flatter attenuation than the foam kinds, and
>they're also usually not as strong.  But...they have one big problem: when
>things get hot and humid and sweaty they don't adhere to my ear canals as
>well as the foam kind.  Fine if you're using your plugs to inspect an
>industrial worksite or somesuch, as I'm sure they were designed to do, but
>problematic in a rave environment.  I still use them, but I try to bring
>along a foam pair in case my jumping around happens to dislodge one of
>those sweat-slick blobs...I find that the foam "Noise Husher" variety,
>available in most drugstores, are excellent, although they really kill the
>treble and they can make casual conversations difficult.
...
>anarch@scruznet.com

The only plugs I'll use are the North Sonic-II earplugs. They are available at any good 
music store. They run about $15 (worth it) and they have metal filter elements in a 
soft rubber fitting. The elements are removable for cleaning of the fitting, which 
inserts in your ear. Their basic function is to rollof the mid-highs and highs, such 
that you can still hear, but not at dangerous levels. Check 'em out if you are looking 
for a single pair to last a lifetime (or until u lose 'em). ;) What's really nice about 
these is that you can actually make out conversation better with them in (I guess that 
voice is more low-mid and doesn't get filtered as much by the plugs). I've also never 
experienced any difficulties with them jumping out of my ears! :D

matter

it. I think it's a buncha bullshit, myself." - James Douglas Morrison

With all this talk about Goa, I feel compelled to mention the Dragonfly 
label. If you're not familiar w/ the Order Odonata CD's, get familiar w/ 
them. Particularly the Experiments that Identify Change ('96, white 
cover). The newest one, Technical Use of Sound in Magik, is pretty bomb 
too.

Of course, there are a lot of other cool labels out there too (Blue Room, 
TIP Records, etc). Get yer butts out to Frequency 8 (this is not an 
ad) for some good recommendations.

						Hugs :)
							Dave

In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.3.95.961209221803.2062C-100000@boris.ucdavis.edu>

On Mon, 9 Dec 1996, Uncle Noah wrote:

> Or should we let the scene become documented only by Hard Copy
> 'investigations' and faded memories of an Altimont-like event with a
> day-glow MTV hanging in the background?  I am starting to give this some
> serious thought as a project, so if anyone else thinks it might be
> interesting, let me know, okay??

Hm, it really depends on the angle you are going to take.  Formalizing and
quantifying the "rave experience" will probably produce something on the
order of PLUR -- which, besides being way, way off the mark, would
probably *not* be good thesis material ;)

However, recently on PBS there was a multipart documentary on several
different kinds of music and their associated cultures.  Each part
consisted of a two hour segmented cusing on a particular genre.  I was
only able to see the piece that traced the origins of rap and dance music,
and it was *excellent*.

Unfortunately, I don't remember the name -- has anyone else seen it?  It
was incredibly thorough, well thought-out, obviously well researched, and
included interviews with people like Derrick May an De La Soul.

Noah, if you're serious about pursuing this, I would highly recommend this
documentary as a starting point.

	Sami

Subject: Earplugs
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
