[ to sfraves ]
Recently, matter <arduous@mcs.netmentioned a good pai of earplugs:

> The only plugs I'll use are the North Sonic-II earplugs. They are 
> available at any good music store. They run about $15 (worth it) 
> and they have metal filter elements in a soft rubber fitting. The 
> elements are removable for cleaning of the fitting, which inserts 
> in your ear.
 
 I've owned a pair for over 15 years, and the rubber fittings are still
soft and resiliant. I do keep them in their container.

> Their basic function is to rollof the mid-highs and highs, such that 
> you can still hear, but not at dangerous levels. 

 They also do a good job of evenly rolling off the bass too - very 
musical compared to other foam and silicone earplugs available to the 
general public.

 However - sometimes the sound at amplified music events has too much 
mid-highs and highs than would be musical anyway! I think this is due to
a combination of hi-frequency deafness in the over-stressed ears of the
soundman, and distortion caused by redlining the volume. In those cases,
the foam earplugs give a better spectral low-mid-high balance than the
high quality Sonic II plugs.

 I was able to test this out last Thursday at ASCENDENCE. I tried both my
Sonic II earplugs and my favorite dayglo orange fish-shaped foam earplugs 
that I bought in the gunnery section of my local sporting goods store.
Both seemed to affect bass evenly, but the Sonic II plugs gave a more
even , "musical" reduction in mid and high freq sounds. However, if 
I wanted to concentrate on midrange stuff , I did better with the foam
fishes in my ears.  But, of the two, I detect more distortion from the 
foam earplugs than the Sonic II plugs .

> ...  What's really nice about these is that you can actually make out 
> conversation better with them in (I guess that voice is more low-mid 
> and doesn't get filtered as much by the plugs). 

 I can verify that by my experience at ASCENDENCE too. Better voice
comprehension may also be caused by the higher fidelity of the Sonic II 
plugs.

> I've also never experienced any difficulties with them jumping out of 
> my ears! :D

 Gotta get them in good tho' - they can back their way out if you put 
them in casually. That rubber's wiggly. On the other hand, if you're
speaker tweeking, it'll be VERY OBVIOUS that you've lost one!

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

Precedence: bulk

I want to second Nancy's comments.  Hype! was great because it brought
back some of my own history.  In the mid-1980s I was involved somewhat
in what, for lack of a better term, I would call the "alternative"
scene in Portland.  We really did't have a name for it.  It had two
main genres, punk/hardcore and, for lack of a better term, "underground
pop."  The Wipers were the foundation of the first -- the real progenitors
of the grunge sound, but I was more in the second, with bands like the
Dharma Bums here in Portland through whom I met the Young Fresh Fellows,
Conrad Uno and so forth.  It's their sensibility that informs the
viewpoint of the movie.  As Kurt of the Fellows and Fastbacks says in
the movie, "Yeah, every so often we wake up and find out Seattle got
famous and we missed out."  

But the grunge sound and sensibility tapped into a much wider interest
or need of a mass audience than the smart (and smart-aleck) rock
sensibility of bands like the Fellows.  I remember one year at Bumbershoot,
the huge Labor Day music and arts festival at the Seattle Center, my
old housemate Mike (who was tight with the whole Bums/YFF/Replacements
crew) and I went with the gang to see NRBQ play outside in front of the
Space Needle.  There we all were -- Scott McCaughey, Joey Kline, Mike,
me, a bunch of others, right up at the stage jumping up and down with
the Q and having a great time.  Then we went inside of one of the halls
and watched a much larger crowd absolutely surging back and forth to
the new crop of grunge bands (I believe Alice in Chains was the main
attraction, unknown except in Seattle at that point).  

This is, in essence, what happened to "rave" in Europe already.  It
started as a small, dispersed, underground network of musicians and
other participants playing utterly obscure, cutting-edge records in
out of the way places because there was no acceptance of the sounds
in any of the standard venues.  

But soon events grew to the thousands and have now been held in arenas,
stadiums and old airports, to name a few of the largest locations.  
In 1992, when 177 Townsend and the Galleria were probably the largest
venues going in the SF scene (and those were infrequent), Universe was
holding outdoor events in the UK for 25,000 people.

I've often felt we have been doubly blessed in the SF scene by having
things be relatively small but benefitting from the music coming out
of Europe.  Now things are starting to catch up.  Cool World and Autechre
and the Chems on MTV are only the leading edge.  We have a new generation
for whom the idea of turntables in a bar, a warehouse or a stadium is
the most natural thing to imagine.  But the music they are inclined to
hear -- sorry, but I'm going to express an opinion here I know is not
fully shared -- is the grunge of the late 1990s, epitomized in my view
by the slow, grinding sound of the Chemical Brothers and the crossover
sounds summarized by the term "funky breaks."  Which, in my own view,
have as much to do with house, acid house and techno as Alice in Chains
does with the Young Fresh Fellows.

There will still be a dance music underground, as there is still a
guitar-alternative-band underground.  But facts are facts: no longer does
this represent the cutting edge that it once did.  The juice, the momentum,
is swinging toward the mass audience.  It won't be the same as the overnight
sensation of grunge.  This will have its own history too, and it's hard to
predict where it's heading.  But just pick up a recent issue of Mixmag,
DJ or Muzik to see some clues ...

phred

On Mon, 9 Dec 1996, Steve Cooley wrote:

--snip--

> Please, people! use SOMEthing in your ears.  You're going to need your
> hearing when you're older.  (I felt like a parent there.. whew.. weird)
> ..  but on the real, take care of your ears.. there's *no* difference in
> sound, and in fact, you can hear a broader range of sound when you do
> use some protection in your ears.
> 
> Oh yeah, and I don't wanna hear any of that 'Oh, it's already too late,
> my ears are fucked up and why bother now?" ... 'cause that's bullshit! 
> Cells *DO* regrow, and if you're not fuckin' em up every weekend by not
> using at least a ball of cotton (last time I checked they're about $0.01
> apiece) you'll be doing yourself a favor.. 
> 
--snip--


--	I saw the coolest thing this past summer.  I was at the Zurich 
Energy Parade (excellent vibe, BTW), and some people were handing out 
free foam ear plugs to the crowd.  I thought it was the most superb product 
promo.  It was warranted, because these European-techno-float-parade 
things pump out a lot of decibels.
	Maybe the SF party organizers can incorporate that into their 
future offerings.  Since there are free fruits, candy, and stuff, why not 
have a bowl of cotton balls marked as "ear-protection" or sumfin?  
	At a massive after the parade, I ran into a stand that gave out 
free ecstasy information flyers.  It was non-biased, had the _correct_ info 
concerning physiological effects (or the basics of it anyways), proper 
care during and after ingestion (drink liquids, milk, etc.), what to do 
in an emergency, overdose symptoms, how to behave around cops, and lots 
more.  It wasn't extravagantly published (printed both sides on one 3" x 5" 
flyer), but best of all, it didn't preach, but advocated self-control and 
common sense (I thought the max of one pill a week was rather high, but 
then again, I know someone who takes six pills a time  X-P~~ ).  I 
thought it was a good idea, since not everybody has access to this type 
of information (I was lucky I had very knowledgable and caring friends, 
however, not all newbies are so privileged).  Shouldn't our rave 
community have some responsibility to help its members in certain ways as 
well?


MellowDrama

Received: from [131.106.110.23] by xinet.com via ESMTP (940816.SGI.8.6.9/931108.SGI.ANONFTP)
	for <sfraves@hyperreal.com> id MAA24372; Tue, 10 Dec 1996 12:47:08 -0800
Date: Tue, 10 Dec 1996 12:47:08 -0800
Message-Id: <v0300780faed1e89a44b8@[131.106.110.23]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Tony Rotundo <tony@xinet.com>
Subject: WOMO and all that...
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I'm writing this post, not because I feel I have to explain _why_ I threw a
private party (I say "I", but really, myself and two others were the main
organizers, and a whole bunch of people helped pull it together...), but
rather to educate some misguided people.

I'm sorry that you have to read/hear this, if you have no idea what party
I'm talking about.  I know most people on this list are cool, but if we, as
an online group can convey a message to the ravers at large, then I use
this forum to do so...

I believe that to truly learn, you must choose mentors, friends and
coworkers who will offer you insight, knowledge and time in the areas you
are passionate about.  In the past couple years I have been fortunately
enough to become part of some of the finest production groups in the Bay
Area Underground Rave Scene (BAURS).  I have learned a lot from these
people, who include members of Friends and Family, Cloud Factory, Harmony,
Syntonic, and a host of others.  I have worked just about every kind of
shift you can think of.  I did it willingly, so as to learn, and give to
those people I feel honored to be around.  Honor is a funny thing...it can
really motivate you if you let it.

I believe that to truly teach, you must lead by example.  You also must be
open, and tolerant and brave.  You must be able to accept your mistakes and
take responsibility for them, teaching yourself and anyone around you the
lessons to be learned.

I got a call from a friend about a space he is moving his company into, and
he explained that I could throw a party there, but it had to happen fast,
and there couldn't be too many people.  I decided, with the direct
assistance of two friends, and the indirect assistance from members of
Cloud Factory, FnF, and Syntonic, to throw a word of mouth party, limiting
attendance to those people myself and the two friends know.  That's the
bottom line.  The party originally had no name, but eventually got dubbed
WOMO (word of mouth only).  =)

I threw this party for myself, and my friends.  I threw this party to show
people what I have learned under their tutelage.  I threw this party to
give back to my friends, my mentors, essentially...my rave family.  It was,
for me, a final exam.  And I'm so fucking proud to say...I passed.  The
party rocked!  It wasn't flawless, but it was pretty damn close, and for
that, I have a million thanks to spread to all the people that helped.

I didn't throw this party for the whole underground scene, just a piece of
it.  I didn't throw this party for SFR and all it's members.  I didn't
throw this party so someone at another party could dish surplus people off
on me, right at the peak of the night, so their party could continue.

With that said, if you didn't get invited, well, there's always next time.
I refuse to apologize for that.  It didn't matter if you know every member
of FnF, this was not an FnF party, it was WOMO, it was me and my friends,
and no one has the right to say word one about getting in, or not getting
in.  If that sounds selfish, then so be it.  I have the right to throw a
party and invite anyone I want...

As do you.  If you felt slighted by not getting in, then throw a party of
your own, invite who ever you want.  If I don't get in, I'll live with
that.  I'm rather perturbed at the ruthless nature of people at the door.
The excuses and lies to get through the door.  The complete lack of respect
for the door people.  I live by a few simple rave rules:

1) Always bring your sunglasses, no matter how long you PLAN to stay.  =)

2) Respect the door, the space and the people

3) If possible, thank the organizers for their hard work

4) Don't dance too hard, too close to the decks

5) If you have energy, offer to help clean-up

Anyway, until you experience it for yourself, you can never understand how
hard it can be working the door.  On one hand, you'd love to let everyone
in, on the other, you have to limit the crowd to the space, the
temperature, the toilets, and the attitude.  And it's all on your
shoulders.  I wish you all luck in going out and discovering places to
throw parties and pulling them off.  It can be very rewarding.  Even when
people disrespect you and your space.

The BAURS will survive.  I can't believe the energy, talent and enthusiasm
of the people around here.  It is what we make it, and in my eyes, it will
be alive and well in 1997.  Even if SFR dwindles to a few bickering
people...

Thanks for your attention,

Tony

P.S.  Andrew Rawnsley wrote:

> More vibeless, money oriented parties.

Not unless you do something about throwing vibeful, non-money oriented
parties...

> Promoters who resemble your bank manager and insurance salesmen.

Unless they are YOU!

>DJs who resemble Bon Jovi  -the DJ as rockstar. Can't wait for the videos.

Or DJs who are the last to help clean-up at 2PM on Sunday afternoon, who
offer their sound system and expect no reward...

> Bad drugs in the scene, in higher quantities (remember the end of "hippy"?)

Well, it's all about the drugs right?

> More kids getting fucked up on bad drugs, and not knowing why.

Lead by example...

> Hoards of clueless "ravers" who go 'cos it's trendy.

Help set trends by throwing quality parties...

>The music will get REALLY commercial and shitty and generic (it's getting
there already.)

Offer slots to upcoming DJs, make them work to find the right music...

[ to sfraves ]

 Well, at first I thought the "free book to a child with every 25 emailings"
was suspiciously like an urban legend/hoax, but it seems to be on the level.
You can get the details at the Houghton-Mifflin web site:

http://www.polarexpress.com    

and

http://www.polarexpress.com/96screens/HTML/aboutsts.html#2

 It's "Polar Express" because that's the book that's going to be donated
( that or some other book by the same author ). The campaign is called
"The Polar Express Share The Spirit Campaign" .

 As with all emailings sent around the Internet via "word of mouth", many
"fine print" details are missing from the message that has reached us
here at SFRaves. Check out the web site for full details,then email
is it feels right to you. I'm still thinking about it.

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

[ to sfraves ]

 Let me propose the following - 

1. Those who go to underground raves in our area ( ie not flyered or posted
  on SFRaves ), please review them on SFRaves. Please include "how-to"
  details as well as the usual "the vibe was HUGE!!!/no vibe AT ALL!!!" 
  comments.

   I think this would be of special benefit to everyone, and may encourage 
  folks here on SFRaves to hold their own! Also to get away from the
  "I paid my ticket, now show me a good time" concert mentality.

2. We others on SFRaves who weren't in on the "special elite super secret
  attendee list" solemnly PROMISE PROMISE PROMISE not to bug the poster
  of the review with whiny requests for invitations to the "next one". 

   Given that a lot of the folks in SFRaves use SFRaves to learn about 
  raves, not how to do one, this may be an impossible request. Maybe
  a special "anonymizer" email address that would strip off the sender's
  email address befroe sending off to SFRaves?

 What do you folks think?

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

(series??) of beach parties in the spring of 97'  I think it's about
time for me to progress past the house party scene to which I've been
catering for the past two years...  Im looking for a theme for these
parties to be a mixture of Trance, Drum and bass, and hardcore /
experimental / gabber:   The new underground.  I think I'll most likely
not make a cent off these ventures, but hey, you can't put a price on
LOVE, right???  So in January I'll begin begging for volunteers and
looking for decent equip. rental places...  Again, I think that the new
breed of DJ's will show all the scensters that the underground is quite
alive...

hello everyone, just thought i'd send a plea for help ...
chicago is desperately in need of a trance scene, and i thought that sf
would be just the place to turn to... is it possible to import good vibes
and great music to a place that hails harsh attitude and deep house as the
great gods of raving??? i thought LA was style-conscious, but this is out
of control...
anyhow, for all the nastiness there may be in the sf scene, look at what
you have and give it lots of love, and give yourselves lots of credit,
because it fully beats what's going on here. 
happy winter and all the fun things that go along with it!!!
stay warm!!! (i'm trying)
joy and peace to all; CAN"T WAIT TO SEE EVERYONE!!!
love and smiles,
allegra :)

other cultural rituals but it is today's ritual for many ravers.

>I threw this party for myself, and my friends.  I threw this party to show
>people what I have learned under their tutelage.  I threw this party to
>give back to my friends, my mentors, essentially...my rave family.  It was,
>for me, a final exam.  And I'm so fucking proud to say...I passed.  The
>party rocked!  It wasn't flawless, but it was pretty damn close, and for
>that, I have a million thanks to spread to all the people that helped.
>
>I didn't throw this party for the whole underground scene, just a piece of
>it.  I didn't throw this party for SFR and all it's members.  I didn't
>throw this party so someone at another party could dish surplus people off
>on me, right at the peak of the night, so their party could continue.
>
>With that said, if you didn't get invited, well, there's always next time.
>I refuse to apologize for that.  It didn't matter if you know every member
>of FnF, this was not an FnF party, it was WOMO, it was me and my friends,
>and no one has the right to say word one about getting in, or not getting
>in.  If that sounds selfish, then so be it.  I have the right to throw a
>party and invite anyone I want...


i must absolutely concur. getting hit by a bunch of RUDE, SNIVELLING,
ATTITUDE INFESTED
NON-RAVERS at 2 in the morning was a real jolt.

and get this...at about 4am one of those ungrateful bastards had the
unmitigated gall
to complain to me that the line for the bathroom was"SOOOOO LONG"!

an open word to thomas trouble

you are responsible for the people you solicit for your parties. the
indignant pigs that showed up at my PRIVATE, UNFLIERED party waving their
tickets to your party and saying we OWED them entry
are proof that once you bow to the all-mighty buck you'll pimp yourself out
to anyone...
it may not have been YOU, but it was probably one of your patrons, and a
man's reputation is
usually reflected is his associates...

and i'll say this. this scene is going back underground just because of
this shit.
i don't do flyer drop parties because the potential grabber of that flyer
these days is
not consistently trustworthy any more. after every big rave there's always
the usual banter about
posers and circle jerkers and attitude flashers and thieves.

HELLO!

THESE PEOPLE AIN'T RAVERS!

THESE AIN'T RAVES!

this is why i run with friends and family. this is why we suffer the slings
and arrows or our peers,
to keep raves enlightening and meaningful.

this is also why people influential to our community seek us out!
i have never had such a great honor in my life as when dennis p. and his
band of raving revelers
from the CBC showed up sat. nite.

this is why our alters are more than candy tables.
this is why i push a cart with 25 cases of water around the most crowded
costco in the world
on sat afternoon, and give it away on the dance floor at 3am
 this is why i can make 3 phone calls and get big sound for many rooms
FREE! and jk's finest to
run it!

these parties we do, to the disgust of the folks stuck in line behind Home
Base, will continue.
they will continue to be the crucibles in which people with vision can
visualize the harmony
that will be crucial to our advancement as a community.
they will continue to seem elitist, because they , like adulthood,drugs,
sex, they demand the
responsibility on the part of the participants. if it means a secret code
to separate the riff raff
out so we can get on with the transformation, then so be it.

peace and positivity,
greg
P.S. neils- did it occur to that the only victim of your censorship is
yourself?
add me to your list if you wish...

     yes, you see i am actually on your side, maybe i didn't make it fully 
     clear.  this would be perhaps the difference between having a glass of 
     wine at dinner as a social function (which i suppose we could call a 
     ritual) and getting sloshy drunk.  yes, maybe some people consider 
     getting sloshy drunk a ritual, but...
     
     how about this?  when there's no personal or spiritual growth 
     involved.   it's hard to pin this one down.
     
     but a lot of people just do drugs to escape the physical world.  
     they're meant, i think as a stepping stone.  but when we get down to 
     it, we really don't need drugs to step into the other realities, they 
     can be gotten by meditation and such.  
     
     i don't think there's any clear definition, though we could probably 
     start a whole ong string on that, which im sure has been done before.  
     i suspect a large portion of you already know what i mean.  
     
     deepfog

>      the biggest problem with today's drug scene is "there's no rituals
>      involved.  it's just recreational use..."

        Ritual won't protect anybody from their own drugs. 

	Drugs can occasionally be helpful for personal development
	for certain people, but mostly they're a trap. I'll bet
	everyone on this list knows at least one casualty.

	If you've lost faith that the walls of ego can be broken down
	at all, then *maybe* something like E or acid can help you.

        If you already know that the walls come down when you take E or
        acid - but you think that's the *only* or the *best* way to do
	it, then you're probably already caught and don't even know it.

>   TGARCI02 wrote:

>     the biggest problem with today's drug scene is "there's no rituals
>     involved.  it's just recreational use..."

Good point!  But I think that problems can arise in ritual as well.  Ritual
can become monotonous and eventually lose its meaning.

Having a reason, a search, a question to be answered, a vision quest, in
other words needing to break free of pressing constraints of ones reality
to see or perceive something new, is in my opinion, the only reason to
partake of a substance, in any form, that will alter my reality.

But if one sees life as an illusion then this reality doesn't seem so
restricting and being able to make new perceptions comes quite easily.  So
then is the substance really necessary since reality can be altered so
easily within?



jocelyn


>
>

At 11:54 PM -0000 12/10/96, Steve Simitzis wrote:
>And there's nothing better than a crowd of people in baggy pants
>clawing at a warehouse door to attract Officer Bob... That sucked. I'm
>honestly surprised that the party wasn't busted. There was, after all,
>a police car hanging out on 6th and Mission when I showed up.


And that's the point that I was trying to make about people being able to
miss a party...I kept telling people that by them being in the street, our
party would get busted too...

Here's how it went down with the cop.  As he approached about 30 people
scattered to a distance of about 25 yards on either side and watched like a
rumble was about to being.  Our story was straight...we were having a
private party celebrating the moving in of a software company (actually,
multimedia), and it was a free party, by invitation only.  Officer Tim
waved me out, I approached confidently.  He asked what was going on.  I
said, "We are having a moving in party for my friend's software company."
"These people," pointing left and right, "don't look like software types."
I smile.  "You're right.  A party was busted down the street, and they came
here thinking it was an open party.  It's not."  "I see.  What's the
address here?"  "xxxx Mission Street."  "Okay..."  "Thank you, my name's
Tony."  "My name's Tim."  Shake hands, Tim goes to his squad car, I shut
the door tight.  Within 5 seconds, people are again rushing the door....

Crazy!  He was soooo cool, I thought we were going to have the swat teams
on us in minutes.  Never saw another cop.  Maybe they were busy down the
street?  =)

Tony

From: MarsMyRat@aol.com
Received: by emout11.mail.aol.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id UAA04873 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Tue, 10 Dec 1996 20:22:47 -0500
Date: Tue, 10 Dec 1996 20:22:47 -0500
Message-ID: <961210202246_674769932@emout11.mail.aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: NRR but yummy...
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Please pass this on to people you know.  The poor woman!
     
This is a true story that was forwarded to me.  Read it and learn.  Bake 
the cookies and enjoy them and then forward this to all you know!
     
My daughter & I had just finished a salad at Neiman-Marcus Cafe in Dallas
& decided to have a small dessert.  It was so excellent that I asked if
they 
would give me the recipe and the would you let me buy the recipe?
With a cute smile, she said, "Yes."  I asked how
much, and she responded, "Only two fifty, it's a great deal!"  I said 
with approval, just add it to my tab.  Thirty days later, I received my 
VISA statement from Neiman-Marcus and it was $285.00.  I looked again and

I remembered I had only spent $9.95 for two salads and about $20.00 for a

scarf.  As I glanced at the bottom of the statement, it said, "Cookie 
Recipe - $250.00."  That's outrageous!!  I called Neiman's Accounting 
Dept. and told them the waitress said it was "two-fifty," which clearly 
does not mean "two hundred and fifty dollars" by any *POSSIBLE* 
interpretation of the phrase.  Nieman-Marcus refused to budge.  They 
would not refund my money, because according to them, "What the waitress 
told you is not our problem.  You have already seen the recipe - we 
absolutely will not refund your money at this point."  I explained to her

the criminal statutes which govern fraud in Texas, I threatened to refer 
them to the Better Business Bureau and the State's Attorney General for 
engaging in fraud.  I was basically told, "Do what you want, we don't 
give a crap, and we're not refunding your money."  I waited, thinking of 
how I could get even, or even try and get any of my money back.  I just 
said, "Okay, you folks got my $250, and now I'm going to have $250.00 
worth of fun."  I told her that I was going to see to it that every 
cookie lover in the United States with an e-mail account has a $250.00 
cookie recipe from Neiman-Marcus... for free.  She replied, "I wish you 
wouldn't do this." I said, "Well, you should have thought of that before 
you ripped me off, and slammed down the phone on her.
     
So, here it is!!!  Please, please, please pass it on to everyone you can 
possibly think of.  I paid $250 dollars for this...
     
I don't want Nieman-Marcus to *ever* get another penny off of this 
recipe....
     
     
   (Recipe may be halved.):
     
     
     2  cups butter
     4  cups flour
     2  tsp. soda
     2  cups sugar
     5  cups blended oatmeal**
     24 oz. chocolate chips
     2  cups brown sugar
    1  tsp. salt
     1  8 oz. Hershey Bar (grated)
     4  eggs
    2  tsp. baking powder
    3  cups chopped nuts (your choice)
     2  tsp. vanilla
     ** Measure oatmeal and blend in a blender to a fine powder.  Cream
the butter and both sugars.  Add eggs and vanilla; mix together with 
flour, oatmeal, salt, baking powder, and soda.  Add chocolate chips, 
Hershey Bar and nuts.  Roll into balls and place two inches apart on a 
cookie sheet.  Bake for 10 minutes at 375 degrees.  Makes 112 cookies.
     
     
Have fun!!!  This is *not* a joke --- this is a true story..

On Tue, 10 Dec 1996, Greg-n-Cindy wrote:

>  this is why i can make 3 phone calls and get big sound for many rooms
> FREE! and jk's finest to
> run it!

	Be careful, or those same people might start looking at this as 
attitude and be more reluctant to help out...

> they will continue to seem elitist, because they , like adulthood,drugs,
> sex, they demand the
> responsibility on the part of the participants. if it means a secret code
> to separate the riff raff
> out so we can get on with the transformation, then so be it.

	This is something I have been kind of struggling with. What 
exactly are each of us going to call the underground? It is a select 
crowd of people we know that come out to parties and act the same, go to 
all the same parties? Or it something little more open than that? If it 
is something that is a little more open, how do you filter out the 
trendies who go around demanding to smear glitter all over you? How can 
something be open so it does not get stale without getting bogged down in 
attitude or people who are going to request some nice goa (sorry if that 
offends someone, it is not meant to, just it is what is liked by a lot 
now, so I am using it as an example) when I play gabber ;) How do we 
expect to "evolve", as I have heard just about every group that has a 
name out say they are trying to do, with stagnation?
	Why don't small parties even consider trying something new, and 
saying so - We are going to try something new and drop the price to just 
cover our costs with the additional influx of people, (or donate the 
extra money to the same or additional charities it has always been going 
to).
	My last observation is about individual responsibility. We work 
to put on parties and one of the things I would like to see come out of 
that is having people learn how to handle themselves a little better. 
This is one of the reasons I like bringing people out into the middle of 
no where, it is one of the reasons I like Burning Man so much, and it the 
biggest stumbling block I see for opening parties up to more people - the 
party will get busted because dumb shits sit outside the party with their 
car stereo blasting, or walking across 1 in bright reflective gear after 
parking in a visible location, or just plain looking like they are going 
to a rave by walking down the street with 10 billion stuffed animals, all 
glittered up and being loud and loud outside is gonna get you busted 
inside right? enough sermoning.... take what you will, I don't know how 
to say this in any other way than I just have...

dave

Subject: NRR:  What the F$#?! is going on?
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-id: <7EEEAD32813E657C*7EEEAD32813E657C#064#X-PA-PAHV-MS4.XN@SMF>
MIME-version: 1.0

Posting-date: Tue, 10 Dec 1996 18:23:11 -0500
Hop-count: 3
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I wonder what would happen if we eliminated PLUR, love, and fuck from 
 our vocabulary?  Would we learn how to communicate better?  Would we want to?

I have a ten year-old son, Nicholas, who's quite intelligent (IMBO).  
 Whenever we go to 80 Acres (some land a friend of ours has), we tell 
 the kids they could cuss as much as they want to.  They speak foul, 
 unspeakable combinations that are often funny but it would often last 
 for about five to ten minutes and then they'd go back to being their 
 wonderful selves.  Nowadays, I tell him he can only use words 
 (including profanity) if he understands their definitions and usage.  
 Sometimes he tells me funny jokes that use profanities but overall, he 
 doesn't swear.  I wonder if we, as grown-ups, can do the same?  
 Finding clarity in describing what's ganking us can be difficult but 
 it could also avoid alot of flame wars, too.  Lord knows how many 
 posts I delete just to get some pertinent info on this list!

So, remember:  children can be great teachers.  Think of an infant who 
 knows and asks exactly what s/he needs--s/he cries when he's hungry, 
 wet, or tired.  And we provide... (Note the difference between needs 
 and wants!)

So I'm asking each of you to try and simplify the verbosity and 
 aggressiveness on the list by checking our attitudes at the door while 
 getting back down to the basics that brought us together:  music and dance.

Nah, it doesn't have to be pretty, well versed, or spelt correctly!  We 
 all have our special way of expressing ourselves and our humble 
 opinions.   But to tell someone to fuck off, etc. is showing something 
 that should be taken off the group list and into a personal 
 communication.  So show the entire list some respect and take it off 
 the group list.  We know you're intelligent and better than the 
 average bear, so show it!

Breathe deep and let's get real!  (Personal flames can be received at 
 tabellij@adoc.xerox.com and then there's always the delete key!)

See ya on the dance floor!
Diane

P.S.  If you want to check out a cool NRR website promoting unity 
 consciousness, please check out http://www.gaiamind.com

   Gulp!.... ahhhhhh..... imaginary sedative taken...
   
   So when I was starting on the internet, I was told, imagine you're in person 
   with the person you're writing to.
   
   So I guess kill files are like putting your hands over your ears and 
   screaming "I can't hear you".  Well, at least nobody's bragging about or 
   publishing who they've cut off... oh wait...
   
   I suppose I can understand... I want to be able to post to 500 people, but I 
   don't want to have to listen to them in return.
   
   Kill files were set up as an Anti-Spam measure.  Don't associate yourself 
   with SPAM production and distribution and I guess you don't belong on one.  
   Not everybody likes "Hi, it's a great day HUG" messages (that's the only 
   common thread I could think of among those people who appeared on the 
   published Kill List).  I myself personally sometimes very much appreciate 
   them and sometimes just ignore them.
   
   Anyway, at the risk of ending up on a dreaded Kill List myself, that was 
   pretty cruel.  Whether you read their posts or not, we all got that message.
   
   As for the responses, well... group unity is a weird thing.  Whenever you 
   have three or more people, shit like this is eventually going to happen.  I'd 
   hate to hear that somebody is going to kick some ass or some other crap.  
   Suffice to say that there is one benefit of Neils' Kill File list... those on 
   it can now freely spout evil devious shit about him without his knowledge.
   
   It's not about PLUR, or even raving.  It happens everyday on the net.  Don't 
   make a big deal out of it... it's just one person on a mail list being 
   inconsiderate (as in "I don't even consider reading mail from you and you and 
   you and you"), that's all.
   
   It leaves us open to a better understanding of tolerance of interests.... 
   Neils' well informed political commentary and Matt's super warm bear hug 
   posts are probably both relevant to a group of us, and probably equally rave 
   related.  Do we bash both or tolerate both?  I choose tolerance...
   
   Peace,
   AndyW
   
   Oh... and Neils... HUG!!!  ;)

You know, up here in Portland we're used to the rain, though it's a bit
much this year with almost 55 inches of the stuff so far (compared to our
normal 38) even for us.

But I have observed that rain makes Californians crazy, or at least it's
the only explanation I can come up with for what's happened on sfraves
since Thanksgiving time.  Old friends of mine are yelling at each other
online and it don't make no sense.  People are expressing opinions on the
list that may or may not be thought-out or based on reality, but then
others jump in with flamethrowers on full without considering the dynamic
this sets up.

I'm no longer one to preach, but let me quote one of my current favorite
records, one that Allen Ameba played about a month ago at 1015.  As a
non-believer in the organized-church sense, I think it still stands as a
startling reminder of how amazing life is and how easy it is to lose that,
in the rain or otherwise:

  Not to condemn you
  Not to put you down
  To raise you up
  Elevate your sights
  To let you know
  That there's something MORE out there
  That God wants you to HAVE.

It's the season for honoring our earth and ourselves, whether you are
a fan of Christmas, Hanukkah, the Solstice or None of the Above.

peace out
phred

all right kids - KNOCK IT OFF!!  if i see ONE more person wasting
bandwidth by complaining about/insulting someone who's wasting bandwidth
with non-rave or TOO-rave-related stuff, i'll have to get nasty!  :)

Being a member of a community means dealing in a responsible, reasonable
fashion with the downside of the community.  Cursing and swearing and
personally jabbing at people is hardly constructive.  If you must do this,
take it off the list where it belongs.

The way i see it (and i've said this before) these mailing lists were
created to be used by the rave scene about the rave scene.  I have no
problem with NRR posts, as they're being posted by people who do have
something in common with me and are part of the scene, therefore they have
a right to post anything they want.  By that argument also i shouldn't
really bitch about all the annoying arguments and flames either, but to
me, these are less necessary and nowhere near as interesting.  :)

my only $.02 about the issue is ... if you're responding to a post ...
DON'T include the whole damn message in your response with only a "yeah,
right on" at the very end.  THAT is truly annoying.

it's unfortunate that while we flee an evil, we bring it with us ... so
much for unity :P

pounce

The top reasons when it's time for a new dj:


Top Several Signs It's Time For a New DJ.

  -  Four words: James Brown Is Dead.

  -  The mixing sounds like it was done on a veg-o-matic

  -  The DJ is just standing there staring at the way cool
      label design and it goes round and round and round . . . .
      (this is only really bad if the needles hit the inner groove
      when shes doing this)  <Actual Anecdote>

  -  Two Words: Amtrax Derailment

  -  You lose your sanity and proclaim "even breakbeat would be better
        than this junk!" (of course assuming that you realize that
breakbeat
        is the most annoying gunk in the galaxy...reminds me of being
forced
        to clean my room as a child)

  -  The dj actually *starts* spinning breakbeat
    
  -  You begin to humm your favorite classic rock song
    
  -  Wax in your ears turns out to be a GOOD thing
    
  -  Ready ready SKIP!
    
  -  Amtrax Just Had Another Acciednt
    
  -  You hear crickets between songs
    
  -  Dj starts screaming "lets scratch the night away!"
      or alternatively and more effectively "its breakbeat time!"

  -  When there are more backspin segues than grooves on the record

  -  The dj picks up the needle and move it back a couple inches
      cuz it was about to end and they were talking to other people

  -  A pair of headphones comes flying out of the booth...

  -  Someone walks up and requests prince or janet jackson
      and the dj is glad to hear a good request finally


had to share it....

plur everybody,

--adam--

TGARCI02@ccsmtp.farinon.harris.com wrote:
> 
>      well, that's true too...
> 
>      meditation is the better route, because you have to really focus and
>      work hard to get there.
> 
>      they (drugs) do lift us up, but only to a limit, and then they limit
>      us because it takes a while for the chemicals to leave our system.
>      then were tired or cant sleep.

this is why DMT is so convenient... all the information received on a 48 
hour acid stint can be obtained in ten minutes...  a very quick and deep 
in and a very quick out... and the fact that its metabolized within half 
an hour makes it the safest psychedelic on the market... hell, caffeine 
stays in your system three times as long... but DMT is not an escapist 
tool... this is a biotechnology designed to instruct on how to coexist in 
parallel spacetime continuums... not that you have to take it seriously, 
but don't take it without the commitment to gain something from the 
experience... wave probability isn't something to fuck around with, 
especially when your mind is the link...


> 
>      obviously these substances wouldn't be here if we werent meant to use
>      them if we want.  but someday hopefully we will be able to move on
>      once enough people are enlightened.
> 
> 


notice how psychedelic art (circa the 60's) is now being produced by 
people who never touched psychedelics in their lives... this is because 
LSD now sits comfortably within the collective subconscious... it is far 
more accessible now than in 1960... i wonder what will happen once DMT 
consciousness sits this comfortably a decade or two down the line... 
perhaps this is the quantum leap Mckenna and so many others expect to 
happen in 2012, coinciding with some astrological developments...  Leary 
said on his spoken word LP "once that last person turns on, it will be 
like an enormous ripple of laughter... everyone will just start 
laughing..."  biotechnological invention spawns viral induction...

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

>         Drugs can occasionally be helpful for personal development
>         for certain people, but mostly they're a trap. I'll bet
>         everyone on this list knows at least one casualty.
>

anyone i know who became a casualty was using drugs recreationally, 
and not integrating their experiences before dosing again... this was not 
for mere adventures in spiritism, but for the banal intoxication of it... 
i've seen the downward spiral in a few cases actually... it starts with 
weekend use which accelerates into twice a week... and as usage increases 
the subconscious residue of undealt with trips builds- even if they're 
totally unaware and thinking they're still having a good time... it's at 
this point that Spalding Gray's metaphor to a pile of shit brown energy 
piling on a stainless steel counter, and this is attatched to a pile of 
bubbly pastel positive energy so if you pull the negative off you're left 
with nothing but a stainless steel counter... some casualties just go 
catatonic for awhile... others let the negative build under the surface 
until WAMMO!  the BIG BAD TRIP... after which they go straight edge and 
deny all their experiences or at least quit drugs for a long period of 
time... many of this type of casualty finds it convenient to blame the 
drugs for all the terrors of their own subconscious mind...

...the key in all of this is to remember that we are using drugs for 
PURSUITISM NOT ESCAPISM... take responsibility for what you ingest... 
know what it is at least... take the time to research it... i read as 
much as i could find by Grof, Leary, Hoffman, McKenna and several other 
research engines that spent their careers studying psychedelics before i 
dropped my first tab, and i didn't stop there...  


 
>         If you've lost faith that the walls of ego can be broken down
>         at all, then *maybe* something like E or acid can help you.
> 
>         If you already know that the walls come down when you take E or
>         acid - but you think that's the *only* or the *best* way to do
>         it, then you're probably already caught and don't even know it.


but always remember DRUGS SHOW YOU THE WAY, BUT ARE NOT THE WAY ITSELF...

Gioni Pasquinelli wrote:
> 
> TGARCI02@ccsmtp.farinon.harris.com wrote:
> 
> >      the biggest problem with today's drug scene is "there's no rituals
> >      involved.  it's just recreational use..."
> 
> stuttering deleted...
> 
> I am not so sure this is true...what do you consider a ritual.  Lots of
> people here on this list get all dressed up, go to a rave, meet new and
> see old people...is this a ritual?  Obviously this isn't like Indian
> other cultural rituals but it is today's ritual for many ravers.
> 
> G

as a sometimes practicioner of chaos magick, i know myself that rituals 
needn't have any orthodox form... but there needs to be some forethought 
put into the act... a goal to accomplish through sleight of mind 
technique... this does not include simply dropping acid with a bud and 
going to a party and seeing what happens... more empirical methods yield 
better results... the most one could observe from a party experience, and 
 vaguely at that, would be how the collective subconscious affected their 
consciousness throughout the evening... in throwing parties and djing i 
have had a better position of observation, watching how the programming 
affects the environment... and how a subconscious message can be sent 
with specific resonance at peak astrological dates to exact results 
within the scene... xenophrenic was an event that changed the london, 
ontario rave scene for 2 years and the boob series in toronto is 
currently invoking experimental drum+bass as a force to be reckoned 
with... we took away the four-on-the-floor for a night and everyone lost 
it!... (timothy leary once said "it becomes necessary to go out of our 
minds in order to learn how to use our heads")... the best parties are 
always planned around key dates, even if the promoters are totally 
unaware of occultural phenomenon... some promoters do it out of instinct, 
the ones who are more aware of it (at least the ones out here) seem to 
have the most intense parties... it's too bad we couldn't post suggested 
"drop co-ordinates" like the Operation Organic series out here (E23, A2) 
and get more people involved in a feedback process to make the craft even 
more effective... 

...but it has to be a responsible combination of science and religion, 
art and logic, 23, not some new-age quackery which can't be objectively 
discussed...


perhaps i digress into esotericism, but i hope those of you out there who 
understand will appreciate this...

the alchemist

That's right, I'm posting again. This time it's to tell EVERY single person
on here that if this crap does NOT stop here and now, I will make it a
point to have you taken off this list for good or at least I'll die trying.
I don't just mean Neils and John, I mean ANYONE. This does NOT belong on
this list. If your going to fight, take it off this list after the first
flame. You would not believe what things can be accomplished off in
private. Neils and myself worked out our little tiff, so why can't everyone
else do the same.

You do NOT have to CC: the list when your flaming someone, do it off the
list. I'm here to meet new people, talk about parties and read the BSP's.
Not F-you for saying this to so and so. If you don't like Neils post to the
list then I suggest you put him in YOUR kill file, otherwise take it off
the list. People flaming him for what he is saying only makes it worse. So
let's stop this nonesense.


I think EVERYONE needs to take a good look and read the Welcome to SFRaves
letter again. It's cut and dry about what should and should not be on this
list. If your not sure, then either don't post it, or re-read the Welcome
message again, if what your going to post doesn't have anything to do with
"raving" or what it describes on the Welcome letter, then DON'T post it to
the list, post it privately to the person that you want to address.


Take this warning however you want, but believe me when I say I'll make it
a point to have you removed from this list, or die trying, if you don't
comply with the rules of this list. And this my friends goes for EVERYONE.


I don't need a post saying, "I agree, or way to go, or even, I'd like to
see you try it". Just comply to the rules of the list and everything will
be fine.


Tim (knucklehead)

At 08:22 PM 12/10/96 -0500, you wrote:
>Please pass this on to people you know.  The poor woman!
>     
>This is a true story that was forwarded to me.  Read it and learn.  Bake 
>the cookies and enjoy them and then forward this to all you know!
>     
>My daughter & I had just finished a salad at Neiman-Marcus Cafe in Dallas
>& decided to have a small dessert.  It was so excellent that I asked if
>they 
>would give me the recipe and the would you let me buy the recipe?
>With a cute smile, she said, "Yes."  I asked how
>much, and she responded, "Only two fifty, it's a great deal!"  I said 
>with approval, just add it to my tab.  Thirty days later, I received my 
>VISA statement from Neiman-Marcus and it was $285.00.  I looked again and
>
>I remembered I had only spent $9.95 for two salads and about $20.00 for a
>
>scarf.  As I glanced at the bottom of the statement, it said, "Cookie 
>Recipe - $250.00."  That's outrageous!!  I called Neiman's Accounting 
>Dept. and told them the waitress said it was "two-fifty," which clearly 
>does not mean "two hundred and fifty dollars" by any *POSSIBLE* 
>interpretation of the phrase.  Nieman-Marcus refused to budge.  They 
>would not refund my money, because according to them, "What the waitress 
>told you is not our problem.  You have already seen the recipe - we 
>absolutely will not refund your money at this point."  I explained to her
>
>the criminal statutes which govern fraud in Texas, I threatened to refer 
>them to the Better Business Bureau and the State's Attorney General for 
>engaging in fraud.  I was basically told, "Do what you want, we don't 
>give a crap, and we're not refunding your money."  I waited, thinking of 
>how I could get even, or even try and get any of my money back.  I just 
>said, "Okay, you folks got my $250, and now I'm going to have $250.00 
>worth of fun."  I told her that I was going to see to it that every 
>cookie lover in the United States with an e-mail account has a $250.00 
>cookie recipe from Neiman-Marcus... for free.  She replied, "I wish you 
>wouldn't do this." I said, "Well, you should have thought of that before 
>you ripped me off, and slammed down the phone on her.
>     
>So, here it is!!!  Please, please, please pass it on to everyone you can 
>possibly think of.  I paid $250 dollars for this...
>     
>I don't want Nieman-Marcus to *ever* get another penny off of this 
>recipe....
>     
>     
>   (Recipe may be halved.):
>     
>     
>     2  cups butter
>     4  cups flour
>     2  tsp. soda
>     2  cups sugar
>     5  cups blended oatmeal**
>     24 oz. chocolate chips
>     2  cups brown sugar
>    1  tsp. salt
>     1  8 oz. Hershey Bar (grated)
>     4  eggs
>    2  tsp. baking powder
>    3  cups chopped nuts (your choice)
>     2  tsp. vanilla
>     ** Measure oatmeal and blend in a blender to a fine powder.  Cream
>the butter and both sugars.  Add eggs and vanilla; mix together with 
>flour, oatmeal, salt, baking powder, and soda.  Add chocolate chips, 
>Hershey Bar and nuts.  Roll into balls and place two inches apart on a 
>cookie sheet.  Bake for 10 minutes at 375 degrees.  Makes 112 cookies.
>     
>     
>Have fun!!!  This is *not* a joke --- this is a true story..
>
>
>
>
>

From: Minh Le <mle@gwdg.de>
To: Wolfchen@aol.com
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Frankfurt Rave Clubs
In-Reply-To: <961210165900_1321312490@emout20.mail.aol.com>
Message-Id: <Pine.A32.3.91.961211173612.17539A-100000@gwdu10.gwdg.de>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

On Tue, 10 Dec 1996 Wolfchen@aol.com wrote:

> I will be hanging out with some old friends in Frankfurt soon, But they don't
> do the nocturnal nightlife like I do. Does anybody have any recommendations
> as to good clubs and DJ's to check out? Any genre of techno/house/etc... is
> good to me, I like it all.
> 
> Smile ON!
> Alex
> 
--	Frankfurt is chock full of techno clubs.  It is the most 
"American-like" city in Germany.  The architecture and skyline is 
wonderful because it is a big banking city with many skyscrapers and 
such.  However, be careful when you travel because Frankfurt's crime rate 
is also infamous.
	I haven't had the chance to go to certain big name clubs in 
Frankfurt myself, but the clubs there are well known.  As far as I know, 
 "Omen" is supposed to be by far the best.  There is also the "Tunnel 
club," which seems to be very popular.  The third that comes to mind is 
"Dorian Gray."  It is located in Frankfurt airport itself and the club DJ 
is Mark Spoon (extremely famous techno-DJ in Germany who has taken all 
his hype to heart).  I personally do not care for Mark Spoon because he 
is too arrogant and his DJ-ing is over-rated.  He has gotten so fat off of 
his profits that he doesn't even try to please the crowd anymore--he 
spins whatever he feels like spinning (which resulted in an extremely bad 
session once that completely overwhelmed me with disgust).  However, 
personal dislikes aside, everyone knows that he is a master at his craft 
and you should go hear what the best of German techno culture has to offer.
A more comprehensive listing can be had by the monthly _Frontpage 
magazine_ which contains almost all German party dates in its 
"Silverpages" (You have to buy Frontpage itself, but you can get just the 
Silverpages free at any techno type store).  Another mag with listings is 
_Groove(y)_ which is a freebie at techno-culture stores.  Another option 
is the city specific _Prinz_ which isn't too expensive with decent listings.
You can also surf the rave homepages on the net which contain specific 
German/European party information.

Hope this helps,
MellowDrama

P.S.  You can always contact me personally for more information.  Also 
keep in mind, that since Germany is so small (compared to CA) that 
traveling to other towns for parties is a common occurence (there are 
many gems out there).

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Wed, 11 Dec 1996 11:35:27 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Jay Bain <cyberzen@cyberzen.com>
Subject: 10 Best Experiences in 1996
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This is the end of the year, and my first year in SF.  Its also time to
introduce a new topic with a positive vibe to the list, "Your Top 10
Experiences of 1996".  

I'm going to propose to XLR8R's editor's that these postings be featured on
their new site, so there's some kind of record of this...  If you don't want
yours republished, please say so.

These should be somewhat rave/techno related, but any "satori" experiences
would be cool too!  

Here's my top 10 (not in any order):
----------------------------------

1.  Burning Man -- Meeting my new friend, Charles Uzzell-Edwards in the Chai
tent, after a night of dancing by fires in a hallucinogenic state, he played
Money Mark's "Keyboard Repair" entire album and maintained the chill Buddha
posture even though someone was having an acid freakout.

2.  Burning Man -- Having gotten jungle DJ's UFO and Noel up to the desert,
watching them take over the beautiful Wicked sound system.

3.  Going to the Top in lower Haight every Saturday to hear jungle music
mixed by my favorite jungle DJ's, hangin' out in the back with happy junglists.

4.  Seeing the Chemical Brothers three times!  Also, seeing Meat Beat
Manifesto for the first time, after listening to their albums for years.
Seeing Goldie and Doc Scott too!

5.  Burning Man:  Driving our rented Chevy Blazer over to the naked people
mud pit and playing Noel's remix of Alex Reece's "Everybody Loves the
Sunshine" while we watched mud-covered people slip 'n' slide.

6.  Driving to Big Sur once a month to work on the Henry Miller Library web
site; once I climbed to the top of a mountain with my friend Eddie, got
baked and could see the coast, the ocean, the mountains and sunset -- a
"satori" moment for sure, another time with Charles Uzzell-Edwards and his
wife it was raining and I was very sick so we huddled by a fireplace
listening to ambient music while the rain drummed against the roof all night.

7.  Seeing cool sci-fi/technology/nature movies, especially "Bladerunner" at
the Castro on the widescreen; "Synthetic Pleasures" twice and "Baraka"
twice.  The Low Res techno show at 111 Minna was great too, especially the
FSOL film, which blew my mind.

8.  Free Tibet Concert:  Laughing to myself when Beck made a joke about
jungle when he sped his drum machine up to 180 bpm (he's got a sense o'
humor) ....  Interviewing Tibetans, Adam Yauch and Cibo Matto and having my
article published in Giant Robot magazine.

9.  All the times that I met and got to know the DJ's, web hackers and
techno enthusiasts (especially junglists) of San Francisco, including Jonah
Sharp, the XLR8R Andrews, Charles U.E., Noel, UFO, DJ Thad, Abstract, Tomas,
Flux, the Hotwired BetaLounge crew, Dina Marie Alegmana, Freaky Chakra, DJ
Steve from Noc Noc, Raven Lafay, Jessie Singer and many many other cool
people, including the ones I danced with but never met.

10.  Seeing the Survival Research Labs show in that big construction pit,
which made me think a lot about explosions, violence and the ability of
people to create art and destroy it too.  

--------------------------------------------------------

A note on this last one:  Art, especially DJ performances, etc., is
sometimes at its most beautiful when it is only there for a moment, making
it more valuable and memorable.  Its just like all of us -- someday we'll be
30, 40, 50 and will be thinking back about our 'raving' days.  I don't know
how I'll explain all of this to my kids, but these memories are something
I'm going to hang on to.

Thank you SF Raves, San Francisco and everyone else for making this a great
year for me!

OK, I give myself one more since I'm posting the first message:

11.  DJ Gamall (now in NYC) sold me his mixer for $20 -- much less than its
worth -- I have to attribute this to good karma. I'd thought he was an aloof
kind of guy before, but some people you just have to get to know.  Seeing
such good karma, so unexpectedly, was an eye opener for me.  Don't judge people!










---------------------------------------------------------------------
  @..@    C. J. Bain

( >__< )  http://www.cyberzen.com

"...though you may have to explain subjects to your children that you 
 perceive as wrong, it is better to have the freedom to explain it in
 your own words than be silenced under a government that has the power
 to squash anyone who opposes their views"
 ---Perry Farrell, 1990

I am writing you all to get a feel for your interest in the following:  A
few friends and I have concidered (but havn't acted) for quite some time now
throwing a party that would be idm/intellijungle in one room, and ambient in
the another.  The space would be set up like two big ambient rooms
basically, but there would be some dance space as well as
couches/carpet/pillows and what not in the idm room.  You could dance if you
like, or you could just relax and consciously listen.  The chill room would
be chillin as usual.  

What I want to know is, what is the interest level for an event like this?

Rick

>If I recall correctly, the reason they use dat for goa is the heat factor.
>In Goa India,(where the first DJ's started playing that sound) the heat
>melts vinyl. The DJ's mixed all their records before hand onto DAT.

that's nuts! I've never thought of that... did the lack of mixing bother
people at first, or were they OK with the fact that they were basically
dancing to mixtapes?

On Tue, 10 Dec 1996 Wolfchen@aol.com wrote:

> I will be hanging out with some old friends in Frankfurt soon, But they don't
> do the nocturnal nightlife like I do. Does anybody have any recommendations
> as to good clubs and DJ's to check out? Any genre of techno/house/etc... is
> good to me, I like it all.
> 
> Smile ON!
> Alex
> 


I'm not sure how varied the tastes are throughout Germany...but if the 
music is at all similar to what I experienced this summer at the Love 
Parade in Berlin...then expect gabber/trance hardcore (whatever its 
called) at 200 bpm.

There was some variation but not much. I think there was 750,000+ people 
for that parade, so its ok to say techno is mainstream pop culture there.  They
just love it FAST and HARD... 

;)


j

Well the list manager is Brian B. and as far as I know, he is the only one
who can throw people off the list, I think it has only happened once or
twice (if at all)
in SFRAVES history. Over the years the list has gone through changes but I
for
one feel that the current squabblings are rather constructive, I admit
people need to
put less PLUR suffixes on their sentences and try actualizing more of the
real thing (respect that is)
for indeed that is what it's all about.  But it does seem that issues of
race, code words and the like 
keep cropping upe list at least once a year so it seems that this is
obviously a subject that
is crying to come out.  Rather then sweeping it under the rug, (as it
always is) maybe folks should try to deal with
it in a loving and respectful manner.  Denial and vitrol will get no-one
anywhere and the tacking of a PLUR
onto the end of a sentence doesn't gurentee your admission into "raver
heaven" on judgement day.

Maybe what needs to happen is Connection 4 :)

							G

>>In Goa India,(where the first DJ's started playing that sound) the heat
>>melts vinyl. The DJ's mixed all their records before hand onto DAT.

like I believe Goa Gil does. That's why you find him mixing DATs often.
It's mostly his own music.

From: Rob Rayle <robertr@autodesk.com>

To: SFRaves@hyperreal.com, alchemist@internity.on.ca
Subject: Re: [Fwd: Re: Re[2]: mr. spock was an acid casualty]
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> i've seen the downward spiral in a few cases actually... it starts with 
> weekend use which accelerates into twice a week... and as usage increases 
> the subconscious residue of undealt with trips builds- even if they're 
> totally unaware and thinking they're still having a good time...  

	this is a "pure" acid/E casualty scenario, which is relatively
rare. it's much more common for someone to use a powerful psychedelic
infrequently,  but to combine it with regular use of something "harmless"
like humboldt green, which slows down processing of the experience enough
that the same psychic gunk accumulates. this type of drug user takes a lot
longer, and the exact causality is harder to pin down, but it's pretty much
the same process you described so well. 

> some casualties just go catatonic for awhile... 
> others let the negative build under the surface 
> until WAMMO!  the BIG BAD TRIP... 

	... but most just start acting like bigger & bigger assholes
more & more of the time until nobody wants to be around them. they don't
even want to be around themselves. so they switch over to the pure escapist
drugs & they're left with only drugs & other people motivated primarily by
drugs for company. 

	does any of this sound familiar to anyone here?

From: lachim@uclink4.berkeley.edu (michal migurski)
Subject: Re: 10 Best Experiences in 1996
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>This is the end of the year, and my first year in SF.  Its also time to
>introduce a new topic with a positive vibe to the list, "Your Top 10
>Experiences of 1996".

I agree, though I think this should be somewhat limited to even vaguely RR
experiences, so the NRR cops don't get itchy trigger fingers...

here's my top ten:

10: FnF at pt. molate 2.24.96. My first genuine good-vibe rave experience.
Meeting a ton of SFRavers and dancing in the mud for fun.

9: Mad Mondays. I went to Mad almost every monday in february and march
(until it got shut down for awhile) and LOVED IT! Ethan's sets consistently
blew me away, and he even gave me one (2.12.96) on tape for free...thanks
ethan!! I still listen to it regularly!

8: Viberation on the beach 8.17.96. This was my first experience putting
together a party, with my boys Terry and Adam and Tim and Tom and Jonathan
and others... It's paved the way for another viberation, coming out
blastin' like yosemite sam sometime this spring. =)

7: CCC/Goa Gil 10.5.96. A genuine trance party at my own house? fuckin' A!
Goa Gil absatively posolutely TORE SHIT UP.

6: Freedom 7.6.96. The first massive I've ever had a really good time at.
Meeting Andy W., who was cool enough to give me a ride (but hogged the
fries =). Meeting a ton MORE SFRavers, including (but not limited to)
brendan and phelps and re-meeting a bunch more. Also had my first
ExpEriEncE there. =D

5: FnF, 7.27.96. Yowza! My first all-night friends and family. The space
was so perfect, the people so open, and everything worked out wonderfully.
Left with a feeling of deep satisfaction. Also this is where the seeds of
viberation were sown.

4: Harmony 3-year 9.14.96. My first time helping out as a member of
Harmony, as well as having a great time with a ton of friends new and old.
This party was so well-excecuted I don't even have the words to describe
it...

3: FnF 10.26.96. despite the early bust which almost left me in tears, we
moved to a dinky little garage in Redwood City where the party continued
'til noon. In the immortal words of Wayne: this party was "pure."

2: Wrinkle in Time 11.16.96. My favorite b-day party EVER.

1: right now. the culmination of all the great moments and the memory of
all the good times I've had is really giving me the warm fuzzies.

-m.

Received this from a friend...hope it hasn't been 
posted before.

Happy Holidays!
John

>
> Politically Correct Santa
>
> 'Twas the night before Christmas and Santa's a wreck ...
> How to live in a world that's politically correct?
> His workers no longer would answer to "Elves",
> "Vertically Challenged" they were calling themselves.
>
> And labor conditions at the north pole
> Were alleged by the union to stifle the soul.
> Four reindeer had vanished, without much propriety,
> Released to the wilds by the Humane Society.
>
> And equal employment had made it quite clear
> That Santa had better not use just reindeer.
> So Dancer and Donner, Comet and Cupid,
> Were replaced with 4 pigs, and you know that looked stupid!
>
> The runners had been removed from his sleigh;
> The ruts were termed dangerous by the E.P.A.
> And people had started to call for the cops
> When they heard sled noises on their roof tops.
>
> Second-hand smoke from his pipe had his workers quite frightened.
> His fur trimmed red suit was called "Unenlightened."
>
> And to show you the strangeness of life's ebbs and flows,
> Rudolf was suing over unauthorized use of his nose
> And had gone on Geraldo, in front of the nation,
> Demanding millions in over-due compensation.
>
> So, half of the reindeer were gone; and his wife,
> Who suddenly said she'd enough of this life,
> Joined a self-help group, packed, and left in a whiz,
> Demanding from now on her title was Ms.
>
> And as for the gifts, why, he'd ne'er had a notion
> That making a choice could cause such a commotion.
> Nothing of leather, nothing of fur,
> Which meant nothing for him.  And nothing for her.
>
> Nothing that might be construed to pollute.
> Nothing to aim.  Nothing to shoot.
> Nothing that clamored or made lots of noise.
> Nothing for just girls.  Or just for the boys.
>
> Nothing that claimed to be gender specific.
> Nothing that's warlike or non-pacific.
> No candy or sweets ... they were bad for the tooth.
> Nothing that seemed to embellish a truth.
>
> And fairy tales, while not yet forbidden,
> Were like Ken and Barbie, better off hidden.
> For they raised the hackles of those psychological
> Who claimed the only good gift was one ecological.
>
> No baseball, no football ... someone could get hurt;
> Besides, playing sports exposed kids to dirt.
> Dolls were said to be sexist, and should be passe;
> And Nintendo would rot your entire brains away.
>
> So Santa just stood there, disheveled, perplexed;
> He could not figure out what to do next.
> He tried to be merry, tried to be gay,
> But you've got to be careful with that word today.
>
> His sack was quite empty, limp to the ground;
> Nothing fully acceptable was to be found.
> Something special was needed, a gift that he might
> Give to all without angering the left or the right.
>
> A gift that would satisfy, with no indecision,
> Each group of people, every religion;
> Every ethnicity, every hue,
> Everyone, everywhere ... even you.
>
> So here is that gift, it's price beyond worth ...
> "May you and your loved ones enjoy peace on earth."
>
> (c) Harvey Ehrlich, 1992
>
> NOTICE: This poem is copyright 1992 by Harvey Ehrlich.  It is free to
>         distribute, without changes, as long as this notice remains
>         intact.  All follow-ups, requests, comments, questions,
>         distribution rights, etc. should be made to
>         mduhan@husc.harvard.edu.  Happy Holidays!!
>
>
>

Just recieved this and it's the first I'f seen this alert so hopefully it's
not been overkilled on the list.

 Subject:  Virus Alert
     Importance:  High

     If anyone receives mail entitled: PENPAL GREETINGS! please delete
     it WITHOUT reading it.  Below is a little explanation of the message, and

     what it would do to your PC if you were to read the message.  If you have

     any questions or concerns please contact  SAF-IA Info Office on 697-5059.

     This is a warning for all internet users - there is a dangerous virus
     propogating across the internet through an e-mail message entitled
     "PENPAL GREETINGS!".  DO NOT DOWNLOAD ANY MESSAGE ENTITLED "PENPAL
     GREETINGS!"

     This message appears to be a friendly letter asking you if you are
     interested in a penpal, but by the time you read this letter, it is too
     late.  The "trojan horse" virus will have already infected the boot sector
     of your hard drive, destroying all of the data present. It is a
     self-replicating virus, and once the message is read, it will AUTOMATICALLY

     forward itself to anyone who's e-mail address is present in YOUR mailbox!

     This virus will DESTROY your hard drive, and holds the potential to
     DESTROY the hard drive of anyone whose mail is in your inbox, and who's
     mail is in their inbox, and so on.  If this virus remains unchecked,
it has
     the potntial to do a great deal of DAMAGE to computer networks
     worldwide!!!!

     Please, delete the message entitled "PENPAL GREETINGS!" as soon as you see
     it!  And pass this message along to all of your friends and relatives,
     and the other readers of the newsgroups and mailing lists which you are on,

     so that they are not hurt by this dangerous virus!!!!






Tim (knucklehead)

TGARCI02@ccsmtp.farinon.harris.com wrote:
> 
>      ok, good points.
> 
>      but what does captain picard have to do with all this?  i mentioned mr
>      spock because he hosted a show that talked about sacred substances.
>      is picard an acid freak and you forgot to mention why?
> 
>      please explain.

didn't you see the finale of star trek the next generation... alternative 
realities are what DMT invokes... everything around us is a mass a 
energy... LSD strips it down to particle theory... you can reduce the 
world to molecules, and then fuck with your perception to paint it 
differently... or, if you just let the drug ride you (instead of 
vice-versa) your subconscious will paint it for you... on large doses, 
you can slip into wave probability theory... but the come-down usually 
confuses the information gained... DMT literally throws you in an 
alternate probable reality... that's why it seems so inhuman at first, 
then you realize thats why we're all here... to transmute realities... 
just like Picard... of course this can all be accomplished without 
drugs... in order for drugs to work, your brain has to be able to perform 
the same functions to start with... the ohm symbol is an abstraction of 
the original yin-yang which was a black circle with a white dot, a white 
circle with a black dot and a circle (representing the mu, or void from 
which all has come)... the little dot and wavy line above all of this is 
theorized as representing particle theory and wave probability theory... 
of course they didn't call it such, they had more of a poetic 
worldview... but they discovered what science has discovered in the last 
century thousands of years ago... compare the layout of the I Ching to 
DNA... and did you ever notice how the arms and legs on the dancing shiva 
are extended and coil around, not unlike a DNA helix?

shit to think about...

   biotechnological invention spawns viral induction...

> 
>        all co ming  back to me

> 
>          alchemy
> 


the alchemist

Precedence: bulk

You can't get a virus by reading an email message -- you have to run a
program.  The real virus here is that people waste bandwidth by sending
and resending the message.  Remember the "Good Times" virus?

Now if someone mails you a program as an attachment, and you decide to run
that program, all bets are off.  But your computer cannot be harmed simply
by reading mail.

	Sami

On Wed, 11 Dec 1996, knucklehead wrote:

> Just recieved this and it's the first I'f seen this alert so hopefully it's
> not been overkilled on the list.
> 
>  Subject:  Virus Alert
>      Importance:  High
> 
>      If anyone receives mail entitled: PENPAL GREETINGS! please delete

hi all,

just want to introduce myself and hopefully meet some of you at freaky
people. charity in october was my first rave, but i've been hitting one
almost every week since then. although i was a dj at kalx for a period of
my existence, the music didn't hit me until i was introduced to the
accessories associated with raving.

although i've only been on the list for only a couple of days, i think the
community isn't too atypical of the others i am a part of. you have your
periods of flaming and trivalities, but its got real substance as a
community.

i'll probably be a cocteau twins freak this friday, so say hi to me and
i'll speak gibberish...

ooze out and anyhow

ps hi to maly and minor minor if he's around....

First half of the year went kinda slow/bad for me, So most of my top ten 
has been in the past few months.. PLUS I think I'm losing my long-term 
memory (eek!) ANYWAY, Here's my top 10...

10) December 18th, Ed Rush and Dj Trace. If it goes off, it's definitely 
gotta be in my top 10. Heard (from a friend in NZ) Ed Rush is too much 
to handle!

9) 2o12 - although i ended up falling asleep for an hour or 2, i got to 
watch my goa-head friend dance for hours on end to psychedelic trance, 
and gained an ultimate respect for him :) plus the friendships i made 
there, the group hug at the end and the chai was just too good :)

8) Fantasy Island - because I brought my best friend to her first rave, 
danced next to a guy who brought a whole drumset in to play with the 
house (breakbeats manmade live! hehe!), running around filling 
waterbottles all night for people and watching the sun rise off the 
ocean with the bay bridge in the background.. beautiful

7) Lucky Charms. March 31 - not only my favorite cereal! :P :P :)

6) Famtasia - Meeting tons of friendly beautiful people, alot from the 
SFraves list, chilling in the ambient room and not falling asleep to 
ambient for once (hehe), jonathan's set making me dance on NO sleep :)

5) Rhythm and Sound - WENT OFF. 150 Folsom turned into a jungle haven. 
Being turned away at the Wrinkle in Time mapoint was a bummer, but this 
was a way to end the night on a phat junglist positive note. 

4) some sort of massive at Home Base on March 2nd, the night before my 
birthday, got so many birthday greetings and hugs it overwhelmed me! :) 

3) The second Audio Impact - Aint nuthin better than going off on some 
phat jungle sets with your friends for only $5 and having the bass 
rattle your soul! (GREAT SOUND SYSTEM! Gateway was it?) Stareyes and 
Fluxs' intelligent sets rocked my mind. :) YUMM!!!!!!

2) Halloween Tribal Massive - Listening to Dj Rap go off on the tables 
and losing my mind and soul in the music. And I can say she's as 
beautiful as the beats she drops. Also that night, Dieselboy dropping 
"wishing on a star". and walking in to "Code Red - Conquering Lion," a 
CLASSIC and one of my favorites. Great night, met some beautiful 
junglists, and introduced my friend to jungle, and left with a smile on 
my tear-stained face! :)

1)In general: hugging, smiling, loving, and meeting wonderful people. 
Finding a second family. Experiencing the ultimate love for music, 
particularly jungle/drumnbass. As my friend Paul put it, (and he puts it 
so right!) "Music is food for my soul, and people are food for my 
heart." Could anyone say it better? SMILES and HUGS to all of you, 
espscially those who have helped make these top 10 the most wonderful 
experiences of my life! I LOVE YOU ALL! :) 
See ya all at freaky people and/or audio impact! 
LAra
-- 
              (sk3)
      [ J U N G L I S T ]
. . . wishing on a star . . .

Yeah, while we're at it, let's invite all of the TV reporters and camera men to shoot 
it, so they can twist it even more!  No, really...

Dylan, u r so right on! Anybody can see this evil is at work around us right now. 
Urbana/Bloomington, IL has got the nicest vibe going and it's just starting (and that's 
why). There is little to no drug activity in this scene. As opposed to Chicago, where 
most of the bad vibes and attitudes (IMHO) are from the drugs and pushers who are 
trying to make a living by fucking over others. I will flat out say that anyone who is 
selling K, cocaine or herion is an asshole. Further, I am going to disassociate myself 
with all people who choose to associate with these creeps. Sadly, this includes a few 
freinds of mine, but they are going to have to decide where they stand, 'cause I know 
where I stand on this! ;-)

Just like standing up to the crap promoters who continue to rip us off with shitty 
"events", we have to stand up against these assholes and get them the hell out of our 
scene. They are messing it all up and worse yet, hurting our friends!

PLUR -> RAGE!

matter

"I'm a Sagitarrius, the most philosophical of all of the signs, but I don't believe in 
it. I think it's a buncha bullshit, myself." - James Douglas Morrison
