Ok, i guess i can come up with at least ten.....;P

10.Vision 2/10/96 The vibe was excellant, and I got to meet a lot of the
Dj's. I even got to drive Blake baxter around and get him a hotel room for
the night.. Which is cool i guess??:) i did get to pick his brains though
about how he became a dj!

9. Organic 2/17/96 Killer party also! Special moment: Sneak was playing the
Annie lennox Sweet Dreams Remix, and i jumped on top of the bar and started
shaking my ass! Never danced so hard in my life!!!:)

8.4/16/96 Basics Best party in my life! Met my best friend there! Had such
amazing experiences at that party!

7.4/6/96 the Gathering! Nothing to say except, HOLY SHIT! the love i felt at
that party was amazing!

6.4/13/96  Kundalini This party was the most spiritual event that has ever
happened to me in my life. i made a connection with someone that will last
forever!!!

5. All the sunsets, helping the crew when the party ended, seeing everyone
have a great time!! The awesome sunsets!!!

4.Spinning at Viberation in August! (the 17th?)

3. Spinning at both the BBQ and beats! 1+2! It was a dream come true!

2. 10/31/96 Spinning at Spirit! My first real rave!( All nighter) have a
killer time! Watching the crowd during a break in a song, everyone screaming,
and the beat came back in and the whole room just started jumping!!!

1. FAMTASIA 11/15/96 This was one of the best learning experiences in my
life! I have so much more respect for the promoters and people involved in
throwing a party! and playing for a packed house!!! I was on cloud nine!!!

Jonathan

sorry i have to make this eleven: being on Sfraves and meeting so many
wonderful people thru it! It has really changed my life! (Sounds like some
religous thing or something!)

I have to agree with Mike Migurski that there is no reason to get cynical
about 1997. There are way too many dynamic, energetic, and creative people
to allow for stagnation in the scene. I've been fortunate enough to be
friends with many of these people because there's nothing as satisfying as
watching people you care about do monumental things. These are the people
involved with Progress, Harmony, and Lepidoptera. I know for a fact that
these same people care enough to never let "it" turn into the nightmare
vision suggested above.

I use "it" because we have yet to see what it turns into and I'm DAMN
optimistic! This scene has been so good to me and my friends. I think we of
the North have less to fear than our Southern brethren in regards to
commercialization. I think Southern California is a good example of how
prolific, adaptable,  and resilient this scene is.

As For Memorable Events of 1996:

1)Harmony 3 year

2)Progress on 4/20

3)Evolution/Deharo- February

4)Bravo Co. E-Party(hands down)

5)A Wrinkle in Time

6)Harmony-February

7)Lepidoptera(OF COURSE!!!)

8)Spending a weekend with the Cocteau Twins in Charles Manson's old Mansion
off         the Haight and         being corrupted while I was
there!!!AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHH!!!!!!!!
9)VISUALS!VISUALS!VISUALS!VISUALS!VISUALS!VISUALS!VISUALS!VISUALS!VISUALS!

10)Being iebriated and stoned and seeing the TUNNEL all at the same time.

Ok--you can go.

We Are Not
Maly

hello bay area folks,

my name is Clinton, I live in Minnesota. and I thought 
i should let you know i am taking yet another vacation
 to san francisco after a nine month wait!

i was subbed to the sf list last april and march for
a while before coming to visit over spring break. i 
wonder if some of you remember me. well, here i am
listening in on the west coast conversation again.
i'll be in town january 4-10 and i am excitedly looking
for things to do and fun people to hang out with.

When i was in SF last, i had a blast at Mad at the Bahia
and at a party at the Berkeley Marina where i met some
of the nicest ppl in my life! I also played some gabber
on the epiphany of sound show on KZSU-Stanford.

Please help me enjoy this trip once again. I know i will
anyway, but it's so much more fun when you make new friends!

yours,
clinton

Subject: Re: penpal virus hoax...and a real virus at the same time

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


	I think there's a double urban legend: One about the good-times
virus, and another that its impossible.

	Actually, you can get a virus from email, in at least three different
ways:

	- running an encapsulated program (usually requires approval)

	- AOL has escape codes which can be activated by mail

	- some "intelligent terminals" of the early 80's also had dangerous
		escape codes, and some emulators may emulate them (although
		most manufacturers now know its a bad idea).

	However if you get one of the common DOS/WIN viruses, and havent
actually executed something you got in a message, its probably a coincidence.

Andrew

Strollin down Telegraph today I decided to do something I haven't in the 
longest time - pop into Wicked and Primal and pick up some flyers!  I am 
proud to say, as an arrogant Real Raver ;), that I haven't gone to a 
flyered party in forever.  So, I was wondering what wuz up in the land of 
the glossy 4-color...

New Year's Eve
in addition to the infamous CW (the flier is beyond description), Spundae 
and Origin are throwing parties.

Spundae - Laurent Garnier from France, John Howard, Speedy from Vegas, 
and 14 other Spundae regulars.  (415) 974-9389
A club it may be, but their special parties are often very good!

Origin - (lookin' like a UG next to CW!)
Check this out - Minor Minor, Polywog (and others) and Dubtribe and 
Beyond Race LIVE.  (415) 675-5605

Saw a few fliers I didn't bother to pick up (why waste trees?) but 
upcoming are Kundalini, a Ghosttribe production (forgot the name), 
Gathering 5-Year, All in the Family, sumpin called "Acid Breaks" and 
sumpin else called "Candyland".

Things are the same in flyer-land.  Bright colors and cartoon mushrooms.

I also saw an old flyer (Thanksgiving) for Thurzdaze.  This used to be a $5 
bi-weekly 
with RESIDENTS DJ Dan and DRC - is it still goin on??  Or was this a 
one-time only party?

Love, Conservation,
and the Supa-Dupa Underground -
Word of Mouth Parties Rule!

N

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Dec 11 16:33:58 1996

	(Smail3.1.29.1 #3) id m0vXz95-000DGgC; Wed, 11 Dec 96 16:37 PST
Date: Wed, 11 Dec 1996 16:37:03 -0800 (PST)
From: Dave Smith <nazarite@addicted.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: penpal virus hoax...and a real virus at the same time
In-Reply-To: <9612111608.aa02189@andrewk.pdev.sco.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.3.91.961211163506.17252A-100000@addicted.addicted.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

1.) Running an encapsulated program you have received from a group is DUMB.
2.) Escape codes can easily be displayed by any ANSI supported system 
that can reprogram your keyboard.  Its always fun to hit "d" and have a 
bunch of stuff including echo y | del *.* pump out on you.

Other than the reprogrammed keyboard it is not possible for you to obtain 
a virus by reading your mail.

=============-------------------=============
      Dave Smith nazarite@addicted.com
===============---------------===============

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Dec 11 16:44:55 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id QAA16389; Wed, 11 Dec 1996 16:44:55 -0800 (PST)
Received: from wired.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with ESMTP id QAA16380; Wed, 11 Dec 1996 16:44:51 -0800 (PST)
Received: from [204.62.132.174] (wbi2.hotwired.com [204.62.132.174]) by wired.com (8.7.6/8.7.3) with SMTP id QAA29237; Wed, 11 Dec 1996 16:44:54 -0800 (PST)
Date: Wed, 11 Dec 1996 16:44:54 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <v02140b01aed48e968faa@[204.62.132.174]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: Maly <malyly@uclink4.berkeley.edu>
From: rawnsley@hotwired.com (Andrew Rawnsley)
Subject: Re: State of Scene
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>I have to agree with Mike Migurski that there is no reason to get cynical
>about 1997. There are way too many dynamic, energetic, and creative people
>to allow for stagnation in the scene. I've been fortunate enough to be
>friends with many of these people because there's nothing as satisfying as
>watching people you care about do monumental things. These are the people
>involved with Progress, Harmony, and Lepidoptera. I know for a fact that
>these same people care enough to never let "it" turn into the nightmare
>vision suggested above.
>
>I use "it" because we have yet to see what it turns into and I'm DAMN
>optimistic! This scene has been so good to me and my friends. I think we of
>the North have less to fear than our Southern brethren in regards to
>commercialization. I think Southern California is a good example of how
>prolific, adaptable,  and resilient this scene is.
>

        My comments were more in relation to the scene in general, as a
whole in the US. I agree that there are plenty of good people involved with
the local scene. However from my perspective as one of editors of XLR8R, I
get to see and hear alot of stuff that goes on "behind the scenes" of the
parties, and folks it ain't pretty. PLUR is something very much talked
about, but when it comes down to the nitty gritty of putting on events, it
is VERY political, and egos and money enter into the picture way too much.
It's almost as if the more cool PC talk gets used to promote an event, the
more phoney those sentiments are. Let's face it, if you really are throwing
a solid, underground and spiritual vibey event, then you don't need to let
everyone know about it. They'll figure it out for themselves.
        As for me, I'm finding that the connection and vibe I used to find
at parties happens less and less, and therefore I go out hardly at all.
Maybe I'm cynical, maybe I'm just really picky. I don't know. I DO know
that the underground takes care of itself, and that it will change as the
people and parties change. IMO, DIVERSITY is the key to pushing the
underground forward, not more blinkered categorization and single genre
parties, which seems to be the norm everywhere, whether it's House, Techno,
Trance or Jungle. Hearing different music at a party is GOOD. Same stuff
all night is BORING. Raving was supposed to mean having an open mind.
Diversity of music, diversity of people.
         Unfortunately I think that my fears about commercialization and
losing of "rave" values is already with us. Most of the "nightmare vision"
I mentioned already happens, I just exaggerated them to make them even more
ridiculous.             Here's a musical example. Last year at this time
the quality of record releases in all genres was outstanding. This year
sadly the majority of music is  derivative, uninspired and frankly pretty
dull. Perhaps 2 out of 10 records is something worth playing. (I am VERY
picky, but my standards haven't changed that much since last year...)
        A case in point is jungle/drum and bass, which in the start of '96
was simply outstanding. Just about every record I heard was amazing. Since
the genre's acceptance and commercial success in the UK, the quality of
records has decreased to the point where I might buy one jungle record a
week. There is still solid underground music out there, you just have to
search harder to find it. Similarly there are still good underground
parties going on, they're just less frequent.
         RAVE IS DEAD! Like Punk, Rave was more an attitude than a style,
and also like Punk it will take 20 years till most people realize.
        THINK about WHY you're raving and the underground will take care of
itself.

Respect
Andrew

        *****************************************************
        WAXING LYRICAL 'BOUT 1971...THE HANGOVER OF THE '60s.
        *****************************************************

friends and family... of course, when people get together for teh right 
reasons, amazing things happen...

gateway 4:20 party... what a treet

WOMO... see friends and family

Lepidoptera... the next generation taking their first steps, and they got 
the right idea.

Goa Gil at CZ, Berkeley... all my friends, non stop goa, amazingly 
beautiful decor, and a one way ticket to outer space =)

Togetherment... again, all my friends piled into one apartment - i think 
were in heaven, man !

Marcy's and Wayne's pad... for those calmer evenings, nothing like being 
among friends  -  what a grand view of SF.

bbq II... great food, good friends, and a shitload of FnF tix...

St. jon divine rhythm society... i had never planned on going, but due to 
two good friends who got me to go, ended up having an amazing experience.

Something Special... had an amazing time being part of something that 
went so well, learned a helluva lot of things.

and finally: 2o12... working with some of my best friends to do something 
positive =)


oh, yeah, how could i forget:

diverse subject matter) and presentation (much nicer looking with better
paper and more color.) Hope everyone digs it. Let me know what you think.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Dec 11 19:22:42 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id TAA00955; Wed, 11 Dec 1996 19:22:42 -0800 (PST)
Received: from boris.ucdavis.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with ESMTP id TAA00946; Wed, 11 Dec 1996 19:22:38 -0800 (PST)
Received: from localhost by boris.ucdavis.edu (8.8.3/UCD3.7.3)
	id TAA25301; Wed, 11 Dec 1996 19:22:44 -0800 (PST)
Date: Wed, 11 Dec 1996 19:22:43 -0800 (PST)
From: Uncle Noah <napodaca@ucdavis.edu>
X-Sender: ez031733@boris.ucdavis.edu
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: top 10 of 1996
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.88.9612111652.A23439-0100000@svpal.svpal.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.3.95.961211191012.19715H-100000@boris.ucdavis.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


what a great topic!
okay:
10) When the program director of KDVS said, when asked about techno on
KDVS at a new DJ training session, "Well, we like the ambient stuff, but
that T99 stuff that Noah plays:  we don't like that!"

9)  A house party at Jeyson's that lasted unitl about 2.30am and DJ
Marcone was spinning and a woman got up and danced in nothing but a
floor-length blonde wig and velvet undies.

8)  Q: A Celebration of Spring -- a party I tried to throw for my dorm
that wound up being me and DJ Marcone spinning rekkids in Oxford Circle
Park in Davis until the amplified sound permit went bad at like 11pm

7)  A Family Affair (Davis) -- a small party at the domes with lots of
friends...  the first time I took MDMA...  :)  really a change in my life,
I tell ya!

6)  One of my KDVS shows where I was so in the mix that I didn't answer
the phone because I forgot to look at the flashing light that signals an
incoming call.. when I finally answered, it was DJ Jericho and he said,
"Jesus Christ, Noah!  I've been sitting here for a half hour!"

5)  Sending out my Midsummer '96 tape to about a dozen folks who didn't
know it was coming.  :)

4)  Getting my diploma.  I had to go to the post office and sign for it
and everything!  I got it out and danced right there in the middle of the
post office.  Everyone thought I was a nut.  They were right.  :)

3)  Elevation II (SoCal-Raves party):  Jesus... what an event.  The start
of a three week high.  I met so many great people and was given the nicest
little knitted thingy that I wound up showing to Toby at the cabin party,
and it turns out his friend made it!

2)  SFRAVES Cabin Party III:  That weekend was so much fun!  It was so
nice to meet so many wonderful people and it had been so long since I had
spun for anybody besides my tape deck that I didn't know what to expect.
But it was _wonderful_.  I made great friends, got to see Joey get loose
and I even got to drive a rental car that was purple!

1)  Re-joining SFRAVES:  At first I just intended to stay on to read cabin
chatter and then unsub again, but I am glad I've stayed.  Even with the
bullshit, I still have much love for all of you and I love our scene!

So that's what I think
:)
PLUR!

technological text styles floating over a swirly multicolored backdrop, but
what I like is that it manages to look really good in blacklight... it
glows well.  Intentional or not, I don't know, but it's very cool.  I'll
admire it, though I don't think I'll be paying the show a visit.

Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>[ to sfraves ]
>
> Let me propose the following -
>
>1. Those who go to underground raves in our area ( ie not flyered or posted
>  on SFRaves ), please review them on SFRaves. Please include "how-to"
>  details as well as the usual "the vibe was HUGE!!!/no vibe AT ALL!!!"
>  comments.
>
>   I think this would be of special benefit to everyone, and may encourage
>  folks here on SFRaves to hold their own! Also to get away from the
>  "I paid my ticket, now show me a good time" concert mentality.

I am against this 100%.  Why?  Simply put, I think people need to grow
their relationships outside of the list.  Get to know some pople by going
to other events that are not necessarily SFR based.  Make some friends, get
invited.  I think it is as easy as that.  By providing reviews I think it
takes away from the magic, since I think UG's are very, very personal
events.  As for how-to's , I think I just gave THE formula for success.
It's not about being elite, it's about expanding your horizons, getting
out, and making friends, outside the list.

>
>2. We others on SFRaves who weren't in on the "special elite super secret
>  attendee list" solemnly PROMISE PROMISE PROMISE not to bug the poster
>  of the review with whiny requests for invitations to the "next one".
>
>   Given that a lot of the folks in SFRaves use SFRaves to learn about
>  raves, not how to do one, this may be an impossible request. Maybe
>  a special "anonymizer" email address that would strip off the sender's
>  email address befroe sending off to SFRaves?
>
> What do you folks think?
>
> Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

Not to be negative, but I am not down with the 1-2-3 cookbook of getting
into undergrounds.  To me it is the same thing that happened to raves in
teh first place.  At once intimate, now wholly exposed.  The "special"
quality is lost in the mass of people.  Nope, I think UG should be just
that.  Word of mouth or phone, not word of computer.  I think posting
reviews would just fuel the already annoying cries of elitist, and just
prove to be a "I'm in, you're not", that ain't necessarily right, and that
is not the spirit of UG, IMO.

Just my .02 worth.  I'm keeping my mouth shut.  To me UG is way to special
to "give" away.

Peace,
John

P.S.  SFR is pretty UG itself BTW.  How many people outside the list w/o
computers even know we exists.  I would call that special in it's own right.

>         Unfortunately I think that my fears about commercialization and
>losing of "rave" values is already with us. Most of the "nightmare vision"
>I mentioned already happens, I just exaggerated them to make them even more
>ridiculous.             Here's a musical example. Last year at this time
>the quality of record releases in all genres was outstanding. This year
>sadly the majority of music is  derivative, uninspired and frankly pretty
>dull. Perhaps 2 out of 10 records is something worth playing. (I am VERY
>picky, but my standards haven't changed that much since last year...)
>        A case in point is jungle/drum and bass, which in the start of '96
>was simply outstanding. Just about every record I heard was amazing. Since
>the genre's acceptance and commercial success in the UK, the quality of
>records has decreased to the point where I might buy one jungle record a
>week. There is still solid underground music out there, you just have to
>search harder to find it. Similarly there are still good underground
>parties going on, they're just less frequent.
>         RAVE IS DEAD! Like Punk, Rave was more an attitude than a style,
>and also like Punk it will take 20 years till most people realize.
>        THINK about WHY you're raving and the underground will take care of
>itself.
>
>Respect
>Andrew
>
>        *****************************************************
>        WAXING LYRICAL 'BOUT 1971...THE HANGOVER OF THE '60s.
>        *****************************************************

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Dec 11 22:26:50 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id WAA13520; Wed, 11 Dec 1996 22:26:50 -0800 (PST)
Received: from netcom13.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with SMTP id WAA13457; Wed, 11 Dec 1996 22:26:35 -0800 (PST)
Received: from DialupEudora (jsl@localhost.netcom.com [127.0.0.1]) by netcom13.netcom.com (8.6.13/Netcom)
	id WAA00841; Wed, 11 Dec 1996 22:26:40 -0800
Date: Wed, 11 Dec 1996 22:26:40 -0800
X-Sender: jsl@localhost
Message-Id: <v03007805aed4de4c9ef1@DialupEudora>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: "John S. Lee" <jsl@netcom.com>
Subject: Neils & Jsl...I like us, and I STILL like you too!
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I really don't know why many of you have jumped on Neils and my shit.  I
can understand that many of you are upset that we've "ruined your vibe".
By now, I fully expect to be in many peoples kill file.  But I also know
that I am still on many people non-kill list.  The attacks on my brother
Neils have been even more aggregious.  Suprisingly, Adder has probalby not
been attacked publicly and it was HE and I who got into words.  Neils came
to my defense when many of you wanted to jump in and chime negative on me.
I guess in a certain way many were supporting Adder.  Hmmm...interesting.
In any case, I find the attacks on my brother distateful and wrong.

My man, and I am PROUD to call him my man, is a proud brother, who knows
plenty about history and could teach many of you quite a few lessons.  Not
only of history but of life.  Now some of you will say that "How do you
know that he has anything to show me...you don't know my life!".  Or don't
I?  If many of you can glean from MY posts that I am some angry man, you
can only imagine what I see from my view.  I wont enumerate it, just think
about it.  Neils has many experiences, and many views.  He is by far not so
one sided, and is a very fair person.  Like me, he jumps when he gets a
slight smell of those who are or who condone injustice.  I think, NO I
KNOW, it has something to do with his family and his life.  Much like
myself we have both felt the sting of injustice first hand.  It is not, as
it seems  for many of you, an excerise of academics.

Speaking for myself, I see the world as both good and ugly.  The good is
sometime hard to find through all the shit.  Yeah, we can rave, but there
are children who are starving, fighting wars, and being raped.  I can take
all the E and hug a teddy bear, and give out candy to my hearts content,
and I will ALWAYS know that no matter how good life is for me, for someone
else it is shit.  Why do I care?  Becuase I am raising a child, and
children matter to me.  SOmeone said to me, and I paraphrase, "..would you
want to ruin your childs view of wonder, with what could be called the ugly
truth, ruining the wonder." .  Since my son is Jewish and Bi-Racial, I
cannot let him walk this earth thinking that pevery person will perceive
him as an equal.  That would do him a disservice.  That is my world, and it
is a very, very real one.  Ask any jellybean ;(.

For all the negative you might see, there is a positive side to both Neils
and I.  It might require some work on your and OUR part to find it, but it
is there.  I used to fight viciously with Neils, read the archives.  But in
the end, we found we had more in common than difference, now I consider him
a strong brother, my man.  We BOTH had to work at it.  If you beleive in
all this religion you spout,all this PLUR, then you'll do the same.  If you
only look for the negative, then you will reap what you sow.

Any more negativity about Neils or I should be directed in private where it
can be handled properly.  Remember, pimp slaps are given at NO EXTRA
CHARGE! ;)

Now, lighten up...let's talk about UG's.  I'll whoop your butts in private,
or you can take it to my face.  That is MUCH better to me anyway.

Peace out, now time to answer all that private e-mail,
John

Booty, booty, booty!

Date: Wed, 11 Dec 96 22:41:52 PST
From: "Ciaran OHara" <ciaran.ohara@CCMAIL.AirTouch.COM>

Subject: PLUR, raving

     Firstly, lets all be honest with ourselves : "Raving" in this or any 
     context basically means dancing to electronic music under the 
     influence of ecstacy or some other libido reducing, tactile 
     sensation-increasing empathogen.
     
     Do you know what impresses the shit out of me about dance culture ?
     
     Scantily clad beautiful girls (or boys) giving you smiles that melt 
     your heart.
     
     Tough lads that used to pick fights hugging each other and not being 
     worried about looking like a sissy.
     
     Those same guys that are the toughest heads in my hometown shaking my 
     hand and being *scarily* cheerful.
     
     Straights and gays dancing together to pumping toooons.
     
     Not having to bother with that whole pain in the ass chat up line 
     bullshit routine. If you chill, act natural, hang out the beautiful 
     people will come to you.
     
     Girls not having to listen to tired old chat-up lines.
     
     Being able to forget about your pains and troubles in the real world.
     
     Kicking it with your brother, your sister and feeling pure fucking 
     love so strong you don't even need to say it.
     
     Catholics and Prods coming together in Northern Ireland, nationalist 
     tattoes/union jack tattoes exposed and going for it.
     
     Talking to complete strangers and realising that the more you are your 
     own person the more people will like and respect you for being that 
     person.
     
     
     Partying hard like my friend Randolph to embrace what is left of life.
     
     
     Btw folks, you can take what you learn while under the influence and 
     bring it into your everyday life. After a while you may even attend 
     the occasional party sober and still have a good time. If I can do it 
     anyone can...

Most undergrounds are just that, Undergrounds.  They are not about elitism, but they are about being
connected, and I'm not talking about 28.8.  They're about expanding your horizons, a smile on the dance floor.
Surrendering into the now, and not having a job (or not caring that you have a job) to go to in the morning.
Mostly they are about being in the Tao.  I was out last saturday with a new friend who just came to visit from
Austin. Unfortunately the party fare seemed pretty lame, There was lovegarage. a full on deep house groove but
the crowd is way to clubby and pretentious (still the music is killer).  We first tried to go to the burning man
X-mas thing but discovered that that was Sunday not Saturday, still it was fun to crash some fashion show at the Somar gallery.  I
stepped outside LoveWorks to make a phone call and someone jumped out of a car and handed me a flyer for
Anarchest's Disco!! Donavan's underground being held in the mission, full on with Ernie Munson playing! (I first
achieved Trance at the hands of Ernie, at the Scandia Russian River Rave of 92.  Leave it to donavan to not decide to have
a party till thursday, and have the venue packed saturday night so that you couldn't get in. And indeed a UG it was.
Full on crackerjackin on the dance floor, E-piles, everything. Only problem was it was way too hot!, Garth was just
getting ready to spin (around 5 am) when the po-pos came and turned off the music.

Actually, Gil *can* beatmatch but the style of music he favors doesn't
generally seem to require it.  I think of him more as a "textures" DJ
than a "groove" DJ.  He has an uncanny ability to build up the energy
within a set.  That's almost the rarest quality of all.  Haven't seen
him spin for a while, but the first time was maybe mid-1992 at a small
party where the lineup was Gil, Carlos and Darwin Chambre (that's how
they spelled it then) playing live.  Now *that* was variety!

phred

No, sigh.  No email message can cause a boot sector virus (what KIND?
Mac? PC? Sun? Linux? -- of course these so-called "alerts" never say).

For those who aren't aware, the comp.virus newsgroup on Usenet continues
to be an excellent resource for absolutely up-to-the-minute information
about viruses of all types (boot sector, "Trojan horses," macro viruses,
polymorphics, etc.).  And there are many Web sites devoted to this issue.

phred

 Well, I'm just recently finished with finals and can now focus on

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: knucklehead@club.net (knucklehead)
Subject: 10 best of 96
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Will these are not necessarily the best experience, but also best times,
feelings of 96 that I remember. There are several others, but I would be
listing them for days.

10. Viberation: My first party I spun at. Thought every mix sucked, but I
was told I did good. Too nervous though, and I guess you get over that
after awhile.

9. Spinning for 2 1/2 to 3 hours at Wayne old Loft for about 7-10 people.
Sitting next to Burger Kings roommate Brad, after every mix we'd look at
each other and go "Damn that was good" and then when I was done standing up
and the people sitting down on the floor said it was an awesome set. Great
Feeling.

8. Many trips to Sacramento with a case of beer and going to BioJeff house
to spin with him and listen to him spin. Trying to either trade a record or
have him make a mixed tape. Some of the best sets are done like that. Also
going to see a movie and having lunch with Amy S. and Melanie.

7. 2012

6. Sunsets/Sunset Boat partys

5. Cooking a shit load of lasagna for about 10+ people at Waynes old Loft
right before going out to a party. I love cooking for people.

4. WOMO, Now that was a party.

3. All of the Harmony parties I helped out with and went to.

2. All the FnF parties.

1. Throwing the BBQ & BEATS daytime parties. Even the one in the rain.

And of course meeting everyone I know in the "rave" scene the past two
years. All you guys and gals will never know how much you really mean to
me. I've never had a better time in my life, then I've been having the past
two years since I've been out of Navy.


Tim (knucklehead)

--
     
Welcome to the sfraves mailing list!
     
Please save this message for future reference.  Thank you.
     
If you ever want to remove yourself from this mailing list, 
send the following command in email to 
<sfraves-request@hyperreal.com>:
     
    unsubscribe
     
Or you can send mail to <majordomo@hyperreal.com> with the following 
command in the body of your email message:
     
    unsubscribe sfraves TGARCI02@ccsmtp.farinon.harris.com
     
 Here's the general information for the list you've subscribed to, 
 in case you don't already have it:
     
*******************************************************************************
     
        Welcome to the San Fransisco/Bay Area RAVE mailing list!
     
        NOTE:  This is a very high volume mailing list, consisting 
        mainly of topics of interest to those who live in the Bay 
        Area or plan to visit here.  Many new subscribers find the 
        traffic level too high to handle.  If you decide to unsub- 
        scribe, PLEASE send your message NOT to sfraves, but rather 
        to sfraves-request@hyperreal.com, so your unsubscribe 
        message doesn't appear in everybody's mailbox.  Thanx.
     
*******************************************************************************
     
     
                       ***PLEASE READ THIS***
     
        This mailing list is dedicated to discussion involving the
rave/ underground club/techno scene now developing here in the Bay 
Area. But first, a little history....
     
        I moved up here from LA in the August of '91, fresh from being
heavily involved in the techno scene there for a couple of years.  I 
loved the scene down there, from breaking into aircraft hangers on a 
particular New Year's Eve, to sliding down a water slide at 2 in the 
morning, to picking up dozens of flyers with the most gorgeous artwork 
on them, to hitting all the local techno record stores and spending my 
life savings on compilation CD's, to having my mind twisted by the DJ 
work of Doc Martin, Barry Weaver, and count- less more..... and then 
when I moved up here to school, it was like culture shock to me - it 
was hard finding out about events, about clubs where the music wasn't 
Top 40 drivel, where there wasn't an age limit, etc.  But, I started 
picking up some flyers, meeting other people up here who knew about 
such-and such going on, going to rave-style concerts (The Orb was 
GREAT), and I came to realize that even though the scene wasn't as big 
up here, there was a much greater sense of _community_. By that I mean, 
people going to these parties and meeting lots of other people, all 
sharing a love for the music and the atmosphere; I guess the best way 
to descibe it is that it's very social, without being "cliquey" or 
exclusionary. And the best part of all is - the ravers go for the love 
of the music, much more so than for the drugs. Down south I was 
beginning to wonder whether the scene would degenerate into an excuse 
for teenagers to inhale nitrous or take X. The scene up here has 
restored my confidence in the future of this music, and of the culture 
that has developed around it.
     
        Well, that's my sentimental view of it all. Now for the meat
of the matter - the list. I want to promote the close-knit feeling of 
the scene up here by providing a forum for discussion about it. I knew 
from postings to the machester list as well as ba.music and 
rec.music.industrial that there must be quite a few people online in 
the Bay Area who were itching for some way to talk about the scene 
without annoying manc-list subscribers in Australia or USENET sites in 
Iceland. Well, here it is.
     
        Appropriate topics include: announcements of upcoming events;
reviews of previous shows/DJ's/new records, etc; discussion about 
SF-related and rave- culture-related topics, like smart drinks; 
discussion about rave-related stories on TV/in the newspaper, etc. 
Ideally we should try and stay away from, "Hey, did you catch that 
Orbital song on "Beverly Hills 90210" last week?"  stuff, or from 
over-generalizing ourselves: "Can Depeche Mode be considered "techno"? 
", etc. But, other than that, I want it to be pretty free form. The 
list should _not_ be about rave scenes in other parts of the world; an 
occasional post about a huge megaevent in LA or a monthly report on the 
scene in other cities might be okay, but remember there was a reason 
this is called SFRaves; if you want to start a mailing list for your 
area, ask your sysadmin, as that was all I had to do. If that fails, 
there's alt.raves, the USENET newsgroup, where you can post just about 
anything you want.
     
        This is how most of you got on this list:  you sent a message
to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
     
subscribe sfraves
     
in it.  Cool, perfect.  now, if you want off, you send the following 
message:
     
unsubscribe sfraves
     
And if you just want Derek Chung's weekly calendar, you can send
     
unsubscribe sfraves
subscribe sfraves-calendar
     
It's that easy :)
     
        Normal etiquette is to wait around 2 weeks or more before you
start posting anything; that ensures that you don't tread on old 
ground and that you have a reasonably good idea of the mindset of we 
who have been here for months. Another piece of bad etiquette that 
holds for most mailing lists on the net is to use the list to 
blatantly advertise or promote yourself; you can post info about where 
to buy smart drinks, for example, as a satisfied third party, but 
selling your own wares is somewhat verboten.
     
        Even though this list is geared to the Bay Area, anyone is
welcome to join. (Though you might get a little frustrated at being so 
far away!) As long as your comments stay within the context set above, 
no problem. I wouldn't mind if Mr. Ashdown wanted to post a review of 
the next rave he holds there in Utah :-).
     
        Please bear in mind that you are entering a virtual community;
that the people here exhibit a friendliness and familiarity with each 
other, and while criticism of posts is not discouraged, please treat 
other people's posts with the same respect you'd want yours treated.
     
        SFRaves itself has a great history - we've been up and running
since February, and since then we held a rave-nic in May (a picnic in 
the Oakland Hills where everyone brought food, I brought a sound 
system, a permit was obtained, and the Hardkisses and several sfravers 
DJ'd), as well as a full- out rave on a beach in Santa Cruz in August 
(called Connection, with Carlos, Dutch, Moonpup, SFRaver Jon Drukman, 
and others, lasted until 9 in the morning, free w/donations, and people 
called it the best rave they'd ever been too).  There may be references 
to past events and such... you can try mailing me first if you have 
what might be a "newbie" question (or I might say it's something you 
could ask the list).
     
        There is now an FTP/gopher/WWW archive installed on this
machine - that means, if you have direct Internet access, you can
     
1) do anonymous ftp to hyperreal.com and pick up any and all
files in the sfraves directory (the ambient directory is pretty cool too).
     
2) access it via gopher, i.e. "gopher hyperreal.com"
     
and the best, 
     
3) point your WWW browser to http://hyperreal.com/
     
There should be an up-to-the-minute calendar in there; if you have 
info on events that aren't listed, send me your info and I'll add it. 
If you have any other files you think would be appropriate, put them 
(via anonymous FTP only) in /incoming.  In the /sfraves directory 
there are also archived posts since March 1992, the month we started.
     
        The list's home was originally on a machine here at Berkeley
called Petrus - that machine was transferred to a different 
department, so I had to move the list to the OCF. However, the list 
was far too big for the OCF's mail handler to deal with, so it was 
moved to Stanford. Finally, in July of 1994, Stanford wanted their 
machine back, so I scrounged together some money and borrowed some 
bandwidth and put hyperreal.com online as a home for this culture we 
suddenly had.  Still, with over 6000 messages a day going through due 
to sfraves, there may be problems every now and then (multiple copies 
of messages, etc.) If everyone keep their cool and doesn't worry about 
it, it'll be fine. I read the group every day, so I see problems as 
they're happening.
     
        So, enjoy! For new subscriptions, write to sfraves-request at
the same address, and I'll be sure and respond promptly. And if you 
have a problem with a particular post, write to owner-sfraves (that's 
me, too!), and I'll look into it. Remember, this is _our_ list, so 
make it great!
     
        Love, happiness, peace, and respect,
     
     
        Brian
     
        brian@hyperreal.com

In no particular order:

1.  The Chai hut at Burning Man.

2.  Spinning for six hours Friday night in the Chai hut at Burning Man.

3.  Strapping huge stalks of bamboo from my back yard to a ski rack on top
of my car, driving with them sticking out like antlers out in front of my
car and then setting them up like a bamboo forest at Burning Man.  The
"Bamboo Family!!" clanking our respective sticks of bamboo together on the
night of burn, then spearing the fallen BM.

4.  The rainbow out side FnF in the morning.

5.  All the live shows we were fortunate enough to play.

6.  The last to Tahoe cabin trips.

7.  My kind Lama after I asked him what I might do to purify my self of some
stuff I wasn't happy with anymore, requesting that I do what turned out to
be three to four times the amount of meditation per day than I was
previously doing.  I said "Lama I don't know if I can," and with out
hesitation he said "I think you can if you try."  He was right :)

8.  The Light camping party by the stream.  Hanging out with 20 or so
beautiful men, women and children as well as animals, all naked and natural
down stream at the swimming hole.  The warm feeling of love I felt in seeing
a beautiful couple naked, on the grass under a tree taking the braids out of
the womens hair.  A very primal feeling watching such a grooming ritual.  It
was just beautiful.

9.  Playing music at RAW and meeting Cami, Andy, John and several other
sfraves because of it.  Working there for food.  Getting paid for playing
there with a huge box of organic fruit.

10. Taking a trip to Salt Lake City to visit a friend and go camping in the
Rockies.  Seeing Meat Beat Manifesto who just happened to be playing in Salt
Lake while I was there.  Going out to dinner and while on our way to one
place, stopping suddenly at an Indian resteraunt and deciding to go
there.....and while there, meeting a Rinpoche (high Lama) from Tibet, being
blessed and reminded of the importance of compassion for all sentient beings.

Hi,

This is Thomas, SDream's hamsta.  I regret to inform you that SDream met
with a horrible fate: he has stopped partying.  Yes, sad, but true. 
See, it seems that there was this picture taken of him being smooched by
a girl.  The smooch itself wasn't a big deal, but it was a very hot and
humid rave, and neither were wearing shirts. Said picture found it's way
into his girlfriend's hands.  His girlfriend had only having been to a
couple of parties with SDream, both of which were not so hot that people
were shedding clothing, before she decided that raving was not her gig. 
She flipped.  To head off any possible break-up, SDream had to swear off
raving.  The hamstas helped him pack up his funky hats, his rave album,
his flyers, etc., and put them in a large box up in his closet.  Now he
listens to his tapes and wishes...  He values his relationship with his
girlfriend very much, and would rather she didn't feel threatened, so he
stays away from the parties.

Rumor has it though that she has seen a difference in his demeanor since
then (he seems older?) and may be pressuring him to go to one again, so
who knows?  

Me and the other hamstas are still throwing raves in SDream's study, but
we're a little more underground about it.  We had too many uninvited,
non-vibey squirrels showing up.  Our rave scene goes through phases that
way.  Most squirrels are cool, but you get these ones that just put out
a scarey, tough-rat vibe.  Some rodents just don't get it...  And we
always invite SDream.  Sometimes he comes in and dances, and you can
tell he really misses it.

Anyway, for those of you who wonder what happened to SDream and why he
doesn't show up anymore, that's why.  He raved his brains out for a
year, but had to make a sacrifice for someone he really cares about.

Thanks for your time,

Thomas Covenant Hamsta, esq.

On Wed, 11 Dec 1996, Ann Elizabeth Loraine wrote:

> By the way..how does one write a "killfile?"  I've always been slightly
> curious about this.  
> 

I thought this might be of public interest so I am posting it publicly.

I use a package called procmail available on most UNIX platforms. If you
are using a UNIX shell and have procmail available create a file called
.forward in your home directory like:

"|IFS=` `&&exec /usr/local/bin/procmail -f-||exit 75 blkadder"

and replace blkadder with your user name. The placement of the quotation
marks is crucial. Also the procmail program may not be in
/usr/local/bin/procmail. You can find out where it is on most platforms by
doing a "which procmail" or "whereis procmail" which should tell you where
it is located, and is what you would replace the /usr/local/bin/procmail
statement above with.

Then, create a file named .procmailrc in your home directory like:

# .procmailrc

PATH=/usr/bin:/usr/local/bin
MAILDIR=$HOME/mail
LOGFILE=$HOME/log
SHELL=/bin/csh

:0:
* ^Sender:.*sfraves
* ^From:.*Foo Bar
/dev/null


where Foo Bar is the name of the person who you do not wish to receive
mail from. The beautiful thing about this is that you never see the mail,
it just silently goes away. 

Procmail can do a lot more than this, but this is the easiest way to
implement a killfile with it.

If you are using a PPP account, using something like Eudora Pro is
probably your best bet. It is much easier to set up as opposed to all this
UNIX-weenie stuff.

                                        Black Adder

Subject: Re: Dumb Drugs (was Re: Special K)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     
     Well...
     
     There was a time when cocaine was the drug you did casually, and acid 
     and pot were for fuckups (and the BeeGees were the b*o*m*b).  Now it's 
     cocaine that's for fuckups, while some of my partying friends do LSD 
     somewhat regularly.  If somebody wants to put something in their body, 
     let em.  I don't care if it's cocaine, ketamine or John Holmes.  
     Personal liberty is weird that way.  It's not for me to decide what is 
     right for you.  The safest drug tends to be going sober, but it's not 
     for everyone all the time.
     
     As for the scene, I think it's a good general rule to consider raving 
     as "going out".  Don't do large amounts of GHB or get piss drunk, 
     don't use dissociatives at parties that might get busted because 
     passed out, immobile, incoherent people suck in that circumstance.  
     But in your own home... shoot all the smack, smoke all the crack you 
     want.  Just don't croak or get sick... we like you and we'd hate to 
     read about you in the paper.
     
     Determining which drugs should and shouldn't be okay is about as fair 
     as deciding which people should be tried as witches in early Salem.
     
     I think we should work on enforcing laws that punish harmful 
     behaviors, not alternative lifestyles.  Perhaps if all drugs were 
     legal we could address some of the real problems.  It would be really 
     hard to have to steal for drugs if they were cheaper, which they could 
     be if they were legal.  Drug dealers wouldn't have turf wars, because 
     they'd have no money except what they make from pimpin and stealin, 
     and nobody supports their pimp or their fence like they do their drug 
     dealer.
     
     But the argument goes on...
     
     Peace,
     AndyW


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Dec 12 10:23:01 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id KAA05287; Thu, 12 Dec 1996 10:23:01 -0800 (PST)
Received: from acergw3.acer.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with ESMTP id KAA05274; Thu, 12 Dec 1996 10:22:53 -0800 (PST)
Received: from smtplink.acer.com ([204.160.139.137]) by acergw3.acer.com (8.7.3/8.7.3) with SMTP id KAA23447 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 12 Dec 1996 10:19:14 -0800 (PST)
Received: from ccMail by smtplink.acer.com (SMTPLINK V2.11.01)
	id AA850415130; Wed, 11 Dec 96 18:35:14 pst
Date: Wed, 11 Dec 96 18:35:14 pst
From: "Andy Wyszkowski" <awyszkow@smtplink.acer.com>
Message-Id: <9611128504.AA850415130@smtplink.acer.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: 1996 Top Ten
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     
     Well... a lot has happened.  I joined the list and started partying 
     out here.  Been to parties before in Utah and LA, but only midway this 
     year did I start getting to the good stuff up here.
     
     10.First time really 'getting off' on E at Promise.  Lying with my 
     head in a new friends lap, as her friends all find me pretty funny/or 
     cute because they're all giggling as they bring me stuffed animals and 
     toys.  Most spoiled rotten moment of my life...
     
     9. Attending St.John's Divine Rhythm Society.  Dancing in a church to 
     house when I most needed it (I had OD'ed on trance & goa a half month 
     earlier) was pretty divine in my book.  Thank you to everybody who 
     invited me to an UG party... it's most appreciated.
     
     8. DJ Random's set at Elevation in LA.  Tacky, sloppy, almost clubby 
     music, but the guy knows how to spin at a party.  Had the crowd the 
     whole time, and whipped em all over the place.
     
     7.  Cloud Factory's Planetarium.  After having six thousand things go 
     wrong with the newbies I brought, they finally went to sleep.  I went 
     to see what was going on at the top of the hill by myself and caught 
     the best sets I've heard from Saben and Deaks then going into morning 
     at the little stage.  Freezing cold, amazing vibe, economy 
     pyrotechnics display at the BBQ, tired for weeks afterwards, but all 
     the way worth it.
     
     6. Juan Atkins at Space Children Three Year.  Amazing E, the Godfather 
     of Techno going off, my best friends from LA coming up to see me, and 
     my 25th birthday all in one.  Damn cool laser at that party... I don't 
     usually like lasers.  
     
     5. Meeting the really cool people from the bizarre booth at the back 
     of Freedom.  They were giving away stickers and had a blacklight.  
     That's about it.  Some of the coolest people I have ever met, and I've 
     been seeing them at parties on and off ever since.  I guess I'd have 
     to put meeting all the amazing people I've met this year here.
     
     4. The realization that a set can be anything the DJ desires at the 
     moment they pick their next record while listening to Brian spin at a 
     Moontribe.  The common thread doesn't have to be the sub genre of 
     music being played... it can be anything disco to minimal techno to 
     house to gabber to goa and be a great journey regardless.  The lines 
     we draw exist only because we draw them.
     
     3. Getting more involved.  Helping clean and setup at a couple parties 
     has been really rewarding, and an opportunity to really get to know 
     some of them smiling faces.  Even got offered to play a party... wee!
     
     2. All the mail list and mail list related events: BBQ & Beats, Monday 
     Night Dinner, Thursday Lunch, meeting all these list people.  Well and 
     those nice people that I always end up hooking up with too.  You're 
     all spiffy.
     
     1. Seeing the spirit of misfit power in it's purest forms time and 
     time again.  I keep remembering images of people...
     
          : a woman at a busted rave  gathering about twenty people 
          into singing and clapping techno (including a drag queen 
          making 303 growls) as the cops stood there staring
          
          : kids gathering around the car with the loudest stereo in 
          the parking lot after Blitzkrieg got busted shouting 
          hardcore! hardcore!
          
          : Energy Circles
          
          : Driving Crunchman's car past a forest fire as he's 
          tripping out of his gourd on the sky glowing all red and not 
          knowing where the hell we are and pretending to be confident
          
          : Waking up to a gabber set with my aching head practically 
          in the speaker at FNF (July).
          
          : Meeting someone who raves that speaks Polish (there is 
          another...)
          
          : The countless DJ's who made me go back to school about 
          what DJing is: Electric Skychurch and Orb at Organic
          
          : Free outdoor parties
          
          : Knowing I can just walk up to most of my friends and hug 
          the piss out of them anytime without offending them
          
          : getting in near flame wars with people, and realizing 
          they're actually okay after I meet them
          
          : 2 mph dirt roads that go forever in cars never designed to 
          go offroad
          
          : E Kissing
          
          : going into the mightiest doumbek trance at Harmony3... and 
          the chill room from H3
          
          : Vegan Capsules (no animal gelatin)
          
          : that place I go when I close my eyes and just dance for 
          dancing (still)
          
          : weeklies that don't suck... MAD (and I had fun at the 
          Velvet Shop in San Jose once)
          
          : Meeting people who came up to me when I didn't know 
          anybody in SF, especially the very first (and also from the 
          list), John K.
     
     And a thank you to all those that risk their money and freedom to keep 
     the 'scene' pure, breathing and active instead of some over 
     commercialized corporate washout.  I for one appreciate it so much.
     
     Peace,
     AndyW

hello all-

disclaimer: this message is not rave related in the strict sense, but it is rave related in my sense of the word, i.e. having to do with ravers.  besides, the people who flame me already have me in their kill files, already! =)

i'm going through the same shit in one of my vocal groups that sfraves is going through right now.  and i just want to say:  hey, it happens!  this group is growing, reforming, and changing, and who know's what the hell it will turn into.  i just know that i'm along for the ride, and i'm amicable to whatever sfraves, the living, breathing, organism that it is, becomes.

i know that it's not cool to say this anymore (but hey, i'm going for the kill file record!), but here goes:

i love you all!

later-

matt l

Please tell SDream we Love him very much and very much notice his lack of

girlfriend was not able to see the beauty and freedom of raving before this
tragic incident, or at least get to see a hot, sweaty, can't stand it so I
gotta take my close off rave.  Let him know that I once quit skateboarding,
something that was very dear to me at one time, for a girl I loved.  Said
girl is now gone, and so is skateboarding.  (I did pick it up again, but it
was just never the same)  It still bums me out sometimes.....I was pretty
good at it ya know, and had a lot of fun doing it.  I guess it's all about
choices, and I hope this is the correct choice for optimum learning of
SDream's spirit.  Make sure he knows he is loved, and that I respect his
devotion to his loved one.  That much devotion is a truely beautiful thing.

Love 

Rick

[ to sfraves ]
Recently, we got the bad news of a loss in the ranks - 
> This is Thomas, SDream's hamsta.  I regret to inform you that SDream met
> with a horrible fate: he has stopped partying.  Yes, sad, but true. 
> See, it seems that there was this picture taken of him being smooched by
> a girl.  The smooch itself wasn't a big deal, but it was a very hot and
> humid rave, and neither were wearing shirts. Said picture found it's way
> into his girlfriend's hands. ... 
> She flipped.  To head off any possible break-up, SDream had to swear off
> raving.  ...  He values his relationship with his
> girlfriend very much, and would rather she didn't feel threatened, so he
> stays away from the parties.
>... 
> Rumor has it though that she has seen a difference in his demeanor since
> then (he seems older?) and may be pressuring him to go to one again, so
> who knows?  

 Suggestions -
1. Wait for Sunsets and outdoor parties to start up again, so she can 
   be there to "picnic" without having to be part of the action. She might
   even be seduced into raving!
2. Chastity belt.
3. Ball gag.
4. Have a shirt printed that says "Don't kiss me, I have herpes!" Promise
   to wear it at every party. Get photographic proof.
5. Have a photo of SDream being kissed by a shirtless guy ( umm, might
   make things worse... )

 Continue moping to a higher degree... 
6. Start dying individual hairs gray.
7. Sigh a lot in her presence. 
8. When she's around,  dance every time you hear "ravish" music , 
   especially during commercials. 

I hope these doesn't hurt ...

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

Yaaaaaa!!!!

my top 10 SF events for 1996, with a DOUBLE BONUS:

=80 fresh produce - in LA with my bro, my second rave, Jesse spinnin' =
phat breakbeats

=80 harmony 3 - 3rd rave ever, chill room went off, shakin' my booty

=80 greg's b-day - playing with the keyboards in the chill room

=80 Sunset - my first sunset, made a friend, great visuals

=80 215 - what a trippy party!

=80 FnF - chillin', finding Marcy, makin' friends, party busted, =
party moved, partied hard

=80 Final Sunset - meeting up with friends, watching the sky

=80 Samhain (sp?) - roaring bonfire, driving drum circle, phat =
ambient room

=80 my bro got a better job, moved up here

=80 Meeting Omar - great guy, there's a reason he has so many friends!

=80 Wrinkle - got to contribute, met more awesome people, tripped hard

=80 Cabin - met more people from the list, learned a spiritual nature =
to pinball! :-)


peace and love, y'all are the bomb!

deeje

n Wed, 11 Dec 1996, Andrew Rawnsley wrote:

> >I have to agree with Mike Migurski that there is no reason to get cynical
> >about 1997. There are way too many dynamic, energetic, and creative people
> >to allow for stagnation in the scene. I've been fortunate enough to be
> >friends with many of these people because there's nothing as satisfying as
> >watching people you care about do monumental things. These are the people
> >involved with Progress, Harmony, and Lepidoptera. I know for a fact that
> >these same people care enough to never let "it" turn into the nightmare
> >vision suggested above.
> >
> >I use "it" because we have yet to see what it turns into and I'm DAMN
> >optimistic! This scene has been so good to me and my friends. I think we of
> >the North have less to fear than our Southern brethren in regards to
> >commercialization. I think Southern California is a good example of how
> >prolific, adaptable,  and resilient this scene is.
> >
> 
>         My comments were more in relation to the scene in general, as a
> whole in the US. I agree that there are plenty of good people involved with
> the local scene. However from my perspective as one of editors of XLR8R, I
> get to see and hear alot of stuff that goes on "behind the scenes" of the
> parties, and folks it ain't pretty. PLUR is something very much talked
> about, but when it comes down to the nitty gritty of putting on events, it
> is VERY political, and egos and money enter into the picture way too much.
> It's almost as if the more cool PC talk gets used to promote an event, the
> more phoney those sentiments are. Let's face it, if you really are throwing
> a solid, underground and spiritual vibey event, then you don't need to let
> everyone know about it. They'll figure it out for themselves.
>         As for me, I'm finding that the connection and vibe I used to find
> at parties happens less and less, and therefore I go out hardly at all.
> Maybe I'm cynical, maybe I'm just really picky. I don't know. I DO know
> that the underground takes care of itself, and that it will change as the
> people and parties change. IMO, DIVERSITY is the key to pushing the
> underground forward, not more blinkered categorization and single genre
> parties, which seems to be the norm everywhere, whether it's House, Techno,
> Trance or Jungle. Hearing different music at a party is GOOD. Same stuff
> all night is BORING. Raving was supposed to mean having an open mind.
> Diversity of music, diversity of people.
>          Unfortunately I think that my fears about commercialization and
> losing of "rave" values is already with us. Most of the "nightmare vision"
> I mentioned already happens, I just exaggerated them to make them even more
> ridiculous.             Here's a musical example. Last year at this time
> the quality of record releases in all genres was outstanding. This year
> sadly the majority of music is  derivative, uninspired and frankly pretty
> dull. Perhaps 2 out of 10 records is something worth playing. (I am VERY
> picky, but my standards haven't changed that much since last year...)
>         A case in point is jungle/drum and bass, which in the start of '96
> was simply outstanding. Just about every record I heard was amazing. Since
> the genre's acceptance and commercial success in the UK, the quality of
> records has decreased to the point where I might buy one jungle record a
> week. There is still solid underground music out there, you just have to
> search harder to find it. Similarly there are still good underground
> parties going on, they're just less frequent.
>          RAVE IS DEAD! Like Punk, Rave was more an attitude than a style,
> and also like Punk it will take 20 years till most people realize.
>         THINK about WHY you're raving and the underground will take care of
> itself.
> 
> Respect
> Andrew
> 
>         *****************************************************
>         WAXING LYRICAL 'BOUT 1971...THE HANGOVER OF THE '60s.
>         *****************************************************
> 
> 
>

>please describe both technically (bpm, layering, etc.) and in "feel", the
>following:
>
>-gabber

150-200bpm slamming hammer drums and people hollering and lots of samples
that are so horrifying, so shocking, they're comical. I can't for the life
of me take gabber seriously, but I like it. is it supposed to be take
seriously???

>-breakbeat (what is a breakbeat?)

not even going near this one... I can recognize breakbeat but I'll be
damned before I try to explain it! =)

>also, where does the word Goa come from? I seem to remember reading that it
>references to a meditation or trance (practice??) (sect??) (style??)

"goa" is the geographical name of a certain part of India where the goa
trance scene was born.

-m.

Subject: JSL's TOP CrackerJack Moments!
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Thu, 12 Dec 1996 11:22:45 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Precedence: bulk

Ok, here are my highlights.  They are few, but they were grand:
-Stompy Cafe Jan 1, 1996.  "Uhhh, ok, lemme have some of that." 3:00 p.m.
"Damn, hwere was I for the past 5 hours?" 8:00 p.m.  Damn!  ABS in full 
effect (if you don't know, you're not supposed to!). ;)  I remeber seeing 
Alan Ameba, and  looking for my glasses.  I was told I had a great time, 
all smiles, with shades all  night.
-Stompy Cafe July 4, 1996. Took the S.O. out for our public debut.  I 
don't remeber too much, not even the after party at Johnny's, where I was 
told I had a great time smootchin the girlfriend, and sitting in a 
doorwell.  I was told I had a good time.  I didn't wear shades, but 
could't see.  I drank alot of booze, smoked alot of weed, and injested 
lotsa stuff.  All smiles, and I swore off substances.  Yeah right.
-Stompy in Octiober.  the music wasn't all that hot, but I was high.  
Time to go home, gather a group of friends, start to drink, get higher 
and spin some rekkids.  Statyed wrecked all day on Saturday, woke up on 
Sunday @ 8.  I am old, I cannot do this anymore.  From here on in no more 
"stuff" unless it is green and tokeable.  I hang up my psychedelic hat 
for the last time.  Stay tuned.  It was an OK partay, but eh music left 
plenty to be desired.  Saw Rawno, and a host of other motley characters.  
Matty chases Preston in a wig, classic.

The rest I dare not talk about.

Hey Rawno:  When in the fuck are you spinning again and where?  Lemme 
know, I want to hear you play sucka!

Peace,
John

I usually hate virus warnings on the list but since this ghost exe was
posted here I thought it should be posted.  I'm skeptical that simply
removing the file will remove the virus because infections occur when a
file is executed, not when it is simply sitting on your hard drive.

David

Halloween may have been circulated  among AT&T Wireless Services
employees.

This virus is scheduled to detonate on Friday Dec. 13th.

If you did receive ghosts.exe delete it immediately.

FORWARDED MESSAGE FOLLOWS

Just to be on the safe side - make sure the original mail message is not
saved in your mail folders, if you forwarded it - check your sent items
folder, and do a search for ghost.exe on your hard drive.  If you
forwarded the message, let those people know, and so on ...

 ----------

Um, if any of you guys received the file with the flying ghosts and
witches
I sent to a bunch of people recently for Halloween, DELETE IT
IMMEDIATELY--meaning the ghosts.exe file. Apparently it is set to
destroy
your PC on Friday, December 13.

 ----------

Now that Halloween is over... everybody must remove the Ghost.exe file
from
their computers by December 12th.  If not this enjoyable trojan Horse
will
crash your files and system.  Up until December 12th, the Ghost.exe file
will
remain harmless.

 ------- FORWARD, Original message -------

The following message comes from another law firm.   I haven't verified
the
accuracy of  the information but due to the nature of the problems it
describes,  I feel it is in the firm's best interest to forward it on to
EVERYONE.  As it states, please delete both files if you have them and
inform MIS.  Also, if you have installed any unauthorized software
please
call MIS
for assistance in removing it.  Thank you for your cooperation.

     It has come to my attention that a couple of ghoulish visitors have
taken up residence on our network in the last week or so.  These
visitors,
one a
mouse cursor locator called EYES, and the other an animated screen
add-on
called GHOST.EXE, are both apparently harmless and very "cute".
 Actually, they are anything but harmless.

     EYES creates a serious drain on your PC's resources and will cause
system freezes and general protection faults on a regular basis.  This
may
result
in the loss of edits to documents or corruption of files that are open
at
the time your system fails.

     GHOST.EXE is a much more serious problem.  GHOST is a "trojan
horse"
virus which is scheduled to become active on the next Friday the 13th,
which
happens to be in December.  This virus will attack and delete
SERVER-based
system files and could potentially bring down the entire network.

     IF YOU ARE RUNNING EITHER OF THESE PROGRAMS ON YOUR PC, DELETE THEM
IMMEDIATELY.
     This situation highlights the seriousness of the problem we have at
 {firm name deleted} surrounding the unauthorized loading of software on
firm PCs.
 It is impossible for most users to determine if a game, screensaver, or
other software add-on poses a potential threat to the information
systems
at the firm.

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Tue, 10 Dec 1996 23:50:10 -0500
From: Daniel Ferreira <tranced@gate.cybernex.net>
To: az-raves@getnet.com, boston-raves@ccs.neu.edu, DCRAVES@AMERICAN.EDU,
    fl-raves@cat.net, mo-raves@nicar.org, mtn-raves@hyperreal.com,
    mw-raves@hyperreal.com, nw-raves@hyperreal.com,
    pb-cle-raves@hyperreal.com, SERAVES@AMERICAN.EDU, sfraves@hyperreal.com=
,
    socal-raves@ucsd.edu, txraves@io.com
Subject: Children of the Light: Rave Documentary

Let me begin by apoligizing for the cross-posting, and plead that any
discussion relating to this subject be mailled to me and kept in it's
perspective mailling list so as not to flood all US raving lists with
unwanted mail. If you want to skip reading all this just aim your
browser to:   http://www2.cybernex.net/~tranced/coftl/
All the information, developments and updates will be added to this
page.

with that said on to the topic:

Recently, our scene has been the attraction of a lot of negative press
and one sided bias portrayals by the mass media. This as always been an
issue within our sub-culture (among many others), but more so now, that
raves are getting bigger, and sparking up attention within the
mainstream. Personally I do not fear the growth and development of our
music and our scene as long as it is depicted for what it really is, I
do although fear the distorted and bias representation of what we really
are about... It is very disturbing to know that the evil many of us call
tabloid news shows as well as reputable news broadcast network stations,
have taken something that is so special to so many and twist it to
extended measures for ratings.=20

I will not deny that drugs are in part an issue within our scene, but I
find it highly disrespectful that the mass media choses to focus and
magnify this consequence, which is obviously out of reach of the
promoters hands anymore than inner city public school principals are to
blame for drugs inside their schools. =20

More so than any other music scene, whether it be rock-&-roll or
country, I have never been part of such a tight movement, but much like
any other musical culture, it is the expression within the techno beats
mastered by the talented DJ=92s that perform at these parties that bring
us together, as we all know. The DJ=92s are our rock stars, and raves are
our concerts. Just because it isn=92t a mainstream activity and it isn=92t
presented in the same format as other popular events such as concerts
(were you sit and listen to sound as opposed to letting it guide the way
your body moves), why should it loose its validity as a scene and a
culture???=20

Most news reports are only aiding the side of our scene the media
disapprovingly portrays, by tempting young kids to attend these parties
and do drugs. Most news stories are nothing more than negative
advertisements for who we are trying to exclude from our culture, those
whose sole purpose at these events is mainly to get their fix and have a
place to recover just in time to go back home. We within our own scene
are trying to combat the plague that haunts us, and it's bias media
reports that have turned something special into something
negative.=20

There as been much bickering and complainting on this issue both among
the net and outside as well. Many of us have responded to some of the
stations and program producers, and most to no avail. We can all just
sit back complaint and let things develop as they are either for the
better or worse, or we can take charge and try to do something with our
resources. There have always been negative depictions of our scene
through out most of it=92s existence, and some may think this doesn=92t pos=
e
an immediate threat to our culture, and there=92s no need to worry about
it. The difference now, is that our scene is rapidly and unavoidingly
rising. We have the choice to either let it escalate in the public eye
with the negative reputation it=92s been represented as, by the
pessimistic media, or we can use our means to present it for what it is,
and reveal that we are not just freaky teenagers looking for places to
invade and get drugged. During the last month, there have been several
mis-informed and terribly uneducated attempts to define the rave scene
within my area (New Jersey/New York), including a WNBC news report, an
American Journal story, among other ignorant rants on several prime-time
shows and News Channels. I have also been informed that many other local
news stations around the United States have been focusing and negatively
reporting the rave experience.=20

Me, along with a group of ne-ravers have decided to produce a
documentary video contrasting and combating the negative publicity
that=92s been degrading our scene as the =93new teenage trend known for its
open and accepted drug use=94 that has been depicted through many
wide-scale news stories Our sole purpose (or at least mine) behind this
project is to have something out there in the basic "media" format to
portray our scene for what it is, as seen by it's true participants as
opposed to what people on the outside perceive it to be...=20

As of now, I'm just trying to get footage of past events and start
laying down some kind of format or outline for the program. I'm hoping
that all footage and interviews necessary will be gathered and ready to
cut by around the end of Mosaic II (NE-RAVES party scheduled for middle
of February).=20

As of right now, I would just like some input and comments on creating
an outline.. The basic idea I have for the project is a professional and
journalistic look at the rave scene in general, covering all aspects
that make up our sub-culture, be it the music, drugs, the internet,
history, legalities and so on... and portray it in a positive,
educational manner..=20

And for any of you out there who have ventured into raves with your
video cameras and have some sort of rave footage, wether it be a DJ
spinning, someone comenting on the scene (you can even do this
yourself), or people dancing, and wouldn't mind sharing in exchange for
credit please e-mail me so we can work something out... I'd be more than
willing to exchange a blank video tape along with S&H charges for tapes
with footage, or if someone doesn't have access to 2 vcrs or any copy
equipment, I'd be more than glad to copy and immediatley return the tape
along with any other charges... Thanks :)=20

Everyone remember, this is a no-budget, no-profit project relying only
on the effort of those willing to contribute their labor, time, etc.. We
are following a couple of promoters around with our cameras as they
organize, prepare and throw a party as well as interviewing willing
attendees on their take of the rave scene. If you are a promoter or an
active member of your local rave scene, and are interested in
participating in this project, please e-mail for more information. We
are covering several parties here in the north east in the coming
months, but I would like extend the proposal and footage to the entire
United States in general. If you are throwing a party and/or attending
one in which you know the production staff, and wouldn=92t mind taping
some footage as well as interview some of your peers, promoters, local
authorities etc. and would like to be part of our team please e-mail me
for further discussion. Again, any contribution/opinion/constructive
criticism is welcome!=20

All we really need as of now is to gather up footage, work on a
narration, interview the right sources and get the thing cut... If you
have any footage or anything that could help or contribute to the
project I'd be glad to hear from you.=20

Remember, it is either up to the mass media to portray our scene as they
see fit to it=92s zombie-like audience who will never question their
sources, or it its up to us to inform and educate the mass public as
well as the media that our scene is not just another night out on the
town doing drugs and getting wasted...=20

If anyone knows of any current documentaries or related video tapes out
there please inform me???=20

Thank You
                                                   Daniel.Ferreira

From: Rick Riffle <rdriffle@ucdavis.edu>
Subject: The Plenum
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I have experienced the Plenum.  The Plenum would be a great place for a
party should one have access to said Plenum.  But knowone will be able to
throw a party in the Plenum so Rick is just pipe dreaming at this point.  Ya
see there's this building at the UCD Med Center in Sacto that has a
Plenum...which I experienced yesterday.  Old buildings have Plenums I am
told.  You are wondering what a Plenum is? No?  Well it seems that this
building has one centeral devise to move air throughout the entire two story
building.  This area has three gigantic fans (bigger than you and me put
together) in it that move the air throughout the building.  To get to the
Plenum you need a key to go through one door, then you must shut that door
because a Plenum has something to do with air pressure being greater in some
areas than others.  Then you open another door to an empty room with a
grated floor.  You have to shut that door as well....something about
pressure.  Then you go through a grated stair case in the grated floor down
to the sub/sub level.  This pipe dream of a party would truely be the
"underground."  In that room there is a big metal door that says "DO NOT
ENTER, OPEN BY PERMIT ONLY"   I asked what would happen if I opened that
door, and our escort said we'd be sucked into one of the fans and surely
parish.  This would add a sense of adventure to the whole party atmosphere,
cuz you could die.  That room wasn't very big anyway.  Then there was the
next room which was really big and had a huge fan (safely contained behind a
chain link fence) about 10 or more feet tall blowing air every which way.
The room was big, plenty big enough for a 100 person party.  And there was a
constant stream of air, not so strong as to blow you over, but you could
really feel it.  Then further back the floor raised up about three feet and
the room continued on for another 40 or so feet turned a corner and went
back another 50 feet.  A great big cubby hole chill space if you ask me.  I
could just see it.  Psychadelic lighting all over, and streamers and strips
of cloth attached to the walls, or sheets attached to the ceiling and walls
on one side so the other would blow in the wind.  I'm sure the sensation of
flying could be easily simulated.  Then music of course.  And 100 happy
raves raving in the Plenum.

Just a dream, thanks for listening.

Rick

Subject: 10 Best of the year
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Isn't this more of a New year's thing? But since I'm off to get video of
whales and volcanos in Hawaii over the break I'll look back now:

1) St. John Rhythm Soc events (all of 'em) Best joyful moment looking up and
  seeing Rachel dancing on the high alter... talk about dedicating a celebration.

2) New Moon at Goat Rock... wonderful outdoor beach celebration. Bonnie reminded
   me how good short hair feels... smiles all around.

3) Tribal Future ... the Ameba's rock - garden's of delight.

4) 3rd Year Harmony... I loved the ambient room and outdoor setting.

5) Light outdoor at the Berkeley Marina... what a way to change the seasons.

6) Gateway 4th of July campout... stars all around. dave abel woke up the forest
   with lights and lasers til even the trees were dancing... creeks help make
   for ambience.

7) Organic in LA ... band after band until Orbital live split my mind... I 
   resolved to play more e-music... inspired at 8000 feet.

8) Mad at the Bahia... what a way to hang out for a short evening..

9) Planetarium Campout.... when clouds float up to the mountain top watch out...
   The cloud factory makes things happen... looking forward to another.

10) Last but not least FnF where it all began (for me).... whenever you are
   blessed with a rainbow floating overhead in the morning you know the gang
   must have done something right....

 Mike
-- 
     Mike Clay      meclay@ix.netcom.com    (415) 572-8971
**** Alone and Ecstatic a young rainbow learns to levitate. ****

>  ; discussion about

 Rave culture-related topics mean in my mind everything that I communicate
with people and think about, regarding the future of humanity when I am in
an altered state at a high energy rave party.

Does this relate?

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Dec 12 12:21:25 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id MAA17496; Thu, 12 Dec 1996 12:21:25 -0800 (PST)
Received: from Kitten.mcs.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with ESMTP id MAA17470; Thu, 12 Dec 1996 12:21:17 -0800 (PST)
Received: from arduous (arduous.pr.mcs.net [205.164.41.157]) by Kitten.mcs.com (8.8.2/8.8.2) with SMTP id OAA11473; Thu, 12 Dec 1996 14:21:15 -0600 (CST)

From: matter <arduous@mcs.net>
