To: Dylan.K.Bryne-1@tc.umn.edu, mw-raves@hyperreal.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com,
        matter <arduous@mcs.net>, Andy Wyszkowski <awyszkow@smtplink.acer.com>
X-PRIORITY: 3 (Normal)

Message-ID: <Chameleon.961212142421.arduous@arduous>
MIME-Version: 1.0

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Allright, already.

I can c this is gonna be on of those discussions...

I'm not out to flame here, but simply clarifying my views on this topic...

Andy Wyszkowski <awyszkow@smtplink.acer.com> wrote:

>     
>     Well...
>     
>     There was a time when cocaine was the drug you did casually, and acid 
>     and pot were for fuckups (and the BeeGees were the b*o*m*b).  Now it's 

Hmmm, u remember things differently than I do. This is all IMO, of course... I never 
thought the BeeGees were much of anything at all. :D I never thought acid and pot were 
for fuckups. ;-) I've only known two people in my 29 years of existence who were able 
to do cocaine casually.  Everyone else is who does it becomes an addict. It so happens 
that cocaine and herion and K are physically addictive drugs, whereas the substances, 
which I don't disapprove of, are not.  People may become mentally or emotionally 
addicted, but when they have to stop using them, by choice or otherwise, they don't 
start shaking, hallucinating, and spasmodically convulsing on the floor. :-O

>     cocaine that's for fuckups, while some of my partying friends do LSD 
>     somewhat regularly.  If somebody wants to put something in their body, 
>     let em.  I don't care if it's cocaine, ketamine or John Holmes.  

Hehehe. That's pretty funny. Do you mean all of John Holmes or just the famous part?

>     Personal liberty is weird that way.  It's not for me to decide what is 
>     right for you.  The safest drug tends to be going sober, but it's not 
>     for everyone all the time.
>     
>     As for the scene, I think it's a good general rule to consider raving 
>     as "going out".  Don't do large amounts of GHB or get piss drunk, 
>     don't use dissociatives at parties that might get busted because 
>     passed out, immobile, incoherent people suck in that circumstance.  
>     But in your own home... shoot all the smack, smoke all the crack you 
>     want.  Just don't croak or get sick... we like you and we'd hate to 
>     read about you in the paper.

I c your point on personal freedoms, however when people are going to expose their 
negative energy to a group, which is supposed to be about love, fun, happiness, good 
times and the like, I do care, deeply. Because it's not just what they are doing to 
themselves, they are affecting the entire group by their self-destructivity and bad 
vibes.

>     Determining which drugs should and shouldn't be okay is about as fair 
>     as deciding which people should be tried as witches in early Salem.

Burn the witch, burn the witch!!! ;-)

That's not where I'm coming from... I'm sure there are some exceptions to the rule. 
There are a handful of people out of a thousand who can have a good time and spread 
love and happiness, while they're all strung out on some barbituates and/or 
amphetamines. But, I have been around and I have seen a lot of stuff. It's not the norm 
and that's for sure. I had a friend in the Detroit area who, now, sells her body to 
support her herion addiction. She's lost all of her friends, her future as a school 
teacher and her health in general. All I know is that usually the aforementioned 
(junk), causes big health problems, physical addiction and bad vibes for everyone who 
is exposed to the individual "under the influence". Most psychedelics don't seem to 
have this effect, in fact from my experiences, the effect of psychedelics on a group is 
usually quite pleasing, as long as everyone maintains some sense of reality.

>     I think we should work on enforcing laws that punish harmful 
>     behaviors, not alternative lifestyles.  Perhaps if all drugs were 
>     legal we could address some of the real problems.  It would be really 
>     hard to have to steal for drugs if they were cheaper, which they could 
>     be if they were legal.  Drug dealers wouldn't have turf wars, because 
>     they'd have no money except what they make from pimpin and stealin, 
>     and nobody supports their pimp or their fence like they do their drug 
>     dealer.

I pretty much agree with u here, except the law part. I think we need less laws and 
more conscience-motivated (pro-active) behavior regulation. I guess, that's pretty 
ideal. In a way, karma is gonna get u, anyway so who needs laws? Laws are only good for 
something after it's been done and it comes time to punish. Karma lasts a lot longer. 
But hey, we're only human and we do the best we can. It's discussions like this, that 
help us to grow and learn and at least consider other people's opinions...
     
>     But the argument goes on...     
>     Peace,
>     AndyW

Yeah and I'm right! (just kidding) ;-)

pluricity,
matter

P.S. Even the guy in my quote below, got all screwed up on all kindsa bad stuff near 
the end of his life (27 years).  It's a shame, really it is -> mostly smoking, drinking 
and cocaine...

"I'm a Sagitarrius, the most philosophical of all of the signs, but I don't believe in 
it. I think it's a buncha bullshit, myself." - James Douglas Morrison

I think almost everything we do, in some way, realtes to tother things we 
do in life.  I mean partying/raving whatever, is just another extension 
of yourself.  So why shouldn't other aspects, even (yikes) spirituality, 
come into play at some point.  Same thing with socialization, etc.

I think also that since we live in such close proximity to the epicenter 
(which I consider SF to be when looking at the bay area), other things 
will come into play.  At times it will get muddy, but I think there are 
very few topics that don't relate.  Energy levels?  Sure why not.

It is all good, IMO, all good.

But as the great Marcus Mark was heard quoting "Everything in moderation, 
even moderation!".  Maybe applying this to all aspects of SFRaves topics 
might be a good idea.

I have been wading through all of this mail, catching up on all the
negativity that has been haunting this list.  This message unfortunately 
won't reach a lot of the people whoi have unsubscribed I do want to say
one thing though to those you are still here:  the only way we are going 
to get through this negativity is by continuing to communicate and not
unsubscribing or by trying (and maybe this is what needs to be done)
having the people who are having a problem meet in person, out of this
sometimes diificult to commmunicate medium, and hash it out in real deep 
discussion.  Some of my best times at raves have been in the ambient
room with  people I was feeling negative with.  Being in the rave
environment helped drop the fear and start the communication.  that is
what I have always liked best about ther social space of raves.

IMHO,
Cassandra

P.S. 
I wouldn't mind facilitating such a discussion if necessary now that
school is out of session.

     I am thoroughly interested by the post below. In the interests of 
poloitical correctness I believe that not wanting to have sex with an alien 
based on their (the alien's) planetary origin is an act of gross discrimination.

was squeamish about having sex with me based on my alien status. However, if the
person didn't wish to have a sexual encounter with this alien owing to the fact 
that I have two heads, two penises, eight arms and three buttocks thats another 
matter altogether.

michal migurski wrote:
> 
> >please describe both technically (bpm, layering, etc.) and in "feel", the
> >following:
> >
> >-gabber
> 
> 150-200bpm slamming hammer drums and people hollering and lots of samples
> that are so horrifying, so shocking, they're comical. I can't for the life
> of me take gabber seriously, but I like it. is it supposed to be take
> seriously???



i think gabber is the morbid monty python of the rave scene...
	"get this thing out of my body!!!"



> 
> >-breakbeat (what is a breakbeat?)
> 
> not even going near this one... I can recognize breakbeat but I'll be
> damned before I try to explain it! =)
>



a broken down beat- ie.  hip-hop, but usually sped up.... a lot of 
breakbeat started with dj's playing hip-hop on 45...


 
> >also, where does the word Goa come from? I seem to remember reading that it
> >references to a meditation or trance (practice??) (sect??) (style??)
> 
> "goa" is the geographical name of a certain part of India where the goa
> trance scene was born.



goa trance has its origins with the band Ministry (yes, ie Alain 
Jourgenson)... ministry's second record (the first one was a pop sell-out 
to generate income for the record company and hence doesn't count) 
"Twitch" was produced before they introduced guitars into the equation... 
this LP spawned much of what became the new-beat movement (black turtle 
necks, industrial dance types) in Europe... when the likes of Darren 
Emerson (Underworld) among others started frequenting the beaches of goa 
as an inexpensive escape from Europe, the music fused with East Indian 
culture and the hippie culture that had fled to Goa from the fallen 
60's... full moon parties, eastern spiritualism, the aggressive driving 
beat borrowed from industrial (you can the origins of goa in Ministry's 
"over the shoulder") this was a crazy fusion if you think about it!  as 
goa got media attention, the locals seemingly cracked down every other 
year... so there were "on" years and "off" years... for the most part, 
the authorities were easy to pay off, and the parties went off without a 
hitch... recently with all the media attention in the club scene that 
goa's been getting, the scene is falling out there and many of the true 
"goa" parties don't even happen in india anymore... you would be better 
off visiting somewhere like Thailand... most goa is made in the UK and 
Isreal though, many of the artists having never been to india...
 
this is goa to the best of my knowledge.... word up to Neerav (canada's 
Richie Hawtin of Goa DJ's), Nivoc and Guy Sebbag (Isreal)...



dj alchemist, toronto

()()()()()()()()()()()wandrlst@aimnet.com()()()()()()()()()()()() 
"The President has kept all of the promises he intended to keep." 
 -Clinton aide George Stephanopolous speaking on Larry King Live 
     
     
     
     
   CAREER OBJECTIVES
     
     
If I ever become an Evil Overlord: 
     
1. My legions of terror will have helmets with clear plexiglass visors, not 
face-concealing ones.
     
2. My ventilation ducts will be too small to crawl through. 
     
3. My noble half-brother whose throne I usurped will be killed, not kept 
anonymously imprisoned in a forgotten cell of my dungeon.
     
4. Shooting is _not_ too good for my enemies. 
     
5. The artifact which is the source of my power will not be kept on the 
Mountain of Despair beyond the River of Fire guarded by the Dragons of 
Eternity.  It will be in my safe-deposit box.
     
6. I will not gloat over my enemies' predicament before killing them. 
     
7. When the rebel leader challenges me to fight one-on-one and asks, "Or 
are you afraid without your armies to back you up?" My reply will be, "No, 
just sensible."
     
8. When I've captured my adversary and he says, "Look, before you kill me, 
will you at least tell me what this is all about?"  I'll shoot him, and 
then say "No".
     
9. After I kidnap the beautiful princess, we will be married immediately in 
a quiet civil ceremony, not a lavish spectacle in three weeks time during 
which the final phase of my plan will be carried out.
     
10. I will not include a self-destruct mechanism unless absolutely 
necessary. If it is necessary, it will not be a large red button labelled 
"Danger: Do Not Push".
     
11. I will not order my trusted lieutenant to kill the infant who is 
destined to overthrow me -- I'll do it myself.
     
12. I will not interrogate my enemies in the inner sanctum -- a small hotel 
well outside my borders will work just as well.
     
13. I will be secure in my superiority. Therefore, I will feel no need to 
prove it by leaving clues in the form of riddles or leaving my weaker 
enemies alive to show they pose no threat.
     
14. I will not waste time making my enemy's death look like an accident: 
I'm not accountable to anyone and my other enemies wouldn't believe it. 
     
15. I will make it clear that I _do_ know the meaning of the word "mercy"; 
I simply choose not show them any.
     
16. One of my advisors will be an average five-year-old child. Any flaws in 
my plan that he is able to spot will be corrected before implementation.
     
17. All slain enemies will be cremated, not left for dead at the bottom of 
the cliff. The announcement of their deaths, as well as any accompanying 
celebration, will be deferred until after the aforementioned disposal.
     
18. My undercover agents will not have tattoos identifying them as members 
of my organization, nor will they be required to wear military boots or 
adhere to any other dress codes.
     
19. The hero is not entitled to a last kiss, a last cigarette, or any other 
form of last request.
     
20. I will never employ any device with a digital countdown. If I find that 
such a device is absolutely unavoidable, I will set it to activate when the 
counter reaches 117 and the hero is just putting his plan into operation. 
     
21. I will design all doomsday machines myself. If I must hire a mad 
scientist to assist me, I will make sure that he is sufficiently twisted 
to never regret his evil ways and seek to undo the damage he's caused. 
     
22. I will never utter the sentence "But before I kill you, there's just 
one thing I want to know."
     
23. When I employ people as advisors, I will occasionally listen to their 
advice.
     
     
     
     
--
----------------------------------------------------------------------------- 
Matthew at biteme     spore@psibercom.org
                 + Nyquist Theory and Soul Management +

1: Tribal Future in June. A REAL party. Period.
2: Stacey Pullen's "skool 'em" set @ Prometheus Unbound, March.
3: Spinning with Underground Resistance in Toronto, June.
4: Stompy Cafe, New Year's Day. High? You bet.
5: Finding a copy of "Positivity" by Chosen Few on Fokus Records. Been
looking for this record for YEARS. Only paid $1.95 for it, too. Actually
it's been a great year of reaping good record karma. Open Mind rules!!
6: An amazingly beautiful underground in Seattle in July which defined what
it's all about: vibey, spiritual and people up for House, Techno and Jungle
all in the same set.
7: Burning Man. Not for the festival, not for the "rave," but for the
DESERT. Awe inspiring.
8: Full Moon, Mount Shasta, October. Energy, energy, energy!
9: Any Saturday afternoon @ Ameba. Beer, beats and bozos. Thanks for the
memories, Allen!
10: Our house, anytime. Chill.

There's lotsa action as we enter the holiday season...Jungle Love tonight
looks pretty good, then Freaky People and XLR8R's party on Friday.  I
never did get a phone number for Candyland; try the Be-At Line or one
of the other info lines on Saturday.  The rest of the parties on Saturday
look pretty good too, so everyone should have fun...


                                THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://www.hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/gencal.cgi
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Upcoming Parties in the San Francisco Bay Area

   Thursday, December 12nd - _Jungle Love_
   Raymond Roker, Star Eyes, DJ Sifu.
   advance tix at Drop Beat Records (510.654.0992)
   10pm-, 18+, $5. 520 4th St, SF. 415.281.0772
   
   Friday, December 13rd - Harmony presents _Freaky People_
   come and celebrate the spirit of superstition
   Trent, Minor Minor, Brandon, Brian Flip, Greg.
   $10 with a costume.
   limited # of tickets (400)
   $15. sf. 408.486.9591 415.263.4885
   
   Friday, December 13rd - XLR8R Holiday/Release party
   XLR8R Magazine goes all out for the holidays and celebrates the
   release of a beautiful new issue.
   Mark E Quark, Tomas, Matt B, Ethan Jenkins, Andrew Rawnsley.
   Kissing booth by Hyperdelic
   Artist installations by Blasthaus
   18+, $8. 115 Minna (between 2nd and New Montgomery), SF. 415.739.5281
   
   Saturday, December 14th - _Candyland_
   Simon, Carlos, Ghost, Josh, Liquid, Jazz-e, Kwashi, Spinner,
   Tripnotix, Jin, Nam.
   Visuals by L.S.D., Square one.
   free candy all night
   
   Saturday, December 14th - _Scoop_
   Serving You Delicious Helpings of Fat-Free Beats
   Jeno, Tracy, Don Crisp, Timmie.
   10p-8a, All ages, $10. the Zocala Room, 210 W.6th St (@ Broadway),
   Chico. 415.431.1927

   415.522.2365

   _Step Off_ - acid jazz, trip hop w/DJs Mark Farina, Miquel, Julius
   Papp. 21+. the EndUp, 6th & Harrison, SF.
   
   _Sexy T.K.O._ - abstract drum and bass w/DJs Sonic Pioneer, Starsky,
   eclectic guests. 9pm-2am, 21+, $4. 111 Minna St, SF.
   
   _Audio Impact_ - jungle w/DJs Rotating Bass Kru DJs, guests. first and
   third wednesdays of each month
   9p-3a, 18+, $5. 1024 Kearny @ Broadway, SF. 415.332.5800x247
   
   _phresh_ - house w/DJs Jay-J, friends. 10p-2a, 21+, Free. the Top, 424
   Haight St, SF.
   
   _[feminine] PHAT_ - hiphop, acid jazz w/DJs Charlotte, Stef, R-Pos.
   10p-2a, 21+. the Up & Down Club, 1151 Folsom St, SF.
   
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Info Lines

     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.
     * the Buzz-line, a global party network - 415.568.1338
     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Fatline - 415.207.3668
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday morning 9am-11am - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon - Beats, Breakz
       and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford).
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Tuesday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. and
       Monkeywrench. Varied techno sub-genres, noise, spoken word, world
       music. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - the Uncle Noah TV Show - the best
       in Techno and House music. 3-5am, KDVS 90.3fm (Davis)
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

>I must say something in regards to this which came in the post called
>Children of the Light:

        it is the expression within the techno beats
>       mastered by the talented DJs that perform at these parties that brin=
g
        >us together, as we all know. The DJ=EDs are our rock stars, and=
 raves are
>       our concerts.


>The DJ as a working member of the party initiates the mood and
>interactively with the dancers the iteration takes place.  Without the
>dancer it is only a DJ spinning records.  He may be good but the mood of
>the party is not COMPLETELY set by the DJ.  When we make DJs rock stars
>all we have is exactly that a DJ and bunch groupies.  Personally I've seen
>too much of that.  Which is one of the reasons I am so picky about the
>party that I attend.  I'm bored with dancing towards the ALTER.  I want to
>interact and move with the people at the party.  Hide the DJ....a
>performance is not what I am attending for, but the experience.>

When I went to the Mac World convention in San Fran
2 years ago, I stayed at the Marriot and a group called
Pure Ecstasy played in the bar area on the top floor.

My friends and I laughed about the group's name, wondering
what they might play  ;)  They ended up playing (live, not records) 
soul and some funky stuff, if i remember correctly.

all in all, it was fun... even though they didn't play
any techno...  =)

10. Harmony's beach parties last Summer!

9. Restoring the aftermath on the morning of A Wrinkle in Time!

8. Setting up sound in the rain for BBQ & Beats & Mud!

7. Spending Thankgiving with my family at Steve Simitzis' party!

6. Meeting all of Wayne's (Krusty's) insanely *cool* friends in Socal!

5. Seeing parties thrown by good people like Lepidoptera, Famtasia, 
   2012, and Thanksgiving! 

4. Watching Adam become a *Raving Lunatic* at the Gathering in April!

3. Carrying 250 lb. bass cabinets over the hill in complete darkness at 
   Bonnie Dunnes for Viberation! 

2. Picking up cigarette butts at 11 o'clock in the morning at the 
   Harmony 3 year!

1. FRIENDS AND FAMILY!!!!! (nuff' said)

Strange...yes....but very true!

love, energy, and viberations,

On Tue, 10 Dec 1996 21:09:03 -0500 MarsMyRat@aol.com writes:
>oops!!
>
>sorry for reposting an old story, a nifty nice advice bearer let me 
>know this
>one had been around before. and that it is not even true!!

I've never posted before, so I hope this works!  I just had to respond to
this letter, though.  I read this cookie story before in a book of urban
legends by a man named Jan Harold Brunvand.  I believe he's a professor
of mythology and folklore at the University of Utah.  Apparently he's
been collecting stories like this one for several years, and he's written
four books:  The Vanishing Hitchiker, The Mexican Pet, The Choking
Doberman, and Curses! Broiled Again!

Urban legends are false stories that are circulated by word of mouth
around the world.  There are variations of every story.  In fact, Jan
Harold Brunvand lists most of the variations in his books.  The one I
read was not about Neiman-Marcus cookies, but about Mrs. Field's.

So, no, it's not a true story, but the recipe's still good! ;)

--Libby  (aka: Bippy (for you, Shteeb!) or HuggyBear (for Lepidoptera) or
Spunky)

Well I got this idea from Socal-raves which is similar to the 10 best we
have going on now, but I little more.  Not everyone will agree, but that's
whats so great. We will get a chance to see what everyone likes and
dislikes.  And remember, these are all personal opinions, you don't have to
agree, just respect there opinion.


1. Best party you went to in 96?

2. Worst party you went to in 96?

3. Best local DJ for 96?

4. Best Non-local DJ for 96?

5. Best record for 96?

6. Worst record for 96?

7. Best mixtape for 96?

8. Worst mixtape for 96?

9. Best track for 96?

10. Worst track for 96?

11. Favorite location for a party in 96?

12. Least favorite spot for a party in 96?

13. Favorite thing to do after a party in 96?

14. Favorite thing to wear to a party in 96?

15. The most you ever spent in one night at a party in 96?

16. If you can change one thing about raving in 96, what would it have been?

17. What the best DJ name in 96?

18. Worst DJ name in 96?

19. Best name for a party in 96?

20. Worst name for a party in 96?


That should keep everyone busy and thinking.


Tim (knucklehead)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Dec 13 08:53:45 1996

From: Troy Sheets <tsheets@xanadu.cyborganic.com>
Message-Id: <199612131653.IAA09356@xanadu.cyborganic.com>
Subject: Jungle is fun.
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Fri, 13 Dec 1996 08:53:40 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL25]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Went to the jungle thing at the Trocadero last night and wow!  what a fun
thursday night.  Got there at around 10:30 and the place was pretty sparse,
but by 11:30 the floor was populated with people funking out to Star Eye's
set.  The Troc has a great system and it is a thrill to feel those jungle
beats vibrate your insides.  The vibe was friendly and mellow, something
I have not experienced in either the Troc or 1015 for awhile.

A few reasons I like jungle:

1.  Its a music scene.  People are into jungle because they dig the sound
of it.

2.  Its very dynamic.  Jungle never gets boring.  Its always right there
in your face.

3.  You can explore many more different dancing styles with jungle.  You can
mix up moving to every beat, then every other beat, and generally twisting
your body all around.

4.  After 2 hours of jungle, it feels like you have been dancing all night
to regular trance!

Support your local jungle scene,
-troy

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Well, it IS nearing New Year's Resolution time...  Just in case any of us
suddenly gets an Evil Empire (tm) for Christmas, thought I'd share this:

Smiles,
     Chin

>> If I ever become an Evil Overlord:
>> 
>>  1. My legions of terror will have helmets with clear Plexiglas visors,
>>     not face-concealing ones.
>> 
>>  2. My ventilation ducts will be too small to crawl through.
>> 
>>  3. My noble half-brother whose throne I usurped will be killed, not kept
>>     anonymously imprisoned in a forgotten cell of my dungeon.
>> 
>>  4. Shooting is *not* too good for my enemies.
>> 
>>  5. The artifact which is the source of my power will not be kept on the
>>     Mountain of Despair beyond the River of Fire guarded by the Dragons
>> 
>> of
>>     Eternity. It will be in my safe-deposit box.
>> 
>>  6. I will not gloat over my enemies' predicament before killing them.
>> 
>>  7. When the rebel leader challenges me to fight one-on-one and asks, "Or
>>     are you afraid without your armies to back you up?" My reply will be,
>>     "No, just sensible."
>> 
>>  8. When I've captured my adversary and he says, "Look, before you kill
>>     me, will you at least tell me what this is all about?" I'll say,
>> "No."
>>     and shoot him.
>> 
>>  9. After I kidnap the beautiful princess, we will be married immediately
>>     in a quiet civil ceremony, not a lavish spectacle in three weeks time
>>     during which the final phase of my plan will be carried out.
>> 
>> 10. I will not include a self-destruct mechanism unless absolutely
>>     necessary.  If it is necessary, it will not be a large red button
>>     labeled "Danger: Do Not Push".
>> 
>> 11. I will not order my trusted lieutenant to kill the infant who is
>>     destined to overthrow me -- I'll do it myself.
>> 
>> 12. I will not interrogate my enemies in the inner sanctum -- a small
>>     hotel well outside my borders will work just as well.
>> 
>> 13. I will be secure in my superiority. Therefore, I will feel no need to
>>     prove it by leaving clues in the form of riddles or leaving my weaker
>>     enemies alive to show they pose no threat.
>> 
>> 14. I will not waste time making my enemy's death look like an accident:
>>     I'm not accountable to anyone and my other enemies wouldn't believe
>>     it.
>> 
>> 15. I will make it clear that I *do* know the meaning of the word
>> "mercy";
>>     I simply choose not show them any.
>> 
>> 16. One of my advisors will be an average five-year-old child. Any flaws
>>     in my plan that he is able to spot will be corrected before
>>     implementation.
>> 
>> 17. All slain enemies will be cremated, not left for dead at the bottom
>>     of the cliff. The announcement of their deaths, as well as any
>>     accompanying celebration, will be deferred until after the
>>     aforementioned disposal.
>> 
>> 18. My undercover agents will not have tattoos identifying them as
>> members
>>     of my organization, nor will they be required to wear military boots
>>     or adhere to any other dress codes.
>> 
>> 19. The hero is not entitled to a last kiss, a last cigarette, or any
>>     other form of last request.
>> 
>> 20. I will never employ any device with a digital countdown. If I find
>>     that such a device is absolutely unavoidable, I will set it to
>>     activate when the counter reaches 117 and the hero is just putting
>> his
>>     plan into operation.
>> 
>> 21. I will design all doomsday machines myself. If I must hire a mad
>>     scientist to assist me, I will make sure that he is sufficiently
>>     twisted to never regret his evil ways and seek to undo the damage
>> he's
>>     caused.
>> 
>> 22. I will never utter the sentence "But before I kill you, there's just
>>     one thing I want to know."
>> 
>> 23. When I employ people as advisors, I will occasionally listen to their
>>     advice.
>> 
>>  --

Subject: OBSERVATIONS OF A SFRAVE ROOKIE

X-mailer: Pegasus Mail for Win32 (v2.42a)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Here at work, 5 hours after getting back from Jungle Love and 
whatever was going on at the Top.

THURSDAY THE 12TH of DECEMBER: JUNGLE LOVE AND THE TOP

Jungle Love was pretty kool, although the lack of people contributed 
to the corresponding lack of vibe. Wasn't exactly dead, but far from 
jumpin'. The dj's were pretty good, although this D&B stuff takes a 
little getting used to with all of the bridges/drops where the drums 
and bass stop and a unsettling silence or melody takes over for up to 
30 secs. As for the club itself, the lights were a bit annoying - all 
night, non-stop UV+white light intellibeams roaming all over the 
place - most noticeably in your eyes, where you stood. The drinks 
were stiff, though and the staff was pretty mellow. The three buck 
cover was definitely well spent.

Next stop was the Top at about 1:00am, which pretty much defined cozy 
- which equals 
dead if you're looking to shake your money maker. About 20 people all 
snuggled up with one another and not a soul on the dance floor the 
entire time we were there, which admittedly wasn't much more than 45 
mins. However, a tremendous bright spot was the free beer the barman 
sent our way - apparently he poured the wrong one and gave us the 
ale. Not an ale man myself, but it was free and cold. The staff was 
way kool (free beer!) - the cheery doorman promised to recognize us if we 
wanted to come back so we wouldn't have to pay the $2 cover - it 
wasn't going to be a difficult task given the traffic. It looked like 
it had potential, but Thursday night at the Top was defintely a dud. 

So we headed back to Jungle Love and got down to the funky 
jungle/breakbeat/D&B/whatever sounds until it started to die. Then it 
was off to Chinatown for a little early morning BBQ pork and beef egg 
rice. Buts that's a different story!

Endorphin gets a dishonorable mention. After reading their flyer 
which stated people with invites before 10pm get in for half price 
($5 instead of $10), i thought i'd call them up and see what exactly 
was an invite and how do i get one. So i'm talking to the guy who 
answered the phone and he tells me that, no, the flyers aren't 
invites, no, they don't have invites at all for this party despite 
what the flyer said and yes, i'd have to pay the $10 cover. Ouch! ten 
bones for a rainy thursday night ? Maybe i'm still living in the past 
or maybe Endorphin was the party of the year - If anyone was there, 
i'd like to hear wha'ppend!

kincy

[ to sfraves ]
Tim (knucklehead) put out this question: 
> If you can throw a party and money was no object, what would you do and
> have that you never saw at any other party before?

here's my attempt at some suggestions

( Some of the things I suggest below are not so much "never saw" things
  as "very rare" things ) 

1. Chill/non-dance music rooms with perfect sound isolation from the 
   dance rooms!
2. A full-up medical team with a 100% legit personelle.
3. A seaside site that gave people the option of indoor ( warm/dry )
   or beach ( fresh air/nature ). 
4. Smiling security!
5. Free smart drinks and sports drinks.
6. Free keyed lockers to hold your personal posessions, right next to the 
   dancefloor.
7. Water fountains right next to the dancefloor.
8. Showers with soap, shampoo, and towels !
9. Clean, polished wooden floors. 
10. Places to sit near the dancefloor and talk/yell at your friends, or
   just to rest your feet for awhile.
11. Free earplugs.

 That's it for now ..

Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

     SFRaves yet...)

     was high time to send a mail with 50 attachments totaling 34mb last 
     night.  So our puny link was kinda choked for a while.
     
     C. Even thinking about getting automated e-mail directions to work 
     with the above two conditions in place.

Received: from localhost (dislex@localhost) by orion.sfsu.edu (8.8.3/8.8.3) with SMTP id MAA04734 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Fri, 13 Dec 1996 12:58:09 -0800 (PST)

Subject:  year of the rat
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.3.95.961213120736.28489A-100000@orion>

Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Precedence: bulk


more in the vein of Monty's list of memorable moments from this year, my
top ten list would read something like this :

* Aires ((w/ Garth + Mark E Quark)) crazy fucking CIA front party on
Market & 6th, compleate with bogus painters to throw off the cops and
street traffic. never seen a party like that before or since.

* being uninspired at the Pt. Molate FnF party untill the storm comes tru
and Mother Nature starts tearing shit up. danced through the rain and hail
untill the bitter end. didn't even get a cold afterwards.

* while waiting for the bus on Market, crazy fucking homeless guy charges
me and goes, "*you* saved my life in Nam ! i thought that Charlie had us
for sure ! here's my lucky dog-tags !" and then he bolts. this being only 
1 of many random unsolicited weird-shit happenings that have either been
thrown my way or that i have found myself throwing at other people this
year.

* first Sunset of '96, the one that was moved from Dog Shit Park to Pt.
Molate.

* for the 2nd time in as many years, finding myself spending almost the
entire day of the Haight St. fair just head-tripping in Ameba.

* driving Sun & Dave Foust 5 hours to a Sacramento mountain retreat party
that Dave was to spin at. make the last 2 miles on pure fumes alone. being
1 of 5 people to dance at the 75+ person party and thinking to myself,
"there sure are a lot of dancers in San Francisco." having to steal most
of the generators gas to get out of there come morning. 

* the Twilight Zone acid

* showing up at 2pm to help set up at the August FnF party. swept a floor,
hung a banner, and did not much else. listening to Ethan and others give
hippy-isk speaches to the troops and for some reason not feeling the
natural urge to make some sarcastic comment. end up staying till noon the
next day. takes a week for my lips to heal after that night.

* while playing frisbee by Hippy Hill, accidentlly tag this sketchy
drifter type. almost get shot that day. 

* somehow driving people from Berkeley Marina to Pt. Molate to catch
Garth's set during that raided Sunset.

* Dave, Sun, Nick, Michelle, and i taking the magic bus to Burning Man.
spending saturday night feeling like a cross between Lawarance of Aribia
and Charles Manson. come morning, seeing Kevin for the first time in 6
months at Wicked and beeing offered free DMT. for some reason turning that
offer down...

* 818 Divesadero, World Headquarters.

* working on the prop 215 party and seeing Peter Pan.

* Freaker's Ball 2 : Kevin's party in Santa Cruz. naked teenage acid
casualities attacking cars and other inanimate objects in the parking lot,
breaking into homes and bleading all over cops. for some reason the party
continues ...

* getting a new lucky hat.

* going home for the corporate holidays and getting a $20 rave ticket and
mushrooms for my birthday from my kid sister.

* feeling young and immortal and ending up puking for 5 hours straight on
the last sunset boat party. learn something about restraint that day.

* while walking to Roots, stumble across a huge stuffed teady bear that
one of my neighboors is tossing out. decide to show the bear a night out 
on the town. getting weird looks from cops and having girls in wheelchairs
asking me and the bear to help them across the street. the more i think
about it the more i decide that i really like having Roots around. it's no
psychadelic orgasm of epic proportions, but it's more like a good night of
bowling. girls i don't know are giving me a back rubs, Poppy even
comes over and talks to me and the bear for about 10mins. that was cool. 

*  being surprised by the large crowds of people and the large
number of absentee raver superheros at this year's last sunset. the next
day, Kevin and i get up at 4:30am to be extras in some added scenes for
Return of The Jedi. meeting other Burning Man survivers and aspiring
jungle DJ's there ((whassup Dena)). 

* graduating from The State ((next week)) with my BA in video production.
using that to land a job as a copy clerk in a downtown legal firm. score
one for higer education -

* developing meaningful drug relationships, making friends and a few
enemies, dancing more, being high, being in love, being stupid, being
alive -

knucklehead wrote:
> 
> If you can throw a party and money was no object, what would you do and
> have that you never saw at any other party before?
> 
> Tim (knucklehead)


room one:

full concert-block jbl sound sytem place in four corners... pretty much a 
separate system in each corner...

the mixer:  a cloud mixer... capable of separate channel eqing, panning 
and two FX sends per channel... divide the mixer into four rails (volume 
control) per turntable (four turntables of course) so you could control 
where in the room the sound traverses... assign each rail to a corner...

then hire Richie Hawtin, Jeff Mills, Algorhythm... whoever could handle 
it-- to play... where you stood in the room would depend on where you 
were in the mix...


room two:

40 cerwin vega bins, 30 JBL full range cabs

Derek Carter, Mark Farina, Stacy Pullen, Andrew Rawnsley

four turntables, cloud mixer... wall-stereo sytem to push that bass to 
its max...


room three:  outdoors

blue room speakers on a 50,000 watt system... hung from trees, hiding in 
shrubs, etc etc...

GOA:  Guy Sebbag (isreal), Goa Gil, Neerav (montreal), Eat Static LIVE, 
Infinity Project LIVE,Infinite Wheel LIVE, Psychick Warriors Ov Gaia LIVE


room four:  in a bunker type basement room


drum+bass:  full JBL system, overkill on bass... 4 corners

DJ phantasy, Photek LIVE, Squarepusher LIVE, Subtropic LIVE, 
 David Kristian LIVE, Mixmaster Morris, Jonah Sharpe (DJing)



room five:  in a steam bath facility, with lots of foam cushioned floors

turbosound... eight stacks set about the room with a sound spatializer 
running each frequency band in an infinity symbol around the floor...

Chris Meloche LIVE, Cosmic Trigger LIVE, Irrestible Force LIVE...



i digress...


if anyone has a large trust fund or 7 digit bank account figures and 
would like to invest, contact me...


so on and so forth...

the alchemist

> 
> 1. Best party you went to in 96?

Friends & Family (both of them)

> 
> 2. Worst party you went to in 96?

Madness.  I know lots of you had a great time at that one, but for me it 
sucked. I was in a bad state of mind, so to speak. :(

> 3. Best local DJ for 96?

Well, I am still living in Sacramento, so my favorite dj at this time 
would have to be BioJeff.  

> 4. Best Non-local DJ for 96?

Earnie Deaks!!!!!!!  He just rocked at F&FII

> 5. Best record for 96?

n/a for answers 5 - 10

> 11. Favorite location for a party in 96?

Even though I didn't enjoy myself at Madness, that space on Illinois 
Street in Portero Hill was SWEET! ;)

> 12. Least favorite location for a party in 96?

Acme.  Hands down.

> 13. Favorite thing to do after a party in 96?

A bunch of people kicking it at a friend's house with some ambient music.

> 14. Favorite thing to wear to a party in 96?

My gandora!!!  I wore it to Brian D.'s house party and to 2012.

> 15. The most you ever spent in one night at a party in 96?

$35

> 16. If you can change one thing about raving in 96, what would it have been?

More spaces available that are bust free that have LOTS of room, good 
ventilation, and plenty of toilets w/toilet paper.

> 17. What the best DJ name in 96?

haven't given it much thought

> 18. Worst DJ name in 96?

ditto

> 19. Best name for a party in 96?

2012 (second choices would be Lepidoptera and A Wrinkle in Time)

> 20. Worst name for a party in 96?

Lucky Charms

______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: 1996 in review
Author:  knucklehead@club.net (knucklehead) at atlas 
Date:    12/13/96 7:45 AM
     
     
Well I got this idea from Socal-raves which is similar to the 10 best we 
have going on now, but I little more.  Not everyone will agree, but that's 
whats so great. We will get a chance to see what everyone likes and 
dislikes.  And remember, these are all personal opinions, you don't have to 
agree, just respect there opinion.
     
     
1. Best party you went to in 96?
        Submerge @ Big heart city w/ Tall Paul; Orbital/Underworld at the 
Fillmore; Chem bros @ the Warfield, Digweed/Sasha at 1015, Did Banca de Gaia 
play at the Trocadero this year or last year ?
     
     
2. Worst party you went to in 96?
        Chemical bros @ the Trocadero.
     
3. Best local DJ for 96?
        Henrik @ Spundaes, Chris Orr/Jonah Sharpe @ The Top, Felix the dog  
        (downtempo)
     
4. Best Non-local DJ for 96?
        Sasha, Goldie, Digweed.
     
5. Best record for 96?
        Underworld "second toughest in the infants"
     
6. Worst record for 96?
     
     
     
7. Best mixtape for 96?
        Justin Robertson - cdscape (cd), James Lavelle - Cream live 2 (cd)
     
8. Worst mixtape for 96?
     
9. Best track for 96?
     
     
10. Worst track for 96?
     
11. Favorite location for a party in 96?
        Black Rock desert, Nevada; Mission Rock resort, china basin; Sunset - 
        Berkely Marina; 
     
12. Least favorite spot for a party in 96?
        
     
     
     
13. Favorite thing to do after a party in 96?
        Twin Peaks after Spundaes; go to a friend's house, watch the sea-lions 
at Fisherman's wharf; beer 'n' bongs
     
14. Favorite thing to wear to a party in 96?
        Cool t-shirt, jeans, trainers (sneakers), or my cat hiking boots.
     
15. The most you ever spent in one night at a party in 96?
        dont want to even think about that one...
     
16. If you can change one thing about raving in 96, what would it have been?
        That San Francisco DJ's would take the music right to the peak and HOLD 
IT THERE for at least two tracks before bringing it down again. Long enough to 
get the crowd whooping and hollering, long enough to go f$%#in crazy on the 
dancefloor. I HATE this *promise* of a build in a set, that just kills the 
energy.
     
17. What the best DJ name in 96?
        DJ Hugo Nickabollokov ;)
     
18. Worst DJ name in 96?
        Superstar DJ Keoki
     
     
19. Best name for a party in 96?
        Stompy Stomp; Psychedelicatessen (busted by the "filth")
     
20. Worst name for a party in 96?
        Lucky Charms
     
     
That should keep everyone busy and thinking.
     
     
Tim (knucklehead)

On Fri, 13 Dec 1996, knucklehead wrote:

> If you can throw a party and money was no object, what would you do and
> have that you never saw at any other party before?
> 
> 
> Tim (knucklehead)
> 
I would have sensors all over the dance floor and cameras on the ceiling
that were feeding environment information to a cray supercomputer that was
processing the mood and reaction of the crowd to the environment and
adjusting the environment suitably. The supercomputer would be  able to be
set to super-cheesy-happy mode, where its goal is to build <us> into a
super-cheesy-happy vibed party, or spiritual setting would take us on that
vision quest...also, anyone that wanted to could wear a suit of some sort
that was taking biological readings (EEG's etc) as to your personal
response to the environment and adjusting accordingly. 
	the dj would be more than a record spinner...the dj is completely
wired into the ultimate music processing machine, with a glance and a
thought the dj spins that new record, throwsthe base line into effects
processor 12, and the synth line into effects processor 9, removes to
vocals and samples the dancers exstatic clapping response  in real time
and feeds that back into the mix...
I-)
tr.

        Being an employee of the trocodero usually means putting up with
evil drunks, bad music, and way too much misplaced sexuality.  Not to
mention the notoriously aggro security (that are normally on my side), or
the tweeky management.  As lighting designer/operator, I get a unique
perspective of the club, and see things there that sometimes go completely
unnoticed.
        Thursday night was different in many ways, the music was great!
Thanks Star Eyes for the wonderfully inspiring set.  ::hug::  The vibe was
there, not too much negative nastiness.
        Unfortunately some things remained the same...  I watched one
?security? guard elbow someone as he was passing by, and witnessed some
(though not horrible) management attitude.  Can these problems be resolved?
Could a $25.00  cash incentive keep the security friendly???
        On the tech side of things, the equipment was not happy...  The fog
machine, and video projector both died, and three of the seven intellabeams
were down for most of the night...  =(
        Overall I thought it was a great event, and I'm looking forward to
the next one, on January 23.  Feel free to find your way up to the lighting
booth and say hi, it gets lonely up there...  =)

        Thanks again!                   ::hugs::

        e

       |  Aural Pilot    | http://www.immersivearts.org/lmnt/

Hi =

Just wanted to comment on the dance music scene.  I have been producing mus=
ic =

since the early days of Hip Hop.  In the mid 80's in LA we were having litt=
le =

dances at various venues.  Break dancing was the shit, and groups like Newc=
leus, =

Africa Bambaataa, Herbie Hancock ('Rockit'), Egyptian Lover etc. provided t=
he =

tunes.

LA had dance venues all over, and you could hear a variety of all the dance=
 styles =

including European electronic music (Kraftwerk etc.) besides Disco, etc.

There is very little in modern dance music to distinguish much from the mus=
ic =

ten or 15 years ago.  While newbies want to argue the differences of variou=
s =

genres (Jungle, Rave, House, Acid & etc.) and various idiots try to proclai=
m =

"their" style the only legitimate dance music=8Bthose same people only =

demonstrate their ignorance and recent climbing on the bandwagon.

To a veteran like myself it's all Hip Hop,  from Electro to House to Jungle=
, and I =

like it all, even the obnoxious shit that pisses people off.  Why people de=
bate =

which styles are better is beyond me=8Bthey miss the whole point of =

experimentation and evolution.

While debates rage over "Is Techno Dead?" to "Will commercialism ruin the =

scene"  the same thing was going on before most of you were born.  Look at =
the =

Rock/Hippy culture.  The drug addled hippies of the 60's are now running =

corporations and government (Clinton?) and "We have met the enemy and it is=
 =

us..."

Can I speak with any authority?  I was making dance jams with the Fairlight=
 =

sampler in the early 80's before MIDI keyboards and sequencing existed (God=
zilla =

"P is for Party" 1984;  Blackbird Crew "Missle Man" 1984.)  I had barely he=
ard of =

the Chicago scene but believe me the same shit was going on in LA and NY wh=
ere =

there were jumping music scenes with all the hottest dance jams from all ov=
er =

the planet.

The irony is that in the same sense that white people co-opted the Blues an=
d R&R =

from underground black music=8Bmodern wanna-be's are just recycling most of=
 the =

same conventions from Hip Hop, including sampling and speeding up old break=
 =

beats.

So a new generation comes along ignorant of the past and rails about how "o=
ur" =

music is being corrupted.  People don't want to print R*ve like raves are a=
 dirty =

word=8Blike that "scene" is dead and now only newbies are into "corporate r=
ave"

Commercialism isn't "threatening to take over" it took over in the early pa=
rt of =

this centery when "Underground" prohibition parties played Flapper music in=
 the =

Roaring 20's.  Record sales, which amount to about 15 billion $US per year,=
 drive =

the industry which will swallow any trend from Elvis to Moby.

So it's ironic that people are worried about "gangstas" infiltrating house =
parties =

when breakdancing came from violent ghetto scenes=8Ball this 'modern' dance=
 =

music is basically the same=8Bit's just that mainstream white people have f=
inally =

learned how to dance by copying their black cousins who were hipper than yo=
u in =

1930.

The people sustaining the House music scene have all the same human failing=
s as =

any other scene before or after.  The scene never was 'pure' and it can't b=
e =

destroyed=8Bit will only evolve into the next phase.  Some of the most =

'underground' music in the US is Top 40 in Europe, where even Jungle etc. i=
s =

played on Top 40 stations.

Drugs have been around forever (since cave man days at least.)  Some people=
 =

want to be totally straight, others want to experiment with substances the =

creator put here and humans were ingesting before there were governments =

telling us what was "allowed".  Our government has even tried to prevent na=
tives =

of this land from using their traditional Peyote in religeous ceremonies.

The "Right to generate thoughts" that aren't approved by those maintaining =
the =

consensual reality has been legally recognized by the Supreme Court re ment=
al =

patients who want to refuse forced drugging by government psychiatrists who=
 =

wish to eliminate psychotic thinking.

Why should the mass of straight people have a say if a person wants to take=
 a =

substance that alters the way they think?  Thousands of the world's most =

creative artists have indulged in drugs from coffee/alcohol to opiates/hash=
ish =

etc. for the last few thousand years, and life on this world would be prett=
y =

boring without the art of these "maniacs."

If there was any justice on this planet the people into psychotropics would=
 rise =

up and rebel against their fellow alcohol/tobacco/coffee addicts who restri=
ct =

our drugs of choice while they have theirs (besides theirs are nastier.)

It's history that the European underground dance scene merged out of a mixe=
d bag =

of hippies, punks, rockers, gays, straights, trippers, etc.  This music evo=
lved =

from the Hippy/Punk/Rocker drug scene and drugs have been a part of the gen=
re, =

just as in Disco, Rock, Blues, Jazz, and even County (Johnny Cash :) )

If you listen to all the drug references in early Swing music (Benny Goodma=
n, =

Count Basie, Billy Holiday, etc.) you will wonder how we all didn't grow up=
 =

drinking cocaine laced Coca-Cola (it used to be in Coke=99  :)  )

Now I'm not advocating drugs for the masses and most kids would be better o=
ff =

waiting till adulthood to experiment but is there much difference from a pa=
rent =

giving the kid a cup of coffee or that kid picking a mushroom from a cow pi=
e?  =

They both get a mild buzz!

I have seen kids who grew up taking LSD and pot befor age ten and end up =

straight, going for big science degrees in major universities.  I see chron=
ic pot =

smokers who as supermarket checkers can remember all the produce codes.  Ma=
ny =

of the founders of the computer industry in Silicon Valley were big time st=
oners =

(Apple Computer, example.)  So the stereotype of the drugged out carjacker =

doesn't represent the millions of model citizens who use the same substance=
s =

and never encounter the law.

World class surfers go out in killer storm surf where the slightest mistake=
 can =

cost a life=8Bbombed out on weed.  If it really damages perception, reflexe=
s, etc. =

why do some of the most radical atheletes on earth do incredibly dangerous =

stunts "stoned"?

The real danger is a homogenized world run by Fascists where everybody wear=
s =

the same clothes, take only government sanctioned drugs, and accept the =

brainwashing they receive from government-run schools and the media.

Drugs are a threat to the status quo because they help people break through=
 their =

conditioning.  While there can be dangers there are dangers in skydiving or=
 =

bungee jumping.  That people become addicted is a lack of intelligence and =
will =

power.  The same thing can happen with food, television, or mastubation.

Do you take drugs or do they take you?  When you have to have them every da=
y =

then they are the master and you are the idiot!  Take some Yoga and learn a=
bout =

will power!  But if you can use them with moderation like any other pleasur=
e =

then it is nobody's business.  Prohibitions only make people crave more, be=
come =

"criminals", and lose respect for the gov't. =


So re the drug/dance music nexus don't you straight bandwagoneers lecture =

people who created the scene whereas that conjuction created most of the mu=
sic =

and scene.  Conversely if you want to be straight and enjoy music/dancing t=
hen =

more power to you!!!  But the late 80's underground dance scene was part an=
d =

parcel will rebellious 'hippy/dippy/trippy' or punkish drug scenes and that=
's why =

it was underground and anarchic!

Despite the above most people end up having problems with refined and =

chemically synthesized substances, and would be better off using natural =

psychotropics as nature made them, besides there is no FDA testing 'pills =

powders and potions'  for contamination or purity.  Do you really want to t=
rust =

some greedy drug baron from a third world country re the purity of a substa=
nce =

altering your brain chemistry? =


In closing I would like to note that there is a growing dance scene in N. C=
alif and =

that anyone who wishes to network in the Mendocino/Humboldt areas drop me a=
 =

line.  An English DJ Penny Andrews  has a show on Garberville's  KMUD =

Tues.>10PM and she gets lots of fresh material from her brother back home w=
ho =

is a Drum & Bass producer.  For a while Red Eye Lion and Red Lox had a show=
 on =

KHSU (Humboldt State U) in Arcata, but on both stations you can hear some d=
ance =

music mixed into other shows.  =


The Full Moon Family was putting on low cost partys this last year, sometim=
es =

on the beautiful Redwood coast beaches.  Club West and Hefe's in Eureka hav=
e =

House music nights.

I'm focusing on dance music production with a Macintosh 9500, Roland 808, D=
J =

setup, and a few other MIDI pieces & my partner has an Emulator IV sampler.=
  I'm =

also gearing up for an underground warehouse party and a storefront dance v=
enue =

so if you'd like to help contact me.

The dance music scene is about unity.  The founders were drawn to positive =

values drawn from the 60's and world culture.  Now you hear about promoters=
 =

calling the cops to crash other people's gigs!!!  We can either create a ne=
w world, =

a new system, or we can follow the rut of our forebears, and end up as stal=
e as =

the Rock music industry.

Don't become cliquish and elitist dogging the different factions of dance m=
usic.  =

There is a diversity from punkish industrialists to hippy trancers to gay h=
ousers =

to speedy junglists.  Its all good and even the crass commercialization wil=
l just =

serve to legitimize this music (now heard on TV news shows, commercials, pe=
p =

squads, yes even the Macarena or Jelly Head 'aaaaaaaaaaagh!!!' in the nasty=
 Top =

40.

People can always go underground, break the "rules of dance music" and come=
 up =

with something new.  If you listen to the swing music of the 30's & 40's yo=
u will
feel the same positive vibe you get from a jacking house tune today.  =


Perhaps our greatest danger is "experts" defining the genre=8Bthe music wou=
ld =

exist without promoters, music critics, DJ's, and record labels.  All you n=
eed is =

musicians and dancers=8Blike when all we had were hollow logs for drums bac=
k in =

the cave days.  Somebody always wanna be the head witch doctor and tell ya =

what to do. =


Peace Out,

DJ ASB

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: rawnsley@hotwired.com (Andrew Rawnsley)
Subject: Re: Old Skool
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

        Nice to get an "old skool" perspective, but remember "it ain't
where ya been, it's where ya at."
         The reasons that dance music has remained underground in the US
for so long is a) the music industry SUCKS. b) Americans are too
conservative in their approach to music, hence the 7 or 8 year lag behind
European (especially UK) styles. The music originates here, is picked up by
savvy Europeans, developed and mutated, then gets sold back here years
later. The ones who lose out are the originators. Happened in the '50s,
'60s, '70s and '80s.
        Also, hip-hop is only one of a myriad of styles of the past which
went into the melting pot that is '90s dance. NY disco ala
Levan/Kevorkian/Sleeping Bag Records, electro from Detroit (Cybertron aka
Juan Atkins) and LA aswell as NY, '70s Jazz-Funk-mutated into Nu Funk in
the UK in the early '80s, Georgio Moroder, and the almighty Kraftwerk's
back catalogue (without which there would be NO TECHNO, ask anyone in
Detroit) all point us in the direction of mid '90s dance music. Less
obvious, but certainly integral are people like Steve Reich, Brian Eno,
Stockhausen, and many other electronic and minimalist pioneers who
championed texture and rhythm (the mainstays of all innovative '90s dance)
YEARS before it was even remotely hip. Add to this rock bands like Talking
Heads, Can, Tangerine Dream, Pink Floyd, the psychedelic era outfits, and
African juju (King Sunny Ade), Joy Division (and archytypal electronic
DANCE band) and things become even more blurred.
        Sadly though hip-hop was once a magnificent and innovative beast,
what has become of it? The music biz really put it thru the ringer, huh? So
much for the positive vibe it had back in the day. It has become merely a
cliche of itself, much like contemporary R&B, heavy metal and punk.
        I've been doing this "dance thang" for years now (though I'd hate
to call myself (old-skool") and one of the things that amazes me is how
little musical background and history people have. Sometimes you've gotta
go backwards for a while, to go forward. Even so, there ain't no better
place than RIGHT NOW. And right now means a summation of all that has gone
before, with an eye and an ear on the future.
Respect,
Andrew R

        *****************************************************
        WAXING LYRICAL 'BOUT 1971...THE HANGOVER OF THE '60s.
        *****************************************************

Well, it's timely that you ask that question.  Though we're not really 
 doing a party but a celebration of prayer/meditation/visualization and 
 dance based around the GaiaMind project, it'll be free and we're in 
 the midst of planning it with others.  Read below and come join us to 
 see what transpires when money is not the object.

Evolution - A Celebration of Life
---------------------------------------
On January 23rd, 1997, the Evolution Collective is facilitating a free 
 Bay Area gathering for the GaiaMind global meditation and prayer.  
 Evolution gatherings are a forum for relation, creation, and 
 manifestation integrating ritual, movement, and rhythm.  We invite you 
 to contribute to the realization of this goal.   For more info, call 
 415.908.6717.

GaiaMind Global Meditation and Prayer
January 23, 1997
9:30am - 9:35 am PST

Imagine people all over the world sharing a moment of meditation and 
 prayer, a moment of unified global consciousness when people from the 
 world's many diverse spiritual traditions simultaneously focus 
 attention on our interconnected relationship with Gaia--the living 
 earth.  Each persons brings love, compassion and understanding to 
 embrace the possibility of healing the social, ecological and 
 spiritual challenges before us.  As we approach the interdependence, 
 we may choose to join together as a global community in such a moment 
 to catalyze planetary transformation by both envisioning the light and 
 facing the darkness of our times.

On January 23, 1997, there will be an exceedingly rare and archetypally 
 appropriate planetary alignment, a moment in time express in the 
 heavens as a perfect six-pointed star.  This pattern comes on the 
 exact day that three outer planets, Jupiter, Uranus, and Neptune are 
 cojoined together for the first time in almost two hundred years.  Not 
 since the Renaissance have all five out-most planets been so 
 harmoniously arrayed.  On January 23rd, this cluster of planets will 
 center on the first degrees of Aquarius, joined by the Sun, with the 
 Full Moon opposite them all.

The geometric perfection of this pattern serves as a symbol of a unique 
 moment of opportunity, a day on which people all over the world may 
 come together to participate in an intentional expression of the 
 emergent unified planetary consciousness--to affirm that we are all one.

Participation is simple.  On January 23rd, meditate, pray or do 
 whatever brings you into closer contact with the Divine for five 
 minutes starting at the local equivalent of 9:30am PST.  Then, at 
 9:35am PST, join in a minute of focused visualization.  White light 
 seems to be the most universal spiritual archetype, so we suggest 
 envisioning white light in unison as a way to bring ourselves into 
 resonance at the moment the astrological star pattern become exact in 
 New York City.

In addition to the simultaneous global meditation and prayer, many may 
 choose to celebrate the moment when this pattern in the heavens become 
 exact at their own unique place on the Earth.  The alignment pattern 
 will sweep around the plane over 24 hours like a vast relay race in 
 consciousness, perfecting sometime between noon and 1pm across each 
 time zone.  The easiest way to find the precise time for your location 
 is to have an astrologer cast a chart with four degrees Gemini rising 
 on January 23rd at your latitude and longitude.  Astrologically, this 
 particular date represents the first of a series of exceedingly rare 
 multiple conjunctions in the first degrees of Aquarius spanning 
 several weeks.  Archetypically, the major planets involved represent 
 the benevolent expansion of spiritual liberation.

Your help is crucial to spread awareness of this opportunity to 
 catalyze the transformation of global consciousness.  By sharing this 
 information with others in your community, you will help ensure this 
 is truly an international event.  Please photocopy and distribute this 
 flyer to anyone who might be interested.
----------

Just wanted to drop a personal line to Tony and say THANKS  for throwing that 
schwa party last weekend.  It really "hit the spot", exactly!  I had tried to 
go to a party on Friday, but ended up driving a friend all over the city 
looking for her boyfriend. Saturday, I got a flat trying to get to F-8 to buy 
tickets to Karma, got there and it was sold out, but a couple kids on the 
street had two extras (thanks!).  Then, ten minutes after getting to Karma, it 
was busted. Went to 6th and Mission, went in, and was told that street cleaning 
was that night, so I should move my car. Very thoughful. Then, went on an 
errand and bought a little JD for the guy groovin in  his wheelchair. Finally, 
danced danced danced danced.  So much pent up energy was released, It  felt 
truly amazing.  

The party was great, a very diverse crowd: gay and straight, a couple folks in 
wheelchairs, and a slightly older crowd (which is nice to see every now and 
again for us old ravers [scenesters?]!).  Brought a newbie there, and she had a 
great time!  It was really interesting to ask here on the way there what her 
expectations were, and then afterwards what she thought of it. Anywayz, 
hopefully will see y'all at Freaky ppl tonight, but I'm a little hung over from 
a crazy xmas party at the Cal. Culinary institutes. Adios!!!!!

-Nathan

ARE MANY...

On Thu, 12 Dec 1996, michal migurski wrote:

> >-gabber
> 
> 150-200bpm slamming hammer drums and people hollering and lots of samples
> that are so horrifying, so shocking, they're comical. I can't for the life
> of me take gabber seriously, but I like it. is it supposed to be take
> seriously???

	Hmmph... Yes it is my usual spouting place. Gabber starts around 
170, 150 is a little slow, and heads up above 300 bpm (though I cannot 
keep up with beats that fast). Samples, I assume voice samples, can be 
present, especially in the shit coming out of LA which oozes attitude. 
Some people like those samples, I do not. There are some labels out of 
France and Scotland that produce >driving< hard kicked gabber that pushes 
hard and makes me dance and stomp and growl and howl... Just like most 
other types of music, there is gabber that is complete SHITE and gabber 
that is really good. SF doesn't seem 
to like it, so I routinely get up on my soapbox to hopefully keep people 
somewhat open to it....
	If goa can be considered driving and full of energy, then gabber 
that has been pressed well with some attention payed to some that 
kickdown sounds when a needle plays it back should knock those people's 
socks off as they stomp harder and harder ;)

dave

 GOOD LUCK TOTEM

                                                \\\\\\///
                                                =========
                                              ^ \ O   O \
                                             / \  \v_'/
                                              #   _\ \_
                                             (#) (     )
                                              #\//\* *\\\
                                              #\/(  *  )/
                                              #   =====
                                              #   (\\/)
                                              #   \\ \\
                                             .#.--'\ \---.
                                              #'---' ----'

      This totem has been sent to you for good luck.  It has been sent
      around the world nine times so far.  You will receive good luck
      within four days of relaying this totem.

      Send copies to people you think need good luck. Don't send
      money as fate has no price.  Do not keep this message.

      The totem must leave your hands in 96 hours. Send ten copies
      and see what happens in four days.  You will get a surprise.
      This is true, even if you are not superstitious.

      Good luck, but please remember: 10 copies of this message
      must leave your hands in 96 hours... You must not sign on this
      message...

the best party I went to this year was Vibrator in the Anza Borrego
desert. Beautiful flat translucent desert, pooled heavens... and the
people were truly extensions of their surroundings. I cannot express how
much FUCKING fun I had. It was one of those parties that you always think
you've had but don't really realize what its all about until you're there.
I feel that it was by far the most positive, sincere, sharing, absolutely
free party I have ever been to, 
and maybe it will be that way forever. I guess I won't
know until I get there. 

Definitely up there: Ascension, also in the Anza Borrego.

there were a lot of memorable times this year, but here are the one's that
stick out the most...

1. watching the space shuttle fly over freedom at 5 in the morning.
2. Psycobitch and Ms. Thing on 6 at Fusion...the bitches are BAD!!!! whoever
says women can't be djs is full of sh!t.
3. kicking it with Right Front Speaker Family during the summer (even if we
weren't at the right front speaker at Freedom) I LOVE YOU GUYS!!!
4. Freedom...one of the best (and dirtiest) parties i've ever been to. tony,
dan, jon williams, spun, and the idjut boys fucked it up. "feel my
motherfuckin' bass in your face!" i can't wait until next year.
5. Unity....a good party for a good cause. dubtribe fucked it up!
6. watching abbey shake her groove thing in front of the decks whenever jeno
was spinning!
7. the come-unity 5 yr....jeno, garth, and astralmatrix....need i say more. 
8. cracking up in my car with my friends on the way to parties. hey sarvi,
"CLEAR!!!"
9. dmitry and doc martin back to back at eon in january.
10. watching tony dance at any party

i hope to see everyone at freedom on the 21st. 

dorena

Precedence: bulk

Thanks to all who dug my message.  I probably jumped a little hard for a first 
posting so apologies if I offended anyone.  

As one sees the dance music movement crystallizing into a solid entity and 
greedy hucksters try and turn it into the next Rap Industry it stirs the emotions.

I remember ghetto kids with their cardboard and boomboxes breakdancing on the 
streets of LA and you couldn't give Hip Hop away to the record labels there.  They 
wouldn't touch it and laughed at it like it was worthless junk.

Same for Punk Rock, New Wave, etc. etc.

The True Underground will never die and we don't need to cry over "the dayz" 
because the best are yet to come.

My most positive thought is that if there is any chance for world peace and unity 
among all Earthlings then it might come about through dance music and partying 
because no matter what your persuasion the pretenses end on the dancefloor.

Love to All Dancers and Peacemakers

DJ ASB

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Dec 14 14:37:18 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id OAA19072; Sat, 14 Dec 1996 14:37:18 -0800 (PST)
Received: from nak.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with ESMTP id OAA19067; Sat, 14 Dec 1996 14:37:14 -0800 (PST)
Received: from ucdata.Berkeley.EDU.ucdt (ucdata.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.165.25]) by nak.berkeley.edu (8.7.3/8.6.10) with SMTP id OAA21092 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Sat, 14 Dec 1996 14:37:12 -0800 (PST)
Received: by ucdata.Berkeley.EDU.ucdt (SMI-8.6/SMI-SVR4)
	id OAA04328; Sat, 14 Dec 1996 14:35:20 -0800
Date: Sat, 14 Dec 1996 14:35:19 -0800 (PST)
From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: Wrong Way Friday Night
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9612141435.A4227-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Took a couple of wrong turns last night and ended up at 1015, instead of 
the original destination of :) Freaky People.  Had to do with a non-raver 
friend's birthday, and me picking up a nasty cold.  Saw the doctor Friday 
morning and she said there was (quote) an "epidemic!"  (Right, KaySEE?!) Be 
careful, folks.  Be mean ravers and don't share those water bottles, 'kay? ;)

So after a day of sleeping, and a couple of WEEKS of anticipation, I 
could not stay in last night, though an all-night freak fest was out of 
the question.  My booty wanted to DANCE!  After hitting up the cheesy 
Cadillac Bar (which features the world's best bartender, spinning bottles 
and building glass pyramids - I love a showman!), 1015 was on - Donald 
Glaude and Scott Henry (Wash DC) guestdj'ing.

But folks, I am here to officially announce that Nikita is DEAD.  I was 
hoping that at least Donald would induce some of the family to come 
out.  Instead, as Donald dropped the fat beats, only me and like five 
other gruvers were gettin down on the dancefloor.  The rest of the 
crowd consisted of single guys, clutching beer bottles and STANDING on 
the dancefloor.  The high sausage ratio created the very weird vibe of an 
intended pick-up scene thwarted - lotsa guys bemoaning the lack of 
chicks, unable to pick up on anyone and unable to think of anything else 
to do.

Donald's dreads were flying, he was jumping up and down, scratchin' and 
rappin' (I love a showman!) and I was dancing all over the place - until 
my medicinal pot cookie wore off and the body aches and fever came back 
full force.  I had to leave, sorry to miss the end of a tight set, but no 
regrets about abandoning the venue.  Ironically, the front room (rap and 
Wild107 house) was much more crowded - couples doin their thing.  I can't 
report on the 3-hour set by Jerry Bonham in the (so-called) "Underground."

Clubland - when will I learn?  I just want to dance to some great dj's in 
a comfortable locale with some alcohol.  But the majority of people who 
come are there for a different purpose, and enduring the pick-up vibe can 
ruin a night.  I love all the other dancers on the floor though - 
watching others last night I had the wonderfully warm feeling that these 
were my brothers and sisters - Brothers and Sisters of the Groove! :) :)

-N

the dance studio

What a year!  Here are my highlights

=80 Further adventures in debauchery at Stompy Cafe

=80 Chrysalis 1/13/96 - startin it off right

=80 Stacey Pullin + Derrick May.  Aaaahhh shit!

=80 Cesar & myself on the 2x4 @ All Together Now, 4 Tables, 2 =
Playahs, 1 Love

=80 A perfect day to play @ Sunset.

=80 Orbital @ da Fillmoe

=80 Record Shopping with Cesar @ Gramaphone in Chicago.  Pizza in =
Chicago (mmmm!)

=80 Too much fun at the Sunset Boat Parties

=80 FTT Halloween (what I remember of it)

=80 Carl Cox @ 1015 Folsom.  Merciless!!!

=80 DJ Hyperactive & J. Saul Kane @ Be Here Now.  The chunky & the =
thick.  Like (peanut) Buttah!

=80 Getting pschitt from my employer for the high volume of e-mail =
after subscribing to this list...Oh Well...

=80 Sobriety Binges.  What a trip.

=80 Sally [hoochie supreme]

=80 Christmas in Cabo San Lucas (coming soon...).  I'm dreaming of a =
white (sand) X-Mas!

Here's to the future.
- Dre

[ to sfraves ][ not rave related ]

Andy Nourse gave us the latest word -
> >Houghton Mifflin Interactive is sponsoring the Polar Bear Express Share
> >the Spirit Campaign.  For every 25 e-mail messages they receive, HMI
> >will donate a copy of The Polar Bear Express or another Children's book to a
> >children's Hospital.
> 
> This is a hoax.
> The responses have been overwhelming Houghton Mifflin's mail servers
> and they have asked people to please stop sending them mail.

 Not really a "hoax", as this books-for-email campaign was started by
HMI, and there is an official web site about it. I just think that HMI
never realized how wide the Internet's reach is nowadays. I bet they don't
do it the same way next year, if at all. 

 Considering that SFRaves got this 4 or 5 times since Wednesday, I can
imagine how it's going around in the "outside" Internet world...

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

there's a video by an up'n'coming film maker named Kenji Williams (from 
Boulder, Co) called Moment Utopia which is amazing... it juxtaposes raves 
and aboriginal culture... with some great footage of toronto and LA 
parties (i beleive it's moontribe)...

contact him at

i think he sells them for $20, maybe less...

still trying to find a word for the positive vibes and NRG that i felt 
last night...
	fucking BEAUTIFUL?!?!?! 
	no, that doesn't even give it justice. the music was pumpin, excuse me 
did i hear JUNGLE there? (when ah pull mah trigga fingah...) ahh ya :>> 
dancin so hard i feel like i'm floating (or was it the fact i was 
standing in the sand? yay!)
	the people were beautiful, and happy. i didnt meet a single person with 
negative vibes. and all the silver came out of the stuff in my hair, but 
if anyone ever gets the chance to strip up an emergency blanket and put 
it in their hair, it feels so neat! especially running down the street 
at 6:30 in the morning! major props to the guys who dressed as women 
(nice beard!) and everyone else who got funked out last night! i didn't 
feel alone! :>> 
 i'm still high off the love in that party last night.... and HELLO to 
all you SFRavers who i saw and hugged and smiled to!!!! YOU are ALL 
beautiful!!! :>>> 
Take care and much love,
LAra

cures you of any infection you may have.

the doctor perscribes.

hi all:

after a long day of coding, i've got the site set up to generate playlists
based on genre and codec.  i also modified the code to generate a more
random playlist.

anyway, if you have RealAudio 3.0 and a 28.8 modem, you can get a feel for
what's coming by hitting the following url:

http://www.x-radio.com/xradcgi/make_playlist.cgi?genre=trance&codec=ra3.288

i've only got TWO songs encoded for RA 3.0 right now, so it's a tiny, tiny
playlist, but it sounds a lot better than the old RA 2.0 codec...

there's been a lot of people hitting the server tonight, so you might have
trouble getting a slot.  just keep trying and you'll slip in soon enough..

also, i'm getting a 100-cd changer that i'll be connecting up.  (yeah!)

have a killer Saturday night!
pauly

Subject: Re: who wants to be a techno dictionary?
Date: Sat, 14 Dec 96 21:00:32 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
