Precedence: bulk


rawnsley@hotwired.com (Andrew Rawnsley):
>Gabber is the Punk Rock of Rave... spouting forth from the football
>hooligan and fascist infected terraces of Rotterdam. Working class music of
>the '90s.

First, there's nothing wrong with being working class. Just because you
work on computers doesn't suddenly make you rise above the working
class. In fact, knowing the way HotWired pays&treats people, you're
prolly working class too :-). Within 10 years, all of us computer
literate technoid folks will be like plumbers -- working class. So
instead of dissing the working class, you should seek solidarity with
your future bretheren. Either that, or get real good at wearing a tie,
fuck over a few honest hard-working coworkers, and you may be given the
credentials to rise out of working class and into "upper management."
...

Second, I don't think yours is an accurate comparison because punk rock
originally was not "fascist infected" nor "hooligan". It was anarchist,
it fully realized that the pseudo-liberalism of the hippies wasn't
actually helping the majority of people, just an excuse for people to
act flakey, take lots of drugs, and fuck a lot while claiming they were
doing their own thing. The government loved this as it made a whole
class of people too caught up in hedonism to be effective at achieving
political change. Once the young hedonists became "of age" (i.e. over
50), you could throw a few bribes at the average "inhaler" (e.g. Bill
Clinton) and they'd be happy to sell out their college-bred liberalism
to the all-powerful cororate hegemony which governs the nations of the
world.

I think the hooligan/fascist aspects of punk happened once punk was
"dead" (about '81). Of course groups like Television, the Buzzcocks,
and even Devo continued doing the punk thing with "art school"
sensibilities. No fascists there, no hooliganism -- in fact, some
incredibly well-written and poignant songs. I still play them nowadays
to hear how a song *SHOULD* sound now that "punk" is  defined as the
unintelligable muttering of strung out seattle heroin addicts, or
musclehead racist idiots ranting hatred.

Post-death, punk spintered off into new wave (e.g. elvis costello,
talking heads), and experimental synth noise ala Psychic TV, Cabaret
Voltaire, Nervous Gender, etc. In the latter group, we see a lot of
techno progenitors setting up shop (Genesis P Orrige, Richard Kirk).
Not a fascist or hooligan in the whole lot mentioned above. Anarchist,
perhaps... twisted unchristian noise torturers, definitely.

The "fascist" aspect of punk also raised it's ugly head in the mid 80's
-- long after punk was dead. Oi Music, and in the USA, the Aryan
Nations neo-nazi movement (Metzger) embranced the power of punk to
disseminate a message of racial hate and fascism. But that's not punk
-- that's skinheads. And I believe they're glomming on to the raw
energy of gabber in europe in order to disseminate hate amongst the
downtrodden "poor white trash" of europe. Wide distribution of
methamphetamines is fueling the fascist gabber wave of europe, just
like it fueled the armies of Hitler and Hirohito. (did you know that
the US Armed forces *ordered* battlefield soldiers to take
methamphetamines under penalty of court martial in order to be able to
fight the tweaked-out german and japanese armies? Brings a whole new
meaning to "war on drugs" eh?).

Anways... Certainly some punks played fast and loose with fascist
sybols (e.g.  swastikas). I never appreciated that, but I certainly
understand it -- shock value to rattle a society composed of idiotic
corporate drones spouting about freedom and democracy while not even
noticing their own shackles.

Like I said before, what the rave scene needs nowadays is to get back
to "punk" sensibilities of DIY parties and music (not the fascism).
At least they're not playing Jungle on Live 105...

Rantingly yours,
	Niels...

== When yer swimming in a creek and an eel bites yer cheek, that's a moray!==

Precedence: bulk

Excellent rant.  I don't detect any disdain from Rawno about the "working class,"
actually.  The UK and Europe have gone through at least two generations now of
having a permanent "dole class" of working-class kids who in fact don't end up
getting work, mostly because there isn't any.  For good or ill, the Sex Pistols
articulated their perspective and ignited the musical styles and sensibilities
of a generation.  It's a mixed bag.  The Clash, the Two-Tone bands, 
"We Don't Need That Fascist Groove Thang," the Summer of Love and the UK/European
rave scene at its best represent to a great degree a positive response to those
conditions of social and economic repression.  The National Front, football
(soccer) hooliganism and all kinds of protofascist musical styles borrowing on
the harder-edge rock, punk and techno schemes are another direction.  

In my view, class and race divide us here as they do in Europe and the UK, but
in different proportions.  Race is the more predominant factor here.  House music
(and E) had, for at least a while, the miraculous effect of lowering those 
barriers at least for some people, at least for a time.  Which is why many of us
latter-day-old-skoolers still believe in the House Nation (though we do't tend
to preach about it, knowing that actions are more persuasive than words, especially
now).  One of the things I was rather surprised to learn was the lowering of
social barriers across class lines in the UK and Europe during the post-Summer of
Love era, especially across relatively artificial geographic barriers epitomized
by football rivalries -- Manchester vs. Leeds, UK vs. Germany, etc.  More
recently, even our house and techno heroes seem to be reinforcing those trends,
though -- note the tremendous response in the UK to "lager, lager, lager," which
has no cultural handles for us Americans.  

Gabber is fast, hard, uncompromising, insular.  The energy is well-aligned with
the groups that Rawno was talking about.  As music, I don't think much of it,
but like anything there is some of value and I'm actually quite glad Dave Bayer
among others has gotten into it and presents it publicly in a serious way.  
It's one of the many styles of music I see rooted in the disaffection of an
increasing number of people about how our society is running our planet -- not
in a conscious 'political' sense but one that is an expression of personal
emotion, just like hip hop was before Madison Avenue took control.  At the same
time, gabber has a bit of an admittedly Beavis'n'Butthead humorous stance.

So here's a situation where I find myself pretty much in agreement with what
both Rawno and Niels said.  Music has always been used to draw support for
populist movements -- "We Shall Overcome" is probably the most famous example.
The "Christian rock" and "fascist punk/techno" trends both represent to me 
the way other groups have learned to use music to get out their messages.
Even though we may like to think of music as being removed from the political
and social sphere, it never is and the picture is always getting murkier.

One correction.  "Skinheads" come from all across the political spectrum, 
although attention generally gets focuses on the neo-fascist ones, who are
certainly at least a substantial minority.  One response to this I've often
heard is, "there are no racist skinheads, just bald-headed fascists" sums
up the view of the other side.  Again, many of the cultural shadings here are
lost in translation across the Atlantic.  The Two-Tone era (the "first ska
revival" of 1979-80 with bands like The Selecter, Madness and so on) was 
basically a biracial antifascist skinhead movement.  Something that only ever
had faint echoes here in the US . . .

Just my rant-o-the-week . . .

phred

Here's a list of some of the things that I like in the morning after a fun
party:
-being barely able to walk straight enough to get to my Bug, but somehow
having no problem driving properly all the way home, and then being barely
able to walk out of the Bug and into bed
-listening to that "Stayup" guy on KLON 88.1fm playing Dixieland Jazz as I
try to drive home properly :)
-trying to remember who all I promised to give mixtapes to this time :D
-looking at my rekkid crate and thinking, "Wow, I think I spun 8 rekkids
tonight and I brought about 40!"  But if those other 32 hadn't been there,
I know it wouldn't have been the same :)
-knowing that sometime next week a memory is going to hit from that party
that I have just not been able to remember until that point, and at that
moment, I will feel all the love and happiness that kept me vibin' all
night :)

*hugs* to everyone, it's time for Uncle Noah to go to bed.
PLUR
sweet dreams! :)

From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Phred sez:
>One correction.  "Skinheads" come from all across the political spectrum, 
>although attention generally gets focuses on the neo-fascist ones, who are
>certainly at least a substantial minority.  One response to this I've often
>heard is, "there are no racist skinheads, just bald-headed fascists" sums
>up the view of the other side.  Again, many of the cultural shadings here are
>lost in translation across the Atlantic.  The Two-Tone era (the "first ska
>revival" of 1979-80 with bands like The Selecter, Madness and so on) was 
>basically a biracial antifascist skinhead movement.  Something that only ever
>had faint echoes here in the US . . .

Yeah, I agree I too-strongly pigeonholed skinheads. However, IMHO, the
skinhead movement pretty much died around 81 along with the death of 
punk. I was totally in to the "two tone" skin (and punk) stuff myself
when i was in high-school, and from my POV it truly was not a racist
movement.

However, IMHO, anybody that calls themself a skinhead today is pretty
much a "bald-headed fascist"... yeah, there are the "straight-edge
skins" and other such movements, but they really dwarf the fascist
skins, at least in the US. If nothing else, the remaining non-fascist
skins probably get too tired saying "no, i'm not a racist" to society
at large...  at some point they decided it isn't worth it and seek
another clique. But that's just my opinion.

The Alchemist sez:
> as far as genesis p-orridge is coumcerned, he did explore facets of 
> neo-facism in the Throbbing Gristle days which co-existed with punk...

I screwed up in my post when i tied GPO/Psychic TV/punk together. Yes,
I really meant Throbbing Gristle, but due to a brain glitch, I didn't
say that. 

I actually was a little into Throbbing Gristle back in the day, and
even saw them live once. I personally didn't think they were exploring 
neo-fascism. I do think they were exploring paganism, shock-value, and 
any fringe they could exploit. Buncha weirdoes. But they beat the hell
out of REO Journeywagon shite that most everybody else in my town were
listening to at the time!

--------------------

Getting back into the two-tone/mod/skin thing -- i think y'all should
check out the Who's movie "Quadrophenia."  Provides some interesting 
historical parallels on every new genre of music that has emerged since
the 60's... Seems like each generation's coming-of-age
music/fashion/ethos is really the same old thing with a different beat
and different drugs.

I often wonder what happens to the people that were fully into their
"youth culture scene" when they were 16-24 and now they're just more
same-looking blue-haired middle-aged drones inhabiting a mini-mall,
clutching gifts of plasticene consumer goods. If you look closely
enough at some of those 50ish ladies, you might see the ghost of a the
high-school girl in the miniskirt that was partying down to rock and
roll and riding around in a  souped up roadster, hair flying in the
wind... Sometimes you see that 70 year old who musta been the king of
the jazz juke-joint dance floor, flipping his partner overhead while
dressed sharply, cept now he's walking all jittery with a cane. So...
when y'all are 50, will you still be wearing silvery pants and
clutching teddy bears and raving all night? If not, why not? Will you
miss it?  Will you diss the music your children are listening to as
"noise"?? Will you spend hours boring your grandchildren with stories
about how you saw the great starspangled fritillary one morning at 7AM
and the kids'll just look at each other and say, "yeah, gramps is
losing it again... let's hope he doesn't start yammering on about about
how thick the vibe was back in the day!"

==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==
== When yer swimming in a creek and an eel bites yer cheek, that's a moray!==

> I screwed up in my post when i tied GPO/Psychic TV/punk together. Yes,

you lucky bastard!  did you see the final show in frisco?  gen did 
explore neo-facism through throbbing gristle for a while (songs like 
"discipline" etc... they built it up until their following started 
wearing the military garb the band was donning at the time, and when it 
reached the peak of all these kids in army duds with arm bands and the 
lot, they appeared on stage wearing white frilly gowns and the crowd lost 
it... saying "throbbing gristle has sold out!" ...interesting cultural 
experiment... i wonder how many people caught on that they were mere 
pawns in a game...

Hello everyone!

	Well, we have to give massive thanks to all of you who came out and showed
your support! (that includes all 10,000 of you ;)
	The party was insane! The music rocked hard all night long! And the energy
seemed to never stop peaking! The whole dress up thing was pretty cool. You
guys should dress up all the time. I would have but I didn't get my neon
fuzzy fur in time! So with our tradition of Friday the 13th, we got busted.
Although, it was late (or early) enough not really make that big of a
difference. (6:30 am) But all in all, we all had lots of fun and it was
really beautiful. So once again, <<<Thank you>>>
	Also, a super, duper, HUGE thank you to however clean that party up. I
fell asleep and little elves came and cleaned the whole thing! (Thank god!)
You guys know who you are!

	Now here are some of my gripes:
		1. Never before have I ever had to bring this up after a Harmony party,
but 		someone finally screwed up.- We got tagged. It was actually the same
person that 		tagged Lepidoptra. The person tags, "PLUR." Note to this
person-the "R" stands 		for Respect. By tagging you do not respect the
space in which you are parting in. 		You do not respect the promoter/s who
have to go and clean it up. Nor do you 		respect the money that the
promoter looses when you decide to do the stupidest 		thing in the world.
(tagging)
		"Art" has it's place, but tagging is not "art." If you want to express
your "art" at one 		of my parties, you are more than welcome to. In fact, I
can arrange an entire wall 		for your "art." But just sneaking into the
bathroom and tagging a TOILET, is really 		immature and has no place at the
Harmony events. So please do not do this any 		more. We respect you by not
searching your bags (and taking you pens) on the 		way in, so respect us by
not tagging our spaces. Space owners do not like this! 		And of course this
is why there aren't that many spaces left. You need to realize 		that
promoters are loosing spaces because of your actions. Pretty soon you'll
have 		no spaces to tag anyway! Hmmm. I wonder if you'll tag your own toilet?

		2. Beautiful people, I am sorry if any of you got hurt when there was
someone 		loosing control of their trip. Those things just should not
happen, but when it does, 		we all need to be aware that "these things
happen." If anyone hears of any info 		about the man we had taken to the
hospital, please send it to me. -thanks and 		once again, sorry if you had
to deal with that.

		3. Sorry if you missed the map point. We sold out way fast! And then
sorry to all of 		you guys that we packed like sardines. We over estimated
the ticket count. Oops!

	So look for the next party in Jan. of '97. And we'll see you all soon.
Take care.

[ to sfraves ]
Recently, this was posted - 
> I often wonder what happens to the people that were fully into their
> "youth culture scene" when they were 16-24 and now they're just more
> same-looking blue-haired middle-aged drones inhabiting a mini-mall,
> clutching gifts of plasticene consumer goods. ... So...
> when y'all are 50, will you still be wearing silvery pants and
> clutching teddy bears and raving all night?

 What I thought of was "what happens when ravers become parents?". So
many of the "youth cultures" , identified by definition with adolescence
and just-post-adolescence , pay little attention to the baby-raising aspects 
of life. 

 Being a raver and being a parent - would people who are in that
position please clue us in on your experience?

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com
 
PS - I've never worn silvery pants or danced with a stuffed toy (yet).

places on the net for both Mac & PC. Some of these have registration fees,
but they're all "try before you buy."

Larry, okay, I'm not a parent.  I am still my parent's child.  But as I am
in the throws of early adulthood I do know one thing: Among the many things
around me and about me that I don't know, I do know that I am me.  The
culture that I'm "into" is an expression of a part of me and if there are
other people around me who desire to express their selfs in a way which is
harmonious with my own expressions, then that is an experience.  For me I
can't really allow that to make the leap into "culture".  I know for myself
that I am individualistic in a lot of ways - I will not do what everyone
else is doing because it is fashion/fad/in/pop/culture just as I will not
go against something just for the sake of individualism/rebellion/anarchy.
I am wrong often more times than I am right, but I try my hardest to do
what I think is not only is "best" for me, but also make me feel good while
enhancing my "self" without compromising the belief systems, moralities and
makeup of others.  Yes I am young, but these ideals are a part of me and
who I am, not implanted by a scholastic/religous/cult/pop institution and I
hope to live by them and carry them with me all of my life - whether it is
now, thirty, forty, fifty, sixty, seventy, eighty, ninety, one hundred,
married, single, with children, emotionally stable, flipping out, happy,
sad, here in the S.F. Bay Area or whatever/whoever/whenever else because
there's really only one person I have to be comfortable with, and that's
me.

Peace, Daniel

<National Hippy Day Jan. 18th, 1997>

From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: (NRR) Life in the Big City?
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9612151949.A7162-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Friends, I need your help in making a serious decision in my life...

It's been six months since I graduated college and still I sit in student 
housing, working for the University, dealing with Telegraph every day, 
and going to the same old Berkeley house parties on the weekends.  And as 
the year comes to a close, it's becoming more and more clear that it's 
time to MOVE ON - to allow the tides of change to sweep me along to a new 
phase of my life.  It's scary to leave something safe, something known, 
but I know in my heart resisting the flow is wrong.  And everything in me 
says to let go of my old life and take a deep breath and go...

So, I am thinking of abandoning all here and... (TA DA!) moving to San 
Francisco!!  I'll need a job, and an apartment, and new San Francisco 
friends, and it all seems like so much - but I don't want fear to keep me 
chained to a way of life that no longer offers growth for me.

Unfortunately, I'm pretty clueless about the City.  What I really need 
from all of you SF people are your experiences in the City.  What are the 
best neighborhoods?  How much does it really cost to live there?  What 
do you love/what do you hate?  Is it really impossible to have a car?  
And whatever else comes to mind...  And if anyone has been through 
the dislocating experience of graduating and having no clue what to do 
with yourself, a note of support would be MUCH appreciated!!  Change can 
be the hardest thing to deal with...

Thank you in advance!

Nancy

"ARTHUR BRYSON (DJ ASB)" <cmgmedia@razorlogic.com> wrote:
>Commercialism isn't "threatening to take over" it took over in the
>early part of this centery when "Underground" prohibition parties
>played Flapper music in the Roaring 20's.

This just reminded me of a passage from a book:

"An experience fell to my lot this night of the Ball that I had never known
in all my fifty years, though it is known to every flapper and student--the
intoxication of a general festivity, the mysterious merging of the
personality in the mass, the mystic union of joy.  I had often heard it
spoken of...  Even in recent days I had marveled at and loved and mocked
and envied this gleam and this smile in my friend, Pablo, when he hung over
his saxophone in the blissful intoxication of playing in the orchestra, or
when, enraptured and ecstatic, he looked over to the conductor, the drum,
or the man with the banjo.  It had somtimes occurred to me that such a
smile, such a childlike radiance could be possible only to quite young
persons or among those peoples whose customs permitted no marked differnces
between one individual and another.  But today, on this blessed night, I
myself, the Steppenwolf, was radiant with this smile.    I myself swam in
this deep and childlike happiness of a fairy tale.  I myself breathed the
sweet intoxication of a common dream and of music and rhythm and wine and
women--I, who had in other days so often listened with amusement, or dismal
superiority, to its panegyric in the ballroom chatter of some student.  I
was myself no longer.  My personality was dissolved in the intoxication of
the festivity like salt in water.  I danced with this woman or that, but it
was not only the one I had in my arms and whose hair brushed my face that
belonged to me.  All the other women who were dancing in the same room and
the same dance and to the same music, and whose radiant faces floated past
me like fantastic flowers, belonged to me, and I to them.  All of us had a
part in one another.  And the men, too.  I was with them, also.  They, too,
were no strangers to me.  Their smile was mine, and mine their wooing and
theirs mine."

That's from Steppenwolf, by Hermann Hesse, published 1927 (tr Basil
Creighton, 1929, revised).  You could see the whole book as about raving,
actually--it's basically the story of this guy who's depressed and solitary
but then meets a woman who teaches him how to party, and he wakes up to
things.  It's all encrusted with weighty philosophical veneer in typically
Germanic fashion, but that's the core of it.  The music is jazz, the drug
is alcohol, the dances are foxtrots and box-steps, but the vibe is the
same.

anarch@scruznet.com

"Ciaran OHara" <ciaran.ohara@CCMAIL.AirTouch.COM> wrote:
>Why does (for example) Live 105 "the alternative station" not play any
>dance music. Dance muisc is the real "alternative music" these
>days.

They do play a little, though strictly in the Prodigy, Chemical Brothers,
etc hit single vein--in other words, probably a negative rather than a
positive sign.  They used to do real dance music, actually, with proper DJs
coming in and spinning house and techno late Friday and Saturday nights.
That was three or four years ago, though.  I don't know when it stopped,
exactly, but it's been a long time.

>The Year In Review:
>
> 1. Best party you went to in 96?

Lunarseed with Caban, Goa Gil.

> 2. Worst party you went to in 96?

Chemical Brothers at the Trocadero (maybe that doesn't really count, but
all the real parties were pretty good).

I'd like to give an honorable mention here, since I didn't get to bitch
about it when it happened, for the worst party of ALL TIME: Dubtribe in
Santa Cruz, August, I think, of 95.

> 3. Best local DJ for 96?

Too many!

> 4. Best Non-local DJ for 96?

Donald Glaude.

> 7. Best mixtape for 96?

Ganesh, "Bass Chakra."

> 8. Worst mixtape for 96?

Ron D Core, "Blitzkrieg."

> 11. Favorite location for a party in 96?

Subud center in Soquel; Gazos Creek.

> 12. Least favorite spot for a party in 96?

Home Base.

> 13. Favorite thing to do after a party in 96?

Help clean up.

> 14. Favorite thing to wear to a party in 96?

Big black boots and piece-a-shit jacket.  Course, I have a pretty limited
wardrobe...I think I wore those to *every* party in 96.

> 15. The most you ever spent in one night at a party in 96?

$30.

> 16. If you can change one thing about raving in 96, what would it have been?

No cops.

anarch@scruznet.com

there were a bunch of great events that happened in the year of 1996...
but if i had to narrow it down to just 10, i guess these would be mine in
no particular order:

1- seeing dj Rap @ Funky Tekno Tribe-Tribal Massive (damn, it didn't look like
	home base to me! did you see those water fountains?)
2- Unity (the ohm chant brought a chill to my back! it was sooo awesome!)
3- driving down to LA for Funky Shit Happens with raf, sarvi, doug, and
	bryan (oh, and taking that picture under the hollywood sign)
4- watching carl cox @ nikita (enough said)
5- seeing the sun rise @ freedom on that tall ass hill we had to climb!
6- watching psychobitch and ms thang @ fusion (i've gotta go to chicago!)
7- all the parties @ 818 (james,mike, michael, doug, bryan-when are you guys
	gonna have another?)
8- making fun of sarvi every time she sees dj dan (and that thing she has
	in her wallet-HAHAHA) 
9- kickin' it with the Right Front Speaker Family before/during/after
 	each party (i love you guys! don't matter what STATE/city/mind we're
	in,  we'll always be family!)
10- celebrating 1 year with raf (who could believe things could be this
	good? i love you babe)

tah dah! there it is! i hope to add the gathering 12.21.96 to my list too!
(it made my '95 list for sure) i hope to see all of your guys there! 

byebye,
...jan...
delaja00@usfca.edu
(those are two zeros after 'delaja')

 I hadn't checked my sfraves mail for several days last week, so I
missed hearing about Jungle Love until after the fact. I had heard
about another thing going on at 330 Rich street. Did anyone else go?
Noel was spinning, who I had heard before and liked, along with a
couple other DJs I hadn't heard of. 

The place was not really at all what I was expecting. It struck me as
being a dinner club and coctails sort of place. When I first arrived
the music was not jungle and the few people there were either playing
pool or sitting at the shiek stainless steel candle-adorned tables.
I'm not sure who was creating the music or how I would go about
describing it, but it seemed at least partially live.

After about an hour, maybe, the jungle did start up and my body
obeyed. Through the whole course of the evening there were probably
never more than 15 people dancing at once.  I thought it was pleasant
to be completely uncramped. I had a really great time and the music
was excellent. 

I see that it is listed as a regular event on the calendar, described
as being a "showcase or all that encompasses electronic musiq." Does
this mean it is only occasionally a jungle happening? What sorts of
things do Miquel, Laron, Gabe Real, et. al. spin? What is the current
state of Audio Impact? The info in the calendar is incorrect now,
right?

Terrence.

>         The bay area is racially and culturally diverse. I want to see this more
>         in the parties i go to. If it's not happening I want to stay away or    
>         make my own......
> 

There are parties going on that tend to be more "diverse".
Unfortunately today the music scene has become somewhat segragated based allong musical styles and unfortunately race.  You
generally won't
find many people of color at a gabba or hard trance party, the high speed and pounding rhthyms tend to be contrary to what AA and
Latinos's groove to. Goa tends to be frequented primarily by Euros as well.  I don't think these people are exclusionary and almost
all of the CCC people that I've met have been wonderful loving people, the problem is I don't feel the music in my soul (and more
important, my pelvis :)

For a more diverse crowd you might want to check out the House and the Jungle scenes.  The legendary Wicked parties (now
infrequent) had a reputation for being very pan-cultural and pan-sexual.  If large massives are your thing, try Funky Techno Tribe
(the promoters themselves are about as diverse as you can get) and The Gathering.  For smaller parties it's more difficult because
the best ones nowa days are underground, but
for New Years day, stompy cafe will be the place to be, homeboys, crackerjacks, dancers, hookers and hos, DJs, DJ wanna bes, suits,
biker shorts, tank tops and ties. Don't forget your sunglasses and it's BYOB :)
(Bring you own Bottle- can I get a witness JSL )

If you are into the stylish house crowd (which is very mixed up culturally) try loveworks at 111 minna,  Also Culture/Root on
Wednesday nights at 1015 Folsom street. Harmony is a wonderful diverse party for all ages.
Look out for UGs like Anarchist's Disco and the up and coming Flava!
by me and JSL.


>         Why oh why oh why is there such a tendency for people to pigeonhole     
>        themselves to the extent that your into industrial so you wear black,    
>        you like trance so you wear glitter,etc. etc., 
> 

It seems to be the nature of groups to factionalize, which is unfortunate, but remember that House music was originally an
Afriamerican creation, it sprung up in parties that were mostly black and brown,  initially these parties were primarily the abode
of Gay Brothers but the music diversified (there is still a whole section of house that you will only here in black gay discos),
whites, straights started coming and indeed the true mission of House music is Universal Love so noone was ever excluded.  As it
bounced over to europe (the heart of Whiteness :) obviously the music mutated and the complexion of the parties changed, some of
the music generated was not a palatable to the "old skool" chicago crew, but as any of the Wicked DJs can tell you, you play what
you like and what is effective on the Dance Floor, Im a DJ, not a "house" Dj or a "trance" Dj or a "techno" DJ, but simply a DJ.  I
will play what moves me and the crowd at the moment. So since that thime the music has been fragmenting and spreading out, this is
a good thing. What is not a good thing is people who are talking about excluding various folks from their parties because of the
way they dress or their "tudes", let's remember we were all newbies once and " And, you see, no one man owns house because house
music is a universal language, spoken and understood by all." The goal is for each and every "raver" to generate so much Vibe, that
it melts the hearts of the toughest gangsters.
I've seen what a masterful DJ with the right records can do to a crowd that might have some of the toughest homies in it. PLUR
means absolutely nothing if it can't achieve this feat, for that's how the mesage is spread.


>         All this talk about gangstas (sic) at raves seems like a load of bs to  
>       me. Are certain people not acceptable at a party because they are not     
>         middle class and white ? 
>

Back in '93 there was a sound system company from LA that had alot of Gs in their employ.  They would come up here to set up the
systems and groove with us, the manager used to tell us "If you have any problems with Gs coming to your party don't worry, just
talk to one of my boys and they'll sort it out". G recognizes G no matter where your from, but JSL is right when he says that real
Gangsters don't go to Raves, the ones that do are looking for a way out of the Life that's why they're there.  We need to welcome
them and realize that their sensibilites, culture and experience can be different form ours.

 
>         Why does (for example) Live 105 "the alternative station" not play any  
>       dance music.            Dance muisc is the real "alternative music" these 
>        days. 

For the same reason they don't play any "modern rock" either.

"And in every house, you understand, there is a keeper.

And, in this house, the keeper is Jack.

Now some of you who might wonder, 

"Who is Jack, and what is it that Jack does?"

Jack is the one who gives you the power to jack your body!

Jack is the one who gives you the power to do the snake.

Jack is the one who gives you the key to the wiggly worm. 

Jack is the one who learns you how to walk your body. 

Jack is the one that can bring nations and nations of all Jackers together under one house.

You may be black, you may be white; you may be Jew or Gentile. It don't make a difference in OUR House.

And this is fresh.



See you on the dance floor.



						G

> > 16. If you can change one thing about raving in 96, what would it have been?
>

> No cops.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Dec 16 04:04:14 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id EAA26981; Mon, 16 Dec 1996 04:04:14 -0800 (PST)
Received: from precipice.v-site.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with SMTP id EAA26975; Mon, 16 Dec 1996 04:04:10 -0800 (PST)
Received: from ecotopia by precipice.v-site.net (8.6.10/SM-8.6.4)
	id EAA14470; Mon, 16 Dec 1996 04:07:21 -0800
Message-Id: <199612161207.EAA14470@precipice.v-site.net>
From: "Geoff White" <geoffw@cybertribe.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: XLR8R and beyond
Date: Mon, 16 Dec 1996 04:05:02 -0800
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Priority: 3
X-Mailer: Microsoft Internet Mail 4.70.1155
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I had a full on weekend of partying  (which I haven't done in a while :)
I started at the XLR8R release party, arriving with a friend who is sort of new to the whole SF Rave/House thing. Props go to the
XLR8R crew.
The space, (next to 111 minna) was totaly Rad, large and spacious, with plenty of room to dance. 

When i got there, there was some kick ass jungle going down. I liked what I heard but it didn't inspire me to dance, still, I could
see that some junglist seemed to appreciate what was going down. Mark E. Quark followed next on the house tip and I must admit that
I did catch a groove which felt good cuz I hadn't caught one in a while. When you go out, and really slide into trance long and
deep, it's like a night of excellent sex, the next morning you feel all content and relaxed and mellow and together. Wow.
I left rather early because I was to be the pilot on a special mission the next day.

Chico.

A party? In Chico!? Way out there? My stereotyping kickes in.
Oh no way man, beer guzzling meth sniffin farm boys? I ain't goin out there! 
"No Geoff, It's not like that, the kids are a little provintial but really kool"
"Hrummph, You want me to do what? drive out there? How far is it?
PAST SACREMENTO! 85 MILES TO THE NORTH!!, NO WAY MAN!!!"

I call Jeno at 11:15 to see if he's ready. I had wanted to leave an hour ago, but no-one was answering the phone :).  When I went
to my favorite car rental place, they didn't have any small cars so they had to give me a Jeep Cherokee for the price of an Economy
:) we would ride in style. 
11:30 comes, I get there ring him up on the cellular and tell him to come down stairs.  Some homies from the early days of the FMR
were around,
they were going to carry him if he haden't managed to get a ride (which was me) they weren't going to go because their car didn't
have a tapedeck
but my Jeep did so we all piled in, loaded the records, stopped at the store so I could get 3 bottles of diet pepsi (my fav driving
tweek), a serious gensing, superfood and some chips. Off we go by 12 (oops) Jeno is suppose to go on at 3:30 and it is a 3 hour
drive. We immediately hit heavy traffic on the the bay bridge going out of SF, (oops again) still, after we got over to the east
bay it was smooth sailing, up to Sacto and on over to 99. Driving through the dark, at one point we came to this bizarre sight! for
about an entire mile, there were hundreds of rabbits (maybe they were hares) on the right side of the road, hopping sitting,
standing, fucking, etc. it was truly bizzare, then  a road intersection and no more. Freaky.  99 is not a high-speed highway
straight through and I was not disposed to speed through an area that is foreign to me so I never went above 69.
Still we arrived at the venu at about 3:35. The promoter was freaking cuz he thought we weren't coming (oh ye of little faith). It
was different for me but then I haven't really experienced rave life much outside of the Bay Area. The clothes that the kids were
wearing were not quite the trendiest or the freshist and there did seem to be a lot of meth in the air, but all in all the party
was going off in a way that we no longer really see here in The City. La Ron had opened followed by Dj Tracy, this was a home-comin
for her since she lived there for 3 years. She now has her own fan club and young female proteges, one was really excited to tell
her that she had just got her mixer today! After a little freak-out of the promoter (who didn't think Jeno would show so he had
started to play) Jeno took the decks and played a realy great set to a very appreciative audience (this makes all the difference in
the world) Dimension 7 did the lights and the dancefloor had more vibe then I've felt at most SF parties in a while.  Indeed the
openess and enthusiasm shown there did make me realize raving is not dead it's,
"just sleeping in the hills". At one point there was a ruckuss at the door so the police were called, they came promptly and the
matter was sorted, I have to say that I never met nicer police, the woman gave us her card, said that she would be on duty till 3
am and told us who would replace her and if we had any trouble to just call, they seemed really happy and relieved that kids had a
place to go where alcohol was frowned upon (Chico is the home of sierra-nevada brewing company, can you say lots of cheap good
beer?). Still, if all promoters had police like these, the scene would be really different. It was soo nice to chill with the Chico
possee after Jeno's set, I brought 4 issues of XLR8R and the kids had never seen it before, they asked me how much they were and I
told them it was free, they couldn't believe it, a magazine that was filled with rave culture, one EmotivE young lady clutched her
magazine all night and kept hugging me saying to me thank you, thank you!
I have to say that I was skooled that evening, about the dangers of stereotypes, the power of the vibe, and the universaity of
House Music.
I caught a groove long and hard and looked over to my new found friends on the dance floor with that look that every raver knows is
available at around 4 am when the barriers come down and you find yourself "deep in the vibe of House", we connected and know that
we will always have that moment in eternity.
That party had more honest vibe and love then a stack of SF parties, it was well worth the 6 hour commute, and I would do it again
at the drop of a hat.  To the Chico Rave posse, Jeno and I had a wonderful time, thank you for your expression of love and respect.
Looking forward to seeing you again soon.



							G

From: http://www.urbanlegends.com/drugs/dead_baby_cocaine_smuggling.html
Forwarded-by: stevet@eskimo.com (Steven Thornton)

The Corpse Had A Familiar Face: Covering Miami, America's Hottest Beat
        -- by Edna Buchanan (New York: Random House, 1987), p.157:

The stories about drugs in Miami are also larger than life. So many are
true that even the myth of the dead baby has become accepted as modern
Miami-American folklore.

Let's get this straight right here and now: There is no cocaine-stuffed
dead baby, at least at this writing.

The dead baby resurfaces frequently, reported as fact in otherwise
responsible and prestigious -- and some not so responsible and prestigious
- -- publications. It has appeared on the front page of _The Washington
Post_, in _Life_ magazine, and in the _National Enquirer_.  The story,
with minor variations, is that an alert customs official, or airlines
employee on a Colombia-Miami flight noticed that a baby in the arms of a
woman passenger did not look well. Closer scrutiny revealed that the baby
was dead and its body stuffed with high-grade cocaine in an attempt to
smuggle the drug into this country.

The dead baby is reported at least once a year. Each time, I am one of
the many reporters assigned to check it out. It is fiction. It did not
happen.  I have laid the dead baby to rest so often that I can now see
its poor little pasty face in my mind's eye.

Edna Buchanan is a crime reporter for the Miami Herald.

Hello,

Well, when your buying a 10$ ticket from the back of a hatchback in an
alleyway off the SOMA district, you KNOW it's a UG party... 

Got there when the first DJ was spinning, danced a bit.  Really "got
there during MARS set, however, my leg re-pulled some muscle in my leg
in another (sigh) circle...

Chilled out a bit with the two newbes I brought along , did that, "mind
over matter thang" and went off during Mystr-E' s set (meditation is a
powerful tool).  Didn't do too much floor work, fast stepping, but did
some upper movements (and man are my shoulders sore).  

Getting pretty hardcorish in the morning  (DJ Tom?), but getting a bit
hungry @ about 5:30. Nice party all in all, bust out @ 6AM with some
friends to Dennys in Japantown....

Spent the rest of Sunday with my good friend Nature @ two different
beaches off Hwy 1.

"It sucks being misunderstood..."

_Adam

DAMN!! my ass got rocked!!!! My friend called me last night to go and see
orbital and chemical brothers...it wasnt until later that I realized it
was going to be 45 minutes of orbital and only an hour of chemical bros,
interspersed between...ummm other bands ;) well, anyways...orbital was
pretty good, it seemeed like alot of people didnt quite know what to do to
the sound of a beat...but we sure did!...but the highlight of the show was
the chemical brothers...one solid hour of serious getting down! those guys
did not let up the whole time...
	I was wondering how much of what they were playing is
pre-recorded? I've heard that alot of 'live' techno acts simply throw in a
dat and just jump around on stage...

<<1. Best party you went to in 96?
(tie)Emotion, Vancover BC, February
       Gateway, Portland OR. February
       Burning Man
2. Worst party you went to in 96?
I forget the name of the party, but it was at the ACME and Dan Curtain spun
there.  His set was dissapointing, and we had to wait thru some pretty bad
music until he came on.

3. Best local DJ for 96?
 Assuming that it is unfair to vote for one's self,there are several whom I
consider for this.  They are(in no particular order):
-Solar
-Joe Rice
-Felix

4. Best Non-local DJ for 96?
Stacey Pullen

5. Best record for 96?
Impossible to choose.
6. Worst record for 96?
The Macarena. Hands down.

7. Best mixtape for 96?
Assuming that a DJ only puts music he really likes on his/her mixtapes, I'd
have to vote for my own tape "Visions" on this one.  Forgive me.

8. Worst mixtape for 96?
I have no clue, but I'm sure there are many....

9. Best track for 96?
Impossible to choose.

10. Worst track for 96?
See # 6
11. Favorite location for a party in 96?
A boat.
The Black Rock Desert
12. Least favorite spot for a party in 96?
ACME

13. Favorite thing to do after a party in 96?
Sleep.

14. Favorite thing to wear to a party in 96?
Headphones.

15. The most you ever spent in one night at a party in 96?
I'll have to confer with my accountant on this one....

16. If you can change one thing about raving in 96, what would it have been?
I would make it so there were more new/relatively unknown DJ's played more;
There would 've been more FnF's; There would've been more cross-polination
between Deep House & Deep Techno, and  I would ban Goa Trance :) 

17. What the best DJ name in 96?
Who gives?
18. Worst DJ name in 96?
See above.

19. Best name for a party in 96?
Justice.
20. Worst name for a party in 96?
>>NYC
--Monty

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Dec 16 13:23:18 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id NAA11138; Mon, 16 Dec 1996 13:23:18 -0800 (PST)
Received: from adeskgate.autodesk.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with ESMTP id NAA11123; Mon, 16 Dec 1996 13:23:10 -0800 (PST)
Received: from autodesk.autodesk.com by adeskgate.autodesk.com (8.6.12/SMI-5.3) with ESMTP id NAA24106; Mon, 16 Dec 1996 13:22:39 -0800
Received: from klaatu.autodesk.com by autodesk.autodesk.com (8.6.12/4.4BSD) with ESMTP id NAA26578; Mon, 16 Dec 1996 13:21:42 -0800
Received: (from robertr@localhost) by klaatu.autodesk.com (8.7.5/8.7.3) id NAA16683 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Mon, 16 Dec 1996 13:21:38 -0800 (PST)
Date: Mon, 16 Dec 1996 13:21:38 -0800 (PST)
From: Rob Rayle <robertr@autodesk.com>
Message-Id: <199612162121.NAA16683@klaatu.autodesk.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: reviews
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



    Everything is subjective.

    Kundalini - 

	When I heard this thing was in Big Heart City, I had high
    hopes for it. I've been in this space to hear bands live, and I
    knew it had a good sound system, decent acoustics, good ventilation,
    and plenty of comfortable spaces for people to chill in. It seems like
    the promoters mostly took a tech/lighting approach to the space, which
    unforunately doesn't kill the clubby vibe. This space needs more emphasis
    on art objects. Something must be done about the pool tables. The club's
    owners were involved, keeping the bar open until 2AM. I only checked
    this place out for about ten minutes around midnight. I meant to get back
    to it later after the bar closed, but reality intervened. Anyone else know
    what happened here? If this space stays available, I'm sure someone will do
    some very cool things with it. 
 
    Digital Balance - 
	Map point in the Haight, party in Emeryville. It was busted by the time
    I got there. Oh well. Back to Soma for ...

    Galactic Tunnel - 

	Did somebody say underground? The party had this dark subterranean 
    ambiance. The name was apparently inspired by the shape of the main room, 
    which had the approximate relative dimensions of four shoeboxes laid 
    end-to-end. The speakers were positioned on either side of the tunnel,
    about midway down, facing the DJ. This is an acoustical nightmare. Once 
    the music got loud, every bass drum kick came back with a couple out of 
    time slapback echoes. Throw in long periods of time where the only
    lighting on the dance floor is a strobe light that's not synced to the
    beat. I'm surprised we're not seeing more epileptic seizures. Many people
    are apparently nodding out - slumped down along either side of the long wall
    of this dark tunnel. Are they wisely shutting this out? Is this meditation? 
    Or have I walked into a shooting gallery? Well, my mood is shot, anyway. 



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Dec 16 13:30:27 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id NAA11748; Mon, 16 Dec 1996 13:30:27 -0800 (PST)
Received: from trix.cisco.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with SMTP id NAA11736; Mon, 16 Dec 1996 13:30:21 -0800 (PST)
Received: (jwiley@localhost) by trix.cisco.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id NAA08284 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Mon, 16 Dec 1996 13:29:49 -0800
From: Jay Wiley <jwiley@cisco.com>
Message-Id: <199612162129.NAA08284@trix.cisco.com>
Subject: Freaky People
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 16 Dec 1996 13:29:49 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL25]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, this is the first review I've posted in a while.  Its also my last one
for a while. 

I'm glad I got the chance to meet everyone that I have in the past 6 months.

Thanks to the Harmony crew for letting me help out and be a part of your 
wonderful parties.

The party on Friday night was CRAZY!!  I was working water when Li started
spinning and by the time I made it to the dane floor a little after midnight
people were screaming and yelling and dancing like mad.  Magically the lighting
sequences somehow seemed to match with Li's set perfectly.  Minor Minor came on
and I got lost in the music.  Next thing I know I'm sitting on the chill room
floor and everyone seems to be getting up and leaving.  The night ended way to
fast for me but I had a blast.  

I took pictures for the first time at a party.  If I don't get them developed
before I head back to school I'll get them scanned in and put them up on a 
webpage.

j

REVIEW: Galatic Tunnel
or
CONFESSIONS OF RAVE ROOKIE II

Pulled up to the 'map point' and gave the man $$$ for the tix. Turned 
out to be more of a 'direction point' as the event turned out to be all of 
two blocks behind us on the same road. No worries, tho - Parking was 
easy and we bopped right in.

Since it was the first time at an SF 'rave' for me and the first time 
to any rave-type dealie for my two companions, we weren't sure what 
to expect. We cruised up the stairs and found a very dark, possibly a 
chillout room halfway up. Kept on truckin as discovered a sparse 
crowd jammin to some good beats. Moved in closer and started to get 
funky. The crowd was a bit younger than I had expected -average was 
seemed to be hovering around 17 - I felt ancient at 26! 

The sound was excellent, although the bass could have been even better, 
given the tremendous stack of Crest amps they had. What a sight ! The 
dj's were good, mixing seamlessly, although there were a few lapses 
and awkward gaps in the music. 

The lightshow had potential, but it seemed like the operators kept 
forgetting about it.

The place never really filled up (at least up to when we scooted, 
which was 3ish) but varied between almost-empty and half-full. 

All in all, t'was a good night.

kincy
THA ROOKIE

None of these responses have anything to do with any sort of self 
promotion, because you know I would just dominate all the best 
categories.  Plus I'm modest.
- Dre

>1. Best party you went to in 96?
Sunset, April 28

>2. Worst party you went to in 96?
I don't remember the name, but it was at Third Wave dance studio.  It was 
so hot and crowded that I never even made it to the dance floor.  I left 
half an hour after arriving there.  I did meet Jondabomb there though.

>3. Best local DJ for 96?
Mark Farina

>4. Best Non-local DJ for 96?
Carl Cox (but I heard Laurent Guarnier was badass)

>5. Best record for 96?
Probably the one I got most mileage out of...Ken Ishi "Extra",  Wagon 
Christ rmx

>6. Worst record for 96?
I don't remember any titles, cuz I didn't buy them, but there were some 
real stinkers!

>7. Best mixtape for 96?
I don't dance to tapes, I chill to them.  My favorite background music 
that was released on Tape would have to be Everett's Trip Hop (volume 2 I 
think).  Really nice music.

>8. Worst mixtape for 96?
Anything by Keoki (pitch control anyone?)

>9. Best track for 96?
Either the Ken Ishii track or the (kind of) new Eon

>10. Worst track for 96?
see #6

>11. Favorite location for a party in 96?
I really liked the main room @ 80 Oak Street

>12. Least favorite spot for a party in 96?
pACkME!

>13. Favorite thing to do after a party in 96?
Eat. Shower. Sleep.

>14. Favorite thing to wear to a party in 96?
Pasties!

>15. The most you ever spent in one night at a party in 96?
$19.95 + shipping and handling

>16. If you can change one thing about raving in 96, what would it have been?
better vibe.  DJ's who are hired more for their skills and taste in music 
than for their status.  Organization of DJ's by types of music for better 
flow at events.

>17. What the best DJ name in 96?
PSYCHOBITCH is still my favorite.

>18. Worst DJ name in 96?
Superstar DJ Keoki

>19. Best name for a party in 96?
F'TUMSH!

>20. Worst name for a party in 96?
All in the Family/Lucky Charms (tie)

************************************************
   Galactic Uber-Pimp of the )))Vibra Zone(((
************************************************
Sonic Mood Enhancement and Basic Love Vibrations
      for all my subjects...all the time

     << couple of months ago for my tooth ache. And I E'ed my balls off! >>
     
     Thats a graphic thought.... My Virgin eyes!!
     
     ______________________________________________________________________
     
     On a related topic from the "Dragnet Script Lost Archive"
     ______________________________________________________________________
     
     "What does it look like to you Friday?"
     
     "It's a scrotum all right... looks about 20-25, male (duh), probably 
     Caucasian or maybe Latino"
     
     "Yeah, from the look of the spot where they came off, I'd say they 
     we're E'd right off"
     
     "Yep.  About 130mg of pure MDMA or better, mixed with a testicle 
     threatening amount of bass heavy underground partying with fellow 
     scenesters"
     ______________________________________________________________________
     
     I'll shut up.
     
     *******Freaky People**************************************************
     
     Seeing as you got this far, I'd like to leave you with my Freaky 
     People review:
     
     Location:  I really liked it.  Danced all night with my shoes off.  
     Heard next day that there might have been some nails sticking out of 
     the boards in the floor.  But luckily, I can not have my foot pierced 
     by a nail I firmly believe does not exist, I guess.  The crane arm 
     with the disco ball, the sand, the floorboards, the DJ setup (even 
     though I could never tell who was there), the lights (hail hail to the 
     intellibeams... really varied themes for three little elements), the 
     crusty brick walls, the visible semi-chill room, I liked it all.  It 
     was a good rave location.
     
     The People:  I hate some types of extremes.  It seems like people 
     either go to parties militantly sober, or insist on taking so much 
     shit that they spend at least part of their night wrapped up in a ball 
     trying to talk themselves out of scratching their eyes out.  Perhaps I 
     could remind you that you can have a good time at a place like that 
     under the infuence of nothing, or even with a cough and a bad day 
     behind you.  Or even on a reasonable amount of drugs.  Stop taking too 
     much shit.  It will eventually kill the scene.  Ask a cop or a 
     politician why they hate raves... OD's and bad trips.  I should hope 
     it's not all about the drugs.  But the people who do too much drugs 
     will end up fucking it up for those of us who enjoy using moderate 
     amounts of goodies to enhance an already good evening.  Also, if 
     somebody is having a shit time (curled up in ball, obviously tripping 
     out in a not so great way, etc), and you're fairly okay and feeling 
     confident about your own psyche, talk to them, or at least introduce 
     yourself with a smile.  Sometimes just knowing caring people are 
     looking out is all the reassurance you need to start the road out of a 
     bad experience.
     
     If you're wondering what too much is, I don't know what's too much for 
     you and it's not for me to tell you.  It's your own personal 
     responsibility.  I'm a lightweight with some things, and a bear with 
     others.  But if it takes you three or four hits of E just to get off, 
     stop taking it so often (save your body and mind some damage, and save 
     your money for some records or mixtapes).  I saw some guy at Wrinkle 
     that claimed to have taken 10 hits of E.  He was MISERABLE.  If you 
     read about your drugs, you'd realize there are recommended dosages, 
     and good reasons to stay near them (for example, the more E you take 
     past 150mg's or so, the more the 'speedy' side effects become 
     pronounced).  So what gives?  I get the sneaking suspicion there's a 
     lot of people who talk about raves in terms of what they took.  I 
     assure you, I may be newer to this than a lot of you, but there's a 
     lot more going on than drugs.  Perhaps you should experience it with 
     more of you there, mentally.  It's really amazing.
     
     The Vibe:  Yeah, it was definitely there (specially going off on the 
     floor), but almost hard to enjoy.  Lots of people waaaay too fuckin 
     spaced in the corners to really enjoy themselves, and for me that 
     takes away from it.
     
     The Music: Yay!!! More DJ's spinning more variety.  I like four bar 
     snare drum builds, I like jungle, I like trance, I like so much of it. 
      It was so fun looking out at everybody when that Depeche Mode tune 
     came on, because everybody was looking at everybody else wondering 
     what to think.  Fun fun fun!!!  Shilo really pushed some of my 
     perceptions of what a DJ can get away with when the mood is right.  
     Also had a lot of fun listening/groovin to Li's set in the line for 
     the bathroom (which by the way, thanks to so many people cutting in 
     front of me, I was in that line for his whole set).
     
     Best moment:  When the lights first got cut and we went into 
     discoball-and trippy lights world.  One wall of visuals would have 
     made it super peach, but it was really cool in it's own dark way.
     
     Thank You's:       Harmony for a great party and for a nifty space 
     (pleasant change), SFPD for not being bigger assholes (I've seen much 
     worse ways of busting a party), the DJ's for some really good music 
     (you were all the shit!), everybody who "let me in" while they were 
     too high and too scared, and everybody I talked to, danced with, etc.  
     All my bitching aside, there were some beautiful people having a 
     magnificent time and sharing in life, experience and love.
     
     No Thank You's:    Whoever stole the red ski hat right off my head and 
     walked out the door never to be seen again (I saw it happen, I just 
     thought it was somebody I knew and that they were picking on me).
     
     AND A SPECIAL THANKS TO ALL THE PEOPLE I AFTERPARTIED WITH!!!!
     
     Especially Alex and Noah for spinning some great stuff!!!
     
     NEVER QUIT!!!!
     
     Peace,
     AndyW

On Sat, 14 Dec 1996, Fred Heutte wrote:

> Gabber is fast, hard, uncompromising, insular.

	Yes, it is hard, fast and uncompromising, that is why I like it ;)
Though, I wonder what you mean by gabber being insular.  Is my viewpoint
the same as the Adias decked out skin in Rotterdam or Frankfurt? What
about the dread-headed traveller up in Scotland? 

> It's one of the many styles of music I see rooted in the disaffection of an
> increasing number of people about how our society is running our planet -- not
> in a conscious 'political' sense but one that is an expression of personal
> emotion, just like hip hop was before Madison Avenue took control.  At the same
> time, gabber has a bit of an admittedly Beavis'n'Butthead humorous stance.

	Granted this is true of a lot of what comes out, but album's like
Lenny Dee's Emotion Response (yes Lenny Dee doing something that is not
completely hard, noisy, and angry) and Wedlock's Ganjaman and that one
Semtex EP I had covered just about all the ranges of slower techno in
terms of emotional weight conveyed, the driving energy of the tracks, and
the smile parts will bring to my face (ok, this is really subjective and
you have to know me pretty well to know what will and what will not do
this).... It really depends on the production and the aim of whoever is
laying down the track - I can point to tons more shitty house than I could
ever point to what I call good house, most people can point to more shitty
trance than they could to good trance (or wouldn't djs be carrying 50
record boxes because they have so much good material).
	Thing is, just about anywhere you go, the good stuff always seems
to be buried deep in the record crates among tons of poorly put together
stuff... I know a lot of people like the gabber I don't like for the
reasons I do not like - it's either full of attitude or has been so poorly
produced that the kick drum has lost all of its presence in the track... 
I can understand both reasons for liking those forms but I do not like
those forms being the "definitive" gabber types, I definitely cannot go
into someplace like Flop or District 23 or Avalanche (some records shops I
get good stuff in) and read the little review of what type of music is on
the disc in the corner and then go with my stack to the listening
stations, because first there is no little thing in the corner and second
gabber is shoved into the "techno" or hardcore bin. Granted, I listen to
more of what is out there over here, but I find none of what I am really
looking for... 

	But this has all moved off topic, gabber is portrayed as the music
of rasict or fasict skinheads in Europe. Gabber is music that skinheads go
out and dance to in Rotterdamn, Amsterdam, parts of Germany;  whether
those skins are facist or racist, I think we would need to go over with an
openmind to their culture and see if we are just moving our definitions of
what skins are to their culture... Gabber is also played at the free
festis, in little sweaty clubs with jungle netting hung all around with a
jazzy swingy type band upstairs in the ambient? room, in horrid clubs
(what I call horrid) that have tons of neds trying to be hard, eyeing you
up and down from the little doorholes when the club lets out (shivers go
up my spine)... But guess what, it isn't the only music most of these
groups listen to... Gabber covers a wide range of hard, fast, and pretty 
aggressive (my use of aggressive comes from webster:
   2a: marked by driving forceful energy or initiative,
   2b: marked by obtrusive energy
    3: HARSH, INTENSE) music, there are different sounds to gabber and 
each will pull you in a different way - I like it because I have seen it 
pull (maybe push is a better term in this case) people together like nothing 
else...

dave

Craig Roseberry, "the boy most likely to", C&S / Adrenalin Records, New York,
NY  212.253.9613x14  cnsrecords@aol.com.  I have avoided writing this for
some time, but, there's sooo much to say!  So here goes...Hope everyone had a
wonderful holiday.  Thanks to all of those who gave us much love in '96!  And
to everyone else, look for us to blow up in "97!  On your desk soon will be Si
gnify, the new full length from London's space-rock, avant jazz, electronic
experimentalists' Porcupine Tree.  Prog-rock alive in 1997? Who knew?! Chill
into the new year with Night Shift - a dope compilation of laid back trip
hop, electro, and ambient grooves featuring:  The Chemical Brothers, DJ
Spooky, Baby Buddah Heads, and more. Radio will buzz with Soul Tequila, the
smokin', 100% pure funk and rare groove debut from the Soul Providers (think
vintage JB's).  And if all that wasn't enough, Adrenalin comes back at ya
with the long anticipated debut from Manchester's Cotton Club.  For all those
wax heads, the double 12", "Hear The Drummer" & the ultra rare "Nu Jack" 12",
should more than satisfy (the album is gonna be the bomb!).  If you want to
get serviced with vinyl, call me.  Look out for new releases from:  The
Tweakers (12"), DJ Ed (12"), De Donatis III (12"), Stryke (lp "Reality Base")
and, of course, a wicked compilation from DJ Hardware called Rhythm Chamber...
Until next time...I'm out!

Hi all,

Just tuning in from NYC for the next couple of days to see what you all had
to suggest for the night of the 21st...

My eyes lit up when I saw that Alex Patterson will be playing the Gathering
reunion...but not knowing the scene in SF, I don't know if it will be worth
going to.

I tend to like mostly trance and acid...so does that sound like the party
for me??

And yes, I'm the dork that posted about a month ago...I was so thrilled to
have my plane ticket in hand, I jumped ahead a bit too soon. (Thanks for
all your suggestions back then, too!)

But here's the deal...I'm going to drag my two extremely cool and mello
brothers out with me so it's really important that I try and find the right
vibe...cuz they're totally new to this and I don't want to haul them to
some tiny party where they'll be too intimidated to get at it! Plus they're
slightly older than your average raver (uh, just what is an "averge
raver??"),  so I'm thinking lots of variety, not too small, and I'm not
going to overwhelm them with any drugs...I think the whole thing will be a
big enough trip for them.

So please e back if you think I'm on the right track with this
party....also, I've tried calling the number...anyone know any details yet
(at least if tix need to be got, or when the address might be offered up?)

Also, feel free to suggest any other parties you think might be good, just
in case I need a back up!

Thanks SO much, this is going to make my night and probably change my bros
forever!!

-Suzanne

> > It was supposed to be a happy time, but it wasn't.  Santa was really pissed.
> > It was Christmas eve and NOTHING was going right.  Mrs. Claus had burned all
> > the Christmas cookies.  The Elves were bitching about not getting paid for
> > the overtime they had put in while making toys, and the reindeer had been
> > drinking all afternoon and were dead drunk.
> > 
> > They had taken the sleigh out for a spin earlier in the day and crashed it
> > into a tree, breaking off one of the runners.
> > 
> > Santa was beside himself with anger. "I CAN"T believe it!  I've got to
> > deliver millions of presents all over the world in just a few hours from now
> > and all my reindeer are drunk, my Elves are on strike and I don't even have
> > a Christmas tree!  I sent that stupid Little Angel out HOURS a go to find a
> > tree and he isn't even back yet!  What am I going  to do?"
> > 
> > Just then the Little Angel opened the front door and stepped in from the
> > snowy night, dragging a Christmas tree.  He says: "Yo, Santa, where do you
> > want me to stick the Christmas Tree this year???"
> > 
> > And thus the tradition of Angels perched atop the Christmas trees came
> > to pass.
>

Just for the record book I my original post was not meant to diss on
gabber, more a graphic analogy...


>First, there's nothing wrong with being working class. Just because you
>work on computers doesn't suddenly make you rise above the working
>class.

Actually I AM working class...was brought up in the north of England to
working class parents.


 In fact, knowing the way HotWired pays&treats people, you're
>prolly working class too :-). Within 10 years, all of us computer
>literate technoid folks will be like plumbers -- working class. So
>instead of dissing the working class, you should seek solidarity with
>your future bretheren. Either that, or get real good at wearing a tie,
>fuck over a few honest hard-working coworkers, and you may be given the
>credentials to rise out of working class and into "upper management."

Pay ain't that good. Anyway, I'm only an intern here. And I don't wear a
tie. EVER!
...
>
>Second, I don't think yours is an accurate comparison because punk rock
>originally was not "fascist infected" nor "hooligan". It was anarchist,
>

This comparison has to do with the INTENT of the music more than anything.
The impact of the gabber styles is similar to the effect that Punk had back
in the day (and I'm old enough to remember it.) Attitudes aside, the
Rotterdam styles are completely connected with bored youth, attitude,
pissing-off your parents and the authorities, spitting, football and
copious amounts of amphetamines. Leaving football out of the equation, not
that different from Punk really.

ar

On the other hand if the science fiction nature of the future and
dramatic world events interest you and you don't fear death:

This shit is pure Techno 

By the way you Mondo 2000 and Wired types might not be so enthusiaxtic
(sic) about jackin' in afterwards...

 #=P'''

http://www.farsight.org/
http://www.artbell.com/
http://www.strieber.com/index.shtml
http://www.mk.net/~mcf/
http://www.mk.net/~mcf/mnindex.htm
http://www.sjmercury.com/drugs/start.htm

I found all these after a girl posted that alien head link on this list.

The main thing that bugs me is how all this stuff looks like the signs
in Revelations (New Testament) like (to paraphrase;)

"There will be signs in the heavens... " (last year big comet, also
collision of another comet into Jupiter, face on mars)  "All eyes will
see him...  "Like the lightning from east to west...etc."

This Hale-Bobb companion has huge spikes sticking out of opposite
sidesalmost like Saturn's rings but from the sides.   To most
astronomers it appears to be traveling with the comet.

I don't want to lecture re religion (I'm more of a Taoist myself) but
even athiests will be praying after checking the above sites out.

Just more reasons to drop out of the world domination system and go
underground...  small rave cells...  email links...  need to know...
survival research...  don't be so drugged and partied out that we snooze
while paramilitary govt's take over.

Read up on the law in England that allows rounding up ravers with
martial law and no civil rights.  Police use similar tactics and laws to
shut down partys here--that's why we left England (or wherever) a few
hundred years back....

I'd stock up on whipped cream...

DJ ASB

2-4,D

> 18. Worst DJ name in 96?

Ghost

> 19. Best name for a party in 96?

tie: Friends & Family (for my happy raver side), Riot 23 (for my agro
raver side)

> 20. Worst name for a party in 96?

Megga Buzz One (with typo)


A moment of personal reflection:

1996 was easily the best year of my life! I broke up with my
ex-girlfriend (whew!), graduated from college, drove cross-country,
started working in Silicon Valley (every geek's dream), and
experienced a music scene that I had always dreamed about (raving is
just NOT the same where i used to live).

Many of you have become an important part of my life in 96...enriching
it through the friendships that we've formed. I owe quite a bit of it
to SFRaves (egads!) and to living in this beautiful city. This truly
has been a year I'll never forget.

Now if I could only figure what I'm going to do for New Year's...
I think I see a 2 hour road trip in my future...hrm. maybe...

Steve

(please excuse if you've already seen this)

 
Looking back at 1996, it was a pretty good year for dance music overall.
But that's starting to sound familiar, and now I think we aren't going
to see the likes of 1993 (or any year back to about 1987) for a long time.
 
My interests ranged pretty evenly across a good portion of the musical map,
and since I am as always unable to whittle things down to a mere Top 10
picks, herewith ten each in the Canonical Genres (including four techno
albums that each have lots of great stuff), noting that some of these
may actually be late-1995-but-who's-counting:
 
 
Alana Dante - Think Twice (Next Plateau)
Floorbanger - Five
H2O - Livin' for the Future (Liquid Groove)
House People - Music (D-Vision)
Johnick - Play the World (Henry Street)
Andrew Pearce vs Urban Soul Gallery (Damier/Trent + KMS) - Day By Day (Six6)
DJ Pierre vs. Danell - I Love the Way You Love (Emotive)
Salt City Orchestra - The Book (Paper)
Swag - Creative Biting (Jus' Trax)
Winx - How's the Music (Sorted)
 
 
Aux 88 - Exile (Direct Beat)
Brooks - Ascension (Smart)
Fred Gianelli/Daniel Bell - 1st Premonition (Supersition/Telepathic)
DJ K-1 - Metaphysica (Direct Beat)
Monolake - Magenta (Chain Reaction)
Professor Smith - Remember 48024 (XLR8R Traks)
Blood Sugar: Levels (Emissions Lo-Fi)
Detroit: Beyond the Third Wave (Astralwerks)
Dhamas: '96 (First Impression)
Relative Progress: Illustrated Primer (Deep End)
 
 
Bizzy-B - 16 Track Ting (Brain)
DJ Die - Hydroponics (Music Bizness)
Free Hand - I Can't Stop (Smooth)
Funky Technicians - Airtight (Legend)
Mind 21 - Mindz (Urban Gorilla)
One Motive - Real Solutions (Fresh86)
Phume - Freefall (Selector)
Alex Reece/Kruder & Dorfmeister - Jazz Master (Island)
The Mack - Another Playa (SOUR)
Wax Doctor - The Rise (Metalheadz)
 
 
Messages From the Old School:
 
Chic - Sometimes You Win - in honor of Bernard Edwards
Seven Grand Housing Authority - The Question - in honor of Ken Collier
 
 
see you in the future!
phred

Hello everyone,

I would first like to thank everyone for their continued support of Wish
Wednesdays at the Bahia Cabana.  We are in our 34th consecutive week of
weekly Wednesday parties, and are stronger than ever.

I wanted to apologize to all of you who attended Wish last week, the 11th of
December.  As most of you know, we promised a big event with headlining dj
Scott Henry from Fever in Baltimore, Buzz in Washington DC, and Sm:)e
records, New York.  We worked for 3 months getting plane tickets, organizing
accomodations, transportation, etc for Scott, and we were very excited about
bringing out one of the world's top drawing dj's from the east coast.
 However, Scott came down with Pneumonia early last week and was
hosipitalized in Baltimore up until Tuesday night.  He was unable to fly the
next day, and consequently unable to make it to Wish.  Scott Henry did
however play at both Nikita on Friday and Spundae on Sunday night, and for
those of you who attended either of those shows you witnessed an incredible
show.

We found out about Scott Henry not coming to Wish, early on Wednesday, and
with little time to find a new headlining dj, other than the Wish residents,
we came up with Al-Jay from the beach raves and nightclubs of Rio de
Janeiro, Brazil, who was in town visiting with some of the Hardkiss crew.
 Al-Jay played very well, and we had another great Wednesday night.

We aren't giving up on bringing Scott Henry to Wish, we are working with him
again at another attempt in the spring of '97.  Also, we are very proud to
bring you European sensation DJ and recording artist, Peter Lazonby from
London, England this Wednesday December 18th.

Wish will be closed for Christmas on the 25th, for our first wednesday off
in over 7months!  =)  After the break however, we are coming back strong on
the 1st day of the new year, with a New Year's Eve after party at Bahia
starting at 7am, and continuing through to 2am...yep those times are right!
 DJ's for the all day event will be David Michael, Shiloh, Kenneth Sol,
Henrik, MARS, Mystr-E, and lots of others, including special guest dj's?
 Come early though, as we might close in the middle of the day for a short
nap.  Call the Wishline for info - (415) 436-0663.

Take care everyone and see you at Wish!

Happy holidays.

Kenneth Sol  =)

Subject:  Infinite Space radio program, KMUD Garberville CA


DJ Penny Andrew =

Born:  Cambridge, England

Grew in a artistic family surrounded by musicians such as Pink Floyd.

Drawn into the early English rave scene in 88-89  as a
theatre/circus/fire performer and her first rave was Mutoid Waste
Company--a multimedia New Year=92s extravaganza at Kings Cross London.

Worked with Club Dog--now Planet Dog Records
Ozric Tentacles =

Trans Global Underground
The Shamen
Orbital

DJ Penny made mix tapes since age 10--she called megamixes
Began radio DJ career 2 years ago starting her show Infinite Space on
KMUD Garberville--hosting DJ Alex Windsor; DJ Tracey;  DJ Mark Amoeba
among others

Produced a party called Emerald Tribe last December 1995 at the Mateel
(home of Reggae on the River) in Redway CA featuring some of San
Francisco=92s finest DJ=92s

Besides her show she is involved in other media:  music production,
drama, tabloid radio projects, the science fiction genre, & music
engineering.

Penney=92s show is on Tuesday 10PM--1AM on KMUD 91.1 FM for Garberville
and Mendocino County; 88.5 Eureka;  88.9 Laytonville and her show can be
heard from Oregon to Interstate 5 to Wilts/Ukia.  DURING her show she
can be reached with party update info at (707) 923-3911.

She spins Trance, Goa, Ambient, Techno, Deep House, Junglist, Drum &
Bass, Acid Jazz & Trip Hop, and she has a segment devoted to Star Trek
and other esoteric subjects.

Record labels, DJ=92s, remixers, and distributors may send demos, white
labels, CD=92s or cassettes (please include bio/promo material) to:

Infinite Space
KMUD
POB 135
Redway CA 95560

On Tue, 17 Dec 1996, Customer Service wrote:

> Would anyone be willing to run me through this?  I live in berkeley, I

	Easy, undo all the screws on the rubber bottom. There are what 
like 20 of them, and if I remember correctly, three sizes. Each of the 
three sizes come from a different pattern area on the bottom so it is 
pretty easy to remember which came from where... Make a map if you need to...
	Undo the plastic thing in the corner that holds the wires in place.
	Heat the solder points for all four wires and blow/clean all the 
old solder out while removing the wires without letting the solder 
make bridges over the little circuit board underneath.
	Solder the new wires on, don't melt the circuit board...
	put the crimp hold down plastic thingy back together...
	Put the bottom on, pulling all the wires through the correct holes
	Put all the screws in the right places....

dave

To: Rick Riffle <rdriffle@ucdavis.edu>

Subject: Re: need turntable Tech Support!
