Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I fixed this on a Technics1200 once--it's not that hard but if you go
inside the machine you will need to solder the lead.  Makes you wonder
why the RCA's don't plug in a piece of pro gear.

First I suggest removing the headshell and fastening the tone arm down. 
Use a box or something sturdy (a friend) to hold the 'wheels upside
down.  There aren't a million parts gonna jump out and its pretty
straightforward.  Don't rest the deck on the tone arm!!!

If this is too much for you you might try cutting the lead about six
inches from the deck and splicing a new RCA cord--but in my case the
problem was at the circuit board.

To strip the wire slice the sheath lightly with a knife or wire
snipper.  When you have about an inch of braid spread it near the cut
and pull through the inner wire.  Pull the braid taught.  You can just
wrap both leads to the spliced in wire (or solder to board) and wrap
with electrical tape.  Of course shield>shield/core>core, and it helps
to keep "Red for right"  don't cross the leads!

Soldering isn't hard and radio shack can get you a setup for $8-10.

You just touch the tip to the wire and circuit trace and flow a little
solder at the junction.  Don't over solder or over heat!!!

Afterwards you may want to reset your tone arm weights.  Check the wt.
for your cartridge (2-5 grams usually.)  Rotate the whole weight until
the tone arm hovers at a balanced position.  Hold the main weight still
and rotate the scale until it reads zero.  Now turn the entire mass to
the setting.  My Stanton 500's rate 2 g's and the less weight the less
record wear (though they may skip on a dance floor unless you go about
3-4 g's)  You also set the anti-skating to the same weight as the tone
arm.

While I'm on this subject I'd like to diss club owners who never clean
their cartridges or records (let alone replace a worn out stylus)  Radio
Shack has all the stuff you need and it's cheap compared to replacing
vinyl.  If you guest in a club I'd suggest bringing your own cartridges
'coz old dirty ones will ruin your records in one pass. 

Final tip:  Always plug AC wires with the raised/white stripe going into
the fat (negative) plug hole of the electric plug to avoid ground loops
(buzzing).  If the problem continues use ground lifts (3 prong adapters)
to lift all the grounds.  Then run a ground from the mixer to a H2O
pipe, earth ground, (or last resort)) the safety ground or screw on the
wall plug.

DJ ASB available for record production, studio engineering, club &
studio sound installations, Macintosh computer music consultation,
independent music distribution, club DJ/MC, or world domination by dance
music.

Subject: Re: need turntable Tech Support!

Precedence: bulk

My recommendation (I've done it with all of my 1200 and 1210's): There's no
need to even remove the base of your decks or worry about solder. There's an
excellent chance that the cords aren't bad at or near the soldered end
because a plate and screw protect the soldered end of the cord (I've rarely
seen a short in a cord near the base of a turntable). Simply, make a clean
cut of the cord at about 3" from the plate, then strip the insulation clean
to expose roughly 1/2" of the bare wires. I'd recommend purchasing a 12' HOSA
stereo RCA cord (orange for right, grey for left) and several small threaded
electrical caps. Cut the HOSA cord in half and strip to expose the insulated
wires. Mate your new cord with your deck's cord, twist the caps on, and
voila! you've got 6' leads. Tuck the caps and a portion of your cord into the
1200's plate compartment (The hole at the base where the RCA cord comes
from). If this doesn't work, then you'll definitely have to replace the
entire cord. :) MODA

Aw itz jus' a low tech hookup testing the concept.  I just leave my
email checking every 1 minute and pass messages/party
announcements/shouts live on the air to DJ Penny on Radio KMUD serving
Humboldt and Mendocino counties and much of N. Cali.

Her rave show is called INFINITE SPACE and she's an English DJ who has
worked with some of the greats.

I run down the big parties from SF to VAN, give descriptions of kewl
sitez, and towards the end of the show we check out some of the more
sci-fi weird web sites.

Anyone with mixes contact me or send to her at:   INFINITE SPACE   
KMUD  POB135   REDWAY CA 95560 

I was also monitoring the mailing lists for any listeners online or just
chatting with SFRavers

Peace Out

DJ ASB

At 4:08 AM -0000 12/18/96, Aryck wrote:
>        So, if anyone knows of the REAL underground scene, and knows of cool
>gatherings, please tell me. All of these overpopulated drugfests are getting
>to annoy me a bit.
>
>Aryck

If only it were that easy, right?  Two words of advice:  Get Involved.
Find one underground...There's one this Friday that someone posted about on
SFR.  Go to that, help carry speakers through the woods.  Bring some fire
wood, bring coffee for the crew, stay until the party's over, carry
speakers out of the woods, befriend people, ask for names, shake hands,
hug, offer your strong back or other talents to the group, bring altar
items and help set it up and light candles when they blow out, bring
insence, take pictures...Then, in return, "they" will invite you to the
next party they throw.  Do that for other groups, ask nothing in return but
knowledge of when and where the party will be...and on, and on...

It would be to easy for someone to just TELL you where the party is...

=)
Peace!

Tony

Subject: Re: need turntable Tech Support!
In-Reply-To: <961217235932_1456277873@emout18.mail.aol.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.95.961218093651.8751A-100000@value.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

On Tue, 17 Dec 1996 ERMODA@aol.com wrote:

> My recommendation (I've done it with all of my 1200 and 1210's): There's no
> need to even remove the base of your decks or worry about solder. There's an
> excellent chance that the cords aren't bad at or near the soldered end
> because a plate and screw protect the soldered end of the cord (I've rarely
> seen a short in a cord near the base of a turntable). Simply, make a clean
> cut of the cord at about 3" from the plate, then strip the insulation clean
> to expose roughly 1/2" of the bare wires. I'd recommend purchasing a 12' HOSA
> stereo RCA cord (orange for right, grey for left) and several small threaded
> electrical caps. Cut the HOSA cord in half and strip to expose the insulated
> wires. Mate your new cord with your deck's cord, twist the caps on, and
> voila! you've got 6' leads. Tuck the caps and a portion of your cord into the
> 1200's plate compartment (The hole at the base where the RCA cord comes
> from). If this doesn't work, then you'll definitely have to replace the
> entire cord. :) MODA   
> 
Yuck, yuck, yuck! Never use those silly electrical caps unless you know
that the wires aren't going to be moved. Those electrical caps are
appropriate for things like house wiring. If you are scared of solder, at
least use butt splices.(huhuhu Hey Beavis, he said butt-splice.)

                                       Black Adder

Hey man, that's elitist!  Whaddya mean I got to *do* something before I 
am invited?  Hell, I been going out since 1989, isn;t that worth 
something?  Sheeit, I paid my dues already, now bust yourself and TELL me 
where it is.  Why should *I* have to do the hard work.  I am shy, and I 
don't approach people easily, as a matter of fact, I break out in warts 
everytime I try to talk to a DJ or something.  They get all over my 
assneck like little pissclams.  Anyway, I just hope that you and other 
elitist stop all of this "You gotta work to get undergound..." attitude 
you and others spout.

Why not do us all a favor an be quiet.  if you're not going to tell, why 
tease?  Teasing, after all, is not very PLUR at all, not at all.

I feel so dissed.  I asked someone on the hpone where hte UG was, and 
here are some of the answers that I got:

Question: "Where's the underground party at?"

Answers:
-In my pants.
-If you don't know, I can't tell you.
-You mean you didn't get a flyer?  Sorry, I can't help you.
-I dunno.
-What are you asking me for?
-You mean you don't know?
-There's a BART on 16ht & Mission, but I didn't hear of any party.  
They're gonna have a party in the BART?  Cool!

Peace out, and many many many ;)'s.

John

Yea, you should expect to help out.  How long you've been partying doesn't
mean that much.  Gravity and the weight of the speakers does.  The winding
and unwinding of cords.  The pictures on the walls, etc.  Don't be a

yourself connected.  I personnally have more fun when I'm involved somehow.

How to calculate your current _shaman level_ of raving to determine whether
or not you belong to the "underground".  Formula from wise old raver spirit
that appeared in the backyard one time about an hour into a trance set:

SL=(Mass of speakers carried + length of spare speaker wire currently in
trunk/age) + (3.1415927 * no. of vinyl in collection that is kept in an
earthquake,fireproof,floodproof location...squared) + (# of times per week
you spot new & creative places for DIY) + (#of burn scars from lighting
candles, insence, etc.) - (# of times you spent more than $20 to get in a
mega-commercial-party * 303) - (# of times you've wired an amp backwards)

;)
n8

>>>canned. She still works here]]

Date: Wed, 18 Dec 96 12:10:10 pst
From: "Andy Wyszkowski" <awyszkow@smtplink.acer.com>
Message-Id: <9611188509.AA850940301@smtplink.acer.com>

     Hello You Splendid Folk You...
     
     I've noticed when I'm having fun, people get affected by it.  I've 
     also noticed that when people have good energy around me, it increases 
     my energy.  I've also noticed that when this is most pronounced, 
     really good things start to happen.  Like people noticing and inviting 
     me to parties, or asking me to join in on ideas or really great 
     conversations or even FREE DRUGS.  Some people think I have fun at 
     parties, and maybe it adds to their fun.  Wouldn't that be nice (oh... 
     thank you for the hug that destroyed my shit mood last friday MattK).
     
     Is it underhanded or elitist to work to get into a party... no.  I 
     think it's a more honest transaction than paying for it, especially if 
     it's your mommy and daddy's money.
     
     Is a small party elitist?
     
     YES.  Almost by nature.  Not everyone can go... so how do you spread 
     the word to ONLY 80-150 people?  Well, they could be your friends, or 
     people who can afford it, or people who are wearing one red sock, or 
     people who have met both Andy Gibb and Shaun Cassidy...
     
     Grow a brain everybody. We keep talking about how massives suck, so we 
     increase the demand for attendance of small parties.  We talk about 
     parties that very few people get to as if they were the stuff of 
     legend (as I am sure some of them are).  Fact is, WE LIKE TO BE LET IN 
     ON A SECRET.
     
     We have placed such a value on small parties, but only a small amount 
     of us can go to any particular one (did anybody see how many E'd out 
     ravers were walking around the Haight after Freaky People sold out?).  
     So we can do two things... throw more parties, or start segregating 
     the scene into various music genres (goa, jungle, hardcore, house, 
     deep house, straight up techno, trance, hard trance, etc).  I would 
     much rather see lots of small parties ALL playing a variety of crazy 
     music.  I love it all... as long as it's got a heart and a groove.
     
     If you're not getting invited to these bomb parties, throw your own.  
     Even a lame party at your house can be a shitload of fun if people you 
     like to party with show up.  Fun people can have fun wherever you put 
     them together.  And that's what makes a party.
     
     I've been invited to parties by people I have never met (some through 
     this list *thankyouverymuchyoujamandilickyoursoles*).  Whoever you 
     are, and whatever you're into, there are like minded people somewhere 
     who would probably like to boogie with you.
     
     Be yourself, speak your mind, be true to yourself, stay involved.  
     Share dammit.
     
     Go to the freak parties, like an outdoor in the middle of winter (hee 
     hee hee.. anybody know where to get some of those gloves without 
     fingertips?), or a BBQ in the rain, or call that obscure number that 
     somebody you've never met before gave you.  Don't 'out' parties that 
     are word of mouth (I liked the way Adam did it... by individual 
     mailback) by posting to the whole list or by showing up with twenty 
     friends that you told.  Keep it quiet.  Keep it sweet.
     
     Peace,
     AndyW
     
     P.S.       Being alone or with a friend or two and having a good time 
     is the most "underground" party of all... anybody else here ever dance 
     in their room to a damn good mixtape?
     
     Today's 1200 related question-----------------------------------------
     
     I heard you should keep the antiskate at 0 if you scratch or backspin 
     a lot... any truth to this?

yesterday I sent out a massage asking for help rewiring my technics....I
got at least 20 !!! responses, most from people who were willing to do the
work for me,(!) or at least talk me through it on the phone.

You guys rock my world.   I finally chose Jerimiah to be my Soldering Guru
because it was the best option for me.  But for everyone else who offered
help, thanks a million.  I truly wasn't expecting so many people to
respond.

Afterwards I was overwrought with emotion, and on my way back to the Fidget
Farm I was weeping so uncontrollably with joy that as I spun into the
dooryard I plowed right into Grandpa Fidget chopping wood, and landed poor
old Gramps in a traction.


God bless you all.
Sfraves rules.

love,

b))merang

That's what Stanton recomend; however, I prefer to set mine at about 1/2. 
Your best bet is to just fuck with it until you find what wotks best for 
you. Antiskating is supposed to stop the needle from skipping forward. 
Therfore, if your needle usually skips forward use more antiskating, and 
if your needle usually skips backward use less.

Subject: more virus bullshit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey everyone-

	just a quick FYI for y'alls. After all the virus crap that's been 
rolling through sfraves (and the entire Net), I thought this website might 
help clear some things up (Whaddya know?!? The goverment actually IS good for 
something!!! ;)

						Hugs :)
						DAVE
						lepidoptera@earthlink.net
****************************************************************************  
 
   -------------------------- [Original Message] -------------------------    
  
When dealing with viruses and virus warnings, it is perhaps better to
be safe than sorry.  When the virus is a hoax, the "damage" is the fear
and time lost responding to the warnings.  I suggest checking with the
U.S. Department of Energy CIAC virus database whenever you have concerns
about any virus.  The CIAC virus database home page is at:

http://ciac.llnl.gov/ciac/CIACHome.html

 
  According to the CIAC virus database the "Irina" virus is a hoax. 
CIAC's "Internet Hoaxes: PKZ300, Irina, Good Times, Deeyenda, and Ghost"
can be found at:

http://ciac.llnl.gov/ciac/bulletins/h-05.shtml


The CIAC description for Irina is:

"The "Irina" virus warnings are a hoax. The former head of an electronic
publishing company circulated the warning to create publicity for a new
interactive book by the same name. The publishing company has apologized
for the publicity stunt that backfired and panicked Internet users
worldwide. The original warning claimed to be from a Professor Edward
Pridedaux of the College of Slavic Studies in London; there is no such
person or college. However, London's School of  Slavonic and East
European Studies has been inundated with calls. This poorly thought-out
publicity stunt was highly irresponsible. For more information
pertaining to this hoax, reference the UK Daily Telegraph at
http://www.telegraph.co.uk."


  Since viral code MUST be execute to infect a system, it is not
possible to be infected by a virus by simply reading email.  It IS
possible to be infected by an email enclosure which is an executable
file.  As with any executable file from an unknown or questionable
souce, care should be exercised before running them.  Application macro
files may seem to infect your application when simple opened but in
reality infection only occurs when they are executed perhaps by the
applications auto-execute function.

****************************************************************************

Mis-labeled, should be "How to tell if you're really at a ug!"

A few simple signs that you have gotten to the UG:
-None of your friends are there the first time around, if they are, they 
are not real "ravefriends" since they didn't help you figure out where 
the UG was in the first place.  Traitors!
-You look around and ask yourself "Is this place safe?" as you see the 
condemned signs, black widows, health warning concerning carcinogens, and 
of course, someones handily discarded bolt cutters.
-There is a funny odor, and you can't really tell what it is (for 
old-skool; remember Halloween '94, A rave Called Sharon out near Bayview, 
some stinky old warehouse, lotsa sound, plenty of odor).
-There are no lights, except for the one illuminating the dex.
-The muddies most beautiful sound you've heard , EVER!
-Everyones eyes are as big as golfballs.  No extra charge for the sweat.
-You clothes have a greyish film of unidentified origin after the shindig.
-As you approach your car you think to yourself "Hmm..I don't 
remember leaving the window down."

Yikes!

Be careful.  Take lotsa, lotsa.  And please remember, especially you 
stinky ones, BATHE BEFORE YOU RAVE.  

Peace or peas out,
John

uncontrolled host operation.

Virus this and virus that. You know, things don't have to be the way
"they" tell you it is -- as if computer viruses are something
intrinsically inherent to modern computing. There is a reality beyond
the crap commercial software they shove down your throats, and it isn't
plagued by virus susceptibility. ANd it will never come from Microsoft.

If ya wants some virus protection, the best thing to do is run a  REAL
OPERATING SYSTEM. Windows95 and NT and MacOS suck the hairy donkey
dick. They are not real operating systems, just glorified program
loaders with a bunch of lame GUI chrome that mostly gets in the way.
Since they have few notions of system-level versus user-level
protection they are very susceptible to viruses or rogue activity from
an infected user-level-program. Interpreting some mail message in your
mail reader, or running some random Java in Netscape, or
installing/running some shareware you loaded off the net etc. shouldn't
inherently make your system susceptible to software-damage.
Unfortunately, that is not the case with most Microsoft-based shitware
people run. Even worse, you can inadvertently install trojan horses and
latent viruses that you won't even know are there until it's too late
-- until your private data (e.g. your credit card numbers,
tax/financial data, correspondences, etc.) have been made accessible to
people that may wish to do you harm, or until every program you run and
all data you use are infected/corrupted, or until some special doomsday
date hits and your hard-disk gets wiped clean.

I personally prefer Linux, which is a popular Unix variant developed by
thousands of hackers internationally, security-verified by hundreds of 
wizards internationally, and is available for free (as in the source is
free for you to use/modify/sell/fix/extend). For those of you that want
something easy to install, check out www.redhat.com (RedHat Linux 4.0),
which is damn cheap, reliable, simple, and a real, professional, and
intrinsically better-protected-against-viruses OS than any of the crap
that Bill Gates is going to shit down your throat. Y'all should know
better than most that popular doesn't equate to "good" -- the
underground is where it's at.

Windows 95, NT, and MacOS are the CoolWorld of operating systems. Yeah,
they're popular, yeah every doofus with a few hundred extra $$$ can get
it, yeah you can pickup tickets for this "party" at any EggHead
software and any mall across the country ... but once you're in and
committed, chances are you're going to spend a lot more than that
$20.00 admissions fee just staying alive (all those lame anti-virus
programs are like being stuck in a no-ins-and-outs rave where they sell
you $5.00 bottles of watter and make you pay $20.00 for a mini-thin).
Why is it that people who are so insistant on being underground in
music and raves won't go underground with operating systems like Linux?
It's free, tons of free software available, and it blows away windows
95, NT, and MacOS, especially for internet related applications.

PS: some pedantic people are going to say, "but Linux is also
susceptible to viruses." Yes, it can be susceptible, and there are a
few security holes -- the problems are minor compared to the well known
holes in NT or W95... Given Linux's free source, the large
international developer community, etc -- the problems are uncovered
quickly, and fixed even more quickly, and tested by a worldwide
community for which quality secure software is a passion, rather than
"just a job." This means that security problems are discovered and
fixed far more quickly in the Linux community than the lumbering Q&A
processes used by a behemoth like Microsoft. Just like "peer review"
has increased the quality of science worldwide, "free software" and
nonproprietary source makes Linux a higher quality and more robust OS
than any of the "professional" proprietary code coming out of
Microsoft. If there's a problem in a Microsoft OS, you'll never know
because it's a proprietary trade secret, and you'll never be able to
fix it according to your schedule, or to your satisfaction. You are
given the freedom of choice to bow down to the great Micosoft, pay alms
for upgrades, and perhaps the gods of redmond will answer your prayers
in the next release. Or you can tell them to fuck off and run a real
operating system controlled by DA PEOPLE!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==
== When yer swimming in a creek and an eel bites yer cheek, that's a moray!==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

The following are derived from koans in "The Zen of Programming":
--------------------------------------------------------------------
One day a novice was arguing with the Master about operating systems. 
"Significant in-roads are being made in security and ease-of-use,"
claimed the novice.  "Soon, there will be no more manuals.  Programs
will be self-evident."

The Master pondered this for a moment and replied, "Last week I decided
to chop some wood for a fire, but my old axe had become dull and worn,
and since I had not treated the handle or protected it, it was infested
with termites.  So I went to the hardware store and purchased a new
one."

"Um...  That's very interesting, I'm sure, but what does that have to do
with operating systems?"  asked the novice.

"The new axe came with an eight page instruction booklet."

Operating systems are mastered through experience.  Operating systems
are protected by not letting viruses (virii?) get to them in the first
place, ie. safe computing.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

Hearing a disturbance, the Master went into the novice's cubicle.

"Curse these personal computers!" cried the novice in anger, "I've
gotten another virus, and this OS was supposed to have the latest
advances in security!"

The Master spoke:
"There is a cycle, a rhythm to the universe.  Today one OS will be
popular, tomorrow another.  Today 500 viruses will be destroyed,
tomorrow another 500 will rise up.  To understand Life is to 
know that the rhythm exists.  To understand Zen is to live outside
this rhythm, detached from the everyday concerns of life.  Only then
can the mind be free."

"But Master, this is intolerable!"

The Master stared at the novice.  "So what will you do?"

The novice thought on this for some time, then cried, "I know!  I'll
write my own operating system!  It will be called TriNext and it will
combine all the best features of all the other OS's.  It will replace
all the others."

Suddenly the Master struck the novice on the side of his head.  It
was not a heavy blow, but the novice was nonetheless surprised.
"What did you do that for?!" exclaimed the novice.

"I have no wish to learn another OS," said the Master.

And suddenly the novice was enlightened.

----------------------------------------------

> Merry Christmas! (Truth is stranger than fiction)
>
> Roy Collette and his brother-in-law have been exchanging the same pair
> of  pants as a Christmas present for 11 years - and each time the
> package gets harder to open.  This year the pants came wrapped in a car
> mashed into a 3-foot cube.  The trousers are in the glove compartment of
> a 1974 Gremlin. Now Collette's plotting his revenge--if he can get them
> out. It all started when Collette received a pair of moleskin trousers
> from his brother-in-law, Larry Kunkel of Bensenville, Ill.  Kunkel's
> mother had given her son the britches when he was a college student.  He
> wore them a few times, but they froze stiff in cold weather and he
> didn't like them. So he gave them to Collette.  Collette, who called the
> moleskins "miserable", wore them three times, then wrapped them up and
> gave them back to Kunkel for Christmas the next year.
>
> The friendly exchange continued routinely until Collette twisted the
> pants tightly, stuffed them into a 3-foot-long, 1-inch wide tube and
> gave them back to Kunkel.  The next Christmas, Kunkel compressed the
> pants into a 7-inch square, wrapped them with wire and gave the "bale"
> to Collette. Not to be outdone, the next year Collette put the pants
> into a 2-foot-square crate filled with stones, nailed it shut, banded it
> with steel and gave the trusty trousers back to Kunkel.
>
> The brothers agreed to end the caper if the trousers were damaged. But
> they were as careful as they were clever. Kunkel had the pants mounted
> inside an insulated window that had a 20-year guarantee and shipped them
> off to Collette.  Collette broke the glass, recovered the trousers,
> stuffed them into a 5-inch coffee can and soldered it shut.  The can was
> put in a 5-gallon container filled with concrete and reinforcing rods
> and given to Kunkel the following Christmas.  Two years ago, Kunkel
> installed the pants in a 225-pound homemade steel ashtray made from
> 8-inch steel casings and etched Collette's name on the side. Collette
> had trouble retrieving the treasured trousers, but succeeded without
> burning them with a cutting torch.
>
> Last Christmas, Collette found a 600-pound safe and hauled it to Viracon
> Inc. in Owatonna, where the shipping department decorated it with red
> and green stripes, put the pants inside and welded the safe shut.  The
> safe was then shipped to Kunkel, who is the plant manager for Viracon's
> outlet in Bensenville. Last week, the pants were trucked to Owatonna, 55
> miles south of Minneapolis, in a drab green, 3-foot cube that once was a
> car with 95,000 miles on it.  A note attached to the 2,000-pound
> scrunched car advised Collette that the pants were inside the glove
> compartment.  "This will take some planning," Collette said. "I will
> definitely get them out.  I'm confident."  But he's waiting until January to
> think about how to recover the bothersome britches.
>
> "Wait until next year," he warned. "I'm on the offensive again."



--

system. The coolest is when this supposedly user friendly software

delete files from the system directory because uninstall won't work
correctly. I'd rather use "tar" myself. It's easier, and I know exactly
what it's doing, and exactly how it is breaking when things go wrong
(which they invariably do when you're using computers).

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Wed, 18 Dec 1996 20:41:39 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: "Wayne D. Correia" <wayne@club.net>
Subject: [nrr] COURT DECLARES CRYPTO RESTRICTIONS UNCONSTITUTIONAL
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

	COURT DECLARES CRYPTO RESTRICTIONS UNCONSTITUTIONAL
	    Free Speech Trumps Clinton Wiretap Plan

December 18, 1996

                                Electronic Frontier Foundation Contacts:

                                     Shari Steele, Staff Attorney
                                      301/375-8856, ssteele@eff.org

                                     John Gilmore, Founding Board Member
                                      415/221-6524, gnu@toad.com

                                     Cindy Cohn, McGlashan & Sarrail
                                      415/341-2585, cindy@mcglashan.com

San Francisco - On Monday, Judge Marilyn Hall Patel struck down Cold War
export restrictions on the privacy technology called cryptography.  Her
decision knocks out a major part of the Clinton Administration's
effort to force companies to build "wiretap-ready" computers,
set-top boxes, telephones, and consumer electronics.

The decision is a victory for free speech, academic freedom, and the
prevention of crime.  American scientists and engineers will now be
free to collaborate with their peers in the United States and in other
countries.  This will enable them to build a new generation of tools
for protecting the privacy and security of communications.

The Clinton Administration has been using the export restrictions to goad
companies into building wiretap-ready "key recovery" technology.  In a
November Executive Order, President Clinton offered limited
administrative exemptions from these restrictions to companies which
agree to undermine the privacy of their customers.  Federal District
Judge Patel's ruling knocks both the carrot and the stick out of
Clinton's hand, because the restrictions were unconstitutional in the
first place.

The Cold War law and regulations at issue in the case prevented
American researchers and companies from exporting cryptographic
software and hardware.  Export is normally thought of as the physical
carrying of an object across a national border.  However, the
regulations define "export" to include simple publication in the U.S.,
as well as discussions with foreigners inside the U.S.  They also define
"software" to include printed English-language descriptions and
diagrams, as well as the traditional machine-readable object code and
human-readable source code.

The secretive National Security Agency has built up an arcane web of
complex and confusing laws, regulations, standards, and secret
interpretations for years.  These are used to force, persuade, or
confuse individuals, companies, and government departments into making
it easy for NSA to wiretap and decode all kinds of communications.
Their tendrils reach deep into the White House, into numerous Federal
agencies, and into the Congressional Intelligence Committees.  In
recent years this web is unraveling in the face of increasing
visibility, vocal public disagreement with the spy agency's goals,
commercial and political pressure, and judicial scrutiny.

Civil libertarians have long argued that encryption should be widely
deployed on the Internet and throughout society to protect privacy,
prove the authenticity of transactions, and improve computer security.
Industry has argued that the restrictions hobble them in building
secure products, both for U.S. and worldwide use, risking America's
current dominant position in computer technology.  Government
officials in the FBI and NSA argue that the technology is too
dangerous to permit citizens to use it, because it provides privacy to
criminals as well as ordinary citizens.

"We're pleased that Judge Patel understands that our national security
requires protecting our basic rights of free speech and privacy," said
John Gilmore, co-founder of the Electronic Frontier Foundation, which
backed the suit.  "There's no sense in `burning the Constitution in
order to save it'.  The secretive bureaucrats who have restricted these
rights for decades in the name of national security must come to a
larger understanding of how to support and preserve our democracy."

	Reactions to the decision

"This is a positive sign in the crypto wars -- the first rational
statement concerning crypto policy to come out of any part of the
government," said Jim Bidzos, President of RSA Data Security, one of
the companies most affected by crypto policy.

"It's nice to see that the executive branch does not get to decide
whether we have the right of free speech," said Philip Zimmermann,
Chairman of PGP, Inc.  "It shows that my own common sense
interpretation of the constitution was correct five years ago when I
thought it was safe to publish my own software, PGP.  If only US
Customs had seen it that way."  Mr. Zimmermann is a civil libertarian
who was investigated by the government under these laws when he wrote
and gave away a program for protecting the privacy of e-mail.  His
"Pretty Good Privacy" program is used by human rights activists
worldwide to protect their workers and informants from torture and
murder by their own countries' secret police.

"Judge Patel's decision furthers our efforts to enable secure electronic
commerce," said Asim Abdullah, executive director of CommerceNet.

Jerry Berman, Executive Director of the Center for Democracy and
Technology, a Washington-based Internet advocacy group, hailed the
victory.  "The Bernstein ruling illustrates that the Administration
continues to embrace an encryption policy that is not only unwise, but
also unconstitutional.  We congratulate Dan Bernstein, the Electronic
Frontier Foundation, and all of the supporters who made this victory
for free speech and privacy on the Internet possible."

"The ability to publish is required in any vibrant academic discipline,"
This ruling re-affirming our obvious academic right will help American
researchers publish without worrying," said Bruce Schneier, author of
the popular textbook _Applied Cryptography_, and a director of the
International Association for Cryptologic Research, a professional
organization of cryptographers.

Kevin McCurley, President of the International Association for
Cryptologic Research, said, "Basic research to further the
understanding of fundamental notions in information should be welcomed
by our society.  The expression of such work is closely related to one
of the fundamental values of our society, namely freedom of speech."

	Effect of the decision

Judge Patel's decision today only legally applies to Prof. Bernstein.
Other people and companies are still technically required to follow
the export restrictions when speaking or publishing about
cryptography, or when speaking or publishing cryptographic source
code.  However, the decision sends a strong signal that if the
government tried to enforce these rules against other people, the
courts are likely to strike them down again.

Judge Patel has specifically not decided whether the export controls
on object code (the executable form of computer programs which source
code is automatically translated into) are constitutional.  Existing
export controls will continue to apply to runnable software products,
such as Netscape's broswer, until another court case challenges that
part of the restrictions.

	Background on the case

The plaintiff in the case, Daniel J. Bernstein, Research Assistant
Professor at the University of Illinois at Chicago, developed an
"encryption algorithm" (a recipe or set of instructions) that he
wanted to publish in printed journals as well as on the Internet.
Bernstein sued the government, claiming that the government's
requirements that he register as an arms dealer and seek government
permission before publication was a violation of his First Amendment
right of free speech.  This is required by the Arms Export Control Act
and its implementing regulations, the International Traffic in Arms
Regulations.

In the first phase of this litigation, the government argued that
since Bernstein's ideas were expressed, in part, in computer language
(source code), they were not protected by the First Amendment.  On
April 15, 1996, Judge Patel rejected that argument and held for the
first time that computer source code is protected speech for purposes
of the First Amendment.

	Details of Monday's Decision

Judge Patel ruled that the Arms Export Control Act is an
unconstitutional prior restraint on speech, because it requires
Bernstein to submit his ideas about cryptography to the government for
review, to register as an arms dealer, and to apply for and obtain from
the government a license to publish his ideas.  Using the Pentagon
Papers case as precedent, she ruled that the government's "interest of
national security alone does not justify a prior restraint." Under the
Constitution, he is now free to publish his ideas without asking the
government's permission first.

Judge Patel also held that the government's required licensing
procedure fails to provide adequate procedural safeguards.  When the
Government acts legally to suppress protected speech, it must reduce
the chance of illegal censorship by the bureacrats involved.  Her
decision states, "Because the ITAR licensing scheme fails to provide
for a time limit on the licensing decision, for prompt judicial review
and for a duty on the part of the ODTC to go to court and defend a
denial of a license, the ITAR licensing scheme as applied to Category
XIII(b) acts as an unconstitutional prior restraint in violation of the
First Amendment."

She also ruled that the export controls restrict speech based on the
content of the speech, not for any other reason.  "Category XIII(b) is
directed very specifically at applied scientific research and speech on
the topic of encryption."  The Government had argued that it restricts
the speech because of its function, not its content.

The judge also found that the ITAR is vague, because it does not
adequately define how information that is available to the public
"through fundamental research in science and engineering" is exempt
from the export restrictions.  "This subsection ...  does not give
people ... a reasonable opportunity to know what is prohibited." The
failure to precisely define what objects and actions are being
regulated creates confusion and a chilling effect.  Bernstein has been
unable to publish his encryption algorithm for over three years.  Many
other cryptographers and ordinary programmers have also been restrained
from publishing because of the vagueness of the ITAR.  Brian
Behlendorf, a maintainer of the popular public domain "Apache" web
server program, stated, "No cryptographic source code was ever
distributed by the Apache project.  Despite this, the Apache server
code was deemed by the NSA to violate the ITAR."  Judge Patel also
adopted a narrower definition of the term "defense service" in order to
save it from unconstitutional vagueness.

The immediate effect of this decision is that Bernstein now is free to
teach his January 13th cryptography class in his usual way.  He can
post his class materials on the Internet, and discuss the upcoming
class's materials with other professors, without being held in
violation of the ITAR.  "I'm very pleased," Bernstein said.  "Now I
won't have to tell my students to burn their notebooks."


ABOUT THE ATTORNEYS

Lead counsel on the case is Cindy Cohn of the San Mateo law firm of
McGlashan & Sarrail, who is offering her services pro bono.  Major
additional pro bono legal assistance is being provided by Lee Tien of
Berkeley; M. Edward Ross of the San Francisco law firm of Steefel,
Levitt & Weiss; James Wheaton and Elizabeth Pritzker of the First
Amendment Project in Oakland; and Robert Corn-Revere of the
Washington, DC, law firm of Hogan & Hartson.


ABOUT THE ELECTRONIC FRONTIER FOUNDATION

The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) is a nonprofit civil
liberties organization working in the public interest to protect
privacy, free expression, and access to online resources and
information.  EFF is a primary sponsor of the Bernstein case.  EFF
helped to find Bernstein pro bono counsel, is a member of the
Bernstein legal team, and helped collect members of the academic
community and computer industry to support this case.

Full text of the lawsuit and other paperwork filed in the case is
available from EFF's online archives at

        http://www.eff.org/pub/EFF/Policy/Crypto/ITAR_export/Bernstein_case/

The full text of Monday's decision will be posted there as soon as
we scan it in.

<wayne@eff.org>    1550 Bryant Street, Suite 725   fax: +1.415.436.9993

On Wed, 18 Dec 1996, John S. Lee wrote:

> Ahh, most of these viruses attack either PC's or Unix boxes.  They do not
> appear as frequently on the Mac.  Very, very, difficult to write viruses
> for that OS.  IMO, a good thing.  If it were just a bit more stable.

No, none of these viruses attack UNIX boxes. To date, to the best of my
knowledge, there has never been a documented UNIX virus. Worms, Trojan
horses, and all kinds of various and sundry security exploits, but no
viruses.

As to why there are more viruses for the Mac than for the PC, it is quite
simple. It is the same reason there are so many more pieces of software
for the PC as opposed to the MAC: Programmers looked at it and said:
"Why bother?"

Niels,
    
	I find your oversimplification of alternative culture a bit
condescending, and, frankly, a little insulting.  First, who are you to
suggest that there is something wrong with raving as a youngster and then
settling down and doing a variety of different things (which may or may
not include visiting a shopping mall) when you're older?  Perhaps I won't
*want* to be running around with teddy bears and day-glo paint 10 years
from now, just as today, I don't really *want* to do the things I wanted
to do when I was twelve, and when I was twelve, I didn't want to do the
things I enjoyed doing as a two-year old.  It's called maturing and
cultivating new interests--maybe down the road, I'll be interested in
opera and archaeology, and sitting at home with my wife on a Saturday
night, just talking, or hell, even going to a mini-mall and purchasing
something--if that's what I enjoy, will you have the right to call me a
"drone?"  
	And your thinking is all muddled, too: first you say that "every
generation's coming of age music/fashion/ethos is really the same old
thing".  Okay, if that's true, and each generation of young adults' ethos
*is* the same thing, then doesn't that prove that the stage is a
developmental one?  By that corollary, wouldn't someone be in arrested
development if they *didn't* leave that stage of their development as a
human being and enjoy new ones, too?  But then, for some unknown reason,
you go ahead and CRITICIZE previous generations for leaving their youthful
years behind them!  So what are you proposing that they do?  Embrace the
"same old thing"?  You've given individuals two options, and then have the
gall to call both of them foolish.  And if that isn't disorganized logic I
don't know what is. 

	And finally, the structure of your logic aside, I don't even think
that your assumptions are correct!  Each generation's "ethos" is not the
same:  the problem with the 60s' Flower Children was that many of them
were so angry at The Evil And Demonical And Oppresive Mainstream Culture,
that they never learned how to communicate with their purported enemy.
They shouted at demonstrations, hurled everything from insults to rocks,
and were so divisive, that they were unable to gain enough credibility in
their adversaries' eyes so as to be able to persuade them of their
position.  Ravers though, I think, have taken all the beautiful ideas that
the hippies uncovered and have embraced them, emulated them, but have
never forced them down the maionstream's throat: the result?  THe rest of
the world is listening!  Rave elitists may scoff at the techno that now
appears in commercials, or the advertising slogans like "Be Happy", or the
present political climate of inclusion for all, or the fact that
advancement in telecommunications technology is finally bringing about the
idea of a global community, but these are all things that ravers have been
hoping for for a long time, and now that the mainstream is joining in,
it's proof of the power of persuasiveness, and persuasion comes POLITELY.

	So in conclusion then, what do you think it says about you that
your posts *always* seem to generate bad feelings and ill-will?  I think
it's because your tone is so caustic and oftentimes even mean.  And what
good is an idea if it's always rejected? ANd no one listens to it?  Maybe
you should try to be a little more humble, and then maybe you could make
your ideas, many of which are really cool, I think, stick.  Otherwise, why
write posts that result in a flurry of angry responses?  You don't want to
see your ideas die, do you?  So present them as they should be presented-- 
with politeness and thoughtfulness. I mean come on--you really should know
better.   

Timothy

> enough at some of those 50ish ladies, you might see the ghost of a the
> high-school girl in the miniskirt that was partying down to rock and
> roll and riding around in a  souped up roadster, hair flying in the
> wind... Sometimes you see that 70 year old who musta been the king of
> the jazz juke-joint dance floor, flipping his partner overhead while
> dressed sharply, cept now he's walking all jittery with a cane. So...

Mac-			Accounts manager, interns, graphic design
Windows NT	My desktop, I run all the MS shit like Office, Photoshop, Internet Billing software, Business Plan Pro, etc. I also run
an X-windows server so I can talk to....

		webservers (Apache )
		sendmail (mail for 100+ domains)
		inn	netnews
		DNS for 100+n domains
		pop mail servers for 30 domains
	  	NOCOL network monitoring software
		IPWATCH to monitor net traffic across my lan.
		Tpage paging software.
		GCC for compiling all of the freewear that I use to keep my site running.

Um, the reason why you are at your terminal now and not in a rice patty in Vietnam
or on the russian front is because those "flower children" hurled insults and rocks and got shot at and killed at Kent State and
finally America listened.


>Ravers though, I think, have taken all the beautiful ideas that
> the hippies uncovered and have embraced them, emulated them, but have
> never forced them down the maionstream's throat: the result?  THe rest of
> the world is listening!  Rave elitists may scoff at the techno that now
> appears in commercials, or the advertising slogans like "Be Happy", or the
> present political climate of inclusion for all, or the fact that
> advancement in telecommunications technology is finally bringing about the
> idea of a global community, but these are all things that ravers have been

It's a lot easier to be polite when you don't have your Uncle pushing an M-16 in your hand 
and loading you on a C-130.  The young people of today do have the apparent luxury of 
being polite. And it is true that you can win over more people with love then with violence, 
but bear in mind that in 1974 I had a number assigned to my name, it was my draft lottery 
number attached to my birth date, my number was 234, doubtful that I was going, even if 
the war had lasted . My friends who were a year older then me had 34 and 78 respectively, 
they were out of high school and did not do well on their SATs, they were about to go 
enlist in the Air Force (cuz you could choose your assignment, maybe) when finally, an 
NVA tank bashed through the US Embassy gate in Saigon and the war was over.  I guess 
that tank wasn't too polite.  But when someone comes 10,000 miles to your country, turns
your women into whores and your rice fields into death traps and then accuses you of 
agression, well  I guess you could get a little riled up :)


							G

        "Re: more virus bullshit" (Dec 18,  8:25pm)
References: <vines.3uY7+gK5imA@imail1.ul.com> 
	<v03007802aede03092faa@DialupEudora>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.1 10oct95)
To: "John S. Lee" <jsl@netcom.com>, blkadder@value.net
Subject: Re: more virus bullshit
Cc: Dave Quezada <quezadad@ul.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Actually, Macs have long been prone to many relatively benign viruses.
Until mid-1995, I'd say that there were more viruses per capita (or per CPU,
I suppose) in the Mac realm than on PCs.  In fact, I didn't even observe a
real live PC virus until early 1994 (a copy of the classic Stoned).  Now
I'd guess that probably 10% to 20% of all PCs have at least one, and
probably half that percentage on Macs.

Unix is relatively untouched by viruses, though Linux boxes and others running
on PCs are at least vulnerable to boot sector viruses (BSVs) if booted from
an infected disk.  Same for NT.  DOS and Windows programs running within the
NT environment can be infected, but NT's protected-kernel architecture prevents
BSVs -- the most common type -- from infecting the system.  As NT becomes more
widespread, no doubt native NT viruses will be written, but the technical
hurdles are considerable since you can't boot NT directly from a floppy.
Other non-BSVs could develop, though.  

Macro viruses are quite common too, and run on whatever platform the app might
run on.  This gives new credence to the sarcastic acronym my friend Randal
Schwartz gives to a certain hot new programming language: Just Another
Virus Attractor.  It's true that the Java bytecode system for online apps is
designed not to let any nasty stuff happen to your system, and it's also true
that there are holes in its security scheme.  

The worst thing is that as we become more dependent on GUIs that hide and even
deliberately lock away the internals of our systems from us, we become more
vulnerable to viruses.  And *that*, my friends, is one of the true legacies
of the Mac OS.

phred

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I should clarify one little point that was unclear in my last screed on
viruses.  NT is not vulnerable to boot sector viruses directly because it can't
(as I stated subsequently) be directly booted from a floppy.  But just as with
Linux, BSDI, Netware and other OS which either require DOS to boot or can be
dual-booted under DOS, the DOS BSVs like AntiCMOS can, obviously, infect those
systems and pose a risk in future DOS sessions (though Linux, Netware and NT
and so on prevent them from doing anything once DOS is out of the way).

phred

hello all-

[warning:  statistically, topics that are believed by matt to be rave related tend to be interpreted by most as non rave related.  read with caution, and direct all flames to /dev/null.  -mdpkl]

this is matt's message to stressed out ravers-computer geeks-students:   DON'T GET MONO!  PROTECT YOURSELF!!!  NO PAPER, PROJECT, PARTY, OR OTHER COMMITTMENT IS MORE IMPORTANT THAN YOUR HEALTH.

i'm kinda pissed at a society that teaches us that our committments are more important than our health, that it's perfectly justified for a student to not sleep during finals, that a boss has every right to instruct an employee to not sleep and to finish a project.

because of the way i've bought into these attitudes that production is more important than health, i've got a mild case of mono.  it sucks.  that raise is not worth it, that grade is not worth it, that committment is not worth it.

thanks for listening to matt's griping for the day.  now return to your normal routine.

love to you all-

matt

Well, I just barely tapped into my e-mail when your post caught my eye.  I
am a parent (23) in that Post-adolescence stage, I guess if that's what you
want to call it. Even though I'm pretty young I don't look like a raver
during the day.  My typical look is a pair of jeans and a shirt.  My
appreciation for the rave scene is shown by just attending a rave and
enjoying the music and the people. Sometimes I do feel like me and the
youth around me are in two seperate worlds, only because of my experience.
But then again, I think about my old "youth culture" and say been there,
done that.  Were different because of experience, and I'm still not
finished experiencing yet. Only this time my son is a part of everything I
do. He's involved with the music because daddy's a D.J. and mommy loves to
dance. He's already been to his first little "rave".  (during the day, of
course).  But as he grows older he'll be going to more raves with us.
Daddy and I definately dress normal, and at raves wear the old school
clothes, an ameba shirt and a pair of wide legged jeans, and some
Addidas's.  Nothing outrageous, just normal.  I guess when we get old I
still plan to be a part of the rave culture and hopefully my son will too.
I hope to bring him up with a talent for mixing and record knowledge, and
hopefully someday he'll make us happy and press his own label. Eitherway,
he will contribute someway to rave culture.  No I don't think you'll see me
with a pacifier in my mouth, or a stuffed animal, at a rave, but my three
year old son wouldn't mind.

To: cc@cyborganic.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: "Wayne D. Correia" <wayne@club.net>
Subject: [nrr] updated - COURT DECLARES CRYPTO RESTRICTIONS
 UNCONSTITUTIONAL
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

	COURT DECLARES CRYPTO RESTRICTIONS UNCONSTITUTIONAL
	    Free Speech Trumps Clinton Wiretap Plan

December 18, 1996, 21:16 Pacific time.

                                Electronic Frontier Foundation Contacts:

                                     Shari Steele, Staff Attorney
                                      301/375-8856, ssteele@eff.org

                                     John Gilmore, Founding Board Member
                                      415/221-6524, gnu@toad.com

                                     Cindy Cohn, McGlashan & Sarrail
                                      415/341-2585, cindy@mcglashan.com

San Francisco - On Monday, Judge Marilyn Hall Patel struck down Cold War
export restrictions on the privacy technology called cryptography.  Her
decision knocks out a major part of the Clinton Administration's
effort to force companies to build "wiretap-ready" computers,
set-top boxes, telephones, and consumer electronics.

The decision is a victory for free speech, academic freedom, and the
prevention of crime.  American scientists and engineers will now be
free to collaborate with their peers in the United States and in other
countries.  This will enable them to build a new generation of tools
for protecting the privacy and security of communications.

The Clinton Administration has been using the export restrictions to goad
companies into building wiretap-ready "key recovery" technology.  In a
November Executive Order, President Clinton offered limited
administrative exemptions from these restrictions to companies which
agree to undermine the privacy of their customers.  Federal District
Judge Patel's ruling knocks both the carrot and the stick out of
Clinton's hand, because the restrictions were unconstitutional in the
first place.

The Cold War law and regulations at issue in the case prevented
American researchers and companies from exporting cryptographic
software and hardware.  Export is normally thought of as the physical
carrying of an object across a national border.  However, the
regulations define "export" to include simple publication in the U.S.,
as well as discussions with foreigners inside the U.S.  They also define
"software" to include printed English-language descriptions and
diagrams, as well as the traditional machine-readable object code and
human-readable source code.

The secretive National Security Agency has built up an arcane web of
complex and confusing laws, regulations, standards, and secret
interpretations for years.  These are used to force, persuade, or
confuse individuals, companies, and government departments into making
it easy for NSA to wiretap and decode all kinds of communications.
Their tendrils reach deep into the White House, into numerous Federal
agencies, and into the Congressional Intelligence Committees.  In
recent years this web is unraveling in the face of increasing
visibility, vocal public disagreement with the spy agency's goals,
commercial and political pressure, and judicial scrutiny.

Civil libertarians have long argued that encryption should be widely
deployed on the Internet and throughout society to protect privacy,
prove the authenticity of transactions, and improve computer security.
Industry has argued that the restrictions hobble them in building
secure products, both for U.S. and worldwide use, risking America's
current dominant position in computer technology.  Government
officials in the FBI and NSA argue that the technology is too
dangerous to permit citizens to use it, because it provides privacy to
criminals as well as ordinary citizens.

"We're pleased that Judge Patel understands that our national security
requires protecting our basic rights of free speech and privacy," said
John Gilmore, co-founder of the Electronic Frontier Foundation, which
backed the suit.  "There's no sense in `burning the Constitution in
order to save it'.  The secretive bureaucrats who have restricted these
rights for decades in the name of national security must come to a
larger understanding of how to support and preserve our democracy."

	Reactions to the decision

"This is a positive sign in the crypto wars -- the first rational
statement concerning crypto policy to come out of any part of the
government," said Jim Bidzos, President of RSA Data Security, one of
the companies most affected by crypto policy.

"It's nice to see that the executive branch does not get to decide
whether we have the right of free speech," said Philip Zimmermann,
Chairman of PGP, Inc.  "It shows that my own common sense
interpretation of the constitution was correct five years ago when I
thought it was safe to publish my own software, PGP.  If only US
Customs had seen it that way."  Mr. Zimmermann is a civil libertarian
who was investigated by the government under these laws when he wrote
and gave away a program for protecting the privacy of e-mail.  His
"Pretty Good Privacy" program is used by human rights activists
worldwide to protect their workers and informants from torture and
murder by their own countries' secret police.

"Judge Patel's decision furthers our efforts to enable secure electronic
commerce," said Asim Abdullah, executive director of CommerceNet.

Jerry Berman, Executive Director of the Center for Democracy and
Technology, a Washington-based Internet advocacy group, hailed the
victory.  "The Bernstein ruling illustrates that the Administration
continues to embrace an encryption policy that is not only unwise, but
also unconstitutional.  We congratulate Dan Bernstein, the Electronic
Frontier Foundation, and all of the supporters who made this victory
for free speech and privacy on the Internet possible."

"The ability to publish is required in any vibrant academic discipline,"
This ruling re-affirming our obvious academic right will help American
researchers publish without worrying," said Bruce Schneier, author of
the popular textbook _Applied Cryptography_, and a director of the
International Association for Cryptologic Research, a professional
organization of cryptographers.

Kevin McCurley, President of the International Association for
Cryptologic Research, said, "Basic research to further the
understanding of fundamental notions in information should be welcomed
by our society.  The expression of such work is closely related to one
of the fundamental values of our society, namely freedom of speech."

	Background on the case

The plaintiff in the case, Daniel J. Bernstein, Research Assistant
Professor at the University of Illinois at Chicago, developed an
"encryption algorithm" (a recipe or set of instructions) that he
wanted to publish in printed journals as well as on the Internet.
Bernstein sued the government, claiming that the government's
requirements that he register as an arms dealer and seek government
permission before publication was a violation of his First Amendment
right of free speech.  This is required by the Arms Export Control Act
and its implementing regulations, the International Traffic in Arms
Regulations.

In the first phase of this litigation, the government argued that
since Bernstein's ideas were expressed, in part, in computer language
(source code), they were not protected by the First Amendment.  On
April 15, 1996, Judge Patel rejected that argument and held for the
first time that computer source code is protected speech for purposes
of the First Amendment.

	Details of Monday's Decision

Judge Patel's decision applies throughout the country until and
unless it is overturned by a higher court.

It is not yet clear from the decision whether the export controls on
object code (the executable form of computer programs which source
code is automatically translated into) have been overturned.  It may
be that existing export controls will continue to apply to runnable
software products, such as Netscape's broswer, until another court
case challenges that part of the restrictions.

Judge Patel ruled that the Arms Export Control Act is a prior restraint
on speech, because it requires Bernstein to apply for and obtain from
the government a license to publish his ideas.  Using the Pentagon
Papers case as precedent, she ruled that the government's "interest of
national security alone does not justify a prior restraint."

Judge Patel also held that the government's required licensing
procedure fails to provide adequate procedural safeguards.  When the
Government acts legally to suppress protected speech, it must reduce
the chance of illegal censorship by the bureacrats involved -- in this
case, the State Department's Office of Defense Trade Controls.  Her
decision states, "Because the ITAR licensing scheme fails to provide
for a time limit on the licensing decision, for prompt judicial review
and for a duty on the part of the ODTC to go to court and defend a
denial of a license, the ITAR licensing scheme as applied to Category
XIII(b) acts as an unconstitutional prior restraint in violation of the
First Amendment." Professor Bernstein is now free to publish his ideas
without asking the government's permission first.

She also ruled that the export controls restrict speech based on the
content of the speech, not for any other reason.  "Category XIII(b) is
directed very specifically at applied scientific research and speech on
the topic of encryption."  The Government had argued that it restricts
the speech because of its function, not its content.

The judge also found that the ITAR is vague, because it does not
adequately define how information that is available to the public
"through fundamental research in science and engineering" is exempt
from the export restrictions.  "This subsection ...  does not give
people ... a reasonable opportunity to know what is prohibited." The
failure to precisely define what objects and actions are being
regulated creates confusion and a chilling effect.  Bernstein has been
unable to publish his encryption algorithm for over four years.  Many
other cryptographers and ordinary programmers have also been restrained
from publishing because of the vagueness of the ITAR.  Brian
Behlendorf, a maintainer of the popular public domain "Apache" web
server program, stated, "No cryptographic source code was ever
distributed by the Apache project.  Despite this, the Apache server
code was deemed by the NSA to violate the ITAR."  Judge Patel also
adopted a narrower definition of the term "defense article" in order to
save it from unconstitutional vagueness.

The immediate effect of this decision is that Bernstein now is free to
teach his January 13th cryptography class in his usual way.  He can
post his class materials on the Internet, and discuss the upcoming
class's materials with other professors, without being held in
violation of the ITAR.  "I'm very pleased," Bernstein said.  "Now I
won't have to tell my students to burn their notebooks."


ABOUT THE ATTORNEYS

Lead counsel on the case is Cindy Cohn of the San Mateo law firm of
McGlashan & Sarrail, who is offering her services pro bono.  Major
additional pro bono legal assistance is being provided by Lee Tien of
Berkeley; M. Edward Ross of the San Francisco law firm of Steefel,
Levitt & Weiss; James Wheaton and Elizabeth Pritzker of the First
Amendment Project in Oakland; and Robert Corn-Revere, Julia Kogan,
and Jeremy Miller of the Washington, DC, law firm of Hogan & Hartson.


ABOUT THE ELECTRONIC FRONTIER FOUNDATION

The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) is a nonprofit civil
liberties organization working in the public interest to protect
privacy, free expression, and access to online resources and
information.  EFF is a primary sponsor of the Bernstein case.  EFF
helped to find Bernstein pro bono counsel, is a member of the
Bernstein legal team, and helped collect members of the academic
community and computer industry to support this case.

Full text of the lawsuit and other paperwork filed in the case is
available from EFF's online archives at

        http://www.eff.org/pub/Privacy/ITAR_export/Bernstein_case/

The full text of Monday's decision will be posted there as soon as
we scan it in.

<wayne@eff.org>    1550 Bryant Street, Suite 725   fax: +1.415.436.9993
                   San Francisco, CA 94103 USA     <http://www.eff.org>

In 85 Mac's had MIDI sequencing programs and sample editing programs for
the EMU Emulator I, which for about 6-10 grand gave you the power of a
$50,000 Fairlight CMI

The GUI was basically the same as OS 7.5.5

The IBM PC had amber monitors that looked worse than the Commodore 64
with the stupid DOS command line.  Microsoft bought the system from some
guy in Seattle for about $30,000 after IBM threw together off the shelf
parts for their first PC, waking up to the fact that the C64, Apple and
Mac created a new market.

The average user is not a computer science major so now Windoze 95
virtually xeroxed Apple's GUI.

It's ironic that Apple became IBM after the 1984 commercial.

How about a clone from Woz and Jobs, made by Motorola & Sony?

The Crapple...   Banana (yello CPU)...   Orange (orange CPU)   etc.

DJ ASB

This party was the shit! 115 Minna Street is MUCH MUCH better than the 
cocodrie... No nasty security guards shining a flashlight in your faces, 
MUCH MUCH more room to dance, um was it me or was it louder too? Doubt 
it, it was Gateway systems like last time, the music blasted out onto 
the street... NO BAR (yay!) and thus no rude drunk people. It started up 
slow, we got there fairly early, and thought "hmmm i dunno," but as 
usual, the place kicked up arould 11, 11:30... 
	The party had some fouls beyond the control of the b.a.s.s. kru, such 
as Ed Rush and DJ Trace missing their flight (bastards) and sometime in 
the night the mixer busted, and we thought that the party would be over 
incredibly early. But no, the b.a.s.s. kru found another location for 
the party so it could return to $5 without Rush and Trace, and when the 
mixer busted, someone went 6 blocks to get another one, and the party 
started up just where they left off. MAJOR PROPS to the b.a.s.s. kru for 
that one! I know that other parties might have given up by the time the 
mixer busted.. Abstract and Flux's sets stood out in my mind that night 
for some reason (perhaps because they kicked ass? yes, i think so!) 
	All in all, the night was a great night. The jungle was hard, lots of 
beautiful bass, synth and rolling, or hard and bumpin.. Loud enough to 
rattle your body and get you on the dance floor.. Can't wait for the 
next Audio Impact...
Smiles and Love,
LAra

-- 
              (sk3)
      [ J U N G L I S T ]
. . . wishing on a star . . .

Subject: Re: Raver and Parent

Well, I just barely tapped into my e-mail when your post caught my eye.  I
am a parent (23) in that Post-adolescence stage, I guess if that's what you
want to call it. Even though I'm pretty young I don't look like a raver
during the day.  My typical look is a pair of jeans and a shirt.  My
appreciation for the rave scene is shown by just attending a rave and
enjoying the music and the people. Sometimes I do feel like me and the
youth around me are in two seperate worlds, only because of my experience.
But then again, I think about my old "youth culture" and say been there,
done that.  Were different because of experience, and I'm still not
finished experiencing yet. Only this time my son is a part of everything I
do. He's involved with the music because daddy's a D.J. and mommy loves to
dance. He's already been to his first little "rave".  (during the day, of
course).  But as he grows older he'll be going to more raves with us.
Daddy and I definately dress normal, and at raves wear the old school
clothes, an ameba shirt and a pair of wide legged jeans, and some
Addidas's.  Nothing outrageous, just normal.  I guess when we get old I
still plan to be a part of the rave culture and hopefully my son will too.
I hope to bring him up with a talent for mixing and record knowledge, and
hopefully someday he'll make us happy and press his own label. Eitherway,
he will contribute someway to rave culture.  No I don't think you'll see me
with a pacifier in my mouth, or a stuffed animal, at a rave, but my three
year old son wouldn't mind.

Happily Addicted to the Web
 ---------------------------
 (to the tune of "Winter Wonderland")

 Doorbell rings, I'm not list'nin',
 From my mouth, drool is glist'nin',
 I'm happy--although
 My boss let me go--
 Happily addicted to the Web.

 All night long, I sit clicking,
 Unaware time is ticking,
 There's beard on my cheek,
 Same clothes for a week,
 Happily addicted to the Web.

 Friends come by; they shake me,
 Saying, "Yo, man!
 Don't you know tonight's the senior prom?"
 With a listless shrug, I mutter, "No, man;
 I just discovered letterman-dot-com!"

 I don't phone, don't send faxes,
 Don't go out, don't pay taxes,
 Who cares if someday
 They drag me away?
 I'm happily addicted to the Web!


 The Bill Gates Song
 -------------------
 (to the tune of "The Christmas Song")

 Netscape roasting on an open fire,
 Apple begging on its knees,
 Photo popping up on Time magazine,
 Yes, Bill Gates dreams of days like these!
 Everybody knows he's never fully satisfied,
 Throws himself behind each task,
 World dominion is his company's goal.
 Well, hey, is that so much to ask?
 He knows the world is in his sway,
 We'll buy whatever software he might toss our way,
 We'll surf his Internet, watch his TV,
 He'll take us anywhere we ask him--for a fee.

 And so we're offering this simple prayer,
 To Bill and all his MS grunts:
 Since we all follow any standard you write,
 Make it good, please,
 Make it good, please,
 Make it good, please, just once!


 Microsoft
 ---------
 (to the tune of "Jingle Bells" starting with 
"dashing thru the snow...")

 Nine-tenths of a gig,
 Biggest ever seen,
 God, this program's big--
 MS Word 15!
 Comes on ten CDs,
 And requires--damn!
 Word is fine, but jeez--
 60 megs of RAM?!

 Oh! Microsoft, Microsoft,
 Bloatware all the way!
 I've sat here installing Word
 Since breakfast yesterday!
 Oh! Microsoft, Microsoft,
 Moderation, please.
 Guess you hadn't noticed:
 Four-gig drives don't grow on trees!


 I'm Dreaming of a Clean System
 -------------------------------
 (to the tune of "White Christmas")

 I'm dreaming of a clean System,
 Something that fits on one CD.
 Each component matches,
 Not bits and patches,
 Unlike 7-5-point-3.
 I'm longing for a dream System,
 Small, stable, fast, and trouble-free.
 What we want, I think you'll agree,
 Is called System 6-point-oh-3!


 Violent Night
 -------------
 (to the tune of "Silent Night")

 Silent Mac, broken Mac!
 System bombed, screen went black.
 Books suggested things; I tried 'em all:
 Shift key, desktop file, clean reinstall.
 Now my deadline is tight,
 This Mac's been silent all night.

 Violent night, horrible night!
 Lost my cool, filled with spite,
 Threw my Mac through the balcony door
 Watched it fall from the 20th floor,
 Now I'm sleeping in peace;
 Thank God I had it on lease.


 Prove It's So!
 --------------
 (to the tune of "Let It Snow")

 Oh, the papers say Apple's dying,
 But before we start good-byeing,
 We should call them all up and go,
 "Prove it's so! Prove it's so! Prove it's so!"

 They say "Mac OS software's scarcer."
 We say, "Read those numbers, there, sir,
 Sales continued this year to grow.
 There ya go, there ya go, there ya go!"

 When they tell us Win 95
 Made the Mac's famed advantages ebb,
 We'll say, "Why, then, do Macs now drive
 60 percent of the Web?"

 We can win our PR reversal--
 Make the Mac be universal--
 Though we may have some years to go,
 Make it so, make it so, make it so!


 Gil Amelio's Coming to Town!
 ----------------------------
 (to the tune of "Santa Claus Is Coming to Town")

 You better watch out,
 Absurd as it sounds,
 'Cause Apple's about
 To lose a few pounds--
 Gil Amelio's coming to town!

 He's making a list,
 And trimming the rolls
 Of projects that missed
 Their revenue goals--
 Gil Amelio's coming to town!
 He knows what's losing money,
 Like eWorld, PowerTalk . . .
 You'd better make your project work
 Or prepare to take a walk!

 Though you follow his lead
 Right out the back door,
 You know he'll succeed--
 He's done it before!
 Gil Amelio's coming to town!


 God Rest Ye Copland Programmers
 -------------------------------
 (to the tune of "God Rest Ye Merry Gentlemen")

 God rest ye Copland programmers,
 It's finally Christmas Day.
 You've all worked 20-hour shifts
 Beginning back in May.
 No wonder after such neglect
 Your spouses moved away.
 The last real meal you had
 Was late last year--
 That's what we hear;
 And since then you've lived on
 Pizza, Coke, and beer.

 Your bosses change, and change their minds,
 Is Copland off or on?
 Are last week's OS plans in place
 Or now completely gone?
 God rest ye well this Christmas Day,
 You'd better sleep in late--
 It's the last sleep you'll get till '98.
 Isn't that great?
 It's the last day off you'll have till '98!

Well my parents are very cool. My sister and I always pick a theme for
them. This year it's lunch boxes. My mom was the type that would make
our lunches everyday for school and in them she would right little notes
on our napkins(cute huh!) and she would cut out comic stripes too. 
So this year I bought her an old vintage lunch box and my sister and I
are going to put all sorts of goodies in it that tell her how much we
appreciate all the cool things she did while we were growing up. We
bought my dad an original Lone Ranger lunch box, well because he knows
the theme by heart and he always called me Tonto. 
I say pick a theme and have fun with it.

Received: from sierra.zyzzyva.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with ESMTP id LAA11319; Thu, 19 Dec 1996 11:57:31 -0800 (PST)
