        "Dave Quezada" <quezadad@ul.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: more virus bullshit 
In-reply-to: Your message of "Thu, 19 Dec 96 06:48:01 PST."
             <v03007803aede94fe7a4d@DialupEudora> 
Date: Thu, 19 Dec 96 11:54:13 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> Couldn't possibly be the fact that Netscape is so poorly written that it
> REQUIRES a large memory model to run?  Nah, couldn't be ;).
> ...
> John (who has seen a dozen crashes from poorly written software).

If you're running a real operating system, you should be able to run
*ANY* software on your system, no matter how badly written, and it
shouldn't be able to do anything worse than crash the program (not the
whole computer) or corrupt your own personal file-space. When the usual
user-level-program crashes the whole computer, requires you to reboot
your system, or can corrupt system-level files (including boot sectors,
other applications, DLL's etc) then you're not running on a real OS,
you're just running a glorified loader. 

On a Unix-based system, it's easy enough to enable a capability-based
protection (as opposed to the superuser-versus-user dichotomy) which
enables individual programs or calls to access a single facet of
protected system-level functionality. This idea was fully understood
and implemented as far back as the mid-60's (the classical era of
computing), but was somehow forgotten during the dark-ages of DOS and
Windows, along with the burning-at-the-stake of academic software
infidels that wouldn't bow down to the herd mentality of the mass
market and microsoft.

In the upcomping englightenment, some variants of Unix are already
doing this, including Linux. Capability-based OS's give a user an
arrays of non-overlapping capabilities based on their needs/usage which
grant them temporary access to a small subset of protected system
resource for just as long as that access is needed. THis can
significantly minimize the ability for a virus/worm/trojan-horse
inadvertently run by a user to do damage to the system, or even the
user's own personal file-space. It's too bad the dark-ages morons that
invented Java forgot this lesson (which you'd learn in the first few
weeks of any OS class) when designing their language/OS. It would be a
whole lot safer than it currently is, especially when running on
Windows/Mac/NT.

The fact that most people have actually never run software on a real
operating system leads people to accept that user-level software can
crash your computer, or hang your system in an infinite loop, or
corrupt  your system with "viruses" and that those hazards are all just
part-and-parcel with "progress." People supplicate to the misunderstood
and oft-angry gods of computing by rebooting often, or by waving around
magic disks of "anti virus software". Never suspecting that their
unwavering allegiance to the faulty gods of "Windows" and "DOS" may be
the source of their troubles and the cause of all their superstitious
behavior.

But the fact is, the OS's run by the majority of people today are WORSE
than 1960's and 1970's computer technology which solved all those
problems long before most of the new generation of self-designated
"computer geniuses" were born. Multics or Tops-20 had all the necessary
OS concepts you'd need to run safe, virus-free computing environments. 
But since we've lost the capacity to learn lessons from the past in our
headlong rush towards the future (and riches, and commercialism and
market-share/monopoly), it seems some valuable ideas were lost in the
name of progress. ANd most people are paying the price for the
foolishness of a few overzealous snake-oil salesmen/missionaries who
claimed to bring the fire of the gods down from the ivory tower and
into the hands of 'da people.

Part of the problem here is that computer engineering/science is
neither engineering or science, just a bunch of hacks that managed to
get something to work and shipped/productized the hacks w/o concern for
the monster that might have been unleashed. The self-designated
"computer wizards" rush to release often resulted in much
reinventing-of-the-wheel, often forgetting the lessons that can be
learned when you stand on the shoulders of giants that did the exact
same thing just a generation earlier.

In the midst of these dark ages, we find ourselves dealing with
computer alchemists that don't really know what they're doing (compared
to the "real" sciences and real engineering) but will wow us with
bubbling test tubes and melting oxidizing metals... And rather than
understanding what they're doing, why they're doing it, and the role
their inventions are playing in mapping out the future, they're busy
fulfilling quarterly profit-to-earnings ratios, figuring how to
undercut a competitor, and how to monopolize a market. The alchemy of
economics. In these dark ages, we're wowed with the massive twinkling
cathedrals of McNealy/Gates/Clark who will bestow "progress" upon the
unwashed masses by singing the hymn "start me up". In these dark ages,
we hope that the wizards of market-share will show us the light, invite
us into their cathedrals ... meanwhile, some try to ignore the
burning-at-the-stake of any software infidels that will not bow down to
the monopolistic forces at hand, that shout "there is a better way".

The response, fortunately, is coming from Europe, Asia, Australia, and
Japan where lots of people *ARE* ignoring the hype of Pope Gates and
running software that serves their interests, nationalities, and desire
for controlling their own destinies -- Linux.

== When yer swimming in a creek and an eel bites yer cheek, that's a moray!==

Com'on peaple the candy fad is played out!

Everyone knows that candy use leads to drug addiction.  

Ask any heroin addict, he probably started on Hershey's kisses and
M&M's, worked his way up to  candy cigarettes, chewing gum cigars,
chocolate covered expresso beans, coffee milk, tobacco, airplane glue,
whipped cream cans, and from these stepping stones on to harder drugs
like alcohol and No Doze, ultimately leading to crack and smack.

This is part of the Peer Pressure all kids go through.

"Hey, jump off the roof and land on your head... you'll get a head
rush!"

or

"Take a drag on this, it's really cool, you'll feel like throwing up,
get a splitting headache, your lungs will feel like you poured lighter
fluid in and lit it, and then you feel like you are dying...  You'll
feel mature and can hang out with the big kids"

Besides the above candy causes lots of other health problems like
cavities, hypoglycemia, loss of vitamins, etc. etc. so substitute with
honey, Sucanat, barley malt, raisens, etc

And if you don't believe tying candy to raves is a plot look at
Halloween and Xmas...  big candy rush holidays... like we should
associate candy with fun and being a kid!

Lastly, candy at raves is a sign that people have the "munchies" which
is a sure indicator of possible drug use so please point these people
out to the nearest undercover deadhead type (these days the undercover
narcs have the hippest tie dye shirts--watch out for them!)

Ay

My apology, I was responding to Larry Ching's ?


> I often wonder what happens to the people that were fully into their
>>> "youth culture scene" when they were 16-24 and now they're just more
>>> same-looking blue-haired middle-aged drones inhabiting a mini-mall,
>>> clutching gifts of plasticene consumer goods. ... So...
>>> when y'all are 50, will you still be wearing silvery pants and
>>> clutching teddy bears and raving all night?
>>

Well, I just barely tapped into my e-mail when your post caught my eye.  I
am a parent (23) in that Post-adolescence stage, I guess if that's what you
want to call it. Even though I'm pretty young I don't look like a raver
during the day.  My typical look is a pair of jeans and a shirt.  My
appreciation for the rave scene is shown by just attending a rave and
enjoying the music and the people. Sometimes I do feel like me and the
youth around me are in two seperate worlds, only because of my experience.
But then again, I think about my old "youth culture" and say been there,
done that.  Were different because of experience, and I'm still not
finished experiencing yet. Only this time my son is a part of everything I
do. He's involved with the music because daddy's a D.J. and mommy loves to
dance. He's already been to his first little "rave".  (during the day, of
course).  But as he grows older he'll be going to more raves with us.
Daddy and I definately dress normal, and at raves wear the old school
clothes, an ameba shirt and a pair of wide legged jeans, and some
Addidas's.  Nothing outrageous, just normal.  I guess when we get old I
still plan to be a part of the rave culture and hopefully my son will too.
I hope to bring him up with a talent for mixing and record knowledge, and
hopefully someday he'll make us happy and press his own label. Eitherway,
he will contribute someway to rave culture.  No I don't think you'll see me
with a pacifier in my mouth, or a stuffed animal, at a rave, but my three
year old son wouldn't mind.

The only reason I'm giving Mac props on SFRaves is that after leading
all other computers as THE recording studio computer for music
production the last 10 years, for the money it has the most powerful,
easy to use music apps barring getting a $150,000 digital audio
workstation.

Also any Mac with stereo in/out can be a 16 channel digital recorder
with basic software, and the stock OS 7.5.5 makes it a 10 second digital
sampler, with freeware and shareware programs for longer sampling.

Macs can also read IBM and Amiga MOD files and create loop style songs
in that underground format.

Unfortunately as we move towards the Common Reference Platform the Mac
OS seems more like Windoze 95.

Yeah I know about Xerox PARC but the Mac was the first commercial market
GUI that made computing simple and intuitive for non-programmers.  I
consider myself a power user but when the Apple Internet Connection Kit
takes days to set up right then we're getting to be like the DOS world.  

Most people want to use a computer system like a telephone, not be a
programmer and know how the damn thing works, remember Apple? 

Anyone notice that the govt wants do declare Sony's internet/tv box a
weapon and prevent the rest of the world from having cheap internet
access?  Do we come off like the Nazis of the "Information Superhighway"
or what?

DJ ASB

'em. How the needle moves on blank vinyl when I'm not scratching or 
backspinnig is of no concern to me. Your methode will of course provide 
true neutral tracking; however, neutral is not necessarily corect for my 
DJing style.

Michael Standish    DoD#732                standish@sirius.com CBR600F    
 
510.525.FILM     (525.3456)                2 wheels good, 4 wheels bad

 When I'm bored my mind begins to wander  to a faraway land, and my
imagination begins to explore. And I wrote this poem. So here is a poem
from me to all you beautiful people.

P.L.U.R...........
What is PLUR?
Peace is when two people of a different country share advice.
Love is when you show great emotions for one.
Unity is to bring all together and accept each other.
Respect is the care and tenderness you show one another.

Please let your mind explore.
Let your body experience a whole new world.
Unite and believe in one another.
Revive and feel the trance.

LET THE VIBE TAKE YOU AWAY.........................................

Thank you for taking the time to read this. I hope you enjoyed. And I
hope this made your day a little brighter.
This is what I feel PLUR means. This it what PLUR means to me.
Love always Victoria

HEY everyone, THANKS for your suggestions!! :>>
My friend ran home to try every one of your suggestions.. For future 
references, here are some of the suggestions i recieved:
	1) Try the peanut butter anyway, cuz the oil in the PB will loosen up 
the gum.
	2) Apply ice directly to the pants and chip it off as you go along
	3) Try using gasoline on the gum to loosen it up.
	4) Let it sit in the sun and dry out the gum then try.
	5) Put a piece of newspaper/other paper over the gum and iron it off.
	6) Buy new pants. 
	7) a FnF patch.. ;>
	8) Don't sit in gum. (hahahahahahahaha)
Thanks again, you're all great people! 
Love and Smiles,
		LAra

As a raving newcomer (to this highly esteemed bbs) who drops into waves
while cybersurfing and snaking all shoulder hoppers I appreciate why
this is exactly the kind of message one should find on a rave list
instead of scholarly dissertations on the history of disco or the Rules
of Dance Music.

Why I dropped into SFR so hard?  Besides living in N Cali for most of
this decade I've been a little teed about  some of the opinions coming
out of SF through some local dance trades.

As I dropped into SFR I thot, "Kewl, this is almost as good as AOL
was!!!" and I guess I got back into that hacker mentality that does
battle with P.E.T. teams (Isn't that the name of the AOL S.S.?) and fake
hackers working for the other side.

The other aspect was a little research project re Fads and Turf Wars in
the Music Industry, particularly re dance music.

Don't mind me I'm just a fool!

DJ ASB

PS:  Try lighter fluid or that stuff like it at hardware stores that
remove any gunk--but watch the colors!    :)

*************************************************************_____________________________________________________________

THIS IS ONLY A TEST

THIS HAS ONLY BEEN A TEST OF THE BEHAVIOR MODIFICATION SYSTEM.  

Had there been a real emergency you would have been instructed to go to
your nearest pharmacy.

Keep moving on the dancefloor...   NO MOSHING!

Keep moving on the dancefloor...   NO MOSHING!

Keep moving on the dancefloor...   NO MOSHING!
_______________________________________________________________
PSS

You Windoze 95 types will have to understand that some of us ravers are
what society labels "sociopaths" which is like being dislexic to rules. 
I'm worried about the immanent mutation of XLR8R into Rolling Stone
complete with university degreed Music Critics.

Once a new fad has reached the phase of having preachers describing it
for the masses the ka is usually dead.

By controlling the Terms of the Fad one gains Territory which must be
defended at all costs.  Music Critics become the preachers of the Fad,
dividing the followers into sects based on Genre.

As the Fad grows more and more Record Label dollars flow to the fad
media, and they begin to Smooze with Record Labels.

By controlling the local media one can hype one's friends and business
relations and Record Sales fuel this vicious cycle.

I believe we have now entered a time when commercials are more cutting
edge than "serious media."   Watch Saturday morning cartoons for a
while--you are being massaged with a rave of information cultivating
your commercial tastes, attitudes, and of course the usual programming.

To me cyberspace is like the ocean---I don't check in with the etiquette
(sic) FAQ anymore---but then I guess that's why I dropped out of school.

Anyway I saw all the different "stoopid" conversations and rants and
thought at least it was a change from the "Professional" Rave Media.

Will someone please direct me to the Grand Puba of the Mailing List to
have my Bootay Spanked and then force me to read a 3" Internet book 100
times, finally sending me a copy of the Allowable Subject Matter List
for this list?

DJ ASB

WASTED BANDWIDTH TO FOLLOW

I've taken some flack recently for some of my posts so I thought I'd
reply by sampling another mailing list:

Subject: 
               UK-Dance Digest 1835
     Date: 
               Wed, 18 Dec 1996 07:00:04 GMT
   From: 
               UK-Dance <uk-dance@uk-dance.org>
        To: 
               UK-Dance <uk-dance@uk-dance.org>



To unsubscribe from UK-Dance, write to uk-dance-request@uk-dance.org
with a message containing the word 'unsubscribe'.

Contents:

    shit, did I say that, why?
        Steve Merrylees <S.Merrylees@plymouth.ac.uk>
    pills bizniz
        "Vincent Cole" <vcole@era.co.uk>
    Re: too excited for a subject...
        Damian Connon <dconnon@candcdev.demon.co.uk>
    Remove
        Shan Ng <100740.77@compuserve.com>
    A Jammy Bastard Speaks
        "Thomas, Martin" <THOMASM@stg2wc.igw.bt.co.uk>

From: Steve Merrylees <S.Merrylees@plymouth.ac.uk>
Date: Tue, 17 Dec 1996 17:07:33 BST
Subject: shit, did I say that, why?

I would like to sincerely apologise for feeling the need to tell 
everyone on UKD what a lucky bastard I am.   I was just too excited 
about actually having a decent NYE that the part of the brain that 
usually detects potential cheesy or embarressing statements temporarily 
shut down, I'm sorry...
Having said that I think we should start arranging some kind of meeting 
point for everyone going to Mount Universe so I can share some of this 
free booze around and avoid feeling anonymous amongst the 12000.  Also, 
has anyone got any idea about the level of searches employed at these 
events?
- ----------
Did anyone catch the Psychonaughts on the Essential Mix at the weekend?  
Phenomenal, 75 records in two hours apparently, hard to describe but I 
suppose eclectic would be one the words used.  Has anyone taped it?, I 
only got he last 45mins due to Caffreys induced forgetfulness, mail me 
privately if you're prepared to do some copying duties, normal 
arrangement..

Steve
- ----------------------------------------
Until the sky turns green,
And the grass is several shades of blue,
Every member of parliament trips on glue.
- -----------------------------------------

From: "Vincent Cole" <vcole@era.co.uk>
Date: Tue, 17 Dec 96 17:26:58 GMT
Subject: pills bizniz

     Niz, 1826:
     
     > > ...various stuff from me about pills...
     > ...various stuff from niz, saying 'you must have been
overdoing      
       it then'...
     
     Well yeah, thats what I'm talking about! 
     
     When something starts off so good, and it also happens to be 
     psychotropic, you can end up overdoing it without even realising.
But 
     when eventually you have a moment of insight, and stop, and then 
     reality returns, you see what you were missing before (and also
what 
     you were missing before you started doing pills), and then when you
go 
     out, if the atmosphere is good, you can get so high naturally.
     
     Its a cycle that takes you down so low, that you are forced to see
so 
     much more value in life, in order to dig yourself up out. And 
     once you're out, you actually keep going so that you end up higher 
     than ever before - I love it! 
     
     Vince.

From: "Thomas, Martin" <THOMASM@stg2wc.igw.bt.co.uk>
Date: Tue, 17 Dec 96 17:55:00 GMT
Subject: A Jammy Bastard Speaks

I was strolling down Berwick Street on Monday (as you do) when I
happened to 
pass the door of Sister Ray, the well-known and much-loved popular music 
record emporium. What should I hear coming from the speakers inside but 
something that sounded suspiciously like Daft Punk, although nothing I'd 
heard before. Intrigued, I went inside and asked the friendly fellow
behind 
the counter what was playing. "Daft Punk's new album", he replied. 
"But...but...but..." I blurted. "Let me pre-empt you there old boy," he 
said. "You don't think the album's out for a few weeks yet do you?" I
dumbly 
shook my head. I was confused.
"Well, we got 15 vinyl copies of the blighter this morning and there's
one 
left!" he exclaimed. Hardly believing my good fortune I whipped out my 
wallet and bought the bastard there and then, thanking all that is
sacred 
that I recently bought a new belt for my turntable (yeah, yeah, I know
DD's 
where it's at, but what the fuck eh?)
And my verdict? Well, no time/inclination for a detailed critique now,
but 
it sounds like the proverbial bollocks to me. There are a couple of 
bowel-loosening steroid-pumped mutant techno battle chargers from Hell
in 
there, some oh-so-funky disco-stabbed-by-techno-down-a-dark-alley
numbers, 
some willfully obscure pony-tailed knob-twiddling chancer shows off like
an 
only child moments and some *gorgeous* 
quite-hard-to-categorise-but-don't-wear-your-best-pants-when-you-listen-to-it 
type of stuff too.
All in all, a bit of a result. Finally, something that lives up to the
hype.
I'll tell you more about it when I know it a bit better.
Shame about those copyright laws isn't it? I could organise tapes if it 
wasn't for that. Still, it's only a few weeks...

Martin (smug)

------------------------------

End of UK-Dance Digest
**********************

Anyway half the time I'm pulling your leg so don't take it seriously OK?

Ay,

DJ ASB  :D

   Papp. 21+. the EndUp, 6th & Harrison, SF.

   eclectic guests. 9pm-2am, 21+, $4. 111 Minna St, SF.

   third wednesdays of each month
   9p-3a, 18+, $5. 1024 Kearny @ Broadway, SF. 415.332.5800x247

   Haight St, SF.

   10p-2a, 21+. the Up & Down Club, 1151 Folsom St, SF.

   Black. free before 11:30 w/flyer.
   10pm-4am, 21+, $5. Transmission Theatre, 308 11th St @ Folsom, SF.
   415.908.6710

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday morning 9am-11am - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon - Beats, Breakz
       and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford).
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Tuesday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. and
       Monkeywrench. Varied techno sub-genres, noise, spoken word, world
       music. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - the Uncle Noah TV Show - the best
       in Techno and House music. 3-5am, KDVS 90.3fm (Davis)
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

On Thu, 19 Dec 1996, DJ ASB wrote:

> I'm worried about the immanent mutation of XLR8R into Rolling Stone
> complete with university degreed Music Critics.

	I won't really worrying about XLR8R becoming like Rolling Stone or
Spin or whatever. If people read it like they do Rolling Stone or Spin, it
is the people you should be snickering at. Now if XLR8R becomes all high
and mighty because they turn out a free mag which I guess is suppose to
chronicle the rave scene, then they are nice hypocritical human beings who
like most high and mighty types, simply have their heads up their asses
(albeit in top fashion with 100 million people worshipping the words that
fart out of that asshole, but who am I to find that silly). Either that or
their "rave scence" isn't the same one I am involved with. 

> Once a new fad has reached the phase of having preachers describing it
> for the masses the ka is usually dead.

	Well, do you mean that once a movement or religion or the like 
has someone telling you what "it is all about", that that movement or 
religion has lost its meaning? It no longer gives people the chance to 
find their own meaning in what they are doing I would agree. Here have 
this spoon fed meaning, I trust you understand it don't you....

dave

Dave

I suppose I'm just venting a little as the "history" of rave and the
dance scene becomes codified by scribes.  Half the time it sounds like
the usual record industry hype, fluff, and commercialism we see in all
the other music genres.

A rule of nature prevails.  Magazines tend to hype labels that buy ads. 
DJ's tend to play the labels who send lots of freebees and extra
records.  The farther one works up the chain to the big bucks and big
record labels the shmoozing is like some kind of EST program.

Worse than the big labels are phony "peace & love " promoters who are in
it for the money and care nothing about the music or scene.

I'd rather see some of the wacky stuff when rant3rs can really  rave on
this list but maybe I was a little overboard which can happen to silly
fools.

The thing I enjoyed most were the criticisms which make ya check
y'rself.

:D

DJ ASB

Hi,
Just a quick note for anyone interested in UK releases: The Dance Music
Resource Pages publishes a complete weekly listing of UK dance releases
and new imports at

http://www.ndirect.co.uk/dance/music.htm

including details of remixes/catalogue numbers/distributor info, etc.

The new release listing is now also available as a free e-mail service -
to subscribe send a message to

juno@deepside.demon.co.uk

Hope this is of interest!

TOP TEN SANTA WARNING SIGNS

10. Last year, he described his sleigh as an "open transport."
    This year, nobody will support it.
9.  Offers to let you in on the ground floor of Wired stock.
8.  Keeps peeking at a black and yellow paperback called
    "Santa for Dummies."
7.  Stuffs your stocking with AOL sign-up disks.
6.  Hands out Tickle-Me Ellison dolls.
5.  Logged on to the Internet relay chat channel "gift gab"
    and hasn't been heard from since.
4.  Won't touch your cookies.
3.  He made his list, but he cross-linked it twice.
2.  Misread something in a chat room and thought he could send
    gifts as email attachments.
1.  Says Christmas96 is still in beta...wait till February.

[ to sfraves ]

 Well, it's been actually a hectic week, and I intend to just veg out
tonight (Fri). But, I am finally seriously considering going to the
Gathering tomorrow night ( I was going to a thing tonight, but am going
to pass on that for the TV couch and a warm bed ).

 I was watching last night, and the weather reporter was doing the 
five-day forecast thing. On Saturday's graphic was a footnote : "Winter
Solstice" (!) - Oh duh! The Gathering is going to be on the Winter
Solstice! I had completely missed that point in all the recent 
discussion about it ( I've just been skipping over the "Gathering"
related posts so far ).

 So - it'll be a huge crowd, so I'm not going to bother posting about
what I'm going to be wearing or look like. Well.. I might wear my old
red cap with "SFR" painted on it, but that's the only unique thing
I think I'll be wearing.

 CUCMe ? In any case - let's rock the place!!!

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

I think it time to post...

The 101 Uses For AOL Disks Recieved In The Mail
(I've Placed lil smilieys by the actual ones Ive used...)

1. Mini cutting board (great for the office or the car, use metal door
forknife). 2. Attach it to a ruler and presto! - you've got a fly
swatter. 3. Construct a life size replica of Stonehenge. <--  >=)4. At a
restaurant, shove one under a wobbling table leg. 5. Money clip (use the
metal door and discard the plastic case...the "richnerd" look is IN this
year). 6. Eye patch (for one-eyed software pirates). 7. Christmas
ornaments (the more the merrier). <--  >=)8. Give them to young children
to use as building blocks. 9. Glue them to the bottom of the space
shuttle and use them as re-entry burn tiles. 10. Dentures (melt & form
them into new teeth for grandma). 11. Room dividers for hamsters. 12.
Drink coasters. 13. Use multiple disks to create an ideal door stopper.
14. Ice scraper. 15. Bathroom tile. 16. Bookmark. 17. Mini frisbee. <--
>=)18. Air hockey puck. 19. Dog chew toy. <--  >=)20. Dart board. 21.
Pooper scooper. 22. Grill scraper. 23. Use them for karate
board-breaking demonstrations (save a tree). 24. Wrist slicer - after
receiving first AOL bill (use metal door). 25. Conversation piece for
coffee table. 26. Destroy them - smash, burn, or run over to relieve
stress. <--  >=)27. Light switch cover. 28. Chinese throwing stars (tape
2 together). 29. Clay pigeons for target practice. 30. Greeting card
(bind two together at one end). 31. Halloween treat (give them away all
night long). 32. Bullet proof vest (arrange together in triple
thickness). 33. Firewood. 34. Bird house. 35. Paper weights. 36. Pen
holders (make a box without a top). 37. Post it-notes holder. 38.
Refrigerator magnet (glue a magnet to the back). 39. A very sturdy base
for putting the motorcycle sidestand on when parkingon soft surfaces.
40. Keep 'em in the trunk for extra traction in the snow. 41. Solar
Eclipse Glasses (open door and look through disk at the
sun/moon-actually works). 42. Placing one in each back pocket helps
children who get paddled by thecoach. This spreads the force to a wider
area. 43. Make an AOL disk & pasta casserole. 44. Incense burners (put
stick in hole of disk hub and light the incense. 45. Bug Shield (glue a
bunch to the front of your car's hood). 46. Put them on car windshields
at the mall (along with this list). <--  >=)47. Melt the plastic of the
disks into a giant sculpture. 48. Hand them out as party favors. 49.
Hidden/spare key holder (crack open 1 side, insert key and then
placenear door. Completely safe...who would want an AOL disk?) 50.
Vertical blinds. 51. Be an AOL diskette surgeon and disect a diskette.
52. Bench press weights (I can press 120). 53. Grind 'em up and
refertilize the front lawn. 54. The new "Domino's stuffed-crust pizza"
filling. 55. Tell the kids to leave warm milk & AOL disks for Santa. 56.
Brake shoes. 57. House insulation. 58. Recycle them for the scrap metal.
59. Kitchen tile for Bill Gates' new mansion in Seatle (walk all over
thecompetition) 60. Hockey Puck. <--  >=)61. Add water and special plant
life to make a Chia-Disk. 62. Noise maker for your bike spokes (why
damage your valuable baseballcards). 63. Put one on a leash and drag it
along as you walk...makes the perfect pet.64. Poker chips. <--  >=)65.
Baseball practice (throw them up in the air and hit them with the bat).
66. Keychain (Put a key ring through one of the writeprotect holes and
you'vegot a snappy executive bathroom keychain for the office). 67. Mail
to 10 friends-start an AOL chain-letter (add a disk with each link).68.
Earmuffs (glue some fur on one side, then attach a U-shaped piece of
bentcoathanger to both disks). 69. Grind them up to make fake snow. 70.
Earrings (put loop into write-protect hole). 71. Dental floss (use
actual disk). 72. Use them for zipper pulls (instead of ski lift
tickets). 73. When your collection of disks reaches 52, use them for a
deck of cards. 74. Use them to fill potholes. 75. Hood ornament. 76.
Snow blower replacement blades. 77. Put them in your shirt pocket to
make you look smart. 78. Make two stacks of 10 and use them as heels for
platform shoes. 79. Rubic's cube case (make into box). 80. Shipping
material (keeps your photos from being bent in the mail). 81. Protect
your table from burns caused by hot pots and pans. 82. Snack trays
(great for holding hors d'oeuvres at parties). 83. Give them as stocking
stuffers to all those people who piss you off. <--  >=)84. Fly paper
(use actual disk and put string through middle, hang 2" apartand apply
honey to disks). 85. Pocket protector (gee Gilbert I really like your
new pocket protector-thanks Lewis). 86. They make a *dandy* addition to
a #$*+&% neighbor's back yard. Betteryet, get them to actually install
it on their computer. 87. Use them as elbow and knee pads. 88. Wax
scraper for snowboards. 89. Use them to decorate your aquarium and
create Computer City under water. 90. Tape a few together and use them
as a mouse pad. 91. Collect a large mass and detonate a supernova. 92. A
wind clacker (similar to a wind chime). 93. Soap dish (remove metal to
prevent rusting). 94. Row markers for your vegetable garden. (carrots,
beans, peas....) 95. Makes the perfect dance floor for your ant colony.
96. Bread roller (use actual disks and put rod through center-use about
100).97. Hot glue gun resting/protecting pad. 98. Baby mobile. 99. Fence

> Tim (knucklehead)

Commercialization IS inevitable.
Now
The question is who will be in control and who will be profiting
from this unfolding. Will the rave scene follow the model of The
Grateful Dead and keep the expansion, and subsequent exploitation
of the music, culture, image under it's own control?

or will it go the way of Hip-hop and let the record companies pimp it.

Precedence: bulk



>
> Being a raver and being a parent - would people who are in that
>position please clue us in on your experience?
>
> Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com
> 
>PS - I've never worn silvery pants or danced with a stuffed toy (yet). 
>



Being a parent both limits and expands one as a raver. 

The children come first. I try to keep my raving from detracting from their
care. I go home afterward. 

My after-rave glow is always so rewarding in their company.  In the Summer,
a day at the pool is a perfect capper.

Some of my favorite raves are those my children went to: Tribal Future,
Harmony 3 yr., outdoors in daylight.  Kids know how to play!  They love glow
sticks and lasars and hot springs and stickers and glitter and stuffed
animals.  And so do their grown up companions at a rave!  it's a great
equalizer.  

Ruth and Darrell love knowing what I'm up to.  Until this summer raves were
very mysterious.  Now they know and appreciate what it's about.  Great quote
on leaving our last rave as a family "we want to come back and bring our
friends."  Looks like they *got it*!

 


>

On Thu, 19 Dec 1996, DJ ASB (CMG Records) =?iso-8859-1?Q?Ay=99?= wrote:

> A rule of nature prevails.  Magazines tend to hype labels that buy ads. 
> DJ's tend to play the labels who send lots of freebees and extra
> records.  The farther one works up the chain to the big bucks and big
> record labels the shmoozing is like some kind of EST program.

	I am not on any mailing lists for records so I don't know 
anything about labels who send freebies, but as most djs I know, I buy 
the records that sound good in the headphones that are in the bins or 
that some friends over in the UK have told me sound really good though 
the headphones in the stores (ie, they have listened to them). If a label 
were to send me extra records and those extra records were good, I would 
play them. Most of what I consider good is not coming from people who are 
trying to "promote" their labels by giving away free records. Is it a 
label's fault if djs cannot make up their own mind on what they want to 
play? And how much good techno is coming out on the "big" labels? How are 
big labels different from small labels (how much you have to "scmooze" to 
get freebies? Distribution?). I have a hard time getting vinyl because I 
am the only one who seems to want it (that is what I am told when I walk 
in and ask for something a little harder than what I have found ;) )... 
Anyway, if the big labels start pushing into the little record stores, 
then I will make a fuss, but right now, big labels are just silly and if 
a group is silly enough to sign on to some contract for x albums in y 
years, then that group has decided their fate.
	If djs want to play freebies that are shitty, or they just don't
know what they like to play, then those djs might want to start playing
weddings or big events. If people who put parties on ask a dj who plays
freebies from bigger labels to play at their party, then those people have
made a decision.If you start treating people like they can figure out 
what they want to do, they might just start making their own decisions, 
right? The mainstream leads people allow nicely, do you want to follow 
ait or find your own thing?

dave

On Fri, 20 Dec 1996, Sub Commander Lycos wrote:

> knucklehead wrote:
> > 
> > >FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
> > >December 20, 1996
> > >
> > >"Location To Be Announced Rave Design Exhibit to Tour USA"
> > >
> >  <big snipage>
> > 
> > Is this a good thing or a bad thing. Sound to me like a Commercialization
> > thing to me, I don't know.
> > 
> > What are all your opinions on this?
> > 
> > Tim (knucklehead)
> 
> Commercialization IS inevitable.
> Now
> The question is who will be in control and who will be profiting
> from this unfolding. Will the rave scene follow the model of The
> Grateful Dead and keep the expansion, and subsequent exploitation
> of the music, culture, image under it's own control?
> 
> or will it go the way of Hip-hop and let the record companies pimp it.

It will be the latter. Their is entirely too much money to be made for
the record companies not to take advantage of it. There is entirely too 
much money to be made by greedy promoters for them not to take
advantage of it. The Dead scene has a very specific market. If you are
"in" the scene, you generally like the Dead. The rave market on the other
hand has a much broader base of potential revenue as it can be
mass-marketed and mass-produced in many different ways, with many
different bands, and events. 

                                    Black Adder

Subject: Re: more virus bullshit
Cc: "Geoff White" <geoffw@cybertribe.com>, blkadder@value.net,
        "Dave Quezada" <quezadad@ul.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Once again, I have to protest Niels including NT with DOS and Windows.
NT is *not* DOS or Windows.  It is a different operating system, based
in large measure on the architectural concepts of VMS.  It is a threaded,
message-passing, protected-kernel, modular-subsystem operating system,
in other words, a *real* OS.  You can quarrel with some of the things
that have been done with it (the security model is weak, for example),
but it is *not* like the other Microsoft operating environments.

phred

couldn't just pop on to someone's land because too many idiots would turn 
up who would cause trouble, get too fucked, or take a peaceful concert 
and turn it into a violent troubled land, so were they throwing 
"underground" dead parties like the old acid tests, or had they become 
another band, playing huge gigs to buy "beautiful" homes in desirable 
areas?). People who go out to raves still have a certain level of 
awareness in some parts of the world, I would hope we do not lose that, 
but maybe that is eneviable as well?

Careful Niels, Phred does NT consulting. ;-)

NT is in a different category that DOS and Windows, yes. I still find it
severly lacking in many areas, including security, performance vs. price,
and remote management capabilites. I find none of these lacking in many of
the various Unices around. Arguably the only thing lacking on a UNIX
system is really slick GUI's and a lot of commercial packages.

I will agree with Niels, though, that NT 4 has some problems (though
I'd say they are sporadic).  The biggest issue on the Usenet newsgroups
I've been monitoring is the difficulty in getting it to work with
audio cards and scanners.  

Anyway, remembering that there are plenty of people who would love to
have our misery dealing with all these badhorriblebroken operating
systems, I'd like to suggest we lay off the OS Wars and get back to
things of more direct concern to the list.

As for viruses, which started all this, my recomendations are: (1) don't
ignore; (2) don't overreact; (3) stay informed.

phred

Received: from [157.22.229.127] by niles.com
 with SMTP (Apple Internet Mail Server 1.1b2d4); Fri, 20 Dec 1996 13:00:34 -0800
Message-Id: <v0213050aaee0adad20ae@[157.22.229.127]>
Mime-Version: 1.0

Date: Fri, 20 Dec 1996 13:01:21 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: peter@niles.com (Customer Service)
Subject: Most people of my social class...
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

...consider it most alarming that while I am a conductor of classical
symphonies during the week, I frequent these so-called "Techno-Rave
Concerts" on the weekends.  But I find electronic music most extraordinary
and not dissimilar in mathematical structure, to the works of Beethoven and
Mozart.

Some of my most recent symphonies have been plagued by a rash of ill
fortune.  The lesser of these incidents is that I have been misplacing the
sheets of the score, so that, when I turn a particular page in mid-concert,
I discover that the next leaf is missing.  This has led to much
embarrassment for me and for the San Francisco Junior Symphony.

The more disturbing of my recent misfortunes involves the addition of two
young hoodlums to the bass section.  This pair of neandrathals, who call
themselves Slider and Duke, are the most uncivilised half-wits I have ever
had the misfortune to publicly perform with.

By the grace of genetics and thoughtful breeding I am a patient man, but
the shenanigans of these two rapscallions has left me in a bind.
Undoubtedly they prepare for our concerts not with the usual musical
exercises, but more likely by smoking dangerous cocktails of LSD and
hallucinagenic toadstools.  This theory is unproven, I admit, but it
provides the only logical explanation for their incoherent rantings and
bourgeousie behaviour.

Had the choice been mine, I would have expelled these genetically malfunct
mavericks at my inception, but as I am only a junior conductor, the matter
is beyond my power.  Studying music at Berkelee, I was trained to be
patient while conducting an orchestra, but I fear that the boorish
blitherings of my newest pupils has pushed my nervous system to its limits,
causing me to lie in bed at night trembling with fits of sleeplessness.

I originally met Slider and Duke at a Techno-Rave Concert called Harmony,
and was initially pleased with their friendliness and vivacity.  I learned
that they both played the bass, and eagerly encouraged them to join the
symphony.  It wasn't until later that I considered that  their friendliness
during our first meeting was probably inspired by hallucinations from
sniffing rocket fuel or marihuana dust, or a dangerous combination of the
two.

Just last week the orchestra was scheduled to perform its most important
concert to date.  Critics from the Post and the Times would be there, and
if the reviews were in my favour, I would be selected for the London
Symphony Orchestra.

The night before the performance, dear Mother Fidget, at my request, came
up with a plan to arrange the musical score so that it wouldn't become
disorganised as it has in previous concerts.  She divided the score into
the 9 sections that the symphony was to play, and tied a piece of string
around each section, so that as one section ended and the next began, I
could simply untie the string from the pages, and continue without pause.

As for Slider and Duke, they appeared at the concert hall in remarkable
condition--rested, clean and well-groomed.  The first 8 sections were
impeccable; the entire orchestra was in tune and on the beat.  I should
interject here that there is a period at the beginning of the 9th section
in which Slider and Duke are scheduled to step off-stage during a lull and
the music, and return to their instruments for the grand finale.

The first part of the 9th section went smoothly, until I noticed that
Slider and Duke, instead of standing patiently off stage, were carousing in
the lounge across the hall, drinking  glasses of spirits and swallowing
large quantites of narcotics from a pill jar.

I began trembling in horror, unable to stablise the hand that guided the
orchestra.  As the grande finale neared, Slider and Duke emerged from the
lounge and swaggered back onstage, giggling amongst themselves, shuffling
their feet like peasants, and tripping over instruments.

>From behind, I heard horrified gasps from the audience.  Surely, my career
would be ruined because of these two bourgeousie buffoons. With fidgeting
fingers,I tried to remove the string that dear Mother had so craftily tied
to the score, but the knot stayed fast!

As a man of cultured upbringing, I am not the sort to sweat, even under the
most rigourous activities, but I was chagrined to feel perspiration beading
on my brow as I envisioned my own ruin.

Dear friends, I beg you to imagine the pressure I was under:  it was the
bottom of the ninth, the score was tied, and the basses were loaded.

> 
> OK, I am ignorant in this field.  Would somebody explain to me what it
> means when
> 	DJ blah is spinning vs. DJ blah2

It is just an expression.  The thought behind it is that if the 2 DJs
are in "competition", then they will both spin extra good.

Also see "2x4", where you've got 2 djs mixing in and out of each
other's tracks.

-troy

[ to sfraves ]
Recently, *B* 
> OK, I am ignorant in this field.  Would somebody explain to me what it
> means when
> 	DJ blah is spinning vs. DJ blah2
> 
> How does it work?  Why is it vs. rather than something else.

Let me take a few semi-informed guesses here:

 If you go to some stores that sell music on vinyl, you may find some
videotapes for sale of actual DJ contests! Each DJ gets to show off
their fancy scratching and mixing skills and taste in music. In this
case, the "vs." really stands for a competative situation between one 
or more DJs.

 I think , at raves and some other events, the term "vs." is kept,
but more in a nostalgic or satirical sense, as the DJs are more 
into "team mixing" then a real competition. 
 
> P.S. thanks in advance :)
> P.P.S. it's all F-8's fault :P, because they announced their new Mars vs.
> MYSTR-E tape, and I am planning to buy it, but also want to understand what

> Each DJ dons him/herself in vinyl armour.  The can only use 12in's for
> shields and parts of the MK II for weapons.  The pound each other until
> only one is left standing....

an alternate method: each dj is given a dose of a highly toxic mutogenic
psychedelic plastered on a rave biscuit*, which they must lick clean
without using their hands.  normally, one dj is transmogrified into
godzilla, while the other takes the role of mothra.  the titans battle it
out in a post-industrial urban nightscape under the glare of glo-stix.
videotaped footage can be sold to hard copy.
matt.

*recipe for rave biscuit: take a scratched-up 12" vinyl, an insane dose
of drugs, mix well and <bake> at 200 degrees for eight to ten hours.

Following up on Dave Bayer's response to Sub Commander Lycos regarding the
Grateful Dead:

>On Fri, 20 Dec 1996, Sub Commander Lycos wrote:
>
>> Commercialization IS inevitable.
>> Now
>> The question is who will be in control and who will be profiting
>> from this unfolding. Will the rave scene follow the model of The
>> Grateful Dead and keep the expansion, and subsequent exploitation
>> of the music, culture, image under it's own control?
>>
>> or will it go the way of Hip-hop and let the record companies pimp it.

>        The Grateful Dead kept its expansion and subsequent exploitation
>under control? Maybe their own exploitation but the exploitation of those
>people whom they preformed for? I hope the rave scence does not follow
>the model of the dead, or we are doomed to big commerical raves with big
>djs that can spinning fucking amazingly, or, hmmm, seems to the
>commerical megaraves in Germany. Gone will be the free festivals (how
>many free shows did the dead do? How many low cost shows? How many fields
>in the last 15 years did they rent out to have people come to? Ok, they
>couldn't just pop on to someone's land because too many idiots would turn
>up who would cause trouble, get too fucked, or take a peaceful concert
>and turn it into a violent troubled land, so were they throwing
>"underground" dead parties like the old acid tests, or had they become
>another band, playing huge gigs to buy "beautiful" homes in desirable
>areas?). People who go out to raves still have a certain level of
>awareness in some parts of the world, I would hope we do not lose that,
>but maybe that is eneviable as well?

The Dead crossed over inevitably into Massive Land, and for that part of
the U.S. rave scene that will take on the characteristics of massives, they
should learn from the lessons of the Dead on how to deal with the problems
of putting on large, loud gatherings for thousands of people, many of whom
might be interested in breaking the law.  I felt a lot more free at an
Oakland Coliseum Dead Show than at a HomeBase rave 200 yards away.  What
I've always appreciated about the underground rave scene is the relative
freedom afforded, at least in part, by the lack of authorities (official
security or police); massives and Dead Shows take on a different character
because of the presence of people in uniform, although we Deadheads in the
Bay Area were spoiled because the authorities basically winked at the
lawbreaking & drug use.  This freedom is also represented by the relative
democracy of the rave scene, without the separation of "artist" and
"audience" (which couldn't be done as much by the Dead, although Deadheads
were pretty active participants in the process).

Within the Dead community the wealth of the band in their later years was a
big point of controversy.  Given that for their last ten years they played
an average of about 80 shows a year for 2.5 million people, employed a lot
of their own people and paid them well (plus medical, pension), kept ticket
prices relatively reasonable compared to other acts of their size, and
played numerous benefit shows for some important, underfunded causes, I
didn't begrudge them their relative wealth much.  More of an issue for me
was the fact that their own personal drug use made it difficult for them to
criticize the DEA's targeting of Deadheads, and that they didn't do enough
at the end to help Deadheads take responsibility for the scene (i.e., just
lack of communication and enough help for self-policing & crowd control).

Yes, the Dead became massive, but they became massive doing what they
wanted to artistically.  Could they have stayed more UG?  Perhaps, but by
the end perhaps it was too late given how much they were dependent on the
scene they created.  The individual members of the band had their niches,
however -- Jerry Garcia Band shows at the Warfield theater during the 90's
were very low-key, mellow, family affairs, even though at $21 a show and
with a capacity of 2500 they would be classified as "massive" raves.

As for "free festivals," the Dead played a lot more free shows in their
youth than there are free raves today, just taking their equipment into GG
Park, the panhandle or Haight Street itself and playing.  With the
exception of Sunsets, how many public & free events have there been in the
last year here?  A handful, because they are difficult to pull off and
"nothing comes for free."  Obviously there are extremely generous people in
the scene who enable free or inexpensive events to go off through their
work and donation of equipment & energy sources. There are also people who
criticize $15 Gateway & Harmony parties despite the fact that the people
who put those parties on have donated so much to our scene and have to pay
for spaces, equipment, etc.

To get back to Sub-Commander Lycos's original point -- Commercialization is
inevitable, but not commercialization of OUR Underground.  What we need to
do is protect the UG as much possible so that the problems caused by a
larger scene are kept away.  But to the extent that there will be
semi-public massives where certain facets of the UG poke their heads
through -- such as the Gathering tomorrow -- let's hope that promoters can
do as well as the Dead did.

As for commercialization of the music, well, just let the audience tape
everything ;)

leftjab

the Grateful Dead was 5 guys doing things their own way.

The rave scene is millions of people doing things their own way.

Only 5 guys could play a Dead show.

Anyone can throw a rave.

Raves *are* commercialized.  See Planet New Year flyers, MC'd by Live 105's
very own Web Fingers as an example.

But there are also millions of other folks who would never  invite Alex
Bennett to their parties. That's what's so beautiful about our scene.  No
one owns the music.  We can do whatever we want with it.  We can throw
monsterraves or teeny tiny rosey-faced candyraves.  It's a free world in
the underground.  Nothing wrong with commercialism, nothing wrong with
microraves.

Techno music kicks ass.  No wonder everybody wants to be involved!  It has
the potential to open us up to the budding spiritual flowers that we were
before we dropped out of the womb into this stinkin' latrine!

It can HEAL US!

I say, the more people raving, the better off the world will be.

But I gotta admit, I'd rather be at a Harmony party.

-b))m

On Fri, 20 Dec 1996, Troy Sheets wrote:

> > 
> > OK, I am ignorant in this field.  Would somebody explain to me what it
> > means when
> > 	DJ blah is spinning vs. DJ blah2
> 
> It is just an expression.  The thought behind it is that if the 2 DJs
> are in "competition", then they will both spin extra good.
> 
> Also see "2x4", where you've got 2 djs mixing in and out of each
> other's tracks.

	It also could mean that they are tagteaming (one spins a couple 
records then the next spins a couple, then the first spins a couple, and 
so on and so forth)....

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Dec 20 16:41:30 1996

Precedence: bulk

Props:  Huge Waste of Bandwidth Follows, Delete at Will

Well a few people asked my qualifications for shooting my mouth off and
making a fool of myself (which is one definition for raving...as in
"he's a raving lunatic") so I'd better qualify my shoot from the hip
style.

I come from the Hip Hop dance world, and unfortunately being from the
old skool we wern't all huggy, kissy, feely in our actions or gigs.  

Before that I had a brief flirt with punk rock that lasted about as long
as the Sex Pistols, but which shaped my attitudes about the Biz. 
Thirdly I'm an LA boy (born in Boston thank God!) so my vision of the
music industry is a little jaded via Hollywood Pap.

In the Hip Hop world it's more competitive, obviously there are lots of
negative vibes because it comes from the streets where it's survival of
the hardest.  At a gig if you MC or DJ and you ain't cutting it you will
be told or the next boaster will tear you to shreds.  They have their
own squabbles now i.e. East coast vs West coast, Gangsta vs B Boy,
misogamy vs consciousness, etc.

When I used to go to gigs in downtown LA you hoped your car wouldn't be
stolen or you wouldn't get mugged afterwards.  There was no record
labels, no media, and hardly any white people at these underground
events.

On another level I hit all the dope LA clubs (1980-1987) and you could
hear a variety of dance music that was not all that different from
today's music (OK the BPM's are faster)

In music production I was lucky (or cursed, as the case may be) to work
with the following people:

Norman Whitfield (Temptations, Motown, WB. "Heard it Through the
Grapevine")
Lanise Hughes (Rick James Stone City Band, drummer on 'Superfreak')
Duke Jobe (Rose Royce, bass player)
Lenny Kravitz (Virgin)
Tony Lemans (Paisley Park,WB)
Jerry "ZO" Mosely (Motown, Fairlight CMI, Billy Ocean, Boy George)
Stephan Frank (George Clinton, Atlantic Records, 4 On the Floor)

I had some independent releases in 1984 that were played on Agent Ava's
college show in LA (KXLU), made it to some European shows, and were
reviewed in Op (now Option), Fortnightly College Radio Report, and
others, and I was distributed by Systematic Record Distribution formerly
in Berkely (where's my last check!#%*^@@)

My first release "Godzilla Red Dragon Punk Funk"  (1984) had several
songs including punk jazz, a house/disco tune "P is for Party", and a
punkish version of Gloria.

I later (84-85) did a band project (Blackbird Crew) with Lanise Hughes
and Duke Jobe,  two of the baddest funk rythym sections of the decade. 
I played guitar synthesizer and I guess the closest description of what
I was doing was trying to be the Bootsy of guitar--making bleeps, farts,
underwater sounds, and scratching noises while they laid down funk
grooves from Hell (down.)

The cuts played on LA college radio (KXLU) in 1984 were a jam with the
above people "Bubble Pop" which was a slap/pop bass guitar synthesizer
line (yes more farty, underwater sounds) against straight ahead live
drums and manic Hendrix style guitar and my Fairlight sampler opus
"Missle Man" which took a breakdance style rythym track originally made
for some weightlifting twin brothers' "rap" called Brute Strength.  I
had "ZO" Mosely reverse the 2" tape and threw down two reverse guitar
solos, adding a vocal that went like this:

Once I had a vision
That I was the atoms in a nuclear warhead
And I was jazzed because
I was doing what I was made for
Flying to some distant country

And I was thinking to myself
Yeah cool I'm gonna explode
Expanding in a big flash of light
Vaporizing everything I see

And I was flying
Daydreaming to myself
Meanwhile back at mission control
Calm voices marked my destination

Got to fly so fast
Got to expand
You know it's all in your mind baby...

(c) 1984 A.S. Bryson

As I said in another post I was following the E Coast school
(Grandmaster Flash, Newcleus, Afrika Bambaataa, etc)  and the offshoots
drifting into punk/disco like Blondie, etc.

Of course ALL the dance clubs/LA radio were playing Kraftwerk, Egyptian
Lover, Rockit, etc. so pumping dance music through large club sound
systems was no novelty.

Almost any dance you went to had at least a few break dancers/pop
lockers (I was into the latter)  while most people leaned towards the
New Wave/Gothic look/music  (Devo, KROQ, etc.)

Must give props to the Venice Beach skater/dancer street jams--where you
could hear tunes played nowhere else (even for LA) and while the music
played there was little vibes no matter race, genre, etc.

Working with the Fairlight in about '84 (the first practical
sampler/sequencer) opened this guitar player to the world of sampling,
computers, and digital audio, and by '86 I had an Ensoniq Mirage sampler
and  a portable Commodore 64 (the lunchbox style) for MIDI seguencing,
along with a DX drum machine and MIDI Bass.

I put together a project studio with an 8 track Tascam and 20 input
M-520 mixer.  At that point ('86) I got a gig as Lenny Kravitz's (he
wasn't signed then) loft studio engineer handling the pre-production for
Tony Lemans on his Paisley Park debut.  My mixes were going to Prince
every day and I thought it was my "big break" but a fight with the
artist's manager left me unpaid for 10 weeks work except for a $100
check from Warner Bros (FU*&^%$4*## Prince & Paisley Park!)  I still
have a dope 8 track of Lenny playing  Sly Stone's "Thank You" on guitar
& bass with Lemans singing and another "demo" with Prince on
guitar--what a bunch of talented wankers--so I guess I own part of the
copyright as a producer's lien.

I was fairly close to the Motown/Warner Brothers-- Lost Angeles funk/R&B
crowd and they had little or no interest in Hip Hop, House, or Electo
styles at the time, preferring "sophisticated" dance music like Donna
Summer, Bee Gees etc. and the upscale disco scene a la "Saturday Night
Fever" complete with polyester suits and gold coke spoons.

In '86 Jeffery Conners, a hot black bass player who hung with Fishbone
and Miles Davis' bandmembers, was programming jacking house beats into
my DX and introducing me to this East Coast style.

Jerry "ZO" Mosely was leaving for England where he was working with
Billy Ocean and Boy George and yapping about the big dance music scene
over there.  Through 86-92 I had my own project studio and engineered
all kinds of music for my clients--Country, Ranchero, Hip Hop, Metal,
Dance, etc.

What I'm seeing as I get feedback from other scene scribes is that one's
views on the history of modern dance music are colored by your
background--if you were in Hip Hop then it seems like that style.  If
you were in the Gay underground House/Disco crowd then it seems to have
evolved from there, Reggae to dancehall to jungle etc. etc.

I think that the music is better than ever, there are dozens of sub
genres that are all valid and interesting, but there are a lot of
newjacks who don't know where the music came from and they think they
just invented a whole new movement whereas if you've been with dance
music all along you see the same kind of repackaging as when Led
Zeppelin released some old blues jams they claimed to have written--it
goes on all the time in the music biz.

As a musician, producer, programmer, recording engineer & DJ who is ear
trained (I don't read music) I tend to think that all this dance music
is just a variant of Hip Hop/Electro/Disco which if you follow the
evolution you see there are no great leaps of creativity that
distinguish a new art form--but that there are new sub genres in the
same style.  This is my personal opinion and nobody has to accept it.,
just as the term Rock Music covers everything from Little Richard to
Beck for most people.  

Having made a career in the music biz I have a tendency to not like what
comes from music critics--there are very few with any talent at that
game which has mostly evolved as a PR tool for the labels and as a means
to sell magazines and ads.  Then again I have no great love for the
incestuous Music Biz, i.e. big labels picking up on genres 5-10 years
after the independents kept the scene alive.

My other peeve is people who are experts on one or two genres and
discount all the other sub genres.  Even if you hate something (say
Country or Classical, I used to...) why slang it to the public or tell
its followers they are idiots?  You only expose yourself as a narrow
minded bigot with a low IQ, but the people who do this the most are the
newjacks who got into this music in the last 5 years or so.

I kind of saw the whole loop again as ex-Ravers dogged that scene as
"already over" and now people act like you are totally square and un-hip
if you like that.  First it was maybe a few genres--Techno, Acid, House,
etc. but now some idiot will say you are nowhere if you like/don't like
(____________) fill in blank.

Overall I think the SF scene is great, there are great bands, DJ's,
XLR8R, obviously great web resources (like this list) of course the
place is filled with incredible artists of all types.  It's nice to see
a resurgence of unity fostered by the progressive people of this highly
evolved area--which might be closer to the spirit of late 80's European
raves than anywhere in the US!!!

I hope the people into Unity will predominate, but I suppose there is
also a place for the competitive hip hop types as that is the core of
that music that keeps it fresh while it becomes watered down by
commercialism.  You have to be open to criticism and controversy to
evolve and grow also.

OK I hate long music rants too so hopefully this is the last--

Peace Out.

DJ ASB (Arthur Bryson)

I guess you picked up it was a parody of the anti-drug hysteria creeping
on the list.  The war on drugs did it's program on the next generation
but it's ironic because the first ravers (whether high or not) were
about as anarchic and crazed as any group from cubists to punk.

Should we hold drug users in contempt like they are dirty or have a
plague?  
Should we be afraid to talk about drugs and that they are common at
raves?  The other side is already talking about it.  Maybe drug users
can be the new "queers" or "niggers" for straight society.

Drugs, police, govt repression are large factors in the European scene
and the same repression will grow here from the same ignorance.

If I've learned anything from being on both sides at times--

Some assholes are straight
Some assholes use drugs
Thank heaven for the nice people in the world!

Yeah I'm getting my mixes together for a release and I might just drop
one this month (well at least they were made in '96) but it's along the
lines of <this may be a bite off another's title> 'If 1996 Turned Out to
be 1969'

Peace Out
DJ ASB

On Fri, 20 Dec 1996 blkadder@value.net wrote:

> It will be the latter. Their is entirely too much money to be made for
> the record companies not to take advantage of it. There is entirely too 
> much money to be made by greedy promoters for them not to take
> advantage of it. The Dead scene has a very specific market. If you are
> "in" the scene, you generally like the Dead. The rave market on the other
> hand has a much broader base of potential revenue as it can be
> mass-marketed and mass-produced in many different ways, with many
> different bands, and events. 

	Which part will be cut up and sold off by "promoter" pimps? No 
labels used to exist that would take techno, so basement musicians made a 
tape, sent to the pressers and then off to the distributors you can find. 
Well, people are still doing this kind of thing even though labels like 
like Virgin and Island and BMI are starting to sign on a few artists. 
There are labels like EyeQ and deconstruction that are big in the techno 
world, but as far as I know, they aren't evil crank out three LPs every 
quarter type of labels... People still form their own labels to get their 
music out and as long as you can get some type of word out some how, some 
disturbtor WILL pick up your vinyl. As long as techno is sold in big 
crates that you have to sort through and can hear it BEFORE you buy it, 
no big labels will be able to control what you hear, because there will 
always be obsecure distributors (like Jack Acid) who gets stuff that few 
people want to buy, but some people want to hear nonetheless...
	Stores like Tower and Virgin with their nice and easy displays 
and classifications and big posters telling you want the latest great 
albums are cater to one type of crowd. Back ally vinyl shops with 
listening stations cater to another... You don't like vinyl? That could 
be a problem if you don't have the cash for a CD burner... Of course 
there are problems with this, maybe get the distribution company a call 
to get the artists phone and then try and setup a way to get it pressed 
to a CD... I think that people who are open to this knid of thing will 
find it - just remember that those artists going through BMI are probably 
getting bigger offers than the basement artists who press the vinyl to 
have it heard...

dave

Room for rent in large San Carlos home.

Looking for cool, mellow, creative types to share a 3 bed/2 bath house with
two others in San Carlos, which is about 5 minutes from both 280 and 101.

I am a software engineer at Apple Computer, and a budding DJ. I used to do
radio shows on KFJC where I would spin an ambeint mix, and did live events.
I also play drums and guitar occaisonally, and would be wanting to have
parties once in a while (not too often; I'm no party animal or anything).
If there is enough interest, I may work on putting wiring in for a shared
Internet connection. Obviously, I would only do this if the costs were
split by everyone.

I would prefer professionals in the computer/technical fields of any
gender, race, age, etc who are easy-going and mellow. However, I would like
people who also are into alternative/experimental music: ambient/ techno/
dub/ psychedelia/ whatever. Also, anyone with a a sampler or a pair of
Technics SL-1200's gets special brownie points!!

No flakes or drug abusers!! If you fit in this category, I do not want you.

But the bottom-line is I am looking for anyone who is responsible and easy
to get along with.

Available now. Hurry!

Rent will be $675/month + security deposit.
Contact Doug at 408-974-5913 or 408-972-9177. Or reply to this email.

I believe the person who passed away in the abbreviation E.S.W.H. was Will
Higgs. I produced an event with Will in Dec. '92. Will was a very good person
who enjoyed life to the fullest. A month before our event, Will was hired by
a motorcycle magazine as a journalist. He loved to write and he loved to
ride. Unfortunately, at (I believe 23 years old) he was killed in L.A. I
believe it was raining and he spilled his motorcycle in an intersection. It
was not the fall that killed him, but the vehicle that hit him after the fall
at 40+ mph. Before Will died, He wrote something that we printed on the back
of the event's t-shirts. It reads as follows:

House music knows no boundaries, no prejudices.
It transcends the territorial lines that divide the planet.
People of every size, shape and color continually join together
to share this music and the joy of sharing.
It is quite possible this music may someday unite the world.
Join us as we celebrate with music and musicians from around
the globe and show the world the potential of people and music.

-Will Higgs, Global Rhythm Festival, December 19, 1992

R.I.P. 1993

:) MODA

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Dec 20 18:41:53 1996

On Fri, 20 Dec 1996, leftjab wrote:

> The Dead crossed over inevitably into Massive Land, and for that part of
> the U.S. rave scene that will take on the characteristics of massives, they
> should learn from the lessons of the Dead on how to deal with the problems
> of putting on large, loud gatherings for thousands of people, many of whom
> might be interested in breaking the law. 

	Go to a festival in Europe, thousands and thousands of people at 
a free party put on by a bunch of nutters. The ones I have been to had no 
cops, just a bunch of traveller types and students out in the woods. 

> Within the Dead community the wealth of the band in their later years was a
> big point of controversy.  Given that for their last ten years they played
> an average of about 80 shows a year for 2.5 million people, employed a lot
> of their own people and paid them well (plus medical, pension), kept ticket
> prices relatively reasonable compared to other acts of their size, and
> played numerous benefit shows for some important, underfunded causes, I
> didn't begrudge them their relative wealth much.

	I see a band that was making literally millions off of album 
sales, millions off of merchandizing, money off of books and side projects, 
and still charging $20+ for their shows (am I wrong here). I do not 
begrudge the band for doing that. I do however think that a number of 
people put the dead on pedestal as the people who could save the 
Universe. It was those people who I thought lost whatever the dead and 
its community may have had going (and may still have going in small 
underground type places). 

> As for "free festivals," the Dead played a lot more free shows in their
> youth than there are free raves today, just taking their equipment into GG
> Park, the panhandle or Haight Street itself and playing.  With the
> exception of Sunsets, how many public & free events have there been in the
> last year here?  A handful, because they are difficult to pull off and
> "nothing comes for free." 

	Here it is difficult to pull these off, I agree. What is more difficult is 
getting people to come out in the middle of rainy Feb to full moons. It 
is difficult to get people to realize that if they make a scence on the 
way to a rengade party, it will get busted. I know people that have tried 
this and frankly, those were some of the best parties I have ever been 
(one in the rain in back of Travis AFB comes to mind). I don't know if 
the Dead played more free parties than are going on today though. There 
is Sunsets like you said, there have been free full moons going on for the 
last four years or more (put on by different groups, but there has not 
been a break in them for four years as far as I know, except maybe last 
June 1 when everyone I know who was involved went up to tribal future and 
I was in Scotland). There is a free party tonight, there is a free party 
tomorrow night. The dead could do theirs openly because things were 
either a little looser with the law or the people had their shit more 
together back then... 
	I heard about systems such as the Sativa Clan and those people
that are now in Network 23 touring through the continent in the summer
doing totally free festivals, people would house them, and feed them as
they past through, but those people throwing the parties are not coming
out of it with a huge wad of cash, just a bunch of memories and a battered
sound system and friends ALL over the world that will help them out when
they need it... There was one system called desert storm that brought a
new lorry and headed down to I guess Siberia (the one states of former
Czech). Went down and through festis in the middle of a war (they had to
buy the new lorry because their van was all done up in camoflague. In this
country, I know a group that has travelled across the country for AT least
two summers in a row doing FREE festivals, pulling off free parties all
over the country - they got burned in NYC, but they pulled themselves back
together.
	So why don't these happen here? How many people are willing to 
come help move speakers in the pouring rain? How many people will come 
out and keep their wits about them and work together to keep things quiet 
for rengades? How many people will go out into the night when it is 
chilly? How many people will drive more than 45 minutes to get to a 
party? Now you know why they don't happen here....

dave

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Dec 20 19:12:05 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id TAA19293; Fri, 20 Dec 1996 19:12:05 -0800 (PST)
Received: from Zool.AirTouch.COM by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with SMTP id TAA19282; Fri, 20 Dec 1996 19:12:00 -0800 (PST)
Received: from CCMAIL.AIRTOUCH.COM by Zool.AirTouch.COM (SMI-8.6/SMI-SVR4)
	id TAA13117; Fri, 20 Dec 1996 19:11:58 -0800
Received: from ccMail by CCMAIL.AIRTOUCH.COM (SMTPLINK V2.11 PreRelease 4)
	id AA851138053; Fri, 20 Dec 96 19:10:59 PST
Date: Fri, 20 Dec 96 19:10:59 PST
From: "Ciaran OHara" <ciaran.ohara@CCMAIL.AirTouch.COM>
Message-Id: <9611208511.AA851138053@CCMAIL.AIRTOUCH.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Is the word "Rave" obsolete ?
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     
     
     A thought struck me today as I was stuck behind a stuck Muni bus on 
     Market street :
     
     Is it time for a new definition of the scene that this list relates 
     too ? The word "rave" came to prominence during the heady days of acid 
     house circa 1988 (86 ?). To me, the word is synonymous with cheesy 
     compilations, straight-assed marketing execs trying to tap into the 
     "yoof" market and a whole bunch of generic techno by numbers (such as 
     2 unlimited, rednex "cotton eye joe", scooter, etc.., etc..,)
     Would sfdance be a better moniker ?
     
     It seems to me that there has a lot of bandwidth on this list devoted 
     to discussion regarding the state of the scene. i.e.. will MTV 
     trivialize the music, will XlR8R preach electro-dogma now that it has 
     a different format, will gangstas (sic) ruin the vibe, will the 
     underground become commercial, etc.., It seems to me that the word 
     "raver" itself lends itself to compartmentalization. A case in point : 
     I went looking for a full-moon party at candlestick park a few weeks 
     back with a friend of mine. Finally found it at about 8 in the morning 
     and I met someone who I'd seen around before. She mentioned during the 
     conversation that she was "more of a clubber than a raver". 
     
     It is apparent that there are a wider assortment of people on this 
     list than the word "raver" can attempt to describe. There are those 
     that go to clubs, those that go to raves,  there are those that like 
     Jungle, those that like house, hip-hop, trip-hop, gabber techno, 
     detroit techno, euro-techno, goa-trance, funk, not forgetting all 
     producers, dj's and artists that keep pushing the musical boundaries 
     and keeping everything fresh. 
     
     
     Back to my main point : when the mainstream starts to appropriate 
     terms such as "rave" for themselves then it is also time for those 
     that like the music, the scene, etc..., to rename the subclulture 
     themselves. For to me it is all dance culture, meaning that no matter 
     what the color of your skin, family background, sexuality, 
     nationality, gender, religion, marital status or age we are all united 
     by the love of not just partying but also being part of something.
     
     We, the clued-in, the hip, the underground will ALWAYS be able to keep 
     ahead of the tabloid journalists, tv talk shows, the corporation you 
     may work for, members of fraternity houses, network tv. In a nutshell 
     the MAN. 
     
     We all have the power of speech and we can use new words to define the 
     lifestyle that we partake in and no-one need ever know what we're 
     talking about. Except those in the know. 
     So we are all part of the wider "dance culture" and as a minority I'd 
     say we would have considerable political clout.
     
     
     
     Peace,
     
     
     Ciaran, O!
     
     
     P.S. Phew, I just ran a spell check and "Raver" is not in the 
     dictionary. The world hasn't caught up with us yet !

> > "in" the scene, you generally like the Dead. The rave market on the other

> > mass-marketed and mass-produced in many different ways, with many
> > different bands, and events.
