Whatever part needs to pay their bills. I'm sorry, and I don't mean or
desire to start a flame war, but I see some top talent playing shitty,
fucked-up, greed driven parties. People that I like to listen
to. When I have questioned people in the past, I am told that it is "just
a gig." Like it or not, the best and brightest is being sold or selling
themselves, right along with the crappy and commercial, willingly.   


> 	Stores like Tower and Virgin with their nice and easy displays 
> and classifications and big posters telling you want the latest great 
> albums are cater to one type of crowd. Back ally vinyl shops with 
> listening stations cater to another... 

I disagree with part of this. Tower has listening stations, which I
was shocked to see, not having been there in almost a year(albeit select
titles.) Go into Rasputins. See any listening stations? Go into Amoeba(not
Ameba.) See any listening stations? While maybe not "back-alley" they
certainly aren't the big guys. Know what I see in these places? Attitude. 

I totally dig the ability to go into Ameba or F-8 and listen to anything I
want with nice friendly people offering suggestions, but I wouldn't
classify Tower as being in a totally seperate category. Tower has some
damn good releases(dunno about techno in particular but their indie
section is cool) and pretty friendly staff.  


> You don't like vinyl? That could 
> be a problem if you don't have the cash for a CD burner... Of course 

I don't think this holds true any more. I can get a burner for less than
$500. I wouldn't even know where to begin to try to find out how much it
would cost for a vinyl press, or the media itself, but I almost positive
the equipment is more, if not the media as well.

Cleaning up electronic music studio:

Korg Poly 800

-> fully analogue
-> fully MIDI
-> fully programmable
-> polyphonic
-> mine's fully functional

$140 firm.

------------------------------------------------

Yamaha MT1X 4 track cassette recorder with FSK Sync box.

Yamaha multitrack in great shape, recerntly serviced.  4 channel input... each
channel has "sliding" fader, 2 band EQ, LED UV meters, AUX Send level, pan, 
gain.  Monitor mix section with fader and pan on each channel.  Mono
AUX send, stereo return with master AUX OUT and master AUX in.  Sounds
great with DBX noise reduction, integrated SYNC switch for use with...

Yamaha YMC10 MIDI/FSK sync box.  You can use this to sync the multitrack
to a computer or external sequencer.  For example, you first record
a track of timecode, then you sync the sequencer to the timecode to
record the POLY 800 bass line, then rewind the tape and do it again, this
time recording the lead POLY800 line... in perfect sync with the bassline.
In short, this allows you make a real multi-track song with just 1 
synthesizer using tape sync.

Price for both multitrack and sync box: $160 firm.

------------------------------------

Bad news:  it is not worth it to ship these devices, so San Francisco Bay
Area people only for face-to-face transaction.

There's a clothing chain at the big mall in Eureka called RAVE

The east coast crowd disdainfully writes it r*ve

I say we should be like Zero pilots about to scream Kamakazi! as they
descend into Pearl Harbor---RAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAVVVVVVVVVEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE!

Rave attempted to fuse the best notions of the emerging countercultures
and was wildly successful which is why the govt, already prepared since
the 60's anarchy and rebellion, moved about 10 times faster to shut down
raves than they moved on hippy rockers

The best way to beat the commercialization and govt interference is the
underground family parties as is springing up everwhere.  I suppose a
few artists could do the big record label sellout and buy an island
somewhere

Commercialization and a good underground product.  Take the Macintosh. 
If they kept it an underground hacker computer it'd be like the Sinclair
or Commodore.  Now they license it's OS and every big corp is after
them.

Also it seems rave is about jacking pop culture and the media and
feeding it back to the masses using the same subversive, subliminal
techniques as our media masters

Anyway your post rocked shit but I've wondered the same thing--the past
re-invents itself--but I say come out of the closet and give respect to
our teachers, and those jams still rock today!!!

Raver should be good for half a century at least if rock is still
going...

DJ ASB

Well apparently I've  stepped into a domain that might not live up to
it's name because I wrongly assumed that this would be an open forum for
any rave related discussion including rave culture and media.

Though I checked it out for a few days at least, and I've seen a cross
section of things from party reviews to computer OS comparisons, besides
personal messages and even a few odd things that you have to stretch
your mind to connect to rave music, it all seems to fit somehow so it
puzzles me how the content is censored when anyone can just delete  or
bozo filter any maniac they don't like.

While I can imagine there has been huge turf wars here over a myriad of
subjects and the focus is supposed to embrace rave music and events it
would seem logical that rave culture would also be a focus but maybe I'm
just naive.

While my rants have probably gotten me about 5 to 1 favorable responses
apparently I set off the shit detector alarms of the moguls who control
this forum and  have gotten ominous little hints that I'm rocking the
boat (or status quo)

God what a great feeling!

All the talk about bandwidth...do they mean download time or disk
space?  I thought bandwidth wasn't as big an issue nowadays.

So if somebody would be kind enough to forward the FAQ, Boy Scout
Manual, or Robert's Rules of Order I'll try and OBEY but as I said
before I'm kind of dislexic to rules it's a hazard of being mental.

The other option would be to direct this handicapped person to the
nearest liberal rave forum.

Pax  :)

DJ ASB

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Dec 21 00:50:51 1996

Received: from [206.15.69.52] (sf1-ppp80.well.com [206.15.69.80]) by mh1.well.com (8.7.6/8.7.5) with SMTP id AAA28051 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Sat, 21 Dec 1996 00:50:37 -0800 (PST)

Message-Id: <v01510104aee11f6399ca@[206.15.69.52]>
Mime-Version: 1.0

Date: Sat, 21 Dec 1996 02:04:16 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: leftjab@well.com (leftjab)
Subject: Re: festis of yesterday and festis of today
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

First off, I hope this isn't being contentious.  I don't think underground
"raves" will or should be commercialized, and there isn't anything the UG
community needs to learn from the Grateful Dead organization, which was
Dave's original point in responding to Sub-Commander Lycos.  Massives and
commercialized raves, however, are another issue, and so are misconceptions
about the Dead.

[liberal re-quotes from Dave Bayer's post]:

>        Go to a festival in Europe, thousands and thousands of people at
>a free party put on by a bunch of nutters. The ones I have been to had no
>cops, just a bunch of traveller types and students out in the woods.

        In Europe, not here, which has more to do with cultural differences
than organization.  Did you enjoy these events or not?  It sounds like you
did, but don't think they can work here, even though you personally have
worked very hard and successfully in smaller events.  My point is that the
Dead were sometimes able to spread a vibe to arena or stadium size
audiences in the U.S., in a public way with sometimes heavy police presence
and surveillance, while the massive raves in the U.S. don't seem to be able
to do that so well.  On some level it would be great to have a super large
scale rave scene that kept the vibe here, but I don't see it coming.  I
also don't feel the need to convince non-ravers of the value of raving,
either in massives or the UG -- people will seek it and find it for
themselves if they want it.  I do try to bring newbies who are ripe.

>> Within the Dead community the wealth of the band in their later years was a
>> big point of controversy.  Given that for their last ten years they played
>> an average of about 80 shows a year for 2.5 million people, employed a lot
>> of their own people and paid them well (plus medical, pension), kept ticket
>> prices relatively reasonable compared to other acts of their size, and
>> played numerous benefit shows for some important, underfunded causes, I
>> didn't begrudge them their relative wealth much.
>
>        I see a band that was making literally millions off of album
>sales, millions off of merchandizing, money off of books and side projects,
>and still charging $20+ for their shows (am I wrong here).

       Sort of -- they were NOT making millions from albums that hardly
sold well (and which usually sucked in comparison to their live shows) --
really, about 200K copies per album with only a couple of exceptions, and
they usually spent so much time in the studio, and had such shitty
contracts, that they made little if any profit from their albums until In
the Dark in 1987.  Merchandizing was usually bootleg until the 90's.  The
Dead made virtually all their money, and indeed became wealthy, from
touring and touring alone.  They laid off most of the people in the
organization when Jerry died and the endless tour stopped.  Only since
Jerry died has there been a boom in official merchandising, but not even
close to make up for the loss of concert revenue.  I've been to the
Grateful Dead Merchandising warehouse in Novato this year, and it's barely
big enough to hold a small rave.  But yes, the Dead did charge about $30 at
the end for admission, and only a handful of people would get "miracled"
and get free tickets.  The rest of us paid for our experience.

 I do not
>begrudge the band for doing that. I do however think that a number of
>people put the dead on pedestal as the people who could save the
>Universe. It was those people who I thought lost whatever the dead and
>its community may have had going (and may still have going in small
>underground type places).

True enough. Much of it was from the sense of a feeling of deserving what
people "got" from the Dead, and being parasitic towards the band, rather
than giving back to both the Deadhead community and the world as a whole.
It was also a matter of abuse of freedom.  This is a problem in the rave
community as well, and potentially more so because we are more
self-reliant.  This self-reliance, in turn, also leads to greater karmic
rewards in the rave scene when everything clicks.

>> As for "free festivals," the Dead played a lot more free shows in their
>> youth than there are free raves today, just taking their equipment into GG
>> Park, the panhandle or Haight Street itself and playing.  With the
>> exception of Sunsets, how many public & free events have there been in the
>> last year here?  A handful, because they are difficult to pull off and
>> "nothing comes for free."
>
>        Here it is difficult to pull these off, I agree. What is more
>difficult is
>getting people to come out in the middle of rainy Feb to full moons. It
>is difficult to get people to realize that if they make a scence on the
>way to a rengade party, it will get busted. I know people that have tried
>this and frankly, those were some of the best parties I have ever been
>(one in the rain in back of Travis AFB comes to mind). I don't know if
>the Dead played more free parties than are going on today though. There
>is Sunsets like you said, there have been free full moons going on for the
>last four years or more (put on by different groups, but there has not
>been a break in them for four years as far as I know, except maybe last
>June 1 when everyone I know who was involved went up to tribal future and
>I was in Scotland). There is a free party tonight, there is a free party
>tomorrow night. The dead could do theirs openly because things were
>either a little looser with the law or the people had their shit more
>together back then...

        I underestimated the virulence of the full moon scene, but as you
pointed out it is true that the free events today can't often be open.  I
think the Dead could get away with it in '66-'68 because they did guerilla
actions back then, and even a long concert lasting 3-4 hours is shorter
than a rave.  Plus the Dead used to do it in the afternoon, which threatens
the authorities less than overnight events.  And all the audience had to do
was show up -- the Dead hauled the speakers in themselves.

>        So why don't these happen here? How many people are willing to
>come help move speakers in the pouring rain? How many people will come
>out and keep their wits about them and work together to keep things quiet
>for rengades? How many people will go out into the night when it is
>chilly? How many people will drive more than 45 minutes to get to a
>party? Now you know why they don't happen here....

        Maybe we are wimps when it comes to wind & rain, because maybe
there are people who find it harder to enjoy raving in foul weather.  Why
should outdoors in lousy conditions be equated with free UG events and the
spirit of raving?  I saw a bunch of people hauling up the speakers from
Harmony's Panther Beach event in early July after a beautiful summer day :)
But it's hard to complain about a non-publicized party, even if free, not
attracting enough people.

        I don't personally have a problem at all with UGs charging what
they do for indoor events in SF, and all power to people who organize and
work on free parties.  The eternal contradiction is for those people who
believe the world would be a better place if more people raved and want to
get more people involved ideally, yet who prefer small UG events to
massives.  If there are going to be massive raves in the U.S. which succeed
and bring a good vibe despite commercialization, the Dead are not such a
bad role model.

leftjab

Dear Nuncleheads ;)

Just want to say any opinions expressed  under my moniker are solely my
own and do not reflect on DJ Penny Andrews and her show Infinite Space
on KMUD Garberville.

Yes I am doing some live commentaries from the Internet, and I intended
to be available to read any shouts, party listings, or comments from
these lists or my email directed to her audience in N. Calif--as her's
is one of the few Rave shows between SF and Portland for all of us in
the boonies--and it's on non-commercial public radio.  By the way she
will most likely be on Xmas eve and NY eve for those wishing to party
over the airwaves>  Tues 10PM-1AM

She was part of the English scene in the late 80's and has worked with
some of the major acts from that time--besides her brother is a Drum &
Bass producer in England so she gets lots of fresh cuts from that scene.

Some people think I'm spamming and "shouting" too much so if the above
announcement is a spam then I guess I'm trouble :P'''

Perhaps the most interesting thing going on here is the politics,
pecking order, and territoriality you see in all human endeavors, and
it's really a microcosm of the world at large.

It's the job of fools like me to say the crazy shit that would get most
people's heads chopped off in the King's Court.  If someone has a
problem with me then why don't you quote me (out of context of course!)
and we can have a public or private debate on whatever subject, instead
of quietly suggesting I go to the back of the bus for unspecified
remarks.

In the world of street knowledge it's not about muscle or physical
prowess it's about KNOWLEDGE and anybody is free to make any boast or
statement--they will just have to live with the responses.

Some of you might remember when punk came along and challenged the
complacency and commercialization of the Hippy/Deadhead scene... when
"Peace & Love"  became a front for a bunch of farts making millions and
buying condos on Maui.

Some of my best friends are "hippys" who wear tie dye and listen to the
Grateful Dead--but that original movement was about challenging the
power structure, non-conformism--and don't forget, originally,
"revolution." 

Now dance music has a hierarchy, priests, scribes, historians...
essentially a "power structure" where none existed.  Millions of dollars
are revolving around it--record labels, big radio (it's Top 40 in
Europe--your "underground" music)--advertisers and sponsors.

One element wants to infantize the scene... make it purely hedonistic. 
Like ALL we should do is party, suck lollypops, play with dolls,take
drugs, and vegetate like the hippy movement.  THAT whole cycle worked
for the gov't in undermining the 60's revolution.

Look at the "Peace & Love" hippy scene now with 3rd generation stoners
who grew up in that scenario.  On the one hand you have highly conscious
people who have transcended a lot of the programming of our
materialistic society--people who value communal values over society's
values.

On the other hand there are lots of "wolves in hippy clothing" like the
street people that steal other's backpacks or drugs, or will freak out
over something and start smacking heads--a lot of drug addicts who will
do almost anything for drugs--or take any drug>  speed, smack, coke,
etc.  and a lot of those types are throwing parties for the same reasons
since order arose out of anarchy--to get laid and make money.

I'm not dogging drug use (as you may know I'm for ending Prohibition)
but to a lot of people drugs are their gods and they lose their souls in
the pursuit.

Hey the best occupation in life is to do something you love and make a
living at it.  We should use all the tools of the Establishment to stake
our claim to exist, have a self-sustaining economy, and avoid political
repression. 

"We have met the enemy and it is us"
						--George Orwell, 'Animal Farm"

"The emperor has no clothes"
						--common fairy tale

Pax,

DJ ASB

Before someone takes my last ruckus out of context re candy, dolls,etc.
what brought it up for me was remembering the Seattle scene a few years
ago and the faddism and cliques that were forming.

People had their own crews and if you didn't have the right candy or
know their slang "codewords" you weren't gonna be invited to their
afterparties, and were given the "vibe" like you were an outsider.

This scenario is familiar to anyone ever having been in Jr. High school.

On the surface it was playing out with people busting each other's
parties (calling the cops) and spreading massive disinformation
(dissing) each other.

I believe the cartoonish aspects of rave originated from the psychedelic
experience and not from regressing to childish "in crowd" behavior.

Yeah--be as innocent as children but don't act out the stupid pecking
order rituals kids play just like their parents.

This is directed to those kind of people, not the rest of you.

Enjoy the Turnaround,

DJ ASB

  Well we didn't mean to confuse anyone out there! In this case what we
meant by vs. was simply side A <MYSTR-E> vs. side B <MARS>.
  We felt that any other term such as MARS "Likes" MYSTR-E or MARS "plays
with" MYSTR-E wouldn't have sounded right, nor fit the theme of this tape.
   We've been best friends for most of our lives so it definitely was more
of a fun thing for us to do. It probably has to do with our more
competitive nature growing up in L.A.
     Anyways, hope this helped.

          Stay Tuned In.
        M/M @ FREQUENCY 8------>

Precedence: bulk


Friday Night
After two nights of serious drinking (end of finals = crazy partying in 
B-Town), the little nagging, voice of reason inside of me whispered to stay 
home, rest my body, and take good care of myself in preparation for a 
wild Gathering.  So, what did I do?  Why, I jumped up and headed out to the 
City, of course.  27 years of life does not necessarily bring wisdom.

First stop: DNA Lounge
Fabled 11th Street.  Friday night at DNA features a live disco band that 
has to be seen to be believed.  What a show!  Afros, gold chains, 
platforms and a sexy motherfucker of a lead singer, ripping their way 
through the entire 70's repertoire.  Great fun, with a drunken crowd 
hanging from the rafters, dancing on tabletops, and singing along with 
the songs (which rock, IMHO).  After the band ended rather early, though, 
some generic house came on over a muddy sound system, and we decided to 
blow that joint.  One other detraction: at $12 to get in, and inflated 
drink prices, a night at DNA is a costly affair.  Also, only one stall as 
a women's bathroom, with no seat on the toilet and a mirror so warped and 
clouded that a reflection was impossible.  Someone's getting rich off 
this deal, 'cause the money doesn't seem to be going back into the 
facilities.
(BTW, I'm listening to KBIG playing killer disco right now.  Love it!)

So we popped over to that old stand-by...

1015 Folsom
Whoa!  Did I hear someone say Nikita is dead?!  Oh, wait, that was me!  I 
must have been hitting it on the wrong nights, because last night that 
shit was POUNDING.  A different world from last week (I wonder why...? 
must be hit or miss).  Jerry Bonham was throwing down the hardcore 
underground sound in the main room, some crazy tripped-out trance, and 
the unclub crowd was going nuts (including yours truly, of course).  Club 
vibe was nonexistant, especially after two.  And the Family was 
definitely represented - glowsticks, smiles, speakerbabies, ravedancers.  
I kept going much longer than I should have on a beautiful natural 
endorphin high, and finally got to sleep at home in the wee early morning 
hours...

So I hit here now, 7PM on what was to be The Crazy Party Night, but I 
already have several behind me, and sleep is looking so good.  I'm 
undecided, but even now I can feel the beat throbbing, beckoning me to 
follow...

	bright orange whistle and my SFRAVE TAG.  Come say hi :)

	peace, love, and happy holidays  ------>> LETS RAVE

	MHg ;)

>You show up, start spouting lengthy diatribes that appear to be constructed
>as some kind of juvenile 'humor', don't engage in dialogue with the other
>people but start yelling at everyone, yammer about your "5:1 supportive
>email", beg for pity because you're 'dyslexic' (believe me, if you were you

Enclosed find two replies, pick the one that suits ya :)
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Nah I'm not asking for pity--more like I'm responding to some private
mail that took me to task but didn't point out any beefs...

I checked out this list for awhile before responding to some wack (in my
opinion) posts i.e. on the subject of drugs and the general censoring of
topics a few people don't want to see.

Since people asked me to "qualify" my experience in this field I
did--albeit it was a lengthy boring "bio"

Because people send me posts like yours and I figure you probably
represent a few others that won't like my style I tend to answer back at
the public forum for them also--

That's what it comes down to--is this an open forum or a "good 'ol boys"
club?  If you have an intelligent criticism of any particular thing I
said why don't you quote it and if it was stoopid I'd admit it.

I'm really not interested in kow-towing to the existing pecking order
("I'm a local... I've been here longer") or the old world mentality so
many newjacks seem to have.  

If it were not for some enthusiastic replies from some long time members
pointing out the anal retentiveness of some of the others I probably
would have unsubscribed in about 2 seconds because for a minute I
thought I was in alt.rec.stodgy.

Sorry you didn't appreciate my parody maybe I can forward my posts to
you and you can edit them for everyone else since you are on such a
higher mental plane.  

What if I WAS dislexic and "mental"?   It just means I didn't fit into
the niche society prepared for me--to accept their conditioning and be
like all the other drones.   What the fuck is RAVING supposed to be
about?  This ain't no stinkin' chess club as far as I can tell. Is
SFRaves about being like everyone else, not challenging the status quo?

I came in just like it was a club full of ravers and did my dance.  A
few of you bitch and say:  "Nah you can't express yourself that way here
we're very civilized
we don't act that way!" and obviously there are a few nerdy computer
types who are on the tip of being funky but still can't quite loosen up,
probably can't dance if they even try, so they become "Guardians of
Techno Philosophy" and take it to a verbal plane.

It's almost hysterical--people that consider themselves "Ravers" yet
they got to check people for expressing themselves a little too "wildly"

I think I've already apologised for dropping in like a bomb because I
didn't really expect this place to be like all the other groups you find
online.  I said a lot facetiously and in humor and it's ironic how
people pick up on a phrase or two made in fun and feel uptight about it.

Which might bring up a valid topic--how (or why) should the dance
community police itself.  Who should be the arbiters of taste and
propriety?  I could say I hate samples of screaming women in techno
songs--should I tell you you are an idiot if you like them?

"Freedom of Choice"
-Devo

You think I create juvenile humor?  What a compliment, since it's crazy,
whacked juvenile humor that makes a techno song wild.

I know I say some wack shit sometimes, and when someone of intelligence
and knowledge ubraids me, I take it to heart.  Your kind of attack
"describing" what I said is only your interpretation--perhaps you saw
yourself as the target to some of my jibes.

Put on the Bozo Filter
Delete
Rally the Troops
Now Shake Your Bootay!

Peace Out  :)

DJ ASB

Dislexic and Proud... dissing the lexicon :*

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Dec 22 02:28:34 1996

Precedence: bulk

BOY YOU OPENED A BIG ONE!

>what do you mean by the standard conventions?

I guess I'm saying that where raves evolved out of a mixed
hippy/punk/alternative direction and those genres were trying to break
out of the standard music industry conventions, the idea was to create
new contexts for enjoying music, somewhat related to the ancient tribal
rituals but incorporating all the new art forms of the last decade.

As rock culminated in the punk era people were aware of the huge
corporate mentality behind rock--huge tours--the resurgence of
"controlled" Top 40 rock, the blatant PR and how performers were treated
like idols.  Record labels gave contracts taking 95% of the gross
profits, etc. and the alternative market was aware of this disparity.

Ten years later (87-97) we should question the same ossification of the
dance genre, and look for alternate ways to spread the vibe.  Not to put
down promoters (I've been a little too harsh) because even for a greedy,
phony type there is so much work, stress and possibility of being busted
that even the most jaded must have SOME love for the genre or they would
invest somewhere else.

But excitedly there are new outlets popping up.  More and more people
are forming communal rave families;  there are live DJ broadcasts over
the Internet;
people are hooking up online and sharing mixes.  These and others like
them are some of the ways this music is spreading in channels the major
labels never dreamed of and are barely catching on to.

Probably the downside is just trying to replicate what went down
before--mimic the parties of late 80's Europe and go no further--fun but
not too adventurous.  

Also by standard conventions I mean in general terms how fads start, are
spread, and then become homogenized by the masses.  That "Valley Girl"
song came out about 10 years ago, was mimicked by several other media
sources, and now you can go to almost any booney mall in the US and find
a bunch of girls talking that way.

GETTING TOO DEEP

Oh well dig a hole with your mouth...

What does it all come down to?  Fads... how they originate and spread. 
You see the same patterns.  When they get big somebody starts making $
off them and then wants to hype them bigger.  Does it mean anything to
be a hippy or punk anymore?  Nobody is shocked by long hair or nose
rings.  Most people can get a job at a major chain with either prop.

(Reading back now I seem so faddist myself :P''')

Alternative has become the standard uniform now...so from that context
is there any possibility of being cutting edge or doing something
different than what came before?

I guess we get into what Art is, a question that has been beaten to
death over the centuries.  Rave culture took on a life of it's own
beyond the music, not unlike the Deadhead movement.  Now it is more like
a religion or political party, embracing a whole cultural shift.

Is the model of youthful rebellion against parental values played out? 
The media has worked this theme for big bucks even before James Dean
movies--so if your parent was a raver what do you rebel against?  The
shock value in being different is tough when parents might be hippys,
gangstas, or ravers.

But true to form Raves became the next whipping boy for the media & law
enforcement--as if rockers aren't pumping drugs down 10 to 1 over
ravers.

Ironically it's the above kind of attention and sensational stories that
drew a wider audience to this music.

Media archetypes--that's the word I'm looking for.  I think what happens
to any progressive movement is as the average masses swell the ranks,
they eventually codify and ritualize what were originally spontaneous
gestures.  You see this in religions like Christianity and Taoism.  The
founders start out basically saying "Keep It Simple Stupid"  (K.I.S.S.)
but as they pass on and their teachings become canonized, eventually the
average followers lose the original intent and it gets complicated.

Yeesh this just gets deeper and deeper, and it's a plane I get nervous
being on!!!

But as I listen to college radio and hear a wide cross section of music
covering this last century, and some of the various world music types, I
can see how new or mutated genres will continue to arise.

The common thread is the innovators, the creators.  People will continue
to break the rules and conventions and create new (or recycled) genres. 
That story of Throbbing Gristle on this list (they switched from
uniforms to frilly dresses, alienating their core followers) is
indicative of the above explanations--how the average "follower" wants a
tangible stereotype to mimick, something that will give a common
reference and will not lead to doubt.  People (animals too) feel secure
with something familiar--they don't like radical change.

I "switched" my image a lot... having some acting background makes it a
little more fluid.  I was drawn to the "uniform" look because almost
nobody wanted that excepting groups like Devo, the Clash & Throbbing
Gristle.  I used to try to be more individualistic before that, looking
psychedelic, and another phase I wanted to look kind of like a
psychedelic trooper--you might say the day-glo uniform effect though the
main gist came from the "paramilitary disco" look that went by for about
6 months sometime at the height of disco.

Having experienced the Hippy Uniform and resulting police harassment
kind of led me to want to look more "Rambo" than the cops, if I really
wanted to "trip out" hard in my mind.

It's kind of funny to look so straight... maybe be totally bombed and
have a cop ask you if you're "in the service" and just nod stoically. 
You'd be amazed at how often this saves your ass.

Even more fun is to pop up in a group of deadheads and get the total
stinkeye--and they don't even suspect you've "out-tripped" them a
hundred times over.

But all of this is externals and the real revolution has to be
internal.  What you look like, wear, and what club you belong to is
irrelevant.  Can you break out of the programmed being called by your
name but consisting of millions of programmed messages:  "Do this...be
this..etc.)

I was thinking the other day...what is my ego except for my vocabulary? 
The verbal mind is like a dictionary, stringing words together to create
a persona.  

Hell I'm not much more than a spelling checker (and defective at that)
strung together with a bunch of programming.

I was also thinking rave has always been around...sitar music,
aboriginal music, Arabic and Scottish droning music... these people were
tripping centuries and thousands of years ago.  So from that standpoint
we might as well forget fads and revolving genres--we're just continuing
an unbroken chain.

The progressives are probably listening to dozens of genres (all types
of music.)  The faddists will become die-hard "followers" and only
follow "their" music.

The real battleground is the MEDIA.  I think the spirit of rave is to
jack any media source, twist it up a little, rework the media
archetypes, repackage it, and feed it back to the masses

The college radio jock is jamming now--playing a cross section of punk,
industrial, techno, blues/r&b, and Zappa? or something similar.  I'm
amazed at how tastes change because when I was deep into Hip
Hop/Breakdancing I thought the Bee Gees, Madonna, and Blondie were kind
of wack and most people in there would totally dog you if you liked that
stuff, but now it all sounds great and I can't wait to sample it.

Maybe the word rave has become a straightjacket, like Ciaran OHara wrote
in "Is the word "Rave" obsolete ?" and has been echoed strongly on the
East Coast.  This is a reaction to the faddism and commercialism--you
hear rave music on the TV news, at a football game, in ads, etc.

Coming from the Hip Hop world I think the advantage of the rave model is
that it is (or should be) trying to be conscious and intelligent.  Hip
hop has gone after the macho violence stereotype--and there are only so
many ways to work that played out stereotype.

Rave seems to take some ideals from the art world and the
countercultural revolution.  Hopefully it embraces intelligence (smart
drugs?)  Now it is splitting into dozens of sub genres but aren't these
children essentially Rave music?

When ads for BMG's record club look like rave flyers do we need a new
model?

Well just knowing a few people hate my ass on this bbs inspired me to
dump this missive back into cyberspace... bombs away :] this is for you
people.  Keep the letters coming they are great inspiration>

Ta Da,

DJ ASB

Dropping Science

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Dec 22 11:18:21 1996

	id LAA13237; Sun, 22 Dec 1996 11:18:09 -0800 (PST)

Precedence: bulk


boy I shouldn't even add to this but here goes... :)

1) We're _never_ going to have Ibiza in the 80's again.  Once something's
new, it's new and then it's been new and it's old and can't be relived.
However, what we can take from these times is the essence; the spirit if
you will that created those events and caused the movement to be born.

2) The 'techno' 'rave' scene is dynamic.  It always has been.  That's the
point (isn't it?).  It changes to suit our needs as a family, or better
yet, _we_ change _it_.  If the scene didn't change, we wouldn't have a lot
of the great stuff we have now, and we'd still be spinning T99 rekkids
(well, maybe that part wouldn't be so bad... :D)

3) Everybody talks about rock rock rock alternative alternative
alternative punk punk punk but nobody seems to have lived through the
1970's with me.  Does anyone remember disco?  Now the disco thing was odd
at best, but it really mirrored a lot of the musical problems we are
describing with 'techno' and 'dance' music.  There were highly commercial
lables putting out disco records, mainstream artists started trying to
make disco records at the orders of their producers (anyone remember
'Tatoo You' by the Rolling Stones?), and meanwhile there were underground
artists making and pressing disco records and distributing them to DJs who
were trying to keep on the cutting edge of the scene.  Nowadays you can
find all sorts of disco you never heard of in thrift shops and such.
Where did it come from?  It's not on A&M or RSO!  It must be independent
lables!  Oh my God!

Now, the big difference here is that disco shot up and fell down fast as
technology afforded easier ways of creating more compelling dance tracks
(I'm not putting disco down, mind you).  The 'techno' 'rave' musical scene
won't fall this way because there are constantly more and more people
interested in hearing newer and more diverse music.  The 'techno' 'dance'
scene (eg. Kellee, RuPaul, etc.) is commercial... it's the extension of
the commercialized disco market.  It will do whatever it's going to do no
matter what and that's just that.  But if Moonshine sells 100,000 comps
this month or if they sell 5, there _still_ are going to be a hefty crate
of new indie underground rekkids to spin and chances are there are still
going to be DJs who search these things out and spin 'em!

Lables like Harthouse/Eye-Q, Rampant and others have been able to
consistantly produce high quality music with effective marketing and
distribution.  Does that detract from the music?  No!  Is every records
that comes out on those lables my favorite?  No!  Commercialism and
marketing are necessary for larger lables to stay in business, we
shouldn't hold that against them.  

blah blah blah
PLUR
*hugs*
I miss you all!!!

So Cal is fun, but it's just not the same :)

                dBP
   dBP dBP dBP dBP dBP    dBP    dBBP
  dBP_dBP dBP dBP dBP    dBP    dBP
 dBBBBBP dBP dBP dBBBBP dBBBBP dBBBBP
                                     dBBBBb  dBBBBP dBBBBBb     dBP dBP
                                        dBP dBP.BP       BB
                                   dBP dBP dBP.BP    dBP BB   dBBBBBP
                                  dBP dBP dBP.BP    dBP  BB  dBP dBP
                                 dBP dBP dBBBBP    dBBBBBBB dBP dBP

********napodaca@ucdavis.edu**************************************************
      "Uncle" Noah Apodaca - UCDavis Graduate, DJ, Electronic Musician

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Dec 22 12:22:54 1996

Subject: music pluralism (long, but RR)

   o /
  <\\__  DJ ASB:
    |

I was glad to see yet another intelligent and reflective post on sfraves.

I gained a renewed appreciation of this level of depth on occasional 
sfraves posts after briefly subscribing to 'nyc-raves' to check out
possibilities before a few NYC visits last month. The hostile and
neandrathal tone of almost any nyc-raves post makes sfraves posts seem
enlightened by comparason, IMO.  Yours (rave spam) was especially
interesting. Thanks for taking the time to post it.

> The progressives are probably listening to dozens of genres (all types
> of music.)  The faddists will become die-hard "followers" and only
> follow "their" music.

Yes, but I believe this goes beyond the progressives. I think this
statement was probably true twenty years ago, but there has been a
significant change in musical tastes in the past decade.

Hmmm... I'm wondering whether to give a short explanation or a more
complete one. Since your post was extensive, I'll assume you prefer to
look at ideas in depth. Bandwidth war!

So here goes. Sorry if it sounds like it fails to acknowledge the
likelihood that you already agree with all of this...


      In the nineteenth century, the younger generation enjoyed the same
music as their parents. Then at the beginning of this century, young
people discovered the option of daring to enjoy the newer ragtime
and tin pan alley ditties. This was a major change from the cohesive
family musical gatherings of the previous century, but was not yet a major
conflict - many parents also wanted to be "modern" and embraced ragtime
and popular music as well. 

     This dynamic of generational division expanded in the twenties,
thirties and forties, with jazz and swing, with even less parental
approval of the new music. Then in the fifties, another level of
subdivision began to appear: this one was *within* the younger generation
itself. One group of kids would prefer a different sound from another
group of the same age. Some people even began to make distinctions
between the "good" kids and the "bad" based on their musical and dance
preferences.

     While parental disapproval over the new rock and roll intensified,
and teens' music began to split between hard-core rock (greasers) versus
cute-and-clean pop rock, with a sharp decrease in teens who liked the
music of their parents' generation. The labeling of "good vs. bad" kids
based on their musical preferences increased.  Toward the end of the
decade, the "good" kids had another choice with the "Hootenanny" folk
music movement (before your time?).

     This division continued in the sixties, of course, with Mods vs.
Rockers and more diversity in popular music. Folk music evolved into Bob
Dylan and Arlo Guthrie crossovers.   However, the seventies set the stage
for a major paradigm shift away from such either-or choices.


      A pause for a digression:  In 1969, General Electric's Business
Environment Section's published its Study of Significant Value-System
Changes, a forecast of changes from the 1960s to the 1980s.  
 
Changes predicted:                        

     from				to
War (military might)		Peace (economic development)
Nationalism			Internationalism
Federal government		State/local government
Public enterprise		Private enterprise
Organization			Individual
Future planning			Immediacy
Sociability			Privacy
*Uniformity and conformity*	*Pluralism*

      Note the improbability of Sociability changing to Privacy while
Uniformity changed to Pluralism. These trends seem to go in crossed
directions. This study was decades before the Internet came along with its
odd fusion of privacy and pluralism.

     Of course, we now know that the G.E. study turned to be right in most
cases, even predicting the major shifts of the Reagan years.  End of
digression.


     So here we are in the Decade of Pluralism.  In music, I think 
pluralism began to appear as a major trend in seventies popular music with
the increasing options of hard rock vs. soft rock  vs. oldies  vs. disco
vs. new wave vs. punk. You might place this shift earlier.

Twenty years later, we have mainstream popular rock, alternative rock, 
punk, techno/house/coldwave/hardcore/industrial/hard German/trance/Goa/
jungle/ragga/tribal/dub/trip-hop/gabber, ambient, rap/hip-hop/OldSchool, 
R & B, reggae, heavy metal, thrash, trash disco, oldies, surf rock, new
Latin (salsa and techno merengue), Tejano, country & western, cool jazz/
acid jazz, retro lounge, world music, bhangra, Afribbean, just to name a
few...

... as you know, being in the business...

and the most surprising development of all, which you mentioned: for the
first time this century, we now find teens liking much of their parents'
music (Deadheads, teens attending Stones concerts, and the retro
50s/60s/70s listed above). The baby boomers universally *hated* their
parent's music (Lawrence Welk and the like) and vice-versa.


But the most significant aspect of this is that most young people, not
just the progressives, love much/most of these genres of music. Last night
at the Gathering, didn't Alex Patterson close his set (which had included
several of the above genres) with a bagpipe waltz? 

At least that is what I have found. Your experiences may differ, so this
is just IMO.

I feel that a new dynamic of pluralism has superseded the older
pattern of mass trends. In my opinion, this is a change for the better.
I think the richness of diversity is healthy, and I admire the broader
sense of tolerance that many now have for the tastes of others. 

Just my 2 cents worth.

Richard

Hi Uncle Noah:

> 
> Now, the big difference here is that disco shot up and fell down fast as
> technology afforded easier ways of creating more compelling dance tracks
> (I'm not putting disco down, mind you).  The 'techno' 'rave' musical scene
> won't fall this way because there are constantly more and more people
> interested in hearing newer and more diverse music. 

I mostly agree with your spin on this, but I think the fad dynamic also
killed the disco scene, which simmered along just fine for 15 years until 
'Saturday Night Fever' made discos hugely popular/mainstream, then hugely 
Last Year's Fad. John Travolta helped do the same to country/western,
which took more than a decade to recover from its own 'Urban Cowboy'
boom-bust cycle. 

I'm not convinced that the same dynamic can't happen to raves.

Hope I'm wrong. 

I'll get flamed for this, but for the subculture to remain healthy, I'd
much rather see the current spate of ravophobic media attention about
Drugs At Raves Ruining Your Children than a successful major film hyping
rave culture.

IMHO, of course.

Richard

[ to sfraves ]
Some Stuff About Last Night's Gathering at Home Base in Oakland:
1. IT WAS GREAT!!!!
2. What's the problem with the Home Base site? It was my first time
   there, and I was cool with it. Certainly a lot cleaner than some
   warehouse raves I've been to. Lots of rooms, good enough sound
   isolation between rooms.
3. For one reason or another , it's been a long time since I've
   heard Spun or Garth, and hearing that "progressive house" stuff
   again was good for my soul.
4. House and techno and jungle and etc. at the same event - thumbs up
   for that!
5. Eric - I was pissed of at you, but not any more.
6. Can anyone tell me via private email if they saw any gangstas there?
   I must be too old - just saw a lot of young people in young people
   clothes...
7. Definitely a young crowd, average age looked 18 to my 41 year old
   eyes. Your SF Bay area ethnic mix. 
8. For some reason, it made me nostalgic to see the huge crowd having
   a good time, with videos and lasers and strobes. Like the big 
   warehouse raves of my experience ( post-92 ). Of course, this one 
   was being put on by the folks who did most of the best ones of
   my memory, so that may be part of it. 
    But I also think there was a similarity in the mood of the crowd -
   "experienced" ravers and bemused/amused/happy first-timers. Some minor
   fashion differences ( more athletic-logo wear than what I recall ).
   It may also be co-incidence, but I overheard a lot of conversations 
   between strangers about being on E the first time that night.

  That's it for now - bye!

 Larry/larryc@netcom.com

Richard

The only thing I might add to your nice overview is the influence of
jazz and blues to the "good/bad" dichotomy--where you had the raw jazz
from the streets against the slick big band stuff that was for the
masses.

Just as in the blues genre this was "the Devil's music" as gospel turned
into steamy, sexy blues & jazz ballads.

The good music/bad music seems to have become a marketing tool for the
label executives...

Again the "teenage rebellion" marketing angle, perfected with Elvis and
the Beatles and culminating in the Sex Pistols (who parodied the whole
scam.)

Came up with a new acronym:

DIVE (Diversity, Individuality, Vibe, H'mmm...what could E stand
for?...oh yeah, Equipment (take good care of it, you can't have a gig if
the equipment don't work  :) or maybe Energy!

It's a little ironic how many people seem to have a problem with the
PLUR crowd, but I imagine that has to do with the fact that among the
dance crowd you have all types reflecting on society at large:  hippys,
punks, anarchists, hip hoppers, rockers, gay, straight, nerds, jocks,
etc.

A lot of these types have a problem joining any movement as "members." 
("Nasty as I Want To Be"--2 Live Crew)

If I recall articles from a few years back the English trades were
describing the Jungle crowd as being working class, hooligan types as
opposed to the brotherly House/Techno scene--and it was held in disdain
by the mellow types almost like how punk grafted onto the rock scene.

I forsee punkish/gangsta vibe dance crowds with totally opposite
political views complete with macho posturing, fights, moshing, etc. as
punks, industrialists and gangstas merge into the scene with junglists,
etc.

But isn't this what diversity is all about?   Some people like to be
sadistic or masochistic (whether or not they are ill) etc.   I can
imagine Born Again dance a la Moby, as well as Satanic dance or
Matriarchical scenes (Gaia, woman's liberation movement, etc.) and
eventually a scene for every persuasion.  In the party circuit you see a
full range from hardcore S&M sexuality to innocent "Jack & Jill" types
trying to recapture the joy of childhood--and as one of my earlier
detractors said..."It's ALL Good."

Of course as a "straight" one would have to have blinders on not to
notice the unifying effect all this dance music has had on the Gay
community, that has continually been on the cutting edge and sustaining
all the new experiments way before the masses find out.  Back in the
days you virtually HAD to go to Gay clubs if you wanted jumping, cutting
edge music that wasn't playing anywhere else and we could question if
there would be the present scene without that influence.

Ironically for all us "old" farts I know of an all age club in Portland
where they don't want any DJ's over 21, which may be a fitting reward
since that crowd can't go to commercial clubs.  Hopefully the youth will
surprise us all with their raw talent and ability to come up with new
twists on "That Ol' Black Magic"

Maybe as a last consideration we can hope that the new generation will
give props to the last few generations that created and sustained this
music before there was any economic incentive ie. marketing potential
and not fall into the standard age discrimination that has been
perpetuated by the media as a marketing angle.

I can think of lots of wise mature people who have contributed to our
present consciousness such as Timothy Leary, Genesis P'Orridge, James
Brown, George Clinton, Hendrix, and all the other teachers who taught us
how to funk, going back to blues, jazz, R&B, house and disco.  Back in
the blues period they used to say "you had to pay your dues" whereas now
you can just bite some rythyms off a sample cd or pop some prefab MIDI
sequences in your computer and be funky and put out a hit record--it
didn't used to come so easy.

Peace Out and in the spirit of the holidays an olive branch for my
friends that dog me out and make me work a little harder--the
controversy makes it interesting--or we could all just go back to
sleep...  

:)

DJ ASB

*******Happy Holidays Tra-la Tra-la*******

Hello Stonehenge! What a great party! Such a great diversity of music in all
rooms!
All I can say is..

GARTH

WAS 

ON!!!!!


@ 4:40am, he busted out with some *****HUGE***** Jammy-jams! My body was
unable to withstand the groove overload, and did finally succumb to the deep
bass which kept me in the zone for hours! And then, just when we all thought
his set was done, from out of nowhere, a girl with a beautiful voice started
singing, people started cheering,  clapping,  and before you know
it....awwwww yeah! Here come the Beats...round 2!

Great great time!

Well, 2 bummers tho.. at about 4:45 or 5am, during Garth's set, I dropped my
Arnettes (silver sunglasses) which were in a red little felt-type sunglasses
bag with little drawstring... I went back but all I found was the red
bag....all dirty and abused. It looked at me from the floor...I saw its
pain...all crumpled and dirty.. ashamed of itself... violation written all
over it's little felty skin... Looking at me as if to say..
"Whyyyyyyyyyyyy?!?!?!"  What's even worse is that they were new and
specially made to order for me with special lens/frame combination by
Arnette at an ugly cost...and I loved 'em dearly... :( So if anyone found
some..... ju know what to do mane..

bummmer #2.. A miscommunication on who was in which car of the caravan left
me and my bro stuck in Oakland after the party...You know it's a bummer when
you suddenly realize that your friends pulled a major rookie maneuver and
left without you...just how far you are from home, it's 8am, light and
bright out....and all you have to put over your eyes is a little dirty red
sack with a drawstring that won't shut up about never being able to trust
anyone anymore.

Sheeeeeesh..

AufwiederavEn,
Steve

Precedence: bulk


-------
Warning:
If you only like positive posts, press 'd' now.
-------

I, for one, did not have too great of a time. It was too big, too
dark, and I spent more time wandering around alone looking for a
familiar face than I did actually dancing. The only sense of
'Gathering' that I felt was actually 'Herding' as I joined large
throngs of people trying to push each other from room to room.

I've never been to Home Base before, and the space was not bad for a
large venue. My only complaint was the cement floors (which hurts my
knees when dancing), but other than that I suppose it was okay. But as
I drove into Oakland, it made me feel sad to see the ugly, failed
metropolis looming through my windshield. It reminded me how shakey
the SF underground has been lately...Parties have been busted left &
right, and, true, you can get permits in Oakland, but it's just not
the same as being in San Francisco...

At times, I felt like I was more an observer than anything else. The
DJ was very often this tiny figure way off in the corner. I never did
find the DJ booth in the house room, and as a result I felt like I was
at club. Not a bad thing (I've certainly had my days as a clubber),
just the environment and the vibe was very club-like.

I'm usually not a big fan of vendors at raves, but the people last
night seemed to be selling good, hancrafted stuff...Didn't really
check out any of it since I was low on cash.

On the plus side, the music was really really good. Good, hard dark
teksteppy jungle ruled the smaller dance area for some time. Even the
house room was good, and I'm usually not into house. The sound system
was really powerful...one of the first times in a long time that I've
heard such chest-pounding bass at a party. But the sound was really
too loud for me. Yes, even me, after years of hearing loss from raving
and punk rock...alas, my ears still hurt like hell.

Anyway, my original intent was to go to Riot 23, a small underground
jungle and techno party in Berkeley, but they were busted. It's really
a shame. Oh well! Now I know for sure: no more big parties for Steve! :)

(okay, ready, set...flame!)

Steve

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Dec 22 19:02:44 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id TAA00739; Sun, 22 Dec 1996 19:02:44 -0800 (PST)
Received: from Zool.AirTouch.COM by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with SMTP id TAA00731; Sun, 22 Dec 1996 19:02:41 -0800 (PST)
Received: from nit.AirTouch.COM by Zool.AirTouch.COM (SMI-8.6/SMI-SVR4)
	id TAA09887; Sun, 22 Dec 1996 19:02:39 -0800
Received: from eon.nit.airtouch.com by nit.AirTouch.COM (4.1/SMI-4.1/AirTouch-nit:MLC-940403-02)
	id AA09138; Sun, 22 Dec 96 19:02:38 PST
From: eric@nit.AirTouch.COM (Eric Pederson)
Message-Id: <9612230302.AA09138@nit.AirTouch.COM>
Subject: quick gathering review
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (SF Ravers List)
Date: Sun, 22 Dec 1996 19:02:37 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL17]
Content-Type: text
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

We got to Oakland at 2am, and on our way into the Home Base parking
lot some punks decided that my friend had looked at them the wrong way,
so they jumped out of their car and starting shoving him around.
One kid was obviously off his ass on something and kept saying
"I hate all you fucking white people".  The kid was mexican so I 
thought that was kindof odd.  Anyway, we talked our way out of it
and headed in.  There was no line (thank god) and the place was
pretty packed.  Very young crowd... despite being supposedly 18 and over,
I saw lots of girls that were clearly under 18.  That's cool with me
though :)  I spent the night in the house room.  (You know you're having
a good time when all of a sudden the music breaks, you check your watch
and it's 5:30).  The music was good solid house only occasionally venturing
into SanFranDisco land.  There was a fairly good vibe and I talked to lots of
strangers.  I must have had a sign on my back that said "I (heart)
circle dancers" cause it seemed like everywhere I went, some
kid tried to start up a circle.  Towards the end there was big circles
at all the speaker stacks taking up major real estate.  Oh well.
The DJ booth was in the middle of the room, which helped alleviate
the "sit down in the middle of the floor" problem at the 4yr Gathering.
Visuals were great, free water.
Don't know about the bathrooms since I never had to go (I was sweating
too much).  Didn't see one person I recognized (probably the sfravers
were in the techno room).  All in all I had a good time, and I still think
Home Base is a fine place to throw a massive.

Well, needless to say it was my first -LARGE- rave like that.  I've always
tended to hang out at the smaller trance/ambient raves in SF - those don't
seem to ever get busted. :)  Anyway, of course Stone(r)henge was Gr8! and
the laser was trip trip rip, and the ambient room...w00 w00... can you say
ORBED OUT... and the front high energy room :) :)  All were well done.
People were ok to meet, somehow being the happy face I am I am always
getting offered a hit of this, a drag of that, there's extra water if you'd
like! :)  That was the good part, those treasured moments of personable
expression with a few strangers.  What I didn't like was, only the one
doorway into "Stone(r)henge".  After a couple trips back and forth it got
so crowded i was yelling to my friend, "Hey! Let's do that again!" :)  And
I would have to concurr about the "hurding" effect.  I know it might hurt
the promoters, but maybe it WOULD be a good idea to limit attendence so
that people could actually move around and dance without flailing
uncontrollably into 7 people walking through. :)  well well... just my
silly comments :) :) :)  Oh....great....go to rest my legs byt watching R&S
and wind up never getting a chance to sit on the couch :)  Too much tension
outside though....I wanna get my money back....arguing....ego
challenges...and I see what's meant by the Adiddas logo wearing - are there
Adiddas reps not handing out sportsware at raves or are these just silly
people who don't realise they'd look better on a tennies court instead
because they're so blindsided by "fad" "fashion" "the in" "gotsta dress
like my G's br0!" bullshit?  Come on people, live your own lives and not
someone else's - express yourself, not some screwy company who's laughing
at you because "FAD" and your part in it is upping their revenue at your
expense.  Uhmmm...just get an independently made smiley face shirt or...
uhm... tidye shirt....yeah....with a sun.... :)  just kidding :)  ok, me
done rambling now.

viva la b00m b00m

REMINDER: January 18th is National Hippie Day!  Spread the word of love!

Hi all!

I expected to have a great time at the Gathering, and I did! I got to see
so many faces that I haven't seen in a long time. I thought the music was
alright, but it was a little too fast for me to get into. This is the first
party I've been to all year where I didn't leave all soaked with sweat from
dancing all night.

guy with a white "Burnt Crispies" shirt who was tripping hella hard off of
orange sunshine...

Ivan

MIME-Version: 1.0

Subject: another gathering review
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Overall, I had a good time.  I don't know if its me or there seems to be
more things in massives that are bothering me.
I usually go with the expectation that the vibe won't be as good at a
massive.  This seems to be consistantly true, so I go with alot of focus
on enjoying  the visuals and the big sound systems, which I have to say
were great as usual.
The people there seemed very friendly for the most part.  But it seems that
as a whole less and less people are dancing.  There were many people sitting
on the dance floor, and many people continuously walking around through the
middle of the floor seeming to have no intention to find a good spot to 
dance.  And whats up with all these people just standing around the dj.
I'm not a dj myself, and I thought maybe people were trying to get a few pointers
from watching the dj spin.  But it seemed that many were just standing around 
socializing, or just standing around.
I used to like to go up front, because I would find alot of people dancing intensely.

It seems like the concept of shared trance is fading at these massives.

I'm so happy I went over to the smaller room and caught garth's set.  It was nice
to find a good vibe in there.  I found the vibe to be pretty good in that room
all night when I would go.  I kept going back to the main room because I wanted
to hear other music besides the jungle that was playing and to listen to the bigger 
sound system and enjoy the visuals.  
Though I got to say that the jungle music sure is fun, and it seems to create 
a zaney vibe.

The water situation was good, and it was nice to have 3 rooms of music.

Sorry if some of you didn't like some of my venting about the vibe.  I can't
help but have some major concerns about this scene that I love so much
and has brought me so much joy.
Is there a way we can get more people to experience the joys of trancing 
together?
Maybe I should just try to focus more on the people who do enjoy it, and maybe
others will catch on.
Or maybe I need to except the tranceformation that is happening, and give up
on the hope of having a vibe at a massive like the full moon partys at bonny doon.

Any thoughts on this?


peter

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Dec 23 09:02:14 1996

To: Ivan Vasquez <qhelp@newton.apple.com>

Subject: Re: the gathering

Precedence: bulk

I was there! I had really low energy so I didn't do any dancing (which
is a first for me at a party this good.)  Some observations:

	*   DJ in the center:  It takes longer for this configuration to
	    get moving but once it gets going, it really goes off!!
	    At first I didn't like it cuz it seemed that people just
	    milled around without focus, but once the crowed was
	    subjected to one hard hitting, experienced DJ after another,
	    Ego withered and the vibe started to flow in the main room.

	*   Ethan's Set:   When I came in at 11 pm, Ethan was going
	    off!! Very clear vibe in the air. And the crowd was digging 
	    it.  Martin should have scheduled him later cuz this was the
	    kind of energy that could have turned this into an "insanely
	    great" party.  Still Ethan early built a solid foundation
	    for others to follow, though I would have liked to have in 
	    the main room.

	*   Home Base: They seem to be putting up walls and turning this
	    place into a Rave-o-rama. Not a bad local, Martin you
	    still need to have more free water!

	*   Folks on speed: The only negative thing that I observed is
	    WAYYY too many people on speed. Speed effects the vibe
	    directly, it creates Borg consciousness and directly
	    inhibits the flow of love energy.
	
	*   Kevin Saunderson: Tore it up!. I spent most of my time
	    sitting with Jeno watching this virtuoso deliver the goods.
	    The thing I admired most is that he took chances, he didn't
	    play some canned pre-arranged bullshit and really went for
	    it.  At one point he either hit a scratch or just straight
	    out wrecked but he just backed out and kept gettin' up!
	    Sorta like OK, I fucked up, now let's get on with it.
	    I also liked that he played muusic from different 
	    sub-gendres, I heard detroit techno, euro-techno,
	    hard house, garage, progressive house, even that cheesy
	    professional widow track that actually worked! (All the\	
	    kids that listen to KMEL went crazy!!)  It was great to see
	    a master DJ at work who is capable of playing all styles.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Dec 23 11:07:44 1996

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Dec 23 11:15:17 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id LAA22328; Mon, 23 Dec 1996 11:15:17 -0800 (PST)
Received: from gw3.pacbell.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with SMTP id LAA22324; Mon, 23 Dec 1996 11:15:14 -0800 (PST)
Received: from srv.PacBell.COM (mother.srv.PacBell.COM) by gw3.pacbell.com (5.x/PacBell-10/18/95)
	id AA28874; Mon, 23 Dec 1996 11:14:35 -0800
Received: from pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM by srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/Mother-7/26/95)
	id AA11826; Mon, 23 Dec 96 11:14:34 PST
Received: by pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA18884; Mon, 23 Dec 96 11:14:31 PST
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9612231914.AA18884@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
Subject: Gathering
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 23 Dec 96 11:14:30 PST
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hi.  I don't hang out here much anymore, but here's a review and some
subjective thoughts.

Arrived 1ish and started out in the main room.  Excellent sound, nice
lazers, friendly people.  Typical East Bay massive vibe; young, happy,
unfocused.  Groups of friends hanging out, socializing.  For at least half
the people there, dancing seemed to be an afterthought.  Decorating the
speaker stacks like Stonehenge was sort of cute, but also reminded me of
the "This is Spinal Tap" movie.  The huge mural of a forest
looked tacky, but I guess it was better than a wall of bricks.

I was enjoying Josh's set, but got a little bored and decided to wander 
around.  The music in the "Experimental" room had shifted to Jungle. 
Now this was more like it.  The tunes were insane and fresh, and people 
were really going off;  I was great to hear music that (for around here)
sounded so new and creative.  It actually felt like a rave in there.
I started having a great time.

After about an hour, I took a break and wandered over to the ambient
area.  Some kind of live act, Ambient Temple of the Imagination perhaps.
There was a pseudo-paganesque style to it, and then some horribly banal
vocals chased me away.  Back to the Jungle.  Yeah, the people
here were really appreciating the music.  The powerful base and intricate
rhythms pretty much demanded that you either get into it, or leave.  Not
to easy to just stand around and talk here,  though there still
were  a couple of folks who insisted on sitting down in the middle of
the dance floor.  I'd like to say "I'm sorry" to anyone whose hands or
face I may have stepped on, even though I'm really not.

Back in the ambient space, I was amused to see Santa Claus Martin behind
the turntables adding to live mix, though it wasn't clear if what he
was doing actually affected the sound I was hearing.  I would have hung out
there longer but the air was too thick.

After experiencing the Jungle energy, the main room just seemed dull to me.
I wandered in a couple of times, stepped on a few more faces trying to
find a vibey spot.  True, people were having fun, but it was the kind of
fun that any group of high schoolers could have staying up late with their
friends.  It just didn't seem very special.  Perhaps if it was my
first rave, I would have felt differently.  Saunderson played a horribly
cheezey commercial rave tune and I left in disgust.  Yeah, he's a legend;
but that means nothing to me if he's gonna spin crap. (IMO of course).  I
suppose I should have given him more of a chance to impress me.

More fun with Jungle, really killer stuff, DJ Malcom, I believe.  I really 
wanted to hear Tony's set, but now I wasn't sure if I could shift back 
into acid/techno/house.  Once I get really absorbed by the energy of
one musical style, it can be hard to suddenly shift into another.  Sitting
on a the floor somewhere, Peter, Angela and I debated this a little, trying
to figure which DJ would possible be capable of mixing Jungle tunes into
a house set.  Perhaps Markie.

Well, at around 5, I guessed that I should try Tony in the main room. 
But this final foray to the main room only made me realize that I
don't really belong at these kind of massives any more.  By now, it was
just a place to hang out.  As far as the vibe; I might as well have been at 
at a shopping mall.  As good as Tony's set could ever be, I just didn't 
want to be around people for whom it wouldn't really matter.  Sorry, I 
know I'm generalizing here.

But there was hope for me yet.  The Jungle room had just given way to
DJ Garth.  The music slowed, in came the funk, and I knew that something
special was about to happen.

Garth is one of those DJ's who plays records that I would never think of
buying.  It's as though they just wouldn't sound right if they weren't
part of a Garth set. Soulful, funky, deep, twisted.  I don't Garth
personally, but you can feel how he is so emotionally involved
with the music he spins.  The dance groove he creates is less important
that the FEEL grove.  His mixing is pure art:  Anyone can beatmatch, but
Garth will give you tempo changeups and style shifts that while
being totally unexpected, work like a dramatic story, passionate,
with an ebb-and-flow where the emotion of one song sets up the next,
amplifying the power of the moment.  

It was happening; You could feel the energy come together, focused through
he shaman behind the tables, guiding us, taking us to places we rarely
get to go.  It was magical, and the small crowd in the room knew it.
This is the kind of magic I hope for when I go out to a rave.  A true
musical experience.  I'm sure Garth's set would have failed miserably in
the main room, but for me at this party, it was like finding a pearl in 
the carcass of a dead clam.

Now that it's all over, I feel that I was lucky to have had such a great
time.  I can see that that I no longer relate to the mainstream rave vibe.
Martin gave us a great production, but there's nothing he can do to create
the kind of fervor and specialness that I look for at a rave.  That's ok,
I'm really glad that so many other people enjoy themselves at these
kinds events.  Take care, everyone.  I'll see you in the next world, don't
be late.  :)

Lee
_________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com  (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )  lee@hyperreal.com
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Dec 23 12:14:28 1996
