From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Dec 23 12:40:21 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id MAA27419; Mon, 23 Dec 1996 12:40:21 -0800 (PST)
Received: from misnt1.rely.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with SMTP id MAA27409; Mon, 23 Dec 1996 12:40:17 -0800 (PST)
Received: by misnt1.rely.com with SMTP (Microsoft Exchange Server Internet Mail Connector Version 4.0.994.63)
	id <01BBF0CF.1FB765F0@misnt1.rely.com>; Mon, 23 Dec 1996 12:45:06 -0800
Message-ID: <c=US%a=_%p=SoftwarExpress%l=MISNT1-961223204502Z-2216@misnt1.rely.com>
From: Adam Guevara <aguevara@rely.com>
To: "'Sfraves@hyperreal.com'" <Sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: A review of the weekend (sorta weird)
Date: Mon, 23 Dec 1996 12:45:02 -0800
X-Mailer:  Microsoft Exchange Server Internet Mail Connector Version 4.0.994.63
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Good morning boys and girls,

Well let me state first off,  When I usually see a post like this I
think, "Ugh, ANOTHER  loooooooong review??  And hit the DELETE key.  But
If it weren't Rave Related it wouldn't be here (psst. and if ya do read
it YOU might find yourself in it!!!  =) ).

Friday, 
_StarGate_ 

Arrived @ 10:30 to the "spot" (I've  decided that in order to keep
locals secret, the actual geographical locations will be withheld).
There was some chai tea brewing, people talking, struck up an
interesting conversation about harvesting Shroomies with a nice girl
from LA.  Around 11:30 or so the natives were getting restless, still no
sound.   So one of the  promoters and I walked up to the location in the
woods.  After a sorta tiring walk (over the river and through the woods)
we arrive.  He shows me where the turntables will be, the sound, the
tarp to keep us warm.  We share that vision, I can see this party
happening, my belief is solid. Solid enough that I help the promoter
trek ravers up to the site.  Chatting with a few, I come across fellow
SFRavers (hi guys and gals) and we share the enthusiasm of the UG scene.

But we're not too enthusiastic @ 1AM when the other organizer says,
"that's it. it's too wet...".  I remember this promoter from a beach
party in some remarkably cold weather last year.  The cards of fate are
sure unkind to some...  We (about 50 or so partygoers) all head down the
hill, back to our cars, and head our separate ways. I trek home and
crawl into bed @ 3AM or so...

Saturday:

_Gathering_  (here comes the weird part)

So here I am with two newbes (their first rave being Galactic Tunnel
last week), our intentions were to be at this serious hardcore/ jungle
party in Oakland (_Riot 23_),  But afta calling the VM every 15 mins.
from 9PM till 10:30  we say, "Screw it, let got to a Massive".

We get three @ 11PM, No line.  The fine blend of herbs and spices I
inhaled are beginning to take effect.  As I walk in my mind, body,
spirit is "feeling" the crowd, the vibe. So many are here with different
intentions.  It's hard to focus...  My friends are saying something but
it's all quite far away  Im drawn to the front of the room, Ethans
spinning, I get down & start grooving.  I see Claire,  some of the other
"Family members" are around ... Im home again, part of the music, part
of the scene this is a massive but the underground "feel" is evident...
Am I connected -  Yes.

After ethan finishes his set  I decided its time to explore.  I wander
down this huge hallway, past a coat check,  There's a movie room playing
some claymation, I walk past the chill room and into the vending area.
I sneak up behind my friends who are looking around.  they're suprised
to "find" me smiling behind them like an idiot.  We trek back to the
movie room take a few puffs and start cracking jokes about life, TV, the
world.  We're in hysterics in less than 15minutes.  I look at this newbe
and see a reflection of my younger self, looking into the new world we
call the underground.  He's only  eighteen, the same age as I was when I
started. He's trying to connect. 

But there is still that competitive streak in both of them, they want to
"bust it"  and throw down in the house room.  I agree.  My essence is
drifting into  there reality. That other tribe.
*************************************

So check it, The 411 is that I'm OOC (out of commission) since
Ubiquitous.  Doing some serious footwork, I  Kneed it hard.  Keeping my
leg in straps (And still wearing a brace) I've been in the shadows for
the last few weeks...  So  once I hit the circle, I feel that vibe...
Some serious breakdancers doing flips, flops, flares, you name it.  This
is where the Pro's play,  You best have your set in or out be set out...
 I get my body into the vibe,  See the dancers, feel which ones "have
it", and which ones are acting...

There it is, Im there.  My mind is clear ,I know my path. I hit the
floor aware that my leg can't do the groundwork its accustomed to. So I
break into some fast stepping the crowd responds. A few lasers are on my
feet, the song bust into  a drumroll, im spinning fasta than an a
black'n'decker eggbeater.  I see  cigarette ashes on the floor. It's a
firewalk. Those "there" see it others are stupefied at the speed.  It's
all onbeat which make it more intense... 

I snap out. Back in a massive, the music's playing and someone is
patting me on the back.  I smile, I look back in the circle, someone is
"calling me out"  kicking out some splits with his walk.  I can go to
his level and start a "war"  a few other dancers eye me, they got's my
back.  But I don't wanto go there. Im thirsty. I turn, dissolve into the
crowd and get some water.
*************************************
I'm inline smiling:
"Umm, is this, like, the water line or something"
"No, it's over there"
"Ok"
I get to the right line and strike a conversation with (Sam?). His first
rave.  We chat all the way to the front of the water line.  He's amazed
at all the "cool" people here.  He's 26 and remembers breaking back in
the late 80's. I tell him I've been in the know for a wile and we both
"trade" stories. Im seeing the party though this guy's perspective.
Loud.  Cool. We depart at the water line and head into our separate
realities.  He's getting connected.

I hear the jungle throbbing through the walls.  I head back to the
"family" room and see others of our kind.  Ethans dancing in the front
of the room, I see some of the Harmony crew, Claire and Co. are still
around.  I see many new faces that are SFR by their attitude.  Run into
a Junglist that I see, oh, every month or so...  Shes from LA and
"cooling off outside"  I have my huge water bottle and share with
everyone. Only a couple of gulps from me and I pass it off to the
crowd...
I start going deep into the audio world of jungle. Some cute girl with a
(red, Orange?) shirt w/ a lil monster- type thingie on it ask me what DJ
is playing.  I tell her I have No Clue.. We smile at that response.  I
dance around more the vibe has caught me again. I can't control my body,
just letting the sound move me.  I rarely feel such freedom, not in this
world of computers, deadlines,  and paperwork.  I ask that girl for some
of her water we kneel and sip.  We both stay on the floor for a while,
both enwrapped in that serious jungle vibe.  I can't believe I can feel
this way, all of this is with just the music.  No E, no speed.  I try to
talk to her but I can't form words.  I glance her way smiling...
And we go our separate ways....
What happened?

Im back on the floor dancing I see another familiar face, a girl I know
from high school.  I was raving when she was doing her SAT's.  She asks
me what Im doing and I realize im sitting in a pile of clothes and
backpacks.  Wasn't I just dancing a minute ago?  Am I high?  Is it the
vibe?  I figure out that im living in the now of things, I can't
remember 5 minutes ago cos it already happened, all these thoughts are
rushing through my mind, yet im still holding a conversation with this
girl who's name I can't remember (oh, yea.. Hi Jen).  She puts her
backpack down and I still sit for a while longer before that wave of
music engulfs me again...  

Im walking back to get some more water and run into Thomas Trouble, we
chat about Karma III  it's gonna be the bomb I think, lotsa trance
allnight long.  Thomas is really excited about the venue, the sound
system, and the people. And Im ready for it (Friday -Dec 27th).  

Im dancing next to Ethan and offer him some water, the water bottle
disappears for a while but I really don't care.  If it's needed its
needed we all get thirsty out there. I see someone I don't recognize
reaching for a backpack I look at him and sense fear.  He looks back,
eyes wide and drops the backpack, he disappears in the crowd.
---I think I just stopped a theft.---
I get wrapped up in that reality , the cute orange shirt girl is gone,
the water bottle is no longer in existence.  I'm a guard of sorts,
watching out for my fellow scenesters.  I give a glance to people who
are unfamiliar to me.  I stay in this state for I don't know how long...
I know im getting paranoid.  But during this state this scene replays
itself at least four more times:

      Person A walks up to the DJ booth, he looks around.
Me:  I glance back at him, "message one:  Don't even think of it"
      He walks up to a backpack or jacket...
I step up a little more and focus more attention to him.
      He see me and gets it.  He bolts.

I cant stand it anymore. I don't like this reality.  I step away. and
wander out of the room.

Im in the movie room alone, laughing  my  A** off @ the Ren and Stimpy
Show.  As much as I want to chat with people, I feel mentally damaged
trying to wipe out the oh to real sense that everyone isn't as PLURRY as
we make them out...  Im drifiting. I want to dance for the vibes sake
again.
Trying to connect.
****************************************
Here's the deal,  Im stepping in the main room, I see about three
circles going .  I break off into a smaller  group and am dancing, the
place looks more like a giant chill area than a rave, many people just
standing around and watching us dancers than actually moving about.
Many E faces, fish bellies, or other wacked out folks are on the sides.
I try to find a vibe. or at least make my own.  Many times one or two
ruffnecks step up to take the Pepsi challenge and I hush them in their
puppies. Trix are for kids any many of them are just bunnies getting
jacked by this rabbit.  

What happened?  I snap back and noticed I was in yet another  circle.
The pros were stepping out now, as much as I wanted to bust with a flip
or flare I knew my knee would be most unforgiving in the morning.  So
off I go again...
************************************
Sitting back in the jungle room some one asks me for a cigarette,  I
offer her some alternate smokable instead.  We blend our, ahem, stuff
and chill for a but.  I see Steve S. Bouncing with energy which sparks
that vibe in me.. I  stand up and am dancing again in that junglish
state.  I see some others that are having a good time. failing arms in
the air.  And somewhere the music changes more into a breakbeatish type
vibe complete with scratching (although I think its the record not the
DJ).  Suddenly one of the two newbes I came with is there. we go
searching for the second one and find him shortly.  I ask someone and
find out it's 6:30. Im hungry.  We bail out while some girl is singing.

I had a great time, (I think).

And for the 2000+ people who don't know me, I was the guy in blue with a
Fall long sleeve shirt with concert dates on the back.

It is indeed the vibe that keeps me going.  I try to help create it by
dancing, or mixing when I get the chance.  And hopefully, maybe you too,
dear raver, see that truth.  I try to keep positive dispite the negative
that massives carry.  Maybe that's why I only do massives once a year...
 Maybe that's why I try to mix and help throw the UG's.  Maybe that's
why I have a underground mixtape circulating out there.  It's not THAT
great, but I think it's OK.  (oh, yea don't PAY for this tape it's a
freebe.  If you want one, send me an email and we can arrange
something.).  Let's be positive people, cos' no one is going to do it
for us...
Lets keep that vibe alive.  CU @ Karma. and Galactic Tunnel.

"just another weekend"
--_Adam


"Stay Connected..."

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Dec 23 12:51:11 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id MAA28046; Mon, 23 Dec 1996 12:51:11 -0800 (PST)

        Remember that saying & attitude? If I decide that somebody
        is scary based on their looks or whatever, it tends to
        activate this attitude in the person I've so judged.

        Strangely enough, non-judgement & fearlessness also seems
        to work well with the "real" wolves much of the time.


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Dec 23 13:00:05 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id NAA28564; Mon, 23 Dec 1996 13:00:05 -0800 (PST)
Received: from jetcity.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with ESMTP id NAA28558; Mon, 23 Dec 1996 13:00:01 -0800 (PST)
Received: from [204.201.228.121] (annex01-04.jetcity.com [204.201.228.104]) by jetcity.com (8.7.5/8.7.3) with ESMTP id NAA16852 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Mon, 23 Dec 1996 13:01:23 -0800
Date: Mon, 23 Dec 1996 13:01:23 -0800
X-Sender: jdarrow@mail.jetcity.com
Message-Id: <v03007801aee4213aab0b@[204.201.228.121]>
In-Reply-To: <32BEB88C.332F@pacbell.net>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: John Darrow <jdarrow@jetcity.com>
Subject: The Gathering.
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I had a great time at the Gathering, although admitedly the moments of pure
serene power were sparse and a bit unbalanced. That tends to be true at
most large massives, and seems to be getting more true as we get further
away from a certain point where everything got really focused in 1992...
but since then the Gathering and other similar parties have always done
very well at bringing me back to that original point, and I was very
exicted and satisfied with what happened on Saturday night. I'm always
amazed at the sheer number of diverse people that can come together and
contribute toward a single (more or less) cause... that is, if nothing
else, letting go of their regular life and having fun with all these other
people, opening the doorway for mysterious new music and forces to enter
their lives. And with so many people it can really be quite a struggle
getting everyone to let go just enough to keep the energy flowing... but it
always happens, even if we only get to feel it for a second, that moment
when everyone resonates in synch and the energy shoots off toward infinity.
That moment when healing occurs, that moment that is so powerful that a
memory is forged into your mind with such force that you can never forget
it. That's why I will always love massives... even though it's not always a
smooth or easy ride, those moments are such incredible experiences, and
provide the starting points for such grand new dreams.
>
>It seems like the concept of shared trance is fading at these massives.
>
>I'm so happy I went over to the smaller room and caught garth's set.  It
>was nice
>to find a good vibe in there.  I found the vibe to be pretty good in that room
>all night when I would go.  I kept going back to the main room because I
>wanted
>to hear other music besides the jungle that was playing and to listen to
>the bigger

I think as the scene develops and grows, it develops habits. It gets
expectations. In the beginning, it was the transcending of these habits and
expectations that created such an incredible experience... now, we are
struggling... because the vehicle by which we first found this transcension
is now so full of routine and order that it's no longer the door to a new
world, just back into the old one. As a whole, the rave scene is still
newer than most of things we deal with in life, and still provides an
incredible experience... but I see that as fading as time goes on, unless
you personally can realize your routines and find a way to alter them. I
think the concept of shared trance is closely tied in with this, in that
the motivation for letting go of yourself, putting yourself into that
trance state, is in seeking for change. Seeking those other worlds. People
aren't as interested in seeking anymore because they have fallen into the
routine of going to the party. They know what goes on already, so why
should they look for something else. It's a bit of a curse, really. The
answer to the question must keep changing in order to keep itself alive. If
it doesn't change, it starts to decay. But there is a solution. Every new
idea or change has a starting point, namely you. If people aren't dancing,
they will continue not to dance until you start. Forget about all of them
and just start moving to the music. Then everyone will follow. If people
aren't listening to the music, it's up to you to listen. Stop paying
attention to the people who aren't listening and start listening. Soon
enough you will find swarms of people all intently listening to the music,
which will lead everyone toward the shared trance experience.

>Sorry if some of you didn't like some of my venting about the vibe.  I can't
>help but have some major concerns about this scene that I love so much
>and has brought me so much joy.
>Is there a way we can get more people to experience the joys of trancing
>together?
>Maybe I should just try to focus more on the people who do enjoy it, and maybe
>others will catch on.
>Or maybe I need to except the tranceformation that is happening, and give up
>on the hope of having a vibe at a massive like the full moon partys at
>bonny doon.

The scene must change in order to survive. If it doesn't it will get stale
and eventually die. But that means that you must be willing to change along
with it, if you want to continue to share in the incredible experiences
that it can give you. The massives have just as much of a vibe as smaller
parties... sometimes far stronger ones because of all the people
involved... but it is often more difficult to get ourselves to the point
where we can appreciate it. And then when we get there, it might only be
for a fleeting moment before we lose our balance and fall again. It is we
who have to let ourselves go if we want to witness the incredible.
Everything begins and ends with you. and I do mean everything. The vibe you
experience streams from you alone... and it can move through 50 other
people or it can include 10,000 other people... but ultimately you are the
one who must come to terms with it and control it. You must initiate it and
be willing to keep it going, reaccepting it when it comes back to you. If
you close yourself off, fall into routines or develop expectations that
open the possibility of failure, you will find yourself struggling to keep
yourself truly living.

And back to the party...
The sound was great (well balanced), the music was mostly excellent. I
really enjoyed the small room. Sometimes the bass in that room had all my
bones vibrating. It was a neat sensation dancing with that. The large room
had a couple awe inspiring musical moments but with so many people
wandering around aimlessly I had a hard time focusing myself on it. I would
keep forgetting to listen. And socially, I saw lots of very nice people,
and ran into some long lost friends I haven't seen for over a year.
Dancing-wise, I danced for about six or seven hours before my body went
kaputt, and enjoyed every minute of it.

and for Todd, it's always in the darkest hour when the miracles begin.

-john.

--------
by Frank Cammuso and Hart Seely          57 ELM STREETBETHLEHEM,
PA.11:51 P.M., DECEMBER 24TH          We're too late! It's already been
here.           
Mulder, I hope you know what you're doing.           Look, Scully, just
like the other homes: Douglas fir, truncated, mounted, transformed into
a shrine; halls decked with boughs of holly; stockings hung by the
chimney, with care.          You really think someone's been here?
    
Someone, or something.          Mulder, over here-it's a fruitcake.
     Don't touch it!  Those things can be lethal.           It's O.K.
There's a note attached: "Gonna find out who's naughty and nice."
  It's judging them, Scully.  It's making a list.           Who?  What
are you talking about?           Ancient mythology tells of an obese
humanoid entity who could travel at great speed in a craft powered by
antlered servants.  Once each year, near the winter solstice, this
creature is said to descend from the heavens to reward its followers and
punish disbelievers with jagged chunks of antracite.          But that's
legend, Mulder-a story told by parents to frighten children.  Surely you
don't believe it?          Something was here tonight, Scully.  Check
out the bite marks on this gingerbread man.  Whatever tore through this
plate of cookies was massive-and in a hurry.          It left crumbs
everywhere.  And look, Mulder, this milk glass has been completely
drained.
          It gorged itself, Scully.  It fed without remorse.
But why would they leave it milk and cookies?           Appeasement.
Tonight is the Eve, and nothing can stop its wilding.          But if
this thing does exist, how did it get in?  The doors and windows were
locked.  There's no sign of forced entry.          Unless I miss my
guess, it came through the fireplace.           Wait a minute, Mulder.
If you're saying some huge creature landed on the roof and came down
this chimney, you're crazy.  The flue is barely six inches wide.
Nothing could get down there.          But what if it could alter its
shape, move in all directions at once?          You mean, like a bowl
full of jelly?           Exactly.  Scully, I've never told anyone this,
but when I was a child my home was visited.  I saw the creature.  It had
long white shanks of fur surrounding its ruddy, misshapen head.  Its
bloated torso was red and white.  I'll never forget the horror. I turned
away, and when I looked back it had somehow taken on the facial features
of my father.          Impossible.          I know what I saw.  And that
night it read my mind.  It brought me a Mr. Potato Head, Scully.  It
knew that I wanted a Mr. Potato Head!          I'm sorry, Mulder, but
you're asking me to disregard the laws of physics.  You want me to
believe in some supernatural being who soars across the skies and brings
gifts to good little girls and boys. Listen to what you're saying.  Do
you understand the repercussions? If this gets out, they'll close the
X-files.          Scully, listen to me: It know when you're sleeping.
It knows when you're awake.          But we have no proof.          Last
year, on this exact date, SETI radio telescopes detected bogeys in the
airspace over twenty-seven states.  The White House ordered a Condition
Red.         But that was a meteor shower.          Officially.  Two
days ago, eight prized Scandinavian reindeer vanished from the National
Zoo, in Washington, D.C.  Nobody-not even the zookeeper-was told about
it.  The government doesn't want people to know about Project Kringle.
They fear that if this thing is proved to exist the public will stop
spending half its annual income in a holiday shopping frenzy.  Retail
markets will collapse.  Scully, they cannot let the world believe this
creature lives.  There's too much at stake.  They'll do whatever it
takes to insure another silent night.         Mulder, I-         Sh-h-h.
 Do you hear what I hear?           On the roof.  It sounds like...a
clatter.          The truth is up there.  Let's see what's the matter. 
"Stay Connected..."

Lee

God your review and the other big one a few before it are what the Dance
Trades should be about!!! 

Even tho' 2 different people have a 180 degree take on Saunderson (did
he do that wack "Rock to the Beat" song? ...some old master did it...)
it's nice that someone will express an opinion on one of the "Gods of
Techno" and willing to take a shot at our "holy cow."

These reviews are really nice for us out in the boonies as it's almost
like going to a mini rave while reading the post--excellent descriptions
that almost make you feel there especially if you put on some music
while reading.

It's kind of funny hearing the stuff that annoys people at events there
coz when you are in the country you feel like "Send us your cheesiest
dance promoters...please!  We'll take them...) and I guess it's nice you
big city folk can get spoiled  :)

If you don't write for some mag you should --I really enjoyed your post.

I must protest alittle here.

  I myself cannot do speed. My body is just not constructed for such
abusive substances.
  I am sorry that I don't express love at your parties Qeoff. I wish I
could but I can't, I tryed, and I will not fake it.
  Unfortunetly for me, taking E creates even more walls. I cannot open up
on the shit. I can not socialize on the shit. All it does for me, is free
me of the retchid pain of dancing, to hard and to long.
  Alot of people that see me, think I do WAYYY to much speed. I've heard
it, I will hear it agian. I don't do it!

  But anyways.  For my sake.  Why don't you just concentrate on having a
good time. Don't worry about that guy over there that doesn't seem to be a
nice / open individual. 
 And, you don't know. You don't know what he is thinking, you don't know if
he has good or bad intentions. And you don't know if he is on speed. If it
really concerns you though, maybe you should go up and ask the person if he
is having a good time or not. Try to understand the person alittle.
 You might of had a better time knowing that thoughs Borgs were enjoying
them selves as much as you were.


Something like that.
Jeff

Okay, once again I found out that I'm going to be hosting Monday Night
Dinner! :) Which is cool, but between everyone being gone for holiday
vacation and all, I'm not too sure what sort of interest there is,
and I have yet to come up with a place to eat...

So this week's pre-Mad dinner is going to be a bit more *interactive*
(love those buzzwords! :) than usual. What I need from _you_ is a quick
email note (in private please!) telling me:

1) If you're interested in having dinner with a bunch of wacky raver
types/computer geeks (and who wouldn't be???) tonight.
2) Any suggestions for dinner. Note that it should reasonably priced
and be able to accommodate vegetarians and vegans (and in SF).

As always, dinner will be at 8:30pm, and afterwards, we go to Mad at
the lovely and fabulous Bahia Cabana at Market and Franklin. This
week is an extra good lineup, too! (Ethan, Joe Rice, and Alex)

So sorry for the last minute notice... Also, if you can't get to your
email later, call the saturn5 line; I should have some info posted there:

415.248.1997 (saturn5)

I'll post to the list later on with where we're going, and also put it
up on the voicemail (along with directions).

Steve

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Dec 23 16:02:24 1996

          23 Dec 96 15:52 PST

Date: Mon, 23 Dec 1996 15:51:47 +0000
From: "DJ ASB (CMG Records) =?iso-8859-1?Q?Ay=99?=" <cmgmedia@razorlogic.com>
Organization: virtual models
X-Mailer: Mozilla 3.0Gold (Macintosh; I; PPC)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Adidas at Raves WARNING: PARODY TO FOLLOW (PG-13)

Wussup

Wearing Nike Air ACG shoes, a hooded blue plaid shirt bought at the Main
(& only) Mall up here, baggy brown corderoy shorts (Mall) over a
Canadian full length wooley
(Army Navy)

I got a Nike pencil bag I carry my checkbook in
And a bunch of other stuff like dat coz I like Nike

Despite that Nike goes back before rap music I 've never found a
better--more comfortable shoe and I've done a lot of hiking

If you dance a lot and notice how your feet break easily when you break
you appreciate the most well engineered walking shoe.

Nike consistently comes up with ravish (futuristic) designs, check out
their Air Moccasins my vote for The Rave Dancing Shoe

OK so you can buy the complete gangsta outfit in any American
mall--Isn't it funny that a lot of malls won't let groups of gangsta
looking dudes in?

You used to have to work a little for the gangsta look but now you can
just drive up to the mall and have a gangsta makeover

I think a lot of early ravers liked to wear that pop look from the
sixties with plastic bright clothes like Deelite, and huge garish logos
were modeled after the cheesiest things like Tide cartons remember?

To me rave was about James Bond (Mod) futuristic gadgets which I guess
is a ruboff from working with high tech gear like samplers and recording
studios but it seemed like rave was about jumping into the future before
it got here, like the Jetsons (old skool Bart Simpson in the future, air
cars, etc)

When it hit the West Coast the people most sympathetic to it were mostly
hippy types who have a whole 'nother value system based on a lot of
guilt for being white <I couldn't resist that cheap joke forgive me  :>
but the irony of history huh?>

Besides slowing down the frenzy of Techno to a more mello Trance and
House BPM the whole laid back West Coast vibe kind of replaced the Pop
aspect of Rave with the Hippy value system descended from the Deadhead
movement.

My point being as to the previous reference to Adidas (never liked LL
Cool J that much either) which is a staple of the Corporate Hip Hop
Gangsta (tm) look do you think the Army would rather turn a Gangsta into
a killing machine or a Hippy into a killing machine?... 

Well all you have left are Alternative Rockers and they are basically
Hippys (somebody correct me on this.)

My whole point is that if one shops carefully, one can either have the
Corporate Hippy (Alternative) (tm) look; the Corporate Hip Hop Gangsta
(tm) look;  or the Corporate Pop Mod New Wave (tm) look, aka Corporate
Rave look for about the same cost.

Now Hip Hop followers have their own way to acquire the look at a low
cost but that subject belongs on another list.

Obviously the real old skool Hippies do not want to pay money for
clothing (why do we have to wear clothes anyway...everybody get nekked!"
it's just a material thing and it's all part of this Maya which is Hindu
for Illusion.

Any Buddhist will tell you the same thing but these days if you shop for
authentic imported Tibetan doo-dads like a lot of rich Hippys wear you
will pay way more than for a well researched Gangsta makeover.

Which brings us to the subject of Corporate Rave (tm) (boo-hiss) the
Evil Empire of the Rave Philosophy (tm).  

I say now that every newjack raver is striving for more authenticity,
which leads to that Hippy/anarchic lifestyle (have you ever priced a lot
of the baggy, torn up, hip surfer designer shorts the authentic
Deadheads wear, apparently for most of their puberty? <I mean the same
pair :) > 

Despite the authentic never washed look which might have changed their
color, you can usually catch a swank designer label like Stussy or
Jeanco that go for $50-$60 a pair (unless shopping around) at your local
Mall.

Not that the custom designer farmer johns ($90-$150) you see at WC raves
are cheap, check your local surf/sk8/snoboard shop.

Now you can always tell a real Hippy from an Alternative newjack because
a real Hippy always got their clothes at Salvation Army or another
thrift store (see...this kewl Paisley shirt only cost me $1.50!!!...)
though of course some will make their own clothes or give them away.  

The Alternative Rocker wears a descendant of the WC Surfer look which to
be authentic must have a pair of Levi's 501's (buttons only) and a plaid
shirt from Pennys or Sears--though now you can buy the cheap imported
plaid shirts for almost less than a T-Shirt (shop around) and still look
Alternative.  Throw in a name down jacket like North Face and the
Alternative Grunge look can skyrocket way over a full blown Gangsta look
in cost.

What is the answer re non-materialism posed by the previous reference to
Adidas logos at a party?  

You better give up music people coz all your records are made of plastic
and the factories that turn out plastic are also poisoning the
enviroment, besides all the chemicals that go into manufacturing a hi-fi
setup or the computer you are using.

If you really want to approach the full effect of being non-material I
suggest becoming a Buddhist.  Also I got my Nike ACG's for about the
same cost as that eighth of green bud you bought for $50 that lasts a
few days and is gone. 

Has anyone ever wondered how your average Hippy can afford to pay more
for an oz. or two than many of us pay in rent?

My Nike's are helping to keep some Asian or Mexican employed as all of
our jobs are being shopped off to third world countries so we can afford
this Corporate Rave (tm) lifestyle with authentic logos.
 
By the way the odds are the DJ's at your gig used a pair of
Technics1200's that approach $1200 a pair list and if they are like the
swanky-dankey DJ's in Europe who have gone mad for mixer designs then
their mixer prob'ly cost about  $600-$1200 also, whereas you could have
a comparable rig with the $240 Gemini or Lineartech 1200 knockoffs and a
$100 Gemini PMX-15A mixer (the best scratch mixer) for way less, and
nobody would notice the difference on the dancefloor.

Forget about the Denon DN-2700 Dual CD player with sampling & pitch
control for $2300.

So at least you got the right idea.  

But you may notice a lot of DJ types go for the Corporate Hip Hop
Gangsta (tm) look also, probably because DJ's have always looked that
way, and if you don't want to stand out in a crowd and still face down a
gang of wanna-be gangstas at your local mall (it could happen you never
know--people are getting shot in malls these days) then the above look
will probably work, and don't you think the Hippy/Alternative, Surfer,
and GQ looks are just as played out?

But nowdays only the Illuminati can tell a B-Boy from a Gangsta or a
DJ--

How Did Big Logos Become In?

I'm working on that one, it's a delicate socialogical subject that as a
Caucasian  person perhaps I'm not fit to answer. Processing.

Ah...in the breakdance days if you did spins and things on the ground or
if you pop-locked like where you roll around on your ankles and stuff
it's nice to have thick padded high top basketball shoes to support your
ankles and so you don't skin your ankles.

The pop-lockers and breakdancers performing on the street usually
started to one-up each other and flashy matching track suits and
colorful shoes were part of the ritual and the show biz of street skilz.

Shoe makers picked up on this trend (clever those marketing types) and
I'd bet B Boys and Breakdancers did more to create the current style of
flashy BB shoes than all these little basketball stars...

It's kind of funny coz all those crews had names like XXX Posse  or
Wrecking Krew (who is doze guys?) and nowadays in England and Scotland
all those guys into Top 40 House :) call their krews "posse" & "krew."

Anyway I'm not doggin' ya your post got me hysterical and this corporate
rave thing is my theme--I think the radicals should jack the corporate
rave apparatus and be driving Mercedes Benz's & Porshes just like the
rappers.  Materialistic?  Go back to bongos and flutes if you want to be
pure--a big sound system or music production setup can cost thousands
these days.

Is it just me or is this same phenomena playing out re Roland 303's and
909's, besides the Technics mania.  The Roland R-8 Mk II just about
beats those machines with envelope control, etc. not that I don't love
analog (yes you can dump those old analogs on me if they are just
sitting around  :)

I was invited to spin at a "non-commercial" underground up here with a
bunch of "family" hippy types but when I mentioned I mostly spun
cassettes (because a fire took out my studio and record collection--I
got tons of dubs from DJ friends and wanted to spend my money on
production gear instead of vinyl or CD's) I got the total stinkeye like
I was a wack amateur <people I scratch mix records--not just spin them>
(so much for non-materialistic hippys.)

In my club DJ days I found that cassettes will play at much higher
volumes than vinyl or CD's as tables will skip and have stylus feedback
and CD's will not track right either, unless you are in an isolated
booth with a seperate monitor system and I hate that setup preferring to
be in the room with the dancers and being able to tweek the room EQ to
suit each song.

Technically a cassette is just as analog as vinyl and you'd have to
think that magnetic oxide could capture more detail than physically
molded plastic grooves (boo-hiss...I can hear the dissing) though it's
harder to beat match and cue up.

Also a real AAA recording would be magnetic oxide all the way (before
you all pass out from apoplexy yes I love 1200's and scratching on
them--and vinyl does sound great, etc. but they are getting way
overblown and overpriced, probably due to the 1200 fad--Technics gotta
be laughing at the CD industry  :)

It's just that as we make all these "sacred cows" and every newjack has
to get a 1200, a 909 and 303 ten years after--- it's almost enough
reason to chuck those machines and try to produce stuff with whatever
you can get your hands on---there's lots or "Ravish" little boxes that
do it all---like Yamaha's little "Nintendo" SY series or Rolands new
MC-303, besides in the latter all the work's been done for you---built
in drum and bass loops, etc.

Make an "all digital" mix; make an "all analog" mix;  make an
analog/digital blend mix; get a blender out of the kitchen and make an
industrial mix, etc.

I'm burnt out reading Mix Magazine (the big slick recording studio rag,
not the English DJ mag) where you feel an inferiority complex if you
haven't traded in your 16 or 18 bit system for a 20 to 24 bit digital
audio workstation starting at $150,000

So my current project is just using an old 808 (yeah it's all I have
besides the DX and some general MIDI sets) and turntables/scratch mixing
to do some minimalist Electro style jams--it's a little more challenging
to make a mix live to tape than relying on the ease of a computer
sequencer.

Better yet use the Roland GM set that comes with Quicktime or use MOD
sample loops--which is probably gonna be the trend for the next decade
because it lets anybody get in the game.

So if you want to get into record production you better brace yourself
for the materialistic, cliquish, mucho dinero, faddish high tech rat
race or else people like you won't buy the record if it wasn't made with
303's & 909's and played for your massive on some 1200's

War & Peace Out

DJ ASB

my analysis was not based strictly on the observation of individuals.  When you have been
immersed in drug culture for a long time you learn to sense the signature vibe associated
with heavy use of each substance, Our bodies are made up of mostly water and our nervous systems utilize electricity to trigger
movement and send information around.
It's no big deal for sensitive individuals to get "contact highs" by just being in a room with people who are doing a lot of a
particular substance.

Also the use of meth makes people smell a certain way :)

Hi all!  =)

 What a great time!! I havn't been to a large party in so long. And I 
really wanted to go. I knew a lot of people who were going and the DJ 
lineups looked really good.

Great stuff;

 Saying hi to Richard Sun from Ambient Temple Of Imagination. We had 
worked together at a party called Beltane a number of years ago (at the 
Fashion Center in the basement). Richard invited me to join him and I 
contributed some vocal stuff (alien languages, musings, semi-tortured 
sounds). Then Richard pointed to the the coffin and told me to mix 
something up. ACK!! I'm a CD man myself and had never touched a 1200 and 
mixer before. My virgin spinning experience was at the Gathering. I SPUN 
AT THE GATHERING!!!!!! But I must say it didn't last long.  =)

 Being shown around by Eric Reynolds (MODA) including where the nice 
bathrooms were. Eric is the bomb in my opinion. Check out his new mix 
tape. I've only heard side A and I really loved it!!

 Really experiencing John Williams (aka Greg's idol) for the first time. The 
man is good! Thanks to Greg for cluing me in.

 Hanging with the Harmony crowd!!  =)

 Meeting Martin. A very serious worker yet able to take time out to be 
silly. Great party Martin!!

 Handing out polished stones, crystals, petrified wood, and obsidian 
arrowheads to random people! It was kinda funny watching people get a 
suspicious look on their face or actually try to avoid me when I offered 
them "free rocks?". It seems most folks appreciated the gesture. What was 
really touching yet very amusing was when folks would offer me money 
after I had already told them it was free. It was reallly fun giving some 
stones to a few of the security people.

 Handing out choclate covered expresso beans.

 Seeing Liquid 7 and Madame Mercury!  =)

 Seeing Terry and his laminates!!

 Seeing Leslie.

 The crowd. Overall a very good feeling with a minimal of hard looks. 
although after talking to all the people who had stuff swiped I'm really 
glad I used the coat check for my backpack.

 Coatcheck people were awesome!  =)

 Meeting the guy who wigged at Phreaky People. He is okay (a little 
strung out looking though) and we exchanged apologies for such an unhappy 
situation. His name is David and he apologises to everyone at Phreaky 
People for trippin' too hard. I gave him some choclate coverd expresso beans.

Less than great;

 I felt the decorations were a bit sparse (and unplanned) but some of it 
looked really good; like the jungle rooms white cloth streamers and 
strobe light circle.
 Also, for a $20 to $25 entry fee I was very dissapointed at the lack of 
intelligent lighting. This would have really made the main floor spectacular.
 Also, I felt that a 3 watt laser was a bit sparse for the main floor. A 
5 watt laser would have been so much nicer.

 The concrete floors were difficult for me to dance on so I didn't do much.

 The ambient room was a little scary looking. The ambient control station 
area was cool but the rest was tacky or uninviting (the mattresses laying 
everywhere made it look like a cheap sex parlor to me).



 Overall a really fun time!! Thanks to everyone I met and partied with! =) 


hugz,


 Ran D.Dreams



                                      (Namaste)
                                         /
                                   -=*=-/
                                     ~

Hey, all!

	I've noticed (and read comments from many others) that it's
difficult to dance on concrete/cement floors, but not so difficult on
hardwood floors.  Does anyone know why?  I thought the shoes I just bought,
which are very springy, would help me to bounce, but my steppin' was
hampered at the Gathering.  What are the relative merits (pros & cons) of
different surfaces upon which to dance?
Curious,
Eric

> From: Eric P. Peterson <ericp@best.com>

> Hey, all!

bought,

> Eric

i have taken dance classes for years, always on wooden floors, because
cement can damage your joints(knees, ankles).  cement is much thicker and
harder than wood so cement absorbs the entire shock of your dancing, while
wood allows
for some spring.  this is what i have gathered through my years of dancing.
i hope this helps answer your question.
pixie

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Dec 24 00:12:00 1996

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

  I like both cement and wooden floors. Slick tile is better than the both
of em. But nothing tops a basketball court.
  I don't think one is harder to dance on than the other. Once I break out
in a sweat, another energy compounds with the music.
 I could be dancing in a boxing rink, or I could be out doors in the dirt.
I am still going to look just as silly.  =]:..
  But I do think that some floors are harder on your body than others.
  I think bouncing is just a matter of good balance. I find it harder to
balance on the dance floor sometimes with new shoes.

Pros & Cons
---------------------
Wood       Pro: People feel you stomp your feet three yards away.
              Con: Possibility that you might fall into the cellar.
Cement    Pro: You get a rush through your body while stomping.
              Con: Hard to get all the dust off before a ravE.
Tile          Pro: Slick scratching surface for dancing to Carlos.
              Con: Possibility of sitting on a peace of gum, or a
lollpypop.
Court        Pro: People feel you stomp your feet 15 yards away.
              Con: Dancing tell unconcious.

> WAIT. How can we keep the DJ community ELITE without imposing some sort o=
f
> BARRIER TO ENTRY (e.g. equipment $$$)???

its a technology.. and is something that must be understood in that=20
fashion along with artistic medium..  oil painters get enough cash to buy=
=20
oil and canvas and studio space.. why should DJs have everything handed=20
to them? i dont consider it elitism.. i consider it the price of=20
entering the profession..  btw although i'm not a top ranked dj .. i did=20
some of my best prep work on turntables  one with no pitch and another=20
with a ltd pitch wheel.. and an ancient basic mixer with no face and a=20
beat up amp and cheap assed speakers.. all of which cost about 50 bucks=20
and new cartidges and styli.   even more.. i did my radio show in Ottawa=20
with turntables with no pitch and only friends home studios to practice=20
on.. if anyone has the gift.. and cant afford it  there are always enough=
=20
nice people around with the equipment who are eventually willing to let=20
you practice.  its easy to look at it as elitist if you are anti-social=20
and dont make a basic effort to make friends  of course i could be seen=20
as guilty of such lately.. but i havent the cash to go to events yet. =20
does that make all the rave attendees elitist?  nah.. its just life.


>=20

few tape decks have pitch.. Marantz do and they're hella pricy.
as for vinyl.. that all depends on where you do your shopping  huh.. if=20
you want to dj  expect an upfront cost of at least 100 bucks a month ..=20
and if your just an occasional consumer.. theres notthing wrong with=20
having a sexy double or triple vinyl package at the same price as a cd. =20
(vinyl is not grown on trees and i dont think its an easily renewable=20
resource.. therefore..)

as well  you can   in some places  buy used vinyl releases at those above=

mentioned prices.

My Gathering highlights:

1. Seeing Ran "Dionysus D" Kohn and his guest Barbara. (Thanks for the
comment on my tape. BTW....Anyone still want a complimentary copy....email
privately)

2. How many times did I hear "Where's the DJ booth?". Centered DJ, let's see
what party uses this technique next?!

3. Watching the main room DJs painstakingly glue their ears to the floor
monitors
 
4. Stepping on and getting stepped on in the dark

5. Seeing Martin smile when the clicker hit 3000

6. Receiving an SFRaves laminate from Terry

7. Coatcheck...great idea!

8. Polished floors!! kudos to MO'B.

:) MODA

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Eric P. Peterson wrote:

>         I've noticed (and read comments from many others) that it's
> difficult to dance on concrete/cement floors, but not so difficult on
> hardwood floors.  Does anyone know why?  I thought the shoes I just bought,
> which are very springy, would help me to bounce, but my steppin' was
> hampered at the Gathering.  What are the relative merits (pros & cons) of
> different surfaces upon which to dance?

As mentioned, concrete does not give at all, whereas wood usually does
-- unless it's just sitting on top of concrete.  More give = less shock
to the knees, ankles, etc.

For hard dancing I recommend:
-lightweight shoes (less momentum = less shock)  Doc Martens are qool
and all, but weigh a ton.  And unless I'm at someplace with a mosh pit I
don't need the steel caps.
-sport insoles (Sorbothane, SOF, etc.) intended for running

The insoles make a BIG difference for me.  Get full-length (not just
heel cups), as most dancing seems to happen on the balls of the feet.

// grigs

>Not to mention the fact that Vinyl is now more expsneive than CDs... I like
>vinyl, don't get me wrong, but in the old days, 12" EPs cost $2.99-$4.99.
>Now everything is DOUBLE. Vinyl is elite in itself.  You can buy cheap CD
>players with pitch controls. You can use tapes- lots of cassette decks have
>pitch controls.
>

If you play domestics, like, say, hmm, Detroit labels =), singles are $3.99
if you order from the source, $5.99 if you buy them locally, so it's
possible to find decent records for a reasonable amount of money. Imports
have gone up in price, but I can't remember ever buying an import for less
than $7, even back in '87 or '88.

It's worth saving up for, although it does tend to take over your life, and
much of your paycheck...

Joe

It is me!  I'm back to work from this weekend.  For all who did not know it
was my b-day on Sunday.

I went to Microns house and spun a few records after we ate this very good
tai food on haight.  So we head off to HomeBase and there is no line. =)
We walk in and my one friend I brought was picking up his jaw from the
floor all night long.  It was his first time and he had so much fun.

Anyways my high lights for the gathering are:

Alex "fucking" Patterson!!!!!!!!!!  This guy ripped it up, Oh my God!
Malcom X!!!!!!  This is one bad ass jungle dj.
Ethen!!!!!  Dude you tore it up
Joe Rice!!!!!  Excellent  (even though ethen and joe played at the same
time I still heard a little of both) =)
Garth!!!! as usual.

The chill room in general was the bomb!!!!!!

All the people I saw: Terry, Jay, Micron, Libby, Ethan, Li, Sharon, Larry,
Eric, Mosha(sp), Josh, Lots of new people, I can't remember for the life of
me any more names.  You all know who you are! =)  Till next time!!!!!!

The venue was believe it or not my first time there.  I enjoyed it very
much for a MASSIVE!  I have one complaint and I have seen it for many years
so this complaint is worthless, but I would like to say something about it!
Wortheless only becuase I know it wont stop!!!

PLEASE! PLEASE! PLEASE!  Keep your public sex at home.  Jeesh, people you
made me sick.  I can't believe the nerve some people have out there.  Lets
be a little more aware of our drugs we take and try and keep it under
control.  I have been seeing alot of young people really getting messed up
on drugs and letting them selves go.  Young or old we need to have some
sort of awareness when taking substances.  Know your surroundings.  Please!
It was very sad to see some things I saw at the gathering...  Sex is for
private venues not public venues!  I know what I'm saying is not going to
mean a damn thing to the people who do this, but shit I saw really messed
up people not even knowing that there was someone messing with them.  Very
sad folks!  Very sad! =(

On my b-day note, thanks to all the people that said happy b-day to me.
You guys made my night the best b-day ever!  I danced my ass off in the
jungle room so much that I spent almost a hundred dollars on all jungle
tunes last night!=)

And to top it off my boss just gave me $100 dollars for a x-mas present! =)

Thank you all so much for being there with me!


Peace!






Siphon!

Hello all!

	I'm very excited and pleased to say I'm back :)  I waited two weeks
to do this, although I couldn't wait to post my dancefloor question.
Anyway, for those who don't know me, I've been going to parties for two
years (September was my anniversary).  I was introduced to the scene by the
Harmony crew, a wonderful bunch of people (meet 'em!).  My first party was
Jeremiah's E party, and the tickets looked like Disneyland E tickets,
laminated.  It took the first year to figure out some of the differences in
musical styles, and I'm still learning and loving it all :)  It's been
during this past year that I discovered two of my favorite elements of a
rave: vibe and trancing out.  These two things, which work best in
combination, are sooo good for the body, mind, and spirit, when they're
good.  Truly amazing things can happen while dancing :)
	For those of you who know me (there are still a few, right?), I'm
glad to be back, and It's been great keeping in touch with some of you,
even if it was only at parties!  I see many have gone or are going away for
a while.  To those who are I say: best of luck to you, hope to have ya back
before too long.
	Lessee, what else?  Oh, yeah, I'm a Scorpio (beware intensity of
emotion!), I was born during the same few days that Jerry Garcia chose the
name Grateful Dead, the same year of the Watts Riots and not too far from
them (L.A. area).  I've been living in the South Bay since I was four.  I
love beautiful, psychedelic trance, goa trance, any kind of trance that's
not too hard and slamming; I like techno that's not too industrial
sounding, and I like jungle, though most of it I can't dance to ;)
	So, that's me.  I truly believe in trying to live by the concepts
of Peace, Love, Unity, and Respect.  I consider myself Christian, but only
because I follow the wisdom of the one known as Christ, and I'm interested
in exploring other philosophies and faiths, because I believe that
organized religion is largely about control, while faith is a personal
relationship with the divine, a little of which I believe resides in each
of us.
Love to all, peace, joy and many blessings, and hope to see ya out there soon!
Eric

Received: (from robertr@localhost) by klaatu.autodesk.com (8.7.5/8.7.3) id LAA20839 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Tue, 24 Dec 1996 11:12:06 -0800 (PST)
Date: Tue, 24 Dec 1996 11:12:06 -0800 (PST)
From: Rob Rayle <robertr@autodesk.com>
Message-Id: <199612241912.LAA20839@klaatu.autodesk.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: The Gathering
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


	I had a great time. It seemed to have chaotic energy flowing
in many directions, rather than a unified vibe. This was my first massive,
so I don't really have any reference to compare it to. I met several people,
some from the list, and amazingly ran into some people I had met the nite
before at the dregs of a dark rained-out Stargate (amazing because
none of us could recognize each other by sight and there were only about
10 people there anyway - we just happened to start talking about it - 
what are the odds.) Gave away glowsticks & Gatorade (on one level I 
think of a rave as an athletic event - maybe that explains the 
Addidas too). 


	I thought that they did a great job quelling the warehouse-ness 
of the space. Creating a room with a parachute in a warehouse works well. 
The Stonhenge thing was cool, too. Really excellent overall.

	But it can always be done better - so:

	The hardcore/techno room (the one right near the entrance) had some
acoustic & sound problems. The slapback echo on the bass was really noticeable 
in there - probably a function of the room's shape. It seems like something
was distorting or being overdriven - those bass kicks seemed to be turning 
into square waves, which probably means something was clipping. The sound was
so bad in there I couldn't stay & dance, even though I would have preferred
that to what they were spinning in the big room. Oh well. My email course 
"Gain-staging for DJs" is available free to anyone on the list. If you're a
DJ and you don't understand terms like "gain staging", "clipping", "signal 
chain", and "square wave" you *need* to send me mail *now*.

	Sound in the big room was good. Roughly square room with an open
wall. I did most of my dancing in there. The quadrant nearest the open wall 
had the added benefit of more breathable air - aaaah. Excellent. Nice visuals
too.

	Chill room - sound was always good in there. During the early part of 
the evening it was just mind blowingly loud. Loud is often good, but I don't go 
into an ambient room to get my head blown off. It seems like it was louder in 
there than the main room - probably because the speakers were closer in. It was 
packed with people & the air in there was thick with smoke. Does anybody ever 
think of bringing in some big fans to keep the air moving? Later in the evening 
they turned it down, the crowd & air thinned out a bit, and it got really nice.


	Where's the trance music?

	I've heard reports of public sex!!! How the hell did I miss that?! 
All I saw was a little harmless kissing & hugging. Damn! I've GOT to start 
paying more attention to what everybody else is doing & quit all this dancing 
& trancing. Oh well. Could somebody start cruisin around with a spotlite or 
something, just for the benefit of people like me? Please?

Mad last night was *extra* good! Ethan played such a hard, crunchy set
that despite the fact that I was exhausted, it inspired me to dance my
ass off. :) Also, the sound that night was much better than it had
been in the past. Even though it was still the Gateway system, the
bass was really tight and punchy. I understand some repairs where done
to the system, and the difference was really noticeable.

And the vibe was superb! Despite the fact that everyone in the city is
out of town for the holidays, they still managed to pack the dance
floor with good people and positive energy.

Also, I wanted to wish everyone a happy holiday season... I'm leaving
for San Diego in a few hours, and although I'll miss San Francisco,
it'll be nice to catch some sun for a few days. :)

I'll be passing through LA, as well, so if any of you Socal ravers
(and I know you're out there!) know of any good parties in either LA
or San Diego, give me a call: 415.215.8269 will reach me while I'm
traveling. I had heard rumours of a desert full moon party tonight...?

See you on New Year's! :) hmmm... Gateway or Cloud Factory...?

Steve

May Santa Bring You More Bandwidth:

>I'm hoping a friend of mine can help me tonight.  Don't you hate it when 
>all you want to do is print something with your new printer.  But 
>NOOOOOOOO!  It has to be an ordeal! :P


***###***Merry Christmas***###***

May Santa bring you the right driver.  What it sounds like is you aren't
seeing the modem/printer port selection icons in the right box.  If you
use System 7.5 then you probably have Open Transport which replaced the
old modem drivers.  You can tell your version OS by checking About This
Macintosh in the Apple Menu in Finder.  Look for Open Transport files in
your Extensions folder in System folder.

Apple didn't include the Open Transport/Localtalk toggle switch panel
with it's OS--it's in the Apple Internet Connection Kit, which is now
free with new machines.  If I could figure out attachments in Netscape
I'd EM it but I haven't had time to play with it let alone read a manual
<I guess AOL was good for something  :P'''> so I'll have to fire up some
other Email app.

This may be part of your bug... I had this problem when I upgraded my OS
from 7.5.2 

Your answer could probably be found in the Apple Technical Reference
Library which can be found from their home page.  There's a search
engine there but you should also find Apples ftp site to get the right
drivers, Open Transport, and the latest OS (7.5.5) Which is supposed to
have better compatibility with older cpu's

If there is some conflict between the printer driver version and the
modem driver (Open Transport/Apple Modem Tool/third party drivers) this
will hang the Chooser selector windows.

I'd still run a power up (usually hold some switch) print test of the
printer also.

My favorite Macintosh exorcism (besides turning off all extensions, PRAM
zap) is drag everything out of the System file you don't need and add
back a few at a time--start with the most basic stuff.  But you really
need to do that Clean Install--all the Mac Mojos agree on that one.

I installed everything by the book in my new machine and struggled for
days with Netscape and my new printer (Epson) which had it's own
drivers.  I like to think I'm fairly expert short of being a
programmer.  Lots of crashes and problems like yours.  Now with 7.5.5
and Netscape 3.0 (with ATT's ISP driver FreePPP, forget Apple's fancy
Internet Kit) it's fairly stable, but I still crash about once/day, and
superstitiously rebuild my desktop.

These Macs are like a Voodoo ritual I don't know how the average person
can handle it though the Performas are pre-configured with modems, etc.
ready to go.  Hey people these are the horror stories we were hearing
about Windoze 95!!!-

I've got an EZ135 for an alternate HD/backup and between both drives I
reinstalled everything about 5 times, even making several different
Startup Disks with their own system installs--it was like giving a
monkey a typerwriter and hoping to get a Shakespear.

Last ditch rituals:  Talk nicely to the computer, apologize for
screaming at it.

If that still doesn't work, and it's an old machine you are about to
replace, turn it off, whack the sides of the cpu a few times like the
Long Ranger on Trigger, pick up the front or back a few inches and drop
several times.  This ritual sometimes re-seats loose ribbon cables
(WARNING:  THE SURGEON GENERAL SAYS THIS PROCEDURE MAY BLOW YOUR HARD
DRIVE)

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: "Rusty H. Hodge" <rusty@hodge.com>
Subject: Re: Over-obsessing on material things
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Actually, the point I was trying to make is that to be in the elite circle
of kool DJs, it is thought that yuo must have the special group approved
hardware.

I'm completely with you: DJs shouldn't be subsidized (except with NEA
grants, maybe :-> ) and the is a cost associated with creating any art.
Some art is just more expensive. But someone with talent shouldn't be put
off because they think they need to spend $2000

On the same hand, if someone has a huge collection of CDs, they shouldn't
think they need to run out and replace the whole collection with vinyl...
cuz all the cool DJs use vinyl. You can probably create more with a couple
of cheap CD players and a cheap ass mixer than you would think.

Hell, most of this music was born from the synths and drum machines that
were ditched in the early/mid 80s as the new generation of synths and drum
machines appeared. The TB-303 was a piece of shit as far as what it was
originally marketed for (a bass and drum section for rock guitarists!). But
creative people took it and did with it what the designers never considered.

I think that is what I was trying to say.

-- Rusty

 This time of year puts many of us under stress. Those of us that have no 
one to hang with on Christmas day may particularly (sp?) be depressed (I 
know I am). So with that I would like to extend my love and warmth to 
those who for whatever reason don't have folks to hang with on Christmas 
day. Know that I wish we could be together.

 I am fortunate that there are people who have made me welcome on the New 
Year. I hope all of you will go somewhere and be with people of good 
cheer. I especially wish you all have a leafy and prosperous year ahead.


with love,

WASTED BANDWIDTH (Now there's a name for a punk techno band)

I reformatted this for the airwaves.  Thanks for posting it--it seems
even funnier in a script style  :)  Dose guys is geniusez'

X-MAS FILES

Mulder:  We're too late! It's already been here.           

Scully:  Mulder, I hope you know what you're doing.           

Mulder:  Look, Scully, just like the other homes: Douglas fir,
truncated, mounted, transformed into a shrine; halls decked with boughs
of holly; stockings hung by the chimney, with care.          

Scully:  You really think someone's been here?
    
Mulder:  Someone, or something.          

Sculley:  Mulder, over here-it's a fruitcake.

Mulder:   Don't touch it!  Those things can be lethal.           

Sculley:  It's O.K.   There's a note attached: "Gonna find out who's
naughty and nice."
  
Mulder:  It's judging them, Scully.  It's making a list.           

Sculley:  Who?  What are you talking about?           

Mulder:  Ancient mythology tells of an obese humanoid entity who could
travel at great speed in a craft powered by antlered servants.  Once
each year, near the winter solstice, this creature is said to descend
from the heavens to reward its followers and punish disbelievers with
jagged chunks of antracite.          

Sculley:  But that's legend, Mulder-a story told by parents to frighten
children.  Surely you don't believe it?          

Mulder:  Something was here tonight, Scully.  Check out the bite marks
on this gingerbread man.  Whatever tore through this plate of cookies
was massive-and in a hurry.  It left crumbs everywhere.  

Sculley:  And look, Mulder, this milk glass has been completely
drained.
          
Mulder:  It gorged itself, Scully.  It fed without remorse.

Sculley:  But why would they leave it milk and cookies?           

Mulder:  Appeasement.

Tonight is the Eve, and nothing can stop its wilding.         

Sculley:  But if this thing does exist, how did it get in?  The doors
and windows were locked.  There's no sign of forced entry.          

Mulder:  Unless I miss my guess, it came through the
fireplace.           

Sculley:  Wait a minute, Mulder.  If you're saying some huge creature
landed on the roof and came down this chimney, you're crazy.  The flue
is barely six inches wide.  Nothing could get down there.          

Mulder:  But what if it could alter its shape, move in all directions at
once?          

Sculley:  You mean, like a bowl full of jelly?           

Mulder:  Exactly.  Scully, I've never told anyone this, but when I was a
child my home was visited.  I saw the creature.  It had long white
shanks of fur surrounding its ruddy, misshapen head.  It's bloated torso
was red and white.  I'll never forget the horror. 

I turned away, and when I looked back it had somehow taken on the facial
features of my father.          

Sculley:  Impossible.          

Mulder:  I know what I saw.  And that night it read my mind.  It brought
me a Mr. Potato Head, Scully.  It knew that I wanted a Mr. Potato
Head!          

Sculley:  I'm sorry, Mulder, but you're asking me to disregard the laws
of physics.  You want me to believe in some supernatural being who soars
across the skies and brings gifts to good little girls and boys. Listen
to what you're saying.  Do
you understand the repercussions? If this gets out, they'll close the
X-files.          

Mulder:  Scully, listen to me: It know when you're sleeping.
It knows when you're awake.          

Sculley:  But we have no proof.          

Mulder:  Last year, on this exact date, SETI radio telescopes detected
bogeys in the airspace over twenty-seven states.  The White House
ordered a Condition
Red.         

Sculley:  But that was a meteor shower.          

Mulder:  Officially.  Two days ago, eight prized Scandinavian reindeer
vanished from the National Zoo, in Washington, D.C.  Nobody-not even the
zookeeper-was told aboutit.  The government doesn't want people to know
about Project Kringle.

They fear that if this thing is proved to exist the public will stop
spending half its annual income in a holiday shopping frenzy.  Retail
markets will collapse.  

Scully, they cannot let the world believe this creature lives.  There's
too much at stake.  They'll do whatever it takes to insure another
silent night.         

Sculley:  Mulder, I-         

Mulder:  Sh-h-h. Do you hear what I hear?           On the roof.  It
sounds like...a
clatter.          The truth is up there.  Let's see what's the matter. 

"Stay Connected..."

by Frank Cammuso and Hart Seely          57 ELM STREETBETHLEHEM, PA

Hey all,

Had a great time at MAD last night.  I haven't been there since the 
spring (when it used to rock!) and I was happy to see that it's rocking 
just as hard (if not harder) than ever.  The place was packed full of 
happy dancers, and since I was brave and ventured over there alone, I was 
really pleased to see so many friendly familiar faces.  Three bux to hear 
the likes of Ethan and Joe has to be the best deal going in the City :).  
Saw two memorable things on the way home: a gorgeous full moon encircled 
by a huge ring of clouds, and, just off the freeway in Emeryville, rising 
above everything in the blackness, a huge, neon, glaring "E".  I had to 
laugh out loud at that! :) 

Happy Christmas Eve to all of you who celebrate it... I personally have 
been feeling a great sense of rebirth since the night of the Solstice, 
the full moon seems to accentuate it...

-N

Boozin' Ravers has gotten a great response so far... so keep an eye out 
in the near future for the first night of debauchery!

It has been suggested to me that, being that we are all ravers, that we 
may like to drink and then, oh, I don't know, DANCE - and apparently 
dance pickin's on Thursday nights are a little slim.  So, this may be a 
roving bar night, depending on what dance events are going on...

Probably our first night out will be on the second Wednesday of the new 
year, bars in lower Haight and then over to Wish for dancing the night 
away... Stay tuned for a post much nearer the date...

Love, Tunes and
Microbrews,
