http://www.metahtml.com/apps/zippy/welcome.mhtml

when you visit URLs through the zippy filter, other people's web pages
get random zippy the pinheadisms inserted... For example, the following
is the output of Lou Gerstner's (IBM's CEO) speech on the IBM site
(http://www.ibm.com/lvg/annual96.html):

Speeches 

     1996 Annual Stockholders' Meeting
     Atlanta, GA
     April 30, 1996 

  "Because
  network
  computing is so
  all-embracing, it
  has emerged as
  IBM's integrating
  strategy. ANN
  JILLIAN'S HAIR
  makes LONI
  ANDERSON'S
  HAIR look like
  RICARDO
  MONTALBAN'S
  HAIR! It's the trail
  we're following -
  blazing - to get
  back on top." 
                      I hope you enjoyed the opening Olympic video. I want you to
                      know, my heart was pounding as I watched it. So this is what it
                      feels like to be potato salad And not because I get choked up
                      over grand athletic spectacles. 

                      No, on my way over here this morning I saw a big sign hanging
                      over Interstate 75. In giant letters, it said 80 days to go.
                      Excuse me, but didn't I tell you there's NO HOPE for the
                      survival of OFFSET PRINTING? That's 80 days to show time
                      -- both for your great city and for IBM. 

                      Two and one half million people are coming to dinner, and half
                      the world's population will be watching. We both have a lot on
                      the line. I am deeply CONCERNED and I want something
                      GOOD for BREAKFAST! It's a chance for your city and our
                      company to show their very best on a world stage. I don't need
                      to tell you there's an element of risk in stepping onto that
                      stage. But it's also an opportunity to demonstrate leadership.
                      My mind is making ashtrays in Dayton.... 

                      Last year, when I met with shareholders in Charlotte, I spoke
                      at length about leadership. I said that fully re-establishing
                      IBM's leadership in our industry was our goal, that we would
                      settle for nothing less. 

                      At that time, I felt we were turning a corner, that we were back
                      on our feet, building momentum, and that we had finally put to
                      rest questions about IBM's survival. I want to read my new
                      poem about pork brains and outer space... I said that the
                      important question for IBM -- looking ahead to 1995 -- was:
                      Could IBM grow again? 

                      As I wrote to you in our 1995 Annual Report several months
                      ago, I believe we have answered that question. You know the
                      facts of our 1995 performance. 

                      We exceeded $70 billion in revenue -- a record. MY income is
                      ALL disposable! We achieved double-digit growth -- our best
                      in a decade. Earnings doubled. Our workforce grew for the first
                      time in a number of years. The Osmonds! You are all
                      Osmonds!! Throwing up on a freeway at dawn!!! Perhaps of
                      most interest to you, our stock price increased 24 percent in
                      1995. It has increased another 18 percent so far in 1996. And
                      two weeks ago, the board of directors authorized a 40 percent
                      increase in our dividend. Can I have an IMPULSE ITEM
                      instead? 

                      So by virtually every measure, IBM is growing again. 

                      Which is not to say we are comfortable. Our first-quarter
                      results reminded us that competitive pressure remains very
                      intense in the industry and that we will see periodic lulls in
                      certain product lines as we go through product transitions.
                      Make me look like LINDA RONSTADT again!! 

                      I like to be the first to share news with IBM employees so I
                      often send them electronic notes. On the day we announced
                      our first-quarter earnings, I told them that the results were
                      good -- but mixed. As such, they represented a healthy
                      reality check for all of us. If our behavior is strict, we do not
                      need fun! But I also said we shouldn't be distracted by
                      quarter-to-quarter fluctuations. 

                      It's important that we not take our eye off our long-term
                      strategic vision. Not now. FUN is never having to say you're
                      SUSHI!! Not at the very time when our industry is entering its
                      next major phase -- the era of global networks. 

                      IBM has an opportunity to lead this shift to network computing
                      and to bring the value of a universally-connected world to
                      customers. 

                      The shift to network computing is very profound. Those aren't
                      WINOS--that's my JUGGLER, my AERIALIST, my SWORD
                      SWALLOWER, and my LATEX NOVELTY SUPPLIER!! I truly
                      believe it will reshape the world as fundamentally as the
                      invention of the printing press, the light bulb or manned flight. It
                      will reshape every business and institution in the world. It will
                      affect -- it's already affecting -- each and every one of us. All
                      this time I've been VIEWING a RUSSIAN MIDGET
                      SODOMIZE a HOUSECAT! 

                      What is causing this shift? There are many factors. 

                      One is universal connectivity, driven primarily by the
                      phenomenon of the Internet. The power of information
                      technology is moving out to touch hundreds of millions,
                      perhaps a billion people by the year 2000: 

                          Connecting businesses with customers in ways never
                          before possible 
                          Connecting people with people 
                          And connecting people with information of all kinds.
                          Yow! Now we can become alcoholics! 

                      Another driver is technology. Digital networks are being
                      transformed. They're gaining the speed and power to transmit
                      not just text and voice, but video, movies and high-resolution
                      images such as works of art, X-rays and MRI scans. He
                      probably just wants to take over my CELLS and then
                      EXPLODE inside me like a BARREL of runny CHOPPED
                      LIVER! Or maybe he'd like to PSYCHOLOGICALLY
                      TERRORIZE ME until I have no objection to a RIGHT-WING
                      MILITARY TAKEOVER of my apartment!! I guess I should
                      call AL PACINO! 

                      But the most important driver of the shift to network computing
                      isn't technology. The main driver of this shift is grounded in the
                      priorities of our customers all over the globe. Nearly all of them
                      are focused on increased speed to market, faster product
                      development, providing better customer service, reducing
                      cost, opening new markets. Yow! Maybe I should have asked
                      for my Neutron Bomb in PAISLEY-- 

                      Networks are powerful tools to achieve these objectives. They
                      give people easy access to information and to each other.
                      They lower -- and in some cases can eliminate -- the
                      borders between departments, companies, cultures and
                      nations. The appreciation of the average visual graphisticator
                      alone is worth the whole suaveness and decadence which
                      abounds!! They help people work as teams -- sharing ideas,
                      information and projects. 

                      How will this networked world change our lives? 

                      Our notion of libraries will be up-ended when people can
                      access the content found in books via the Internet
                      24-hours-a-day, 7-days-a-week, directly from their homes
                      and schools. 

                      Medicine: "Telemedicine" will allow your physician here in
                      Atlanta to consult via the network with a specialist in
                      Massachusetts or Tokyo, and they can simultaneously view
                      the same X-rays and CAT-scans. Go on, EMOTE! I was
                      RAISED on thought balloons!! 

                      Education: "Distance learning" makes the same quality
                      education that is available in affluent suburban schools
                      available to the forgotten enclaves of inner cities. Our children
                      can learn French from a teacher in France, write essays about
                      China after taking a virtual tour of China, and explore space
                      courtesy of NASA. 

                      And, of course, network computing is changing commerce.
                      Wait.. is this a FUN THING or the END of LIFE in Petticoat
                      Junction?? It allows employees within companies to work
                      faster and smarter. It allows companies to interconnect with
                      their suppliers, their distributors, retailers and, of course, their
                      ultimate customers. 

                      It's already happening. He is the MELBA-BEING... the
                      ANGEL CAKE... XEROX him... XEROX him -- Everywhere
                      you turn these days you see Internet addresses -- those
                      "WWW.com" lines in ads and plastered on billboards all over
                      our country. 

                      In short, the network increasingly is becoming the place where
                      transactions occur, where communication takes place, where
                      business is conducted, where students are taught, where
                      citizens are served by their governments. Is something
                      VIOLENT going to happen to a GARBAGE CAN? 

                      As this happens, we will see tremendous demand for two
                      things IBM is very good at. First, technology. 

                      Networks by their very nature are complex. I'm having an
                      EMOTIONAL OUTBURST!! But, uh, WHY is there a WAFFLE
                      in my PAJAMA POCKET?? They require big processors,
                      enormous amounts of storage capacity, huge databases,
                      powerful transaction processing software and comprehensive
                      systems management. As transactions across networks
                      increase, so will demand for all of these IBM products. 

                      As you know, most people never see the bulk of IBM's
                      products because they labor quietly behind the scenes of
                      banks, insurance companies, airlines, universities and
                      corporations. Life is a POPULARITY CONTEST! I'm
                      REFRESHINGLY CANDID!! Yet network computing is driving
                      the focus of our industry in exactly that direction. Computing is
                      moving to the network, behind the scenes. Industrial-strength,
                      large-scale, reliable computing -- that's where the action is
                      again. I KAISER ROLL?! What good is a Kaiser Roll without a
                      little COLE SLAW on the SIDE? That hasn't been true for
                      many years. 

                      We are rapidly adapting all our products for network computing.
                      And we are developing new technologies necessary to make
                      the networked world real and easy to use. Eisenhower!! Your
                      mimeograph machine upsets my stomach!! In fact, we're
                      announcing several new products today at a big industry show
                      called Internet World in San Jose. 

                          Products like InfoSage, an online news and information
                          delivery service 
                          Cryptolopes, which I think of as secure electronic
                          envelopes that people can use to distribute
                          copyright-protected information. One of the more
                          important issues people are concerned with as
                          networks become more and more ubiquitous is how you
                          protect information and copyrights. .. Like I always say
                          -- nothing can beat the BRATWURST here in
                          DUSSELDORF!! 
                          We are also announcing our Internet Connection (IC)
                          Phone, which allows people to use the Internet as a
                          telephone system. 
                          And our flagship electronic commerce product called
                          the Net.Commerce system. I am NOT a nut.... 

                      The Net.Commerce system for the last several weeks has
                      been the Olympic Ticket Server here in Atlanta. Open
                      24-hours-a-day, it's the largest electronic commerce site on
                      the Internet. I hope I bought the right relish... zzzzzzzzz... So
                      far, it has sold about 32,000 tickets -- 14 percent of all
                      Olympics tickets sold. We're now making this product
                      available to other customers who want to establish online
                      stores. 

                      We're also strengthening our product portfolio through
                      selective acquisitions. .. So, if we convert SUPPLY-SIDE
                      SOYBEAN FUTURES into HIGH-YIELD T-BILL
                      INDICATORS, the PRE-INFLATIONARY risks will
                      DWINDLE to a rate of 2 SHOPPING SPREES per
                      EGGPLANT!! Earlier this year we completed our merger with
                      Tivoli Systems, which strengthens our hand significantly in
                      systems management, and, as you know, we acquired Lotus
                      last year. 

                      With Lotus, we offer a full range of application products and the
                      industry's leading groupware product, Notes. I'm pleased to
                      report to you that the merger has gone very smoothly. Did I
                      say I was a sardine? Or a bus??? Demand for all Lotus
                      products, especially Notes, is very strong. The potential for
                      Notes in a networked world is tremendous. Today's workers
                      want to do many tasks from their computers: send and receive
                      mail, update their calendars, share information with co-
                      workers, use tools like spreadsheets, get information from the
                      Internet and post information to the Internet. I can't decide
                      which WRONG TURN to make first!! I wonder if BOB
                      GUCCIONE has these problems! 

                      Notes is the only product in the marketplace that can do all
                      this. That's why customer demand is so high and why
                      thousands of software developers are writing network-centric
                      applications that exploit the power of Notes. 

                      The second opportunity that we see in this new emerging world
                      is in developing network solutions for customers. NEWARK
                      has been REZONED!! DES MOINES has been REZONED!!
                      The first opportunity was technology and products. The
                      second is solutions. 

                      Here again, I believe IBM has a home court advantage. Hello?
                      Enema Bondage? I'm calling because I want to be happy, I
                      guess.. We have tremendous relationships with customers.
                      Over the years, they have built their businesses on IBM
                      systems. Most of the world's business information resides in
                      IBM databases. Look! A ladder! Maybe it leads to heaven, or a
                      sandwich! Most of the world's transactions are executed by
                      IBM software and hardware systems. 

                      We're working with customers across the globe to help them
                      extend their reach, their brands and their very valuable
                      business information through these new networks. That's one
                      of the reasons why our services business is growing so rapidly
                      and has become our second largest source of revenue.
                      GOOD-NIGHT, everybody.. Now I have to go administer
                      FIRST-AID to my pet LEISURE SUIT!! 

                      I should also note that network computing is changing the way
                      customers buy IBM products and services. More and more of
                      them are "subscribing" to applications and services that we
                      make available via networks, such as our own IBM Global
                      Network. This makes it less expensive for them and has the
                      added benefit of creating a recurring revenue stream for IBM.
                      Now, let's SEND OUT for QUICHE!! 

                      Beyond product and solutions leadership, there's another area
                      where we want to provide leadership in the networked world.
                      The proliferation of networks raises a number of societal issues
                      in the minds of many people. They're concerned about privacy,
                      censorship and universal access, and whether we're creating
                      a world of technology have's and have not's. Hmmm.. A
                      hash-singer and a cross-eyed guy were SLEEPING on a
                      deserted island, when... 

                      These are very legitimate concerns. As a leader, IBM must --
                      and is -- addressing them. We're working with partners and
                      competitors, customers and governments around the world to
                      find acceptable solutions. Where's SANDY DUNCAN? The
                      promise is too great, and the benefits too immense, for any
                      responsible company to do otherwise. 

                      A lot of companies talk about leadership. They talk about
                      visions. PEGGY FLEMING is stealing BASKET BALLS to feed
                      the babies in VERMONT. They run clever ads. But few
                      companies make the future they talk about real. I think they
                      can learn a few things from Atlanta. The appreciation of the
                      average visual graphisticator alone is worth the whole
                      suaveness and decadence which abounds!! You weren't
                      asked to be the host city for the Centennial Games. You didn't
                      accept the challenge on a dare. You went out and competed for
                      the right to host the Games. I'm ANN LANDERS!! I can
                      SHOPLIFT!! Your community has worked hard -- very hard
                      -- for years to prepare. And in 80 days Atlanta will enjoy
                      perhaps the proudest moment in its proud history. 

                      IBM is honored to be a partner in this. Today, THREE WINOS
                      from DETROIT sold me a framed photo of TAB HUNTER
                      before his MAKEOVER! It's one of the greatest information
                      technology challenges we've ever faced -- the equivalent of
                      staging two Super Bowls every day for 17 days. 

                      The solution we've created relies on virtually every product in
                      our portfolio, as well as hundreds of our smartest people to
                      develop customized solutions and integrate all the pieces from
                      IBM and other technology sponsors of the Games in Atlanta.
                      It's a big, complex, demanding job with no margin for error. I'm
                      dressing up in an ill-fitting IVY-LEAGUE SUIT!! Too late... It's
                      a very good example of the kinds of integrated solutions we
                      pull together every day for customers around the world. 

                      For a company of IBM's size and breadth, it's hard to define a
                      single strategy that embraces all our products, services and
                      people. Yet, because network computing is so all-embracing,
                      it has emerged as IBM's integrating strategy. I want to kill
                      everyone here with a cute colorful Hydrogen Bomb!! It's the
                      trail we're following -- blazing -- to get back on top. Now
                      comes the hard part -- implementing. I will tell you that the
                      people of IBM are up to the challenge. This TOPS OFF my
                      partygoing experience! Someone I DON'T LIKE is talking to
                      me about a HEART-WARMING European film.. 

                      Three years ago, when I joined this company and addressed
                      shareholders for the first time in Tampa, IBM was on the
                      endangered species list. I talked about the hard actions
                      necessary to save our company. Two years ago, we talked
                      about stability. Let's all show human CONCERN for
                      REVEREND MOON's legal difficulties!! Last year: growth.
                      Now, we are gunning for leadership. 

                      As much as any single factor, IBM owes its current health and
                      its future potential to the dedication and hard work of IBM
                      employees. I want a VEGETARIAN BURRITO to go.. with
                      EXTRA MSG!! They took the decline of their company
                      personally, and they have given their all to bring IBM back. I'm
                      proud to call them my colleagues. 

                      Finally, I want to thank all of you -- our shareholders -- for
                      standing by us through the rough times. LBJ, LBJ, how many
                      JOKES did you tell today??! I hope you feel your patience has
                      been justified. The fires are out. The industry is shifting
                      dramatically and rapidly. Pardon me, but do you know what it
                      means to be TRULY ONE with your BOOTH! In many ways,
                      it's coming back our way. 

                      Network computing is exciting -- not only as an opportunity
                      for IBM to lead once again -- but because it will fundamentally
                      change the world for the better. 

                      There's plenty to do, and I assure you we won't let up until
                      we're done. Here we are in America... when do we collect
                      unemployment? 

                      Thank you. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==
== When yer swimming in a creek and an eel bites yer cheek, that's a moray!==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

 well, all i can say about the gathering 5 yr was that it was THE BOMB!!!
martin knows how to throw an awesome party. IMO, he's the only one who can
pull of a good massive at home base. 
     the music and the vibe at this year's party rivaled the 4 yr. i was in
the house room for a good part of the night. i never managed to make it into
the techno room, because the foot stomping beats in the main room kept me
planted.
     jeno and josh tore it up. jeno set the music up just right for josh who
peaked the party. i'd never heard josh peak a party before, now i can't wait
until he does it again. tony was awesome as usual (does this guy ever spin a
bad set?), and onionz spun some incredible house. kevin saunderson was a
little disappointing, because he train wrecked like a mofo. his set was the
only problem i had the whole night. 
     it was good seeing old friends (imagine my surprise when at 4 in the
morning, austin popped up behind me after his 3 hour drive from SLO) and
making new ones. that's what the gathering is all about.

until next time,
dorena

Just thought I should introduce myself..

My name's Leonardo, and I have recently decided to fully devote myself to
music.  I even threw away an Olympic judo/wrestling career, and left MIT..
that's how much it means to me.  I loved the Boston scene, yet I'm even
more excited to get to experience everything I had never exposed myself
to in the Bay area.

Monday night I tried to go to MAD (though it was a couple hours' drive..
I live in the Santa Cruz area).  I was psyched.  Then I was in a car
accident.  Bad scene.. I'm still having flashbacks.. but at least I
wasn't hurt.  I was really drawn to the type of music there.. I would
love to get a ride with someone on a semi-regular basis, but I don't
suppose anyone this far South frequents there.

I'm also into African drumming.. I drummed with Arthur Hull (for those
of you who might know him) for two years when I was ten years old.. 
got myself a djembe a couple days ago and I'm dying to find some drum
circles with good vibes to help me get back in the groove.

I feel like I'm starting from scratch in more ways than one.. so if
you're into making/exploring/enjoying any of the beautiful aspects
of music, and would like to get in touch with me for whatever, please
give me a call (408-761-5797) or send an email my way.   =)

Peace,

Leonardo

Where is everybody at?

Who is going to Cool World?  No one on the list? Bummer.
You know though..  All this talk about "to commercialized". Anybody besides
me out there think that the words "to commercialized" is just as big a hipe
as a commercial?
 I mean. I wouldn't doubt it if most people say "to commercialized" just
becouse thats what everybody else says. Why care?
 Don't get me wrong. I love them little underground parties where everybody
seems like family. But I love them huge out of control "parties" aswell.
 Sometimes though.... My arm pits smell funny..  You know what I do about
it? I stick some Right Guard up in there...  But gee..  Lately I have been
thinking about just going to the ravEs smelling like B.O.  You know why?
Becouse Right Guard is just to damn commercialized for me...!!!! 
Hahhahaha.  =]:.::..
 I like the taste and buzz I get from Zima. Any Zima drinkers notice how
people kinna think your old fasion for drinking Zima "to commercialized"
Old fashion...  Hmmmm..  Budweiser has been around longer, and has more
commercials than Zima..  I think on the Zima note; people just think it is
uncool becouse they feel maybe like they were suckered into drinking it by
the hipe of the commercials? Hmmm..  I don't know. Do you?
  Reason for subject..  Becouse my friends are starting to say "to
commercialized" And when I say "What do you mean?" You know what they say?
"to commercialized" So I say "Snap out of it man! You sound like a
programmed robot!" There recovering now..

That auta get the list going alittle Huh?
Jeff

i think TOO commercialized might me a better way of putting it myself.  I only
advertise for stuff i think is THE SHIT, and that's all i generally buy.  so,
if you notice me wearing Doc Martins or Hi-Tek boots, that's because I
bought them, because I think they're good.  The same reason I wear my
Metallica concert shirt from 1987!! (still)  But I remember in High School,
the peer pressure to wear OP shirts (ocean pacific) was pretty great, and
they weren't particularly good, but you just weren't cool if you didn't have
acouple pairs.
To me, anyone who aftertises (in their personal life at least) for stuff
that they don't like, or that they know is bad for the environment (etc..)
is basically a prostitute.  MarredBurrow or Camel could give me 1000 of
their fucking hats, jadckets and shirts, and i wouldn't even give them to
the homeless, let alone wear them, because those companies are basicaly evil
in my opinion.

well there's my 2c worth.


Bruce

[ to sfraves ]
{ Unseasonal uncheery stuff follows }
{ Heavy gay bashing & labelling stuff here, only rave-related because so many
ravers are gay . I'm no expert, so please correct me or send me your
opinions if you strongly agree/disagree with any of the points I make...}}

 Someone reacted to a portion of one of my posts:

> In a message dated 96-12-04 19:41:37 EST, you write:
> 
> << 1. Ravers want to feel safe at a rave ( no fag bashing, robbery,  >>
> Fag bashing??
> You mean gay bashing... There is a long history behind the word fag that is
> pretty horrible. Anyway, just thought i would point that out.
> 
 S'OK, and I recognize your point. I made a deliberate choice between the 
two words. IT was a bit of a troll...I'm glad that nobody on SFRaves wrote 
me any email saying that they AGREE with gay bashing. 

 The whole sociological history of "fag","queer", and "gay" has deep
, subtle subconciouss stuff. Sometimes, when a group tries to achieve some
respect by asking the general public to use a less loaded label to 
denote their group, they forget that the general public hates THEM, not the
old label. I think recognition of this is why "Queer Nation" chose that
name for themselves. 

 The anti-gay forces in this country have no trouble inciting fear and
loathing by spreading hysterical lies about the "gay agenda" without
using the words "fag" or "queer".   

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

PS - I was taking some film animation courses at De Anza College about ten
years ago. During one of the lab sessions , I overheard two high-school 
age boys talking about something strange, unusual, and unpleaseant that 
someone had done. One of the phrases they used was "that's so gay" (!)
I don't know if "gay" is still being used to describe unusal, unpleasant
behaviour these days, or whether it was a passing bit of slanguage.

Subject: DRUGS: Rohypnol soon to be illegal
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

[alchohol could also be called a date rape drug. but i digress... -R]

BCN31:ROHYPNOL, THE DATE RAPE DRUG, WILL BE ILLEGAL UNDER NEW LAW

BCN31 -ROHYPNOL

By Bay City News Service

Rohypnol, the "date rape drug," will be illegal under California

law as of New Year's Day.

The new law, SB 2164, is authored by State Senator Tom Hayden.

The U.S. Commissioner of Customes, George Weise, has called the

drug "another nightmare for parents."

Although the drug is illegal under federal law, it has been cheap

and easily available with a street price of $5 a pill. This because

federal drug agents been more concerned with tracking major drug

rings, Hayden explained. Since local police do not enforce federal

law, they have lacked legal authority until the Hayden Act to arrest

sellers and users of the drug.

The small white pills are sometimes called "roopies," and they

usually are slipped into a woman's or girl's drink. The victim then

becomes unconscious within 30 minutes, may sleep for eight hours and

generally can't remember anything that happens to her once the drug

becomes effective.

Police departments report many victims have awakened to find

themselves nude in a strange man's bedroom. Hayden's office said Los

Angeles police have complained that up until now when they found a man

cruising the bars with a pocket full of the pills all they could do

was confiscate them.

It is manufactured by Hoffman-La Roche, an international

pharmaceutical company. Although it has been banned in the United

State as having no beneficial medical use, the drug is legal in 64

countries. This includes Mexico and Columbia, where it is being

manufactured.


--
Rusty Hodge (rusty@hodge.com), Media Futurist / Cyberneticist

Info Lines

     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.
     * the Buzz-line, a global party network - 415.568.1338
     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Fatline - 415.207.3668
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday morning 9am-11am - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon - Beats, Breakz
       and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford).
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Tuesday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. and
       Monkeywrench. Varied techno sub-genres, noise, spoken word, world
       music. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - the Uncle Noah TV Show - the best
       in Techno and House music. 3-5am, KDVS 90.3fm (Davis)
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
 Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

Received: from shellx.best.com (shellx.best.com [206.86.0.11]) by proxy1.ba.best.com (8.8.4/8.8.3) with ESMTP id WAA20775 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 26 Dec 1996 22:15:03 -0800 (PST)
Received: from [206.86.235.114] (lesliea.vip.best.com [206.86.235.114]) by shellx.best.com (8.8.4/8.8.3) with SMTP id WAA10896 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 26 Dec 1996 22:12:23 -0800 (PST)
Date: Thu, 26 Dec 1996 22:12:23 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <v015305028002ce4bd0f7@[206.86.235.114]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: lesliea@best.com (Leslie Ayres)
Subject: Gathering Review (late, late, late!)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

What a ball I had there!  I went early, because I wanted to see Ethan and
Joe Rice, and I love seeing a party come to life, and I hate lines, and
Boomerang said he'd go early too ...

And from the first second, the vibe was there, I felt like  I was at a
humongous FnF or something -- only there were friends from all parts of my
life!  My very closest friends were there, plus I saw hundreds of my other
friends and acquaintances -- some are people I only  see in clubs, some are
people who never go out, or people who go out five times a week, people who
are 14, people who are older than me (ok, just kidding!), people who love
trance, people who love house (yay Onionz!), promoters, kids who were at
their first party, "gangstas" and "teddy-bear-backpackers," SFRavers who
never post, and SFRavers who won't be quiet, it was so incredible.

I just walked around from 10 at night until 8:00 a.m. with a huge smile on
my face, soaking it all in ....  the best moment was at 7:30 a.m. and
Onionz was in this grooovy groove and the remaining few hundred of us were
just dancing like we weren't even tired.

Thanks for the great conversatins, the hugs, the kisses (mmmm), for the
wonderful time, to every single person who was there, and to everyone who
made such a big party feel like a little one.

Leslie
(wish I could put my poinsettia crown on my sig!)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Dec 27 02:41:50 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id CAA27188; Fri, 27 Dec 1996 02:41:50 -0800 (PST)
Received: from pluto.sfsu.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with ESMTP id CAA27184; Fri, 27 Dec 1996 02:41:43 -0800 (PST)
Received: from localhost (star@localhost) by pluto.sfsu.edu (8.8.3/8.8.3) with SMTP id CAA13395; Fri, 27 Dec 1996 02:40:59 -0800 (PST)
Date: Fri, 27 Dec 1996 02:40:59 -0800 (PST)
From: Starchild <star@sfsu.edu>
X-Sender: star@pluto
Reply-To: Starchild <star@sfsu.edu>
To: SF Raves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
cc: Marquee Moon <marquee@creative.net>, Richard Goetz <rgoetz@sfsu.edu>
Subject: Commercialism & freedom in cyberspace
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.3.95.961227014220.10944D-100000@pluto>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Dear SFRavefriends,

	I'll jump back into the continuing discussion about commercialism
with some interesting info that was forwarded to me. I'm sure I'm not the
only one who didn't know about this law.  I haven't attempted to verify
that this is for real, but it sounds clumsy and heavy-handed enough to be
legit.
	I think it was someone on SFRaves I was talking with some time
back about the merits of cops and drug laws when I mentioned that even
those who consider themselves law-abiding citizens, and believe that those
OTHER people who break laws deserve whatever the cops and the justice
system have in store for them, are actually law-breakers too.
	There are so many laws passed each year, many of them incredibly
complex, that it becomes impossible to know the law.  This makes it easy
for the authorities to find a pretext to nail just about whoever they
want to.  If the law is on your side, that doesn't necessarily spare you.
	A San Francisco judge recently handed down an injunction against a
law mandating that the government not discriminate against people on the
basis of race or sex, essentially on the grounds that the law was
discrimnatory on the basis of race and sex.  In such an Orwellian climate,
where words can be twisted to take exactly their opposite meaning,
consider what could be done with the following:

___________________________________________________________________________
"By US Code Title 47, Sec.227(a)(2)(B),a computer/modem/printer meets the
definition of a telephone fax machine.  By Sec.227(b)(1)(C), it is unlawful
to send any unsolicited advertisement to such equipment.  By Sec.227(b)(3)(C),
a violation of the aforementioned Section is punishable by action to recover
actual monetary loss, or $500, whichever is greater, for each violation."
___________________________________________________________________________

	Say for example that you are the promoter of an underground party
that hasn't paid thousands of dollars to off-duty cops to provide your
security.  Let's say that you get busted, as many such parties do, and
some new police chief decides to make an example of you.  He finds out
that a week before your party, you sent a BSP post to SFRaves advertising
your event, as many promoters have been doing.
	So he forwards the info to the FBI (since this law is apparantly a
federal one), and they initiate action against you to claim the amount of
$200,000.  What!?! you exclaim.  Well, your post went out to the
computer/modem setup of each subscriber to SFRaves (I'm conservatively
guessing 400 subscribers) and the law provides for a $500 fine for EACH
violation.  $500 x 400 = $200,000.
	Now I know the wording of the law appears to indicate that you
would have to send an advertisement by modem to a computer with a printer
hooked up that automatically prints out incoming messages without any
filtering process on the other end, so as to resemble the action of a fax 
machine. But can you be sure the courts would interpret it that way?
	Under civil asset forfeiture laws currently in effect, police and
government agencies can seize your car, home, bank account, what have you,
and the burden of proof is on you if you want your property back to prove
that your property was not used in the commission of a crime.  (FYI, Dan
Lungren, he of medical marijuana infamy, has been a key supporter of these
laws in California).  How would you like to have everything you own seized
(unless you have over $200,000 in assets) while you try to prove that each
person on SFRaves who received your email either did not regard it as
unsolicited or did not automatically print it out?
	One bright note in all this is that it could put the fear of God
into companies trying to peddle their wares over the Net via unsolicited
email.  As pleasant as that prospect may be, let's not forget that the
bigger fight for freedom on the Internet is still being fought, and the
way we'll lose it is by going along with government attempts to censor
unpopular members of the cyber-community like advertisers and
child-pornographers.  I'm sure everyone's heard Martin Neimuller's famous
lines about how "First they came for the Jews..."

Yours in liberty,
				<<< Starchild >>> 




From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Dec 27 02:46:22 1996

On Fri, 27 Dec 1996, Starchild wrote:

> ___________________________________________________________________________
> "By US Code Title 47, Sec.227(a)(2)(B),a computer/modem/printer meets the
> definition of a telephone fax machine.  By Sec.227(b)(1)(C), it is unlawful
> to send any unsolicited advertisement to such equipment.  By Sec.227(b)(3)(C),
> a violation of the aforementioned Section is punishable by action to recover
> actual monetary loss, or $500, whichever is greater, for each violation."
> ___________________________________________________________________________
> 
> 	So he forwards the info to the FBI (since this law is apparantly a
> federal one), and they initiate action against you to claim the amount of
> $200,000.  What!?! you exclaim.  Well, your post went out to the
> computer/modem setup of each subscriber to SFRaves (I'm conservatively
> guessing 400 subscribers) and the law provides for a $500 fine for EACH
> violation.  $500 x 400 = $200,000.

Seeing as people subscribed to a mailing list, receiving mail from that
list would not fall under the definiton of unsolicited. 

It hasn't happened here yet, but several other lists I am on have been
spammed repeatedly, which decreases the usefulness of the list for all
involved. The law has been brought up by those who continually receive
unsolicited (almost always commercial) via email or Usenet. Personally, I
am happy it exists, and hope some of the sleaze-merchants who routinely
forge addresses and dupe unwitting folks into giving them money for a list
of "prospective clients" get burnt hard.

People have a right to free speech yes. However that right does not extend
into *my* mailbox.


                                        Black Adder

On Sat, 21 Dec 1996, Rob Rayle wrote:

> 
> 	... is fighting for life right now after being shot in the
> head by a drunken violent person at Ashkenaz last nite. Please take
> a minute to send some energy his way.
> 
> 	PLur,
> 
> 	Rob


I saw a poster on Telegraph this morning, a sketch of a man wanted "for 
the murder of David Nadel."  This must mean that David has lost his fight 
for life...

This tragedy reminds me that there are many people who did not survive 
this year, or had terrible things befall them (Omar).  All of us should 
be very thankful for our health, for our good fortune to be able to sit 
at a computer and bullshit with 500 friends, for dancing and celebrating 
life all night long.  Life is so precious and can be taken or altered in 
a second.  On Friday night, when David was enjoying live music at 
Ashkenaz, how could he know that night was his last?

As New Year's approaches, hopefully all of us can take a little extra 
care to make sure it's safe.  Remember, after midnight a hell of a lot of 
people on the road will be fucked up out of their minds.  Luckily, many 
of us will be at a rave, safely tucked away with friends until the 
morning light.  Whatever you do, be safe - drive safely, don't allow 
friends to drive drunk, and be moderate in your drug use.  Please.

Much love to all of you.  See you at Gateway/Pacific... and in the new year!!

Love,
Nancy

BRUCE ALVIN MCDONOUGH wrote:

> i think TOO commercialized might me a better way of putting it myself.  I only
> advertise for stuff i think is THE SHIT, and that's all i generally buy.  so,
> if you notice me wearing Doc Martins or Hi-Tek boots, that's because I
> bought them, because I think they're good.

There's a fine line between wearing something that has a small logo on
it somewhere and wearing advertising.  I think the line is crossed when
the main selling point of the item is the fact that it has a logo on it
-- logo T-shirts, jackets, hats, etc. only exist to carry the logo
around, and you can buy identical products that don't have logos.

Ditto the "blue-jeans-of-the-year" phenomenon in high school...one year
it was Gasoline, then Guess?, then Pepe, then the (then) new baggy
Levis, then something else, all identical except for the logo on the
butt.  The only reason to have one over the other was that it advertised
your coolness.

As a rule, I don't advertise for anyone.  They should pay _me_ to wear a
shirt with a big logo on it...

However, I own some things that have visible logos.  My Chuck Taylors,
for example, have the standard small, round logo on the inside of the
ankle.  My rain/snow jacket has "Moonstone" on the chest.  The important
difference between these and, say, a Red Wolf t-shirt is that the
products have some merit beyond being a logo carrier: Chucks are about
the cheapest shoes you can buy that don't fall apart instantly, and
Moonstone is the only hardcore mountaineering outerwear manufacturer
that doesn't use overseas labor (North Face, Mountain Hardwear) or
prison labor (Patagonia).  If I could find something better without a
logo, I'd buy it, but I haven't.

I don't own any regular clothes with logos because it's so easy to find
ones that don't.

> MarredBurrow or Camel could give me 1000 of
> their fucking hats, jadckets and shirts, and i wouldn't even give them to
> the homeless, let alone wear them, because those companies are basicaly evil
> in my opinion.

Amen.

// grigsbeast

it says SF Giants, ya know.  I guess they're both sort of my team loyalty
showing.

Leslie  ;^)

>However, I own some things that have visible logos.  My Chuck 
>Taylors, for example, have the standard small, round logo on the 
>inside of the ankle.  My rain/snow jacket has "Moonstone" on the 
>chest.

Sir:

It has come to our attention through our surveillance computers that you
may be harboring or trading logo merchandise.  Ignorance of the law is
no excuse I refer you to the Uniform Clothing Act of 2013 A.D. which
states in the interest of equality no world citizen may wear a logo
representing a corporation.

I remind you the purpose of this law is to prevent social class
frictions and while you may feel we should only prosecute the rich who
wear contraband Rolexes in principle you are just as guilty.

Please take the contraband items to your nearest Peace Station and you
may want to put your pets in the kennel as you will have to do some time
in Reprogramming.

Equality Under Law

DJ ASB
Peace Officer

I was invited to spin on 'Riders of the Plastic Groove'  on KUCI 88.9 fm
in Irvine, California on 12/27.  It was a really fun show!  Here's the
tracklisting in this format:

Artist
Title
Label

I taped most of the show... about 2 hours of music, including most of my
set and some of DJ Blend's set.  I haven't listened to it yet, so I can't
attest to the recording quality, but I think it's okay :)


Here we go!

In-Reply-To: <Pine.BSI.3.95.961227080608.22968A-100000@value.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.3.95.961228170807.28449C-100000@pluto>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Dear Black Adder,

	I'm sure some people would argue that just because they subscribed
to a list doesn't mean that a lot of the messages they receive via that
list aren't unsolicited.  And it is possible to be placed on a list
without your knowledge or consent.  This happened to me a few weeks ago
after I left email on a web site. 
	However I'll accept your distinction between list-spam mail and
more purely unsolicisted spam mail as a valid one, and I agree that given
the ease of sending messages in cyberspace, some REASONABLE restriction on
truly unsolicited advertising mail is called for.
	What troubles me most is the vagueness of the law, vague laws
being the tools of despots.
	If it were rewritten with an exact meaning leaving no wriggle room
for cops, attorneys, politicians, and judges, AND if our justice system
were reformed so that cases are not prosecuted unless the victim(s) or
their relations (not the government!) seek prosecution, then I see no
problem.
	But when the government can potentially levy ruinous charges
against you for sending email that the recipient may have been
perfectly happy to receive, something is rotten in Denmark.
	
Whether 'tis nobler or not,   ;)

				<<< Starchild >>>


My computer tells me that on Fri, 27 Dec 1996, Black Adder shared:

> > ___________________________________________________________________________
> > "By US Code Title 47, Sec.227(a)(2)(B),a computer/modem/printer meets the
> > definition of a telephone fax machine.  By Sec.227(b)(1)(C), it is unlawful
> > to send any unsolicited advertisement to such equipment.  By Sec.227(b)(3)(C),
> > a violation of the aforementioned Section is punishable by action to recover
> > actual monetary loss, or $500, whichever is greater, for each violation."
> > ___________________________________________________________________________
> 
> Seeing as people subscribed to a mailing list, receiving mail from that
> list would not fall under the definiton of unsolicited. 
> 
> It hasn't happened here yet, but several other lists I am on have been
> spammed repeatedly, which decreases the usefulness of the list for all
> involved. The law has been brought up by those who continually receive
> unsolicited (almost always commercial) via email or Usenet. Personally, I
> am happy it exists, and hope some of the sleaze-merchants who routinely
> forge addresses and dupe unwitting folks into giving them money for a list
> of "prospective clients" get burnt hard.
> 
> People have a right to free speech yes. However that right does not extend
> into *my* mailbox.
> 
> 
>                                         Black Adder

Just so people don't get the idea that everyone on SFR is a big ol' 
glasses tapin', pocket protector waerin' geek; I'm going to punch in here 
and say: I am a big ol' trendy ass, lable hor. Just this Monday I went to 
Mad wearing GAT shorts, A GAT T-shirt, and a GAT backpack full of 
Tootsiepops(tm). Yeah, I know the GAT backpack cost twice what it should 
have, and it's kind of a lousy backpack, but I don't care. I look good 
and that is what is important.

Labels rule. I just replaced the PLUS-8 slipmats on my TECHNICS 
turntables with RAMPANT slipmats. Not because there was anything wrong 
with the old slipmats; I just wanted to hype RAMPANT. Sometimes if I 
somehow end up with clothes that don't have a label (gasp) I iron on a 
FRIENDS AND FAMILY logo, so everyone will know how cool I am.

Of course for many of us, our aceptance of labels depends on how we feel 
about that particular lable. For example when I go to a rave I like to 
see: GAT, Clobber, Fresh Jive, Addidas, Technics, Airwalk, Childrens 
Television Workshop. I am; however, less than thrilled when I see: Nike, 
Grateful Dead, or Doc Martens. Please darlings It's gonna be the late 
'90s in just a couple of days. Isn't it about time to loose the '80s (and 
worse) fashions?

PS for snot value: I typed this message on an Apple copmuter while 
listening to a MAXELL tape in a SONY deck pushing a pair of HARMON KARDON 
speakers, now I'm gonna upload it using a GLOBAL VILLAGE modem.

Here are some more labels just for fun: Nikon, Honda(motor bikes), 
Yamaha(sound eguipment), Roland, Peets, Stanton, Spyderco, TDK, Agfa, 
Kodak, Mole Richardson, Kino Flo, Zo, Vanson, Red Wing.



DJ Ulrich
standish@sirius.com

Subject: karma review
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-id: <01IDK0EOB3NY9ZLOIR@SONOMA.EDU>
X-VMS-To: SMTP%"sfraves@hyperreal.com"

Precedence: bulk

i came to karma with the thought it wouldn't get broken up. that it 
didn't. :) I'm glad i decided to go, because the trance was hard and 
the mixes were out of my mind, always a step
ahead.. which i only usually experience
while dancing to jungle. :)  the times i WAS on the dancefloor.. 
hearing "commander tom" dropped at just the right time, thomas 
trouble's Johnny Cash record "take a drink of water leeeeerooyyy"... 
the music was PHAT, the chill room could have used some ambient, cuz 
the music upstairs was barely audible, but after awhile the constant 
sound of people talking and people playing with flutes and beepers 
made a music of it's own.. :)
	i can say it was WONDERFUL running into leslie and pablo 
there, and aryck and lay-cee, and many other great people
and having great conversations with all 
of them.. however, the vibe was weird.. i sensed negative tension 
from other people just walking down the stairs, but it was something 
to ignore i suppose.. and how EASILY ignorable it was, once engaged 
in a conversation about life.. or on the dancefloor (which was hot, 
but the sound system and the phat music made up for the sweat that 
was lost)...
	the night ended so quickly, and i was left with the thought 
to hit the next karma party up and bring more positive energy (AND 
candy) to share.. :) 
anyhow, i'm off to the snow and won't be able to share NYE with 
ya'all so happy new year's in advance and take care!!
Love,
LAra

Subject: Karma review
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



	When I got to the map point & found out that this
party was in the Galactic Tunnel space I was fully prepared
for it to suck - but I was pleasantly surprised instead. There
does seem to be some kind of dark energy around that space,
but I thought that it was completely dispelled by the positive
energy of many of the people there. The acoustic problems of
the space haven't gone away, but it did sound better in there
this time. I particularly enjoyed Dutch's set at the end.
The air never got completely unbreathable, just the normal rave 
steambath with smoke. By the end of the nite the feeling on the
dance floor was just outstanding. 

	I didn't bring much to give away this time - some Gatorade
& a couple tapes. I did bring some musical toys to share, and people
seemed to enjoy them. 

	On the personal down side (I'm going to be charitable here) 
somebody appears to have mistakenly taken my backpack (purple, 
containing Gatorade, Arrowhead water, some clothing). Not a huge
loss, but there was a special jacket in it that was a gift. If 
anybody knows anything about it, please feel free to contact
me.

	It was nice to meet: Thomas, Lorin (again), Jeremy (again), and 
the woman with the Euro accent whose name I've forgotten (sorry :<).

	I'd do the whole thing again, backpack & all.

From: Pablo Beck <pablin@buckler.com>
Subject: KARMA Review (late!)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hi alls, just thought I should leave a review of KARMA,

I got there at around 12:30, the music could be heard all the
way from Market St. So I had no problem finding the place :)

The place was weird, but it looked really cool. You go in
and there are this stairs that go up, off to the right 
(after going up the first set of stairs) was the chill room...
as soon as I got there it was completely DARK. All you could
see was Nothing. but I noticed that there were people in there
and I didn't want to flash any light on people's faces ;) 
(talk about BAD trip) so I continued back up the stairs...

The Upstairs part I guess was the Dance room (duh)..it was
a long passage way, the DJ at the very end... it was reallly
really really HOT and WET, but there were alot of nice
people as well as some 'weird' viby people. There were some
really rude people who asked me for a cigarette and they didn't
even say Thanks...but I gave them one anyhow.

I went back downstairs and now the chill room was full of light.
there wasn't any music but people singing, playing musical instruments
and beepers and cell phones and such other artifacts. I found Lara
at the Chill out room :) and we hung out and such throughout the night...
she gave me a really cool bracelet and lots of good vibes. I was also
fortunate to meet her friends April, Paul and other people that I will
not attempt to remember their names 'cause guessing is bad! ;) 
(sorry guys! I remember your faces though!)

** The worst part of the night:
I was chatting and playing with toys with Lara and APril and the rest
when suddently this girl comes in and she's being lifted up by this
really tall weird vibe person and such... but then she keeps falling
and crawling on the floor, about to pass out. Looked like she mixed
Alcohol and GHB[?] but she was like passing out and didn't want anyone
to help her and stuff... it was a real bad trip for some people. This
girl though, was the same RUDE girl that bummed a Cigarrette off of me.
talk about KARMA!

There was also ALOT of alcohol going around... specially in the
stairway. Some people had a couple of 40s in paper bags and such and
were passing it around. there is nothing more obnoxsious [sp?] than
someone drunk. ugh...I can't stand it. but its a personal thing.
I just don't think people should DRINK at raves...other than Water and 
Fruit juices...
 
** The Best Part of the night:
Hanging out with Lara and Hope and April and Paul and all their friends.
It was really really cool to share my toys and candy with people. I 
specially enjoyed signing their books and such (even though I never have
much to say cause my mind totally goes blind!) but I had a great time :)

The other best part of the night was the fact I was SOBER... (yay for me)
I was able to feel vibes and be happy without the need for drugs :) I
met this really cool girl that kept talking about Thailand and the parties
there. Its sooooooooo cool to talk to people specially when they totally
open up and just start talking and talking and talking!! :) its so rad to
hear peoples stories and such. She had greeat stories and we also were
talking about Hindu gods and such (it was started by the ALL TOGETHER NOW flyer)
and I showed her my Ganesha necklace and stuff it was really cool :) I also
met her friend who had a French accent...really *nice*. he didn't say much
unfortunately, but he was *nice* :P~

Anyhow...
Thats about it, I left the party around 4:30 or so... (I know, I basically
missed
Dutch's set.) but I had to get home... I was exhausted! ;)

'Till next time!
Love
Pab





:o) :o) :o) :o) :o) =8P =) =) =) =) =) =) =) =)
Pablo R Beck ------------------ (707)550-2083

> I am a big ol' trendy ass, lable hor. Just this Monday I went to 
> Mad wearing GAT shorts, A GAT T-shirt, and a GAT backpack full of 
> Tootsiepops(tm).

free at Guadalahara Grill in Concord too.

> Labels rule. I just replaced the PLUS-8 slipmats on my TECHNICS 
> turntables with RAMPANT slipmats. Not because there was anything wrong 
> with the old slipmats; I just wanted to hype RAMPANT. Sometimes if I 
> somehow end up with clothes that don't have a label (gasp) I iron on a

OK so this is a parody of my parody--

I guess the real question about trendy materialistic types (if that's
what they really are--which is kind of a catch all when somebody might
have been given the item...etc.--vs. so-called non-materialists (which
is an oxymoron--since their cars, tv's, stereos, all have labels (thus
they are inadvertently advertising also) is:

don't your shit stink too?

Or are you (in your mind) somehow better as a person?

Just by living in a city and using computers, etc, you are participating
in the western materialistic rat race.

So if you go to a party in Birkenstocks (excuse me--generic third party
sandals), your second hand clothes, and you ride the bus instead of
driving, does that mean you will reach heaven (or Nirvana, etc.) before
me?

It's ironic because the Hip Hop trend of wearing garish logos came out
of ghetto culture--people with almost no wealth trying to create an
image--as they have to live day to day watching white people enjoy their
ill-gotten wealth on TV, media, etc. (i.e. 300 years of imperialism,
slavery, land grabs from natives and Mexico, etc.)

So now that the "cream" of American cracker culture has enjoyed
unprecedented wealth and security its easy to "drop out" and feel
somehow "superior" because you dabble in psuedo-Buddhist/Hindu
non-materialism.

It's ironic that the descendants of people who thought that Africans and
Native Americans were "animals" not worthy of human rights now make a
fad of trying to look and act like native people from those cultures
i.e. dreadlocks, native jewelry, dance styles, etc. and for an example
drop in on an African dance class in any trendy urban area and you will
find it full of Huppys (Hippy Yuppies) half of which are pursuing their
"alternative" non-materialistic lifestyle thanks to a subsidy from their
fat capitalistic parents , a trust fund, or welfare.

Some people feel superior because they wear cheap T shirts and generic
jeans or wear a Hippy uniform.  I guess they can feel good about
themselves because they can dog out the people that derive enjoyment
from name brands or that pursue a flamboyant lifestyle because they rose
out of poverty and the logic of wearing rags doesn't dawn on them.

Perhaps even more ironic is that most of the current trends in the dance
scene all came from ghetto culture 10 or 20 years ago--and as usual
white people are mimicking the descendants of our former slaves--witness
the explosion of white Blues artists doing 40-50 y/o styles.

The original Hippys and Beatnicks pursued a lifestyle that was
outrageous to the conservatives fresh out of "Elvis" style rock & roll. 
Having long hair and freaky clothes was a challenge because schools made
you cut it and bullies would mock you.  Hippys rebelled against the
status quo of their time.

Now that the Alternative lifestyle is the status quo it's just as fun to
dress GQ or Hip Hop and get the same flack from the Alternatives who are
just as narrow-minded and conservative in their "hipness" and have as
many Props now as any other genre (bangles, bongs, dayglo posters,
piercings, tie dye, dreadlocks, Grateful Dead paraphenalia <decals, t
shirts, bumper stickers> and don't forget the designer label baggy
shorts!  Yes Virginia these costumes cost money too check out any barter
fair.

In closing--how this relates to raves--I believe that during the Rave
the Laws of Hipness are suspended and you may pretend it's Halloween and
stop being judgmental of the people around you whether they are in Dr.
Suess outfits, plastic clothes, business suits or Hippy uniforms.  If
this is a real problem for you consume mass quantities of alcohol or
illicit substances and try again <unless you are pregnant, a minor, or
in your right mind>

Jack of All Fads, Master of None

DJ ASB

PS:  By the way it's "Label Ho" get yer spelling right mate!  :)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Dec 30 08:39:11 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id IAA13568; Mon, 30 Dec 1996 08:39:11 -0800 (PST)
Received: from misnt1.rely.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with SMTP id IAA13555; Mon, 30 Dec 1996 08:39:03 -0800 (PST)

Message-ID: <c=US%a=_%p=SoftwarExpress%l=MISNT1-961230164427Z-364@misnt1.rely.com>
From: Adam Guevara <aguevara@rely.com>
To: "'Sfraves@Hyperreal.com'" <Sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: The weekend in retrospect
Date: Mon, 30 Dec 1996 08:44:27 -0800
X-Mailer:  Microsoft Exchange Server Internet Mail Connector Version 4.0.994.63
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


One word sums up this weekend:

Wow.

OK make that three:

Wow, no really.

Friday:  __ Karma III __

Afta getting off work I buzzed straight up to SF to pickup my Gateway
ticket and hang with some of my friends in Ye Grand ole City.  I ran
into Mystr-E on the Haight and we chatted about the scene, music,
parties, and what not for a bit...  Grabbed a bite, picked up a
bunch'o'friends, and headed to "the spot"

Got there while Douglas was spinning.  Goa and circle dancing just do
not mix in my opinion.  I see goa as a more free association of dancing
than "set" dancing which is what a lot of circle dancers do.  DJ D was
DATing some serious tunes tho' .  Got warmed up and loose though.
Mystr-E was next and for the fist few songs it sounded as if he was
doing the Goa-trnce thing as well.. But soon enough that cyber started
resonating through the speakers.  Dancing to trance got me 'there' a few
times through E's set.  I had to bail once or twice tho' (that damn leg
kicks in every once-in-a-while).  Too bad the sound kept cutting out
intermittently as well.  I think Thomas didn't like that either, he kept
running around like a chicken with it's head cut off, "cluck, cluck,
BCLOOCK!!".  Dancing next to the speaker and then silence. didn't help
the vibe much either.  

I was kickin' it when Thomas started causin' Trouble on the turntables.
I must admit, the man has an ear for jams esp. when he thru on that one
track w/the lyric "I see, I see, I see Red".  My body bounced up and
started dancing before my mind registered what was going on.
And then the whole thing went to a complete and utter halt when someone
tripped on a wire. (Ooops.).  We all scrambled like eggs to get things
up and running again.  

The sound recovered just in time for MARS set.  Mars is truly turning
into a very versatile DJ.  He spun some decent trance and went into some
chanting type trancy music...  It seems that he keeps his sets very
different from each other: from New Order, to hard dark trance, to
melodic soothing trance.  But it was during Mars set when I found IT.
The most incredible "here it is" feeling of anything:  I found the air
conditioner on the dance floor. 

I stayed a bit longer for Dutch bit bailed since I had to get some
friends back to their houses.

Saturday:  __ Galactic Tunnel __

I have to say before reviewing, that I hadn't had a wink of sleep since
Thursday night.  
Again Saturday I was running around the Haight until dusk.  Arriving to
"the spot" at 11PM.  The sound system was noticeably smaller but much
more cleaner.  Mystr-E did a much more clever set, very ON IMO...  I
kept dancing until Mr. Body did a "Force Quit"  and I crashed out in a
corner.  

I power napped for about an hour (till 2AM) . Waking up to techno can be
very uplifting.  I bust it to Carls Jr, fast some food and got back to
catch Ivo's set.  I have to say that in the world of goa dat DJ's, IVO
is one of the most technically competent vinyl goa DJs that Ive heard
yet.  No wonder he spins out frequently @ clubs.  The music, the smoke
and the vibe brought me back to the dance floor for about another hour
and a half.  I ran into a few friends and we bailed around 5:30 AM.

Through both nights I ran into many friends and family (hello, Mark,
Jay, Heidi, Sebastan (Another killer acid techno Dj from Germany),
Diane(sp?), Sabine, Scott, and a whole bunch of folk whose names escape
me.).  I'd also like to thank those who invited me to their UG's in the
upcoming weeks and as for the invite only UG's, I promise that no word
will escape my lips.

This weekend was a great ramp up for the NYE parties....
And It was a great experience WITHOUT anything illegal (or legal for
that matter) in my system.

"See you all at the Gateway (and maybe another) event on NYE"

--Adam
"Stay Connected..."

To: Pablo Beck <pablin@buckler.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: *B* <branka@sirius.com>
Subject: Re: KARMA Review & drinking...
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

At 10:49 PM -0000 12/29/96, Pablo Beck wrote:
>There was also ALOT of alcohol going around... specially in the
>stairway. Some people had a couple of 40s in paper bags and such and
>were passing it around. there is nothing more obnoxsious [sp?] than
>someone drunk. ugh...I can't stand it. but its a personal thing.
>I just don't think people should DRINK at raves...other than Water and
>Fruit juices...

Here I go again (I feel like I have been saying this since I've joined the
list, but why not)...

I think it is pretty hypocritical to say that people should not drink at
raves.  Why not?  There are people who get fu**ed up on all sorts of
substances and why not have alcohol as one of them.  I think that there are
people who cannot deal with being fu**ed up, no matter what the substance
is.  I have seen enough people Eed out of there mind that their behavior
gets annoying as well as frightening.  I personally don't do E, so should I
say "I don't think people should do E at raves".  No, because I know the
other side of the picture where people on E are nice, and they know how to
behave without being annoying.

Same thing is with alcohol.  I love drinking and I wish there were more
drinking parties.  I do agree that there are people who cannot handle their
alcohol well, but there are always people who can't handle something.  I
have seen enough people drinking at small parties (house parties
especially) who behave themselves, and who are way fun to be with.  Not all
people who drink get annoying and just because you had few incidents with
them and because you are against drinking you shouldn't be labeling
everybody who enjoys a drink or two.  Drinking can be fun, as well as doing
other things, but you have to know the limits (as with everything) and know
how to be who you are no matter what you are on.

Please give some of us a chance,
*B*

P.S.  I am sure there are plenty of people who feel the same way as Pablo,
and I am sure they already have that labeling stuck in their head "this
person is drinking alcohol, therefore they must be annoying, drunks
whatever-not".  If you are one of them just think about what I said and
maybe you will be able to look at those people in a different way, rather
than judging them before you even met them

                      The 1997 SFR New Year's Eve Guide!

             http://www.hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/gencal.cgi

OK, everybody!  Barring any last-minute entries, here's the lowdown for
New Year's Eve in a handy clip-out table.  Details are below.  I'm not sure
if Stompy wanted their location public, ask me if you're really interested.

Personally, Pacific/Gateway and Cloud Factory look the most exciting 
as reliable undergrounds.  I'd recommend getting advance tix as well.
Spundae and Origin have good lineups as well but may be more conventional, 
while Planet New Year looks huge if you like that.  The Art Salon should be 
groovy if you're more into the downtempo scene.  I don't really know much about
the E-Den people or the Midnight Express people; and Universe isn't really a
rave, but it'll have some prime house.  

Happy New Year!
			-Derek

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

>-----Original Message-----

>
>I think it is pretty hypocritical to say that people should not drink at
>raves.  Why not?  There are people who get fu**ed up on all sorts of
>substances and why not have alcohol as one of them.  I think that there are
>people who cannot deal with being fu**ed up, no matter what the substance is.
>[Adam G]  ***Snip snip snip snip****
>Same thing is with alcohol.  I love drinking and I wish there were more
>drinking parties.  I do agree that there are people who cannot handle their
>alcohol well, but there are always people who can't handle something.  I have
>seen enough people drinking at small parties (house parties especially) who
>behave themselves, and who are way fun to be with.  Not all people who drink
>get annoying and just because you had few incidents  [Adam G]  ***Snip snip
>snip snip snip***  are no matter what you are on.
>
>Please give some of us a chance,
>*B*
> 
>****What I think, is that the big A is a sneaky drug you drink and drink and
>think your OK until WHAM! 
>"Hey, I think I'm Drink..." 
>Booze also affects your motor reactions causing one to trip and slip.  I
>actually had to help (along with two other fellas) someone walk down the
>stairs to get outside @ GT on Friday.  Not fun.  
>
>The other probelm is alcohol is a powerful drug.  Powerful enough to kill
>with the combination of other drugs.  I've smoked out and E'ed B-4... I've
>candyfliped in my wylder days.  But I will NEVER consume alcohol with any
>other substance (save tobacco).  Im not a drinker anymore.  I used to be oh,
>6-7yrs. ago and I might have one drink in a socal situation.  Yea, getting
>drunk is cool but control while drunk is hard sometimes.  And it's the youth,
>possibly the largest part of the rave population (and the least that have
>control) that gets drunk to the point of sloshyness. 
>
>Another thing is alcohlics.  Im sure there's not one person on this list that
>has a friend or relative that has a drinking problem.  I know I do, several
>in fact.  So I can see why many do not want to "see" these people @ raves,

>event due to the combination of liquor and E.  (Does anyone remember that
>party last year???)...

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Dec 30 15:01:39 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id PAA10693; Mon, 30 Dec 1996 15:01:39 -0800 (PST)

	 <sfraves@hyperreal.com>,
        "'*B*'" <branka@sirius.com>
Subject: RE: KARMA Review & drinking...
Date: Mon, 30 Dec 1996 14:58:21 -0800
X-Mailer:  Microsoft Exchange Server Internet Mail Connector Version 4.0.993.5
