Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


A rave should be full of color; energy; love.

Drugs like LSD; E; and Weed are colorful.  Alcohol is dark.  I associate
booze with the slugs you see on Market St. at night.

Alcohol is for a special kind of person, a 'tuff' guy.  Tuff people are
attracted to it because if maintains that tuff attitude.  Let me
explain.  Say there is a group of guys, they work together at UPS.  Off
work; they hang out at each others homes or the local sports or country
/ western bar.  They ware 'tuff' cloths, eat cheap fast food, and don't
mind getting in a fight now and then.  Alcohol is perfect.  Drink a
little, and you get tuffer.  Drink more, and your ready for a fight.
Think of how many times you have seen EXACT examples of this, in a movie
when a character needs to "get up his courage", and belts down a swig on
whiskey.  He did not light up a joint, he drank booze, because it makes
him 'tuff'.

Now suppose the guy does a hit of acid.  Suddenly, he wants to talk
about what his friends consider 'nonsense'.  He is in no mood for a
fight.  And suddenly realizes a bar is a terribly boring place to spend
a evening.  Any all the talk of smashing a gays face sounds stupid.
It's a whole different mindset.  People high on LSD or E have no
interest in being around a drunk.  Drunks may be dangerous.

Think about it.  How many times have you see two people sit down and
smoke a joint, then get in a fight?  How many times have you seen
friends drinking, they get louder and louder until trouble starts.
Almost every case I can remember that trouble has occurred, somebody has
been drinking.  That is why I feel the way I do, I formulated my opinun
based on years of observation in social situations.  Statistics support
my conjecture:  95 % homicides involve drinking.  98 % of assaults have
some body drunk.  I bet most cops would rather have to deal with a group
of stoned people then a bunch of hot headed drunks.

If I wanted to be with people drinking, I would go to the local bar.  In
my opinun; a rave should be 100% alcohol free.  I want to be in a crowd
of stoned / tripping people with Goa Trance, Strobe lights, lasers,
smoke machines, color everywhere, and everybody in a very loving mode.
Alcohol kills the vibe.
>----------
>From: 	*B*[SMTP:branka@sirius.com]
>Sent: 	Monday, December 30, 1996 12:40 PM
>To: 	Pablo Beck; sfraves@hyperreal.com
>Subject: 	Re: KARMA Review & drinking...
>
>I am sure there are plenty of people who feel the same way as Pablo,
>and I am sure they already have that labeling stuck in their head "this
>person is drinking alcohol, therefore they must be annoying, drunks
>whatever-not".  If you are one of them just think about what I said and
>maybe you will be able to look at those people in a different way, rather
>than judging them before you even met them
>
>
>

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Dec 30 16:05:16 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id QAA15533; Mon, 30 Dec 1996 16:05:16 -0800 (PST)

Date: Mon, 30 Dec 1996 16:05:01 -0800 (PST)
From: Leonardo <wizard@armory.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: RE: drinking...
In-Reply-To: <c=US%a=_%p=netro-corp%l=NETRO-NT1-961230225821Z-563@netro-nt1.netro-corp.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.SCO.3.91.961230153410.10871A-100000@deepthought.armory.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I feel like I really should put in my two cents here..

Without placing any judgement of those who partake in the mass
consumption of alcohol (because the effects of the drug affect
the user much more than the user affects the effect of the drug),
I think we have to recognize that alcohol has its evil effects
on everyone.  Sure, I can see how people enjoy the value of
having a couple drinks to help them wind down and relax, or let
go of their inhibitions.. and I think this happens because it
shuts down part of your thinking; it makes you drowsy.  At the same
time, alcohol is indeed a dark substance bringing out some
undesirable parts of the subconscious.  Although there are
(perhaps many) people who use marijuana or other peace-inducing
drugs and still maintain that "tuff" attitude, it is because
of how big a part that attitude plays in their conscious lives.
My problem with alcohol is not that it makes certain people
"annoying", but that, even among friends, it causes feelings
of aggresiveness, arrogance, superiority, and disrespect to
surface.  The more you drink, the greater the effect, until
you become so drowsy you become too lazy to let your thought/
emotions influence your actions, and eventually cease to have
many thoughts/emotions whatsoever.
Without discussing the benefits of other drugs, or being judgemental
of "alcoholics", I just wanted to say something on the nature
of alcohol that everyone should acknowledge so they can better
understand why there are those of us out there who would rather
have alcohol-free events that would have a more positive vibe
and loving attitude.

Peace,

Leonardo

Subject: what is vibe/ranting and ravingRE: KARMA Review & drinking...
In-Reply-To: <c=US%a=_%p=netro-corp%l=NETRO-NT1-961230225821Z-563@netro-nt1.netro-corp.com>

***Warning: this post has scattered rants and raves, and a long
conclusion that follows...***
Maybe its the rain...maybe vast generalizations annoy me...especially when
I am one of those generalized! but this post is not about being annoyed,
mainly about the rain otside, me trying to describe what I think a vibe is
and my personal argument for more beer...I mean uhhh...personal
responsibility.

> A rave 
>should be ??
>full of color; energy; love.

A rave **should be** nothing, a rave **should be** everything you want it 
to be and it should be nothing that you want, nothing
**should be** anything...could have, should have, and I cant are three
concepts that should be I-) removed from our thoughts... 

> 
> Drugs like LSD; E; and Weed are colorful. 
that depends on how much you use!

> Alcohol is dark.
not true, there are lots of light alcohols, try any domestic big name
beer on the market you will notice that it is definately light. ales tend
to be on the darker side, now, if your talking bass ale or guiness then I
would have to agree with you that these alcohols are dark. 

> I associate
> booze with the slugs you see on Market St. at night.
...yeah, and I associate weed and acid with the junkies and freaks I see
everyday on telegraph ave. and haight street. and e? you should see those
freaks that go to raves and take e and all night and have all night
pagan sex parties.

> 
> Alcohol is for a special kind of person, a 'tuff' guy. 
-e is for that special kind of 'sensitive' person
-weed is for that special kind of 'confused' person
-acid is for that special kind of 'reality challenged' person

> work; they hang out at each others homes or the local sports or country
> / western bar.  They ware 'tuff' cloths, eat cheap fast food, and don't
> mind getting in a fight now and then.  Alcohol is perfect.  Drink a
> little, and you get tuffer.  Drink more, and your ready for a fight.
-I think that this is a totally absurd argument...what are 'tuff' clothes
are they made under some sister company of adidas? (ha ha I-)) what does
fast food have to do with drinking and why does it need be cheap? 

-how many of you have ever sat in a room of ramen eatin, bong tokin,
'dirty' clothes wearin, unemployed, dont even leave the couch to clean the
stinkin hole theyre livin in much less go outside & do something
productive...  (yeah...the good ole days ;-))

> Think of how many times you have seen EXACT examples of this, 
yes, I agree, I do know of this stereotype that you are talking about...
but...(conclusion to follow below) 

> Alcohol kills the vibe.

now, time for me to hold the conch...
	the way i see it is that there are different energies in the
universe. and different energies inside all of us. the combined energies
of all the peoples and the energies they are channeling or trying to
reach for at a rave makes up for what we call the 'vibe'.
	The way i see it, the vibe we feel and find around us is
intimately connected to the individuals emotional system, (or it might be
the same thing, but thats a tangent) and what I have found in my
experience is that my emotional state does not stay the same over time.
And I feel that that is very healthy for me. Sometimes i want to feel the
happy-trippy vibe that you use to refer to what a rave is, and sometimes I
want something with a shade of black, or white, or spirit, or whatever.
But what i dont want is to go to a rave and find the same thing everytime.
How boring would that be?...pick your favorite vibe, ...now try to imagine
how long you could be stuck in that vibe before it drives you insane?
	change and variety are what make me feel that I am alive and
experiencing life as opposed to being some rabbits dream.
	the whole thing about realizing this relationship between your
emotions(vibe) and the overall vibe you experience as your relationship to
your environment (whether that be a rave or work or whatever) is that it
empowers you to have some degree of control over the life you experience.
tangent--> I think that this is something that alot of people are starting
to realize ( or maybe Im just projecting this...) not only in the rave
scene, (although I have found a higher concentration here)  but
everywhere.
	So, how does this all relate to alcohol at raves? it relates in
two ways but the idea is much bigger than just for alcohol at raves.
duh...alcohol, e, acid, pot, ghb, coffee are all drugs and can all
be abused and used. All the drugs except for e, i can give personal
accounts of its both positive uses and negative abuses.
tangent--> My personal opinion on e is that it makes me feel weird,
because most of the time, I can find that e feeling naturally by tuning
into it...but that feeling is also something that I re-learned how to
channel from taking e.

I think that what it basically comes down to is personal responsibility
and respect for self.
Dont put yourself in bad situations or bad vibes, be aware of who you
are partying with, be aware of the vibe you are recieving and putting out,
know the promoters and dj's for the parties you attend, or at least
know what kind of vibe they tend to plant before you decide to get really
hi, or decide to trust them enough to trance out.

-As a promoter putting on a rave, you have a very
important role and one of the responsibilities is planting the seeds which
will grow into full vibes over the course of the night.
-As a dj you are taking possibly many people some of who may be in very
hypersuggestive states on journees inside their consciousness, respect
that power.
-We collectively here on sfraves are also all creating the vibe which we
feel at the parties we go to together, whether or not we know each other
personally. 

i dont mean to sound like a know it all or anything like that, these are
things that i am constantly realizing and trying to put into practice in
my life...so i guess that is all I really have to say, ttfn =)

 respect yourself...the rest will follow

I-)
tr.

ps. if you see me enjoying a petes wicked winter brew at a party...dont
worry, im not the fighting type =)

Date: Mon, 30 Dec 1996 19:26:14 -0800 (PST)
From: Rob Rayle <robertr@autodesk.com>
Message-Id: <199612310326.TAA06251@klaatu.autodesk.com>
To: branka@sirius.com, pablin@buckler.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: KARMA Review & drinking...
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

 
> Same thing is with alcohol.  I love drinking and I wish there were more
> drinking parties.  I do agree that there are people who cannot handle their
> alcohol well, but there are always people who can't handle something.

        Well, I don't have any personal stake in it one way or the other,
as I am a total abstainer from all drugs (including alcohol) and have been
for many years. My attitude towards a drug is mostly based on how much I 
like or dislike hanging around other people who are on that drug, not on what
it does for me personally. 

	Alcohol is my least favorite drug to be around. Actually, it's
pretty much a tie between hanging around alcohol abusers who have plenty
of booze and hanging around junkies who don't have enough opiates - those
are my two least favorite types to be near. 

	Clearly, not everyone who drinks abuses alcohol. But if twenty
people come to a rave to drink, you bet your ass at least *one* of them 
will be an abuser. Alcohol abusers have poor impulse control & often act 
out violently. I don't want to be around that. Short of violence, abusers 
just tend to get obnoxious. They also throw up - often in inappropriate 
places. They also pass out, which I suppose doesn't hurt anything (unless
the party gets busted) but they're not adding a lot either. The rest of
it hurts the scene. Again, not everybody who uses alcohol abuses it, but 
the abusers are the most visible ones - they're the ones going out & 
drinking the most.


	And what makes the rave scene different from the bar scene? 
I think a big part of it is the emphasis on psychedelics rather than 
alcohol. Yes, people can get pretty schizo from psychedelics as well, 
but it just isn't as common, and the up side is that people who are having
positive experiences with psychedelics are often really fun to be around.

	The other thing that makes it different from the bar scene
is respect for & tolerance of those who choose not to use. That's completely
absent from the bar scene. If I go into a bar & don't drink the general attitude 
is that I'm not enough of a man - because real men can down a couple fifths of
Jack Daniel's and not get drunk. 


	I think that the tolerance towards non-users also stems partially
from the emphasis on psychedelics - because it's generally recognized that 
a psychedelic user who wants to stay sane and also wants to go out to raves
more than once a week/month/year ( <- reader's choice ) is going to end up 
hitting some raves sober.


	Anyone can bring just about anything into a rave and nobody
is going to start patting people down for unapproved substances at 
the door. I've seen that demonstrated many times. And I'm sure that
you personally, Branka, will not engage in any of the objectionable
behaviors I've listed above relating to alcohol abuse. And I'm sure
that it will be great fun to meet you & hang out with you sometime, 
whether or not you've got a couple drinks in you. But, Branka, if 
you do decide to come out to a warehouse party instead of the many
bars where they play this kind of music, can you promise you won't
be bringing along some friend who doesn't hold their liquor quite as 
well as you do? Because I don't find people who are drunk funny. 
At best they're pathetic and degraded, and at worst they're dangerous.

weekend. Your going to lose.

: work; they hang out at each others homes or the local sports or country
: / western bar.  They ware 'tuff' cloths, eat cheap fast food, and don't
: mind getting in a fight now and then.  Alcohol is perfect.  Drink a

: Think of how many times you have seen EXACT examples of this, in a movie
: when a character needs to "get up his courage", and belts down a swig on
: whiskey.  He did not light up a joint, he drank booze, because it makes
: him 'tuff'.

: about what his friends consider 'nonsense'.  He is in no mood for a
: fight.  And suddenly realizes a bar is a terribly boring place to spend

: interest in being around a drunk.  Drunks may be dangerous.
:

: smoke a joint, then get in a fight?  How many times have you seen
: friends drinking, they get louder and louder until trouble starts.
: Almost every case I can remember that trouble has occurred, somebody has
: been drinking.  That is why I feel the way I do, I formulated my opinun
: based on years of observation in social situations.  Statistics support
: my conjecture:  95 % homicides involve drinking.  98 % of assaults have

DJ ASB (CMG Records) Ay wrote:

> don't your shit stink too?

Yep.  Just floated a big, fat, smelly log this morning.  Whoo-ee!

> Just by living in a city and using computers, etc, you are participating
> in the western materialistic rat race.

I never claimed to be anti-materialistic, just that I'm not willing to
pay extra money to advertise someone else's stuff.

> So if you go to a party in Birkenstocks (excuse me--generic third party
> sandals), your second hand clothes, and you ride the bus instead of
> driving, does that mean you will reach heaven (or Nirvana, etc.) before
> me?

No, but the second and third _do_ mean that such a person is generating
less waste and polluting our air less.  Personally, I ride my bicycle to
work most days, and am offended that I have to hack and wheeze because
no one else can be bothered to get out of their cars and locomote
themselves to work on a perfectly fine day.

And no, I'm not perfect.  I still own a car, and drive it sometimes, and
I don't always live up to my own standards.  But I've made tangible
changes, and guess what?  I'm a lot healthier and feel better for it. 
And you all get to breathe a touch easier as a side benefit.  

The only way to stop consuming entirely is to be dead.  "You're not
perfect" is not an argument against doing one's best.

> So now that the "cream" of American cracker culture has enjoyed
> unprecedented wealth and security its easy to "drop out" and feel
> somehow "superior" because you dabble in psuedo-Buddhist/Hindu
> non-materialism.
[more "wannabe culture" rant which I generally agree with snipped]

Now _wait_ just a minute here.  I hope you're not pointing a finger at
me, because 1) you don't know me at all and 2) I don't dabble in etc.

> Some people feel superior because they wear cheap T shirts and generic
> jeans or wear a Hippy uniform.  

"There's nothing wrong with thinking you're better than everyone else;
what's wrong is thinking you deserve something because of it" 
-Ray Stricklin

>From a strictly environmental point of view, wearing Hilfiger is no
worse than wearing a generic T-shirt from Wal-Mart.  What's bad is
buying lots of shit you don't need and never using it, or trying so hard
to stay stylish that you stop wearing stuff well before it's worn out.

Buy good stuff that'll last and that you'll still like next year,
whatever it is.  Don't buy super-trendy shit just because it's trendy,
knowing that you'll be giving it away next year.  Thrift stores are full
of so much shit that makes you ask "How did anyone _ever_ think this was
cool?"

> In closing--how this relates to raves--I believe that during the Rave
> the Laws of Hipness are suspended and you may pretend it's Halloween and
> stop being judgmental of the people around you whether they are in Dr.
> Suess outfits, plastic clothes, business suits or Hippy uniforms.  If
> this is a real problem for you consume mass quantities of alcohol or
> illicit substances and try again <unless you are pregnant, a minor, or
> in your right mind>

Good rant.  Both thumbs up from me.

But -- I reserve the right to pass judgment, and likewise, you are free
to call me a judgmental asshole.  Just make sure you know what I think
before ranting about it...

// grigsbeast

On Mon, 30 Dec 1996, Fred Thornton wrote:

> 
> A rave should be full of color; energy; love.

Maybe, maybe not. Ever been to a minimalistic party where there was no
great color, no happy, shiny people, but music that just blew you away? Is
that any less valid as a "rave?"

> Drugs like LSD; E; and Weed are colorful.  Alcohol is dark.  I associate
> booze with the slugs you see on Market St. at night.

You are taking the best characteristics of the first three drugs, and
comparing them with the worst characteristics of the last. LSD, E, weed,
and alcohol all have the potential for use and abuse. Ever see someone
flip on out on LSD? Ever see or talk to someone who had sex or otherwise
did things they later regretted while under the influnce of any of these
drugs? 

> Alcohol is for a special kind of person, a 'tuff' guy.  Tuff people are
> attracted to it because if maintains that tuff attitude.  Let me
> explain.  Say there is a group of guys, they work together at UPS.  Off
> work; they hang out at each others homes or the local sports or country
> / western bar.  They ware 'tuff' cloths, eat cheap fast food, and don't
> mind getting in a fight now and then.  Alcohol is perfect.  Drink a
> little, and you get tuffer.  Drink more, and your ready for a fight.
> Think of how many times you have seen EXACT examples of this, in a movie
> when a character needs to "get up his courage", and belts down a swig on
> whiskey.  He did not light up a joint, he drank booze, because it makes
> him 'tuff'.

You have been watching too much T.V. 

> Now suppose the guy does a hit of acid.  Suddenly, he wants to talk
> about what his friends consider 'nonsense'.  He is in no mood for a
> fight.  And suddenly realizes a bar is a terribly boring place to spend
> a evening.  Any all the talk of smashing a gays face sounds stupid.
> It's a whole different mindset.  People high on LSD or E have no
> interest in being around a drunk.  Drunks may be dangerous.

Or maybe the friend on LSD decides to go play on the freeway, and gets hit
by a car? It has happened to someone I know. 

People on LSD can be far more dangerous than a drunk. A drunk can be far
more dangerous than a person on LSD. It all depends on the person
involved.

> Think about it.  How many times have you see two people sit down and
> smoke a joint, then get in a fight?  How many times have you seen
> friends drinking, they get louder and louder until trouble starts.
> Almost every case I can remember that trouble has occurred, somebody has
> been drinking.  That is why I feel the way I do, I formulated my opinun
> based on years of observation in social situations.  Statistics support
> my conjecture:  95 % homicides involve drinking.  98 % of assaults have
> some body drunk.  I bet most cops would rather have to deal with a group
> of stoned people then a bunch of hot headed drunks.

Your statistics are completely contrived. Please site your non-existent
source so we can all have a good laugh.


> If I wanted to be with people drinking, I would go to the local bar.  In
> my opinun; a rave should be 100% alcohol free.  I want to be in a crowd
> of stoned / tripping people with Goa Trance, Strobe lights, lasers,
> smoke machines, color everywhere, and everybody in a very loving mode.
> Alcohol kills the vibe.

You've obviously never been to a Sunset.

                                          Black Adder

On Mon, 30 Dec 1996, Leonardo wrote:

> I feel like I really should put in my two cents here..
> 
> Without placing any judgement of those who partake in the mass
> consumption of alcohol (because the effects of the drug affect
> the user much more than the user affects the effect of the drug),
> I think we have to recognize that alcohol has its evil effects
> on everyone.  

No, we don't, because it is simply not true. You are making
generalizations, possibly based on your personal experiences, but that is
all they are, generalizations. You cannot, with any validity state that
alcohol has an evil effect on everyone. In order to do so, it would
require that you know "everyone" and have observed their behaviour under
the influence of any degree of alcohol.

> Sure, I can see how people enjoy the value of
> having a couple drinks to help them wind down and relax, or let
> go of their inhibitions.. and I think this happens because it
> shuts down part of your thinking; it makes you drowsy.  At the same

Gee that sounds suspiciously like the effects of marijuana to me. And that
is the important thing to remember: different substances have different
effects on different people.  

> Without discussing the benefits of other drugs, or being judgemental
> of "alcoholics", I just wanted to say something on the nature
> of alcohol that everyone should acknowledge so they can better
> understand why there are those of us out there who would rather
> have alcohol-free events that would have a more positive vibe
> and loving attitude.

I totally respect and enjoy alcohol-free events. I think that you and
others would do well to be a little more tolerant of those of us that
enjoy a drink once in a while. I promise not to throw up in your lap, or
punch you in the face. 

                                       Black Adder

Date: Mon, 30 Dec 1996 23:33:52 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <l03010d09aeedfe9fca74@[206.184.160.104]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: "Eric P. Peterson" <ericp@best.com>
Subject: A thought about alcohol
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Some thread, eh?  Lots of good points to be made; hope I can add to the
good ones here.  There's a great danger in having alcohol at a party.  That
danger is that, if police find it at an "all-ages" event, those over 21 can
be cited for contributing to the delinquency of, or furnishing alcohol to,
minors.  It doesn't matter if no minor at the event in question had any
alcohol.  Now, someone under 21 can be cited for "minor in possession of
alcohol," so no one is safe.
Opinion: the more alcohol is present at parties, the more likely that
alcohol-related arrests will be made, and the more likely that more parties
will be busted, thus endangering the future of the scene.
Advice: if ya can't be good, be careful ;)
Peace,
Eric

and let some people know that we were never booked and won't be playing the

upon between our booking agent and that Sassoon dude.  It's unfortunate that
some promoters finish their flyers and advertise acts that are not yet
confirmed.  There are at least a few other DJs/acts that are on the same

L.A.

On Mon, 30 Dec 1996 blkadder@value.net wrote:

> No, we don't, because it is simply not true. You are making
> generalizations, possibly based on your personal experiences, but that is
> all they are, generalizations. You cannot, with any validity state that
> alcohol has an evil effect on everyone. In order to do so, it would
> require that you know "everyone" and have observed their behaviour under
> the influence of any degree of alcohol.

You're right.  Alcohol doesn't have an evil effect of everyone.. it has
had an evil (sometimes devastating) effect on almost everyone *I've*
known.  And I don't mean having a few drinks; I mean alcohol as a
way of life, getting shitfaced every other day.  Still, it's true that
it is because of personal experiences that not only do I hold my
subjective view on the nature of alcohol, but I also felt inclined
to put in a comment when I hadn't bothered with all the other
bickerings.  I guess I really didn't want anything acknowledged
other than the fact that I, and others, had reason to feel that way.

> I totally respect and enjoy alcohol-free events. I think that you and
> others would do well to be a little more tolerant of those of us that
> enjoy a drink once in a while. I promise not to throw up in your lap, or
> punch you in the face. 

I *tried* to stress that I wasn't placing ANY judgement on ANYone,
simply on what I see as the nature of (excessive) alcohol.  Alcohol
is alcohol, no matter how you react to it.. that's why I ever tried
to make a generalization on what that substance was.. I never meant
to lash out against millions of people I have not met and should not
have opinions on.  I AM tolerant.. the majority of my friends drink,
almost all of their friends drink, my mother certainly drinks, and
it has ceased to bother me one bit now that I feel comfortable knowing
I won't be sucked in to it again (I was an alcoholic at age 12).
When I expressed my appreciation for alcohol-free events I wasn't
saying I was wary of people who drank, or partying with people who
drank.  I certainly wasn't saying ALL raves "should" be alcohol-free.
The only generalized attitude/opinion I can have towards so many
people I have not met is one of openness and desire to understand.

Peace, and prosperous new year,

Leonardo

I just love how not a single SF jungle DJ is listed in this entire message.
Its great that big jungle acts are coming to SF, but there are local people
who have been working very hard in the jungle scene over the past year and
aren't just jumping on the exploding jungle/drum 'n' bass movement as if its
a bandwagon.  I get more excited when I see local DJs sharing the spotlight
with big names, rather than just the big names themselves.

Regardless, I'll probably be at these events 'cause I love drum 'n' bass
(props to FTT for their work)!

junglism (sf) re-launches January 1st at www.cyberzen.com/jungle/

New beta-site online now!

The scientist does not study nature because it is useful;
he studies it because he delights in it, and he delights in it
because it is beautiful. If nature were not beautiful, it
would not be worth knowing, and if nature were not
worth knowing, life would not be worth living."

Subject: Re: KARMA Review & drinking...
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

At 3:26 AM -0000 12/31/96, Rob Rayle wrote:
>They also throw up - often in inappropriate
>places. They also pass out, which I suppose doesn't hurt anything (unless
>the party gets busted) but they're not adding a lot either. The rest of
>it hurts the scene.

And you can tell me that you have never seen a person on E trowing up?  I
have been going to parties for almost a year now, and I can tell you that I
know enough people who can't take E (sometimes LSD and shrooms) without
trowing up.  And they  are not as messed up as people who get drunk of
their asses.  Their body just can't deal with certain substances....  I
also know one person (on E) who curls up and falls asleep at parties and
then her friends have to look for her.  I guess you can call that passing
out.  I am not even going to start talking about passing out on GHB,
because that's the entire new topic.

>	And what makes the rave scene different from the bar scene?
>I think a big part of it is the emphasis on psychedelics rather than
>alcohol.

What makes a rave scene different IMO is people who come there, not the
drugs they chose to use.

>	The other thing that makes it different from the bar scene
>is respect for & tolerance of those who choose not to use. That's completely
>absent from the bar scene. If I go into a bar & don't drink the general
>attitude
>is that I'm not enough of a man - because real men can down a couple fifths of
>Jack Daniel's and not get drunk.

Maybe one of the biggest problems with Americans and their attitude towards
drinking and people who drink is the society (themselves).  I grew up in
Croatia (Europe) where there is no drinking age, and the attitude towards
drinking is nothing compared to the attitude some people here have.  You
don't drink to get fucked up, you drink because you enjoy it.  And for me
it was more than embarrassing to get drunk of your ass in public (in
Croatia).  Things changed when I moved here, and I was a teenager who
followed the rest - I have been drunk plenty of times, with my collage
friends.  At 26, I know what I can do and what I like to do, so if I go to
a bar and drink one beer and if anybody tells me I am not enough of a girl
:P because I can't drink them under the table, I ignore that person.  Who
cares what they think?  I don't need friends or anybody who will feel like
peer pressuring me into things - that's for kids.

> But, Branka, if you do decide to come out to a warehouse party instead of
>the >many
>bars where they play this kind of music, can you promise you won't
>be bringing along some friend who doesn't hold their liquor quite as
>well as you do?

What are you talking about?  I go to enough warehouse parties, and all my
friends are people who have been going to raves for years.  And coincidence
is that almost all of them drink.  And when we have a house party (rave
like party) we drink.  And when we get home from a rave at 8am in the
morning there is nothing better than a cold beer (my roommate would argue
with me and say gin tonic is better, but what the hell).  And when we go to
Sunset we have beer with us.  I have never seen any of these people cause
any trouble because they were drinking.

>Because I don't find people who are drunk funny.
>At best they're pathetic and degraded, and at worst they're dangerous.

Gee, please make sure when you see me next time (and if I have a beer) not
to walk by me, because you never know, I might turn into a wild and crazy
beast and decide to beat you up.  And you never know, being my size maybe I
will succeed :P.

Few things to keep in mind
- not everybody who drinks is drinking to get drunk
- not everybody who like alcohol (and drinks) is an alcoholic
Please don't abuse these terms.

I would just like to end up this lengthy post with the worts and the best
moment (at parties in *warehouses*) that is related to drinking.

Gateway party this summer 7am
*B*: "I wish I had a cold beer right now".
"?": "Alcoholic?"

WOMO a month ago
- having one of the DJs give me a warm beer at 3am
- walking to the store on Mission at 7am to buy some beer to share with all
my other friends who drink, and seeing another DJ buying a cold 6 pack for
his set :)

Enough defending of recreational drinking,
*B*

P.S. Everything I say is about recreational drinking, not alcoholism

     there are some nice pointers here.  one thing to remember is that 
     people can only give opinions based upon their life experiences.  if 
     someone's had a great life as an LSD tripper, their whole life 
     experience will reflect on such.  look at terence mckenna, one would 
     think the only way to touch the spiritual world is through the 
     psilocybin mushroom.  humph.  
     
     on the other hand, if there are people who have had bad experiences 
     with psychadelicks, they are going to say they are bad.  some people 
     are never able to step out of their reality and realize that we are 
     heavily influenced by our life experiences which are all different 
     from person to person.  
     
     i've been to some really cool wicked parties that they had alcohol at 
     and they opened the bar up again around 6:30 am.  that was delicious, 
     candy flippin, havin a beer and gruvin to markie at 7am.  
     
     
     mmmmmmmmmmmmmmm- m!
     
     well, that's all for now...please disconnect your inhibitions and tear 
     down those walls.  you have my permission. :)
     
     deepfog

Big, Big Thanks to all that went to MAD last night.  Somehow, the club was
absolutely RAMMED! Extra special Thanks to JOHN HOWARD who put in a solid set
of Techno Groove music, once again proving that a 'House' DJ can hold his own
amongst the techno afficianados in town.  Nice work!
Please MARK your calendars for next Monday, Jan. 6th as MAD kicks off 1997
with a very special night with guest DJ/composer from the UK, Mark Broom.
 this man is sure to make some ears prig and heads nod, so all the massive
can't miss it!
Finally, Thanks to all who supported MAD since its return this past year.  We
hope that we can 'sock it to ya' some more the nineseven....Have a Happy and
safe New Year!

--Monty
ps-if any one is interested, I'll be spinning tonight/tomorrow morning on the
gateway sound system sometime between 5-7am......
3STRIKES......

........Happy New Year everyone!!!!!  I for one, am going to be especially
grateful for the music I listened to, danced to, spun to, etc. during the
past five years...It may be the "end of the world as we know it."

  I know you've heard the dire predictions that MTV is coming to cash in on
the underground scene....Not only that, but this morning on the TODAY show
(of all places) a talking head from SPIN magazine predicted that the big
music companies are going to begin importing the music from the English
dance scene, or the "old rave" culture.  The industry executives new spin on
this music is to call it "Electronica.."

The talking head went on to explain that Alternative and Rap sales are
diminishing, so the music executives are looking to target a new market...

Stay tuned, or would anyone like to go a bit deeper underground and miss the
bloodsucking money boys as they look to cash in, not create underground
culture.....

Optimistically, we may have created enough culture to withstand the most
tawdry assaults...or maybe smart enough to keep doing what we're
doing..hopefully, the music makers,composers and writers will be given
greater freedom and access to producing new vinyl for us all......

.but, here's crossing my fingers for 1997.....Happy New Year

                                                                         Spi
nSilver

P.S.  Many Thanks to all of you through the years I've known,
      loved,played, and danced with......aka   robertj

>
>

(Just another Tuesday night)

Getting very excited for the celebration tonight!  I just got back from 
picking up a few essentials, and I intend to spoil a whole bunch of 
people tonight ;)  Look out for me and my tangerines, jelly beans, and 
assorted gifts.  And my treasured 70's lounge gown will be making its 
debut!  If that's not enough to recognize me, I dare you to miss my 
ridiculous furry pink bathrobe.  Ah, fashion!

Suddenly torn at the last minute between Gateway and CCC... But I already 
have my ticket for Gateway, and I am really happy to hear it's in 
Oakland!  The less driving this night, the better.  And I partied NYE'96 
with the same tribe... I also ran into old raver friends today on 
Telegraph, who had just driven up from LA just for this party!!  Now 
that's commitment!

Wishing you much fun and insanity on this night, wherever you are.
